PO Box 129 188 Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates Behind the ADIA Building & across Al Nasr Street from the Cultural Foundation Phone (AD): AD Cell: NY Cell:

http://nyuad.nyu.edu/

Jake,

Jeremy said you took note of the Islamist protests and asked for an assessment. Here's my quick take.-Andrew

Islamist forces do not command nation-wide support and probably do not represent a direct political threat to the TNC, but their advanced battlefield experience and access to weaponry could pose a significant military challenge.

• The Islamists are not particularly popular outside of certain areas of eastern Libya. Sallabi and his followers are as vilified as Jibril in much of the country. Indeed, many of the political groups that oppose Jibril, such as those centered in Misrata, view the Islamists with equal, if not, more hostility.

• Both Islamist and secular militias have operated with relative restraint so far. With Sirte and Bani Walid still in regime hands and Qadhafi on the loose, there is enough of a rationale to support continued cooperation.

• However, once operations against Qadhafi and the regime are wrapped up, this force for unity is likely to dissipate. It is at this point that militias, including the Islamists, will probably abandon caution and pursue a more aggressive campaign for power, perhaps including violence.

Even though the Islamists may not be able to displace the INC. Jibril and his allies suffer from a serious credibility problem. If the INC fails to make strides in giving other political movements (in Tripoli, Misrata, Zintan, and elsewhere) a real role in governance, it may find itself without a viable national political base.

subject: S(67) has made her Final Departure from the building
text:
Our beloved 67th Secretary of State has departed the building for the final time in her tenure. After almost a million miles, thousands of bilats, meetings and phone calls, hundreds of pre-briefs, camera sprays, press avails, photo ops, pullasides, clutches, huddles, and drop-bys, not to mention the scores of interviews and townterviews (I have never liked that word!) receptions and dinners, HRC's time here at State has come to an end.

Madame Secretary, From my perch just outside your office I have had quite a view of history in the making and it has been a distinct honor and privilege. Your entire State Department family in Washington and at all of our embassies and consulates around the world have been inspired by your unrelenting passion, dedication, sense of duty and mind boggling stamina!

You will be missed here at the Ship of State and you will always be remembered with the greatest of respect, admiration and affection.

Thank you, thank you, thank you for everything you have done for us, for our country and for so many around the world.

As they say in the Navy, we will always have your six and we wish you only Fair Winds and Following Seas!

Get some rest!

subject: Likud down, Lapid rises
text:
I'm no expert on Israeli politics, but the exit polls are interesting.

As Dan noted in an email to some, the big news is a poorer than expected (but still leading) showing for Bibi, a surprise surge for Lapid, Bennett not so hot after all, and Kadima has fallen off the map. Tzipi's new party is polling 7 seats.

Emerging bottom line: Bibi could do a 61 seat right/right coalition if he can work with Bennett and Shas. Razor thin but fewer parties to juggle and more ideologically cohesive. Or he could go up to 69 in a limited center-right coalition (with the traditional religious parties but not Bennett, and only Lapid from the center.)

So, while the comparatively poor showing for Bibi's coalition looks to be a sign of weakness, the basic coalition options are still the same as expected but a firmer center partner in Lapid IF that's what he's looking for. Remember he has always said, anyway, he favors the broadest possible government.

And, if the center had formed an electoral coalition —and polled the same results they did separately — they would have outperformed Likud/Beiteinu and at least in theory have had the right to try to form a government. Remember that, when you hear laments that the Israeli public is forever more stuck in the right lane. (But then of course also remember that today's center looks reactionary compared to the center of 20-30 years ago.)

And finally, remember the budget issues — a problem with Shas among others —will loom large in coalition calculations.

David

Chris Hensman U.S. Department of State W: 202.647.9130 I M:

Increasing outreach

I was more than a bit annoyed when I heard that at a recent daily meeting, when, in commenting on the success of your web-chat with young Egyptians, you asked why we did not do more of these and someone responded that they were glad to hear they had "permission" to do them. As I know you know, I have been pushing people to do this for some time and have made it quite clear that no permission is required.

Since prodding doesn't seem to work I now plan to "direct" each regional bureau to work with PA to develop a plan for weekly web-chats focused on issues of regional relevance and engaging the full range of DC based FSO's and subject matter experts, including those with language skills suited to each region. We invest an enormous amount in training our officers and this will help leverage that investment. This isn't brain surgery and can be done quite simply and efficiently if people put their minds to it.

In an effort to appeal to their enlightened self-interests I also plan to tell them that I will be providing you with a detailed report on this initiative.

My apologies for not having been able to get this going sooner.

They did a background briefing at the White House today for columnists and opinion makers. Paul Jones participated. Here are two questions -- and the answers given -- that I wanted to call to your attention:

Will the withdrawal be conditions-based or begin automatically?

Summer 2011 is a strategic inflection point.

We are guaranteeing a U.S. troop level for a certain period of time. That is 18 months from now. The situation will change, and so we will naturally reassess where things stand.

Our emphasis is on building capacity so that the Afghans can assume natural ownership of their own security. We plan to begin to remove our combat troops as we transfer responsibility to the Afghans.

The pace of the withdrawal will be based on an assessment of conditions

NOTE: The assumption seems to be that the transfer process will be a district by district effort, and that there will surely be at least one district where we can transfer by summer 2011.

What are the revised endstates and training timelines for ANSF?

Madam Secretary,

I'm writing remarks for your town hall in Sarajevo on Tuesday. Jake and Josh discussed having the speechwriters send you bullets summarizing significant remarks ahead of time, so you can know the direction we're taking and let us know if we're on the right or wrong track.

Below are the main points for Sarajevo; the draft I'm writing is covering this ground. It will follow the flow of many of your previous town hall appearances.

If there is anything you'd like me to emphasize, add, or subject, let me know and I'll go for it.

Thanks very much, Megan

She said that at this point we will probably not be able to attract the number and level of corporate leaders we originally envisioned for next Tuesday. Liz certainly could pull together something with USGLC board members and some military leadership, but if she is to only get one bite of the apple with HRC her recommendation is to "do it right" and move this to January (either the week of the 10th or 24th). The idea in January would be to include members of congress and frame the event as the QDDR making the case for State/USAID's mission and resources in the new environment. Erica, Sam, Jake:

The Africa Bureau has taken the following steps in the past three hours to win support for the Libya vote in the UN Security Council.

Nigeria

We attempted to reach Foreign Minister Ajumogobia, but Embassy Abuja informed us he is in transit in Asia and was unavailable. Our Chargé reached out to Nigerian MFA Permanent Secretary Uhomoibhi, the number two at the Foreign Ministry and President Jonathan's point-man for UN Security Council coordination. Uhomoibhi hedged ultimately but said his government would decide its position at the highest levels and expressed hope that the decision would be the "right one."

South Africa

I reached out to South Africa's National Security Special Advisor to Zuma Welile Nhlapo, detailed the four parts of the draft resolution, and underscored the importance of standing up for liberty and democracy in Libya and pressuring Qaddafi to forestall further violent retribution against people seeking greater freedom. Although it was well after midnight in Pretoria, Nhlapo pledged to pass the message to colleagues working the issue. I underscored the urgency.

Separately, PDAS Yamamoto discussed our outreach strategy with Ambassador Gips in Pretoria, who told us that Minister of the Department of International Relations and Cooperation Mashabane could not be easily reached, as she was at the airport seeing off Aristide;

The South African Embassy in New York told USUN, we understand, that South Africa would vote with us. Regards, Johnnie Ambassador Johnnie Carson Assistant Secretary for African Affairs

subject: A sighting?
text:
Absolutely fabulous -- Cheryl's mind moves at the speed of light, as does Laurie's, and I was SO glad to connect the two of them. Cheryl and she were even wearing the same bracelet -- a gift from Laurie's father to her, and from Cheryl's mentor to her.

We discussed what SBI is doing in Tunisia, Haiti, Pakistan (where we have 22 Pakistani staff and know the country very, very well) and Egypt and what we know regarding being poised to act in post-conflict situations. Cheryl requested a number of follow-ups we'll provide.

I hope you can do one of your working dinners before the event, as you'd really benefit from having this opportunity before you address the group. Cheryl asked me for a list of suggested guests and I'll get that to her in the next several days.

Our only sober note was Syria, which is breaking all our hearts. I pray for some breakthrough there.

Great day. So glad we had the chance.

Jan

Jan Piercy Executive Vice President SBI (ShoreBank International)

office mobile SBI is moving! As of March 1, you can find us at: 1220 19th Street N. W #200 Washington, D.C. 20036 Phone numbers remain unchanged

Marc,

German ambassador Koch phoned at 5pm, said that Westerwelle had reached Khar. Ten minute call, cordial.

W made the pitch: that the international community has been trying to ensure that Pakistan's interests are represented as we work out the future of Afghanistan. It would be a shame if, at this moment, Pakistan would take itself away from the table.

K said she agreed. She said that during the Defense Committee meeting yesterday, the military had pressed hard for her to announce that she would not go to Bonn, but that she had been able to prevent that [somewhat more forward leaning than when I talked to her]. But she was not sure she could sustain that argument in the days ahead.

Ambassador Koch said that the best we could say was that the door is still open, and we need to keep it open as long as we can. We agreed that with a cabinet meeting Tuesday and a parliamentary session coming this week sometime, keeping the door open will not be easy. But we should continue to press the Pakistanis to come to Bonn.

Cameron

subject: Afghanistan
text: The deliverable on health is done and it responds to the health minister's most impt point to you and Congress about their desperate need to double the number of midwives as a way to get basic health care to more people. The midwives (and nurses -- also in announcement) are the foundation to a health system that is still very primative, given where we had to start. There are 2 other components on small grants and public education on health that are part of your announcement. All of the info is coming to Huma but should have been given to you. It has taken weeks to get this done but it is definitely done.

I am in India but wanted to quickly weigh in on the prospects of a Japan stop next week after Europe. I well recognize how brutal the travel schedule has been and have been reluctant to add to that given pressing current circumstances in Libya and elsewhere.

However I believe the Secretary should consider going to Japan for a brief stop next week to do several things: underscore our commitment to Japan and manifest it with more publicity for all we are doing; indicate that we will launch a public private recovery effort; subtly counteract preoccupation worries; meet crisis team in government; thank embassy and military relief team; meet some of the displaced; and speak publicly to the Japanese people.

We can do this in one day and have an historic impact, quite seriously given the stakes and gravity of the situation. Happy to develop a schedule to support this effort if warranted. Best Kurt

I have not been able to get a psychology dinner set up, but I have found the article that you read on the difference an apology can make in the Middle East (coming in next email) and commissioned a useful paper from Louise Diamond, an expert on psychology and negotiations who has done a lot of work between the Israels and the Palestinians herself (attached). It's about 5 pages; I really think it is worth a read. Finally, on changing the frame to look forward, I strongly recommend that you spend 8 minutes to look at a video produced by a Rand study called The Arc, which proposes a high-speed road/rail project connecting the key cities in the West Bank and Gaza. It is a powerful, powerful vision of what could be, one that will play right into Bibi's emphasis on economic growth. For my money, it would be worth a private 8 minutes screening. I will send the link in the next email.

AM

Anne-Marie Slaughter Director of Policy Planning U.S. Department of State (202) 647-2972

I met with Zohra Rasekh on Friday. You may remember her. She'd met with you during your trips to Kabul as Senator. She is an Afghan-American who has been working in Afghanistan over the last six years and is currently the country's Director of Human Rights. She knows the leaders very well --- and I might add, verifies what is known about the rampant corruption, etc. Since you are going to the Hague and since there will be no women from Afghanistan, I asked Zohra to give me her assessment. Her comments reinforce what I heard from several other Afghan women leaders who were in DC over the last week. I hope this is useful.

Senate willing, hopefully I'll be able to get to work soon. Safe travels, Melanne

Arturo: Gather you're on the road but wanted to flag something for you.

Let me know if you can help. Background below.

Best, Phil

Background: In response to a demarche by the Georgian Embassy in Washington in late April, the U.S. Embassy in Santo Domingo raised this issue of Dominican Republic recognition of South Ossetia and Abkhazia with the Acting Foreign Minister (FM was traveling) on April 28, including reiterating U.S. support for Georgia's territorial integrity and sovereignty (see readout cable on the high side). The Georgian Embassy demarched us again in early May. A delegation from the government of the DR, led by the Vice Prime Minister, is currently in Abkhazia on an official visit (May 1213). Our Ambassador in Santo Domingo is calling the DR Foreign Minister today to reiterate our concern (WILL UPDATE AS POSSIBLE). WHA A/S Valenzuela was in the DR this week, but did not raise the recognitions issue.

I just talked to someone who was with the family today. They came away with the strong sense that it is now just a matter of time and that if he leaves the hospital it will only be so that he can pass in his own home. It was unclear but my read is that we could be talking about the next week.

The family also stressed that they are very much hoping POTUS will come to Qunu. While this is their desire it is unclear how the SAG feels and it is also very clear that the logistics of such a visit would be next to impossible.

subject: news
text:
Thank you for approving this! I'm excited to try to do something good over there.

Also, a deeper and more heartfelt thanks for making this such a great place to work. My two hats more often put me in front of Jake, so he's heard me say this and maybe you haven't: I actually can't believe how smoothly this place has run over the years that I've been here. And I attribute it largely to the fact that a handful of people—starting with S. you, Jake, Huma, PIR, D's (well, Jim's a case unto himself)—were all such consummate team players, good to each other and good to all of us. Together you set the tone for the entire seventh floor and building. It's something I'm very sad to see end (hopefully to be reconstituted down the road). And it's something—alongside all the other things people will recognize you for—to be extremely proud of.

If I can ever be of help, I'm not hard to find.

Dan

We were very impressed with the research that has taken place and the level of preparation and technology that has been applied to the planning. There have been some amazing technological breakthroughs in recent years that have opened up new possibilities and we hope that will be the case with this mission. The Smithsonian serves the Nation by ensuring the highest quality of historical and scientific scholarship. A careful degree of skepticism when evaluating all evidence is a crucial component of fulfilling that responsibility. We'll watch with great interest as this latest effort to find Amelia unfolds.

Best Regards, Jack

subject: Noor and ramsey
text:
We've been in touch with Ambassador Susan Jacobs--she is on the road now, but I understand that she did speak with Mr. Bower earlier today. We are keeping her posted on all of these developments.

Someone is apparently providing the Bower family with misinformed "readouts" of both the Secretary's meeting with President Mubarak last week and Senator Kerry's phone call with President Mubarak yesterday (Friday)--and these "readouts" do not/not conform with what we understand actually took place. We do not know the source of this misinformation. When our officers have tried to explain the state of play, the family cite other unspecified sources telling them that the boys will be released.

I intend to see Mr. Bower when he is here either tomorrow or Monday and hope to get us back onto the same page. Margaret

subject: Update
text:
Had lengthy talk w Z. Could not turn him around on his desire to pull out from Accord despite a lengthy effort. He believes M not negotiating in good faith. Says he has direct channel to M and the word back is that M not willing to implement Accord. Z claims his prestige and that of US and OAS are on the line if there is no dignified way out. He said he was most appreciative of strong support from the US. He said he planned to call Lagos and Solis and explain his reasons on the matter.

Z said he would keep the door open if M was willing to offer a creative and serious way out. He asked that I discuss w Corrales, Reina and the OAS.

We just discussed various ways to manage this situation. Suggest conference call. Hugo

Marc, Tom, Doug, Ambassador, and Colleagues:

The negotiating session lasted two hours 20 minutes in the formal conference room of the Cabinet. Secretary of Defense and Cabinet Secretary Nargis Sethi led the Pakistan side of 14, including Secretary of Finance Wajid Rana, and representatives of MOD, GHQ Federal Board of Revenue, Customs, et. al. From the beginning, there was a spirit of good will, compromise, and let's-get-it-done. In opening remarks, I emphasized that we want an agreement for mutual benefit.

We closed on the MOU language except for one sentence directly related to the negative list. We made excellent progress on the negative list, although both sides will need to consult their experts and lawyers on just a few points. We also took some time on the Terms of Reference and made good progress there, too. We agreed we will follow up with a small-group experts' meeting on Monday afternoon.

At the end of the negotiating session, I noted that cargo is still not moving, despite the Pakistani interagency meeting two days ago that cleared 1579 pieces of cargo to move. I said we have a growing perception problem, and urged the Pakistani side to get things moving ASAP. Secretary Sethi fully understood the point and said she would follow up appropriately.

In closing, both sides emphasized the spirit of cooperation and our commitment to come to closure soonest so that we can clear the final document on both sides and then sign.

The invaluable Elizabeth Hoffman is providing a fuller readout and will also send back details on the few remaining questions that need further clarification.

Dick

subject: Bravo!
text: What a remarkable achievement to get the Turks and Armenians to come this far together. You are deservedly getting good positive press for your efforts. I just wanted you to know that the women in NI with whom you "walked the walk" over the years are eagerly looking forward to seeing you. They were so incredibly helpful during your campaign telling the story of what you did to support them, and as we know -- and as they have shown -- women are critical both to the peace process and to the peace holding. Inez is planning to welcome you with a few words -- as she has done for over a decade. I will be with you all in spirit.

As I mentioned yesterday, fm steinmeier asked to speak with you. He said he's available to speak today either between 11:30 and 12:30 or 4-5pm. Below is purpose of call. Also sending you separate news story.

Purpose of Call: FM Steinmeier has asked to speak with you to request your intervention in the deal to sell 55 percent of General Motors' (GM) holdings in the troubled German car-maker, Opel.

We understand the significance of this issue for German industry and German workers. Treasury is the lead agency on this issue, and has been in close contact with your Chancellery and the Ministry of the Economy.

• Our government is taking a "hands off' role. Any decision will be made independently by GM, based on commercial considerations. The United States government does not play an active role nor do we have a position on any particular bid.

Background: An independent trust comprised of representatives of GM and the German government has been weighing bids from several interested parties on a controlling interest in GM's holdings in Opel. The German government has come out strongly in favor of a bid by Canadian Auto Parts Manufacturer Magna and has financing contingent on acceptance of Magna's bid. GM has concerns about this offer. Steinmeier was an early supporter of Magna's bid and came out early in the media to show leadership in protecting German jobs. Chancellor Merkel has since co-opted the issue and has thrown the full weight of the German government behind Magna. In May, Steinmeier spoke to you by phone about possible U.S. support for GM and the repercussions for Opel.

Statement by the Secretary

The Death of Polish President Kaczynski and His Delegation

I join President Obama in offering my deepest condolences to the people of Poland, to the Kaczynski family, and to the families of all those killed in this tragedy. Lost alongside President Kaczynski and his wife were Polish leaders from across the political spectrum, men and women who shaped and sped Poland's post-1989 democratic transformation and were leading Poland into its promising future. The tragedy of these lives cut short will be felt deeply across the world, but their legacy will live on in a free and flourishing Poland.

The United States stands with the Polish people in this difficult hour. Like the country he led, President Kaczynski was one of America's most valued and trusted allies. He was well known in the United States as a champion for democracy against an oppressive regime, a man whose journey took him from the Gdatisk Shipyards to the presidency of a free people. President Kaczynski was an unstinting advocate for freedom and human rights not just in Poland, but around the world. He will be long remembered and sorely missed.

The Polish people have endured more than their share of sorrow, but they have always shown resilience and resolve in the face of adversity -- and I know they will pull- together in solidarity to grieve this loss.

My thoughts and prayers are with all the people of Poland today.

Dearest Madame Secretary, I am in Abu Dhabi, watching you on television with Prime Minister Natanyaou. You are looking so well ! You are more and more impressive...I am so proud of you ! We are planning our Women of the World Conference again for next March. On Saturday night, March 12th, I will be having the 2nd DVF Award at a dinner at the UN. 2 of the recipients will be women from Vital Voices, one will be voted by people on line and the fourth one is the special one give to formidable example of courage and leadership. Last year it was given to Ingrid Betancourt by Meryll Streep. More than anything, I would love if you would be willing to accept that award. YOU are such an example of strength. leadership and spirit to all of us women. Am I dreaming or would you be willing to accept it ? Lots of love Diane von Furstenberg DVF Studio L.P. 440 West 14th Street New York, NY 10014 Tel: 212-741-6607

01:29:41 Fri 12 Nov 2010 Diane von Furstenberg L.P.

I just got off the phone with President Fernandez. His efforts to dissuade Zelaya and Company from traveling tomorrow have not been successful. He was very worried about what would happen, and requested our help in ensuring that no incidents take place at the airport.

I told him I shared his concern. I summarized for him our efforts to date, and told him that nascent engagement with the armed forces and the de facto government would collapse if Zelaya tried to force the issue tomorrow. I told him of the Cardinal's plea to Zelaya to not return. He said the Cardinal in Santo Domingo is close to the Honduran Cardinal, and said he would reach out to him. I encouraged this. I told him that I thought the elements of a deal were on the table, we just needed to find a way to get everyone to sit at the table and start talking. I told President Fernandez that he could play an important role in creating a climate of confidence, and suggested that he reach out to interested parties like Ricardo Maduro and others inside of Honduras. He said he would do so and get back to me

subject: Strategy session
text:
Cheryl and I discussed how to do an effective strategy session. Monday early afternoon is the first clear shot we have at getting the right group of people in the room together for an extended period of time.

We propose to start the discussion from the following premise: We've addressed, in one fashion or another, to one degree of satisfaction or another, most of the major items we set out at the beginning of last near. We've moved the needle, but we haven't changed the game. Now the question is, what are the major milestones over the next 12-18 months? What should we be aiming at? And especially, what are some potential game-changers — moves that would shift the global landscape in meaningful and long-lasting ways?

Everything will be on the table — regional issues, transnational issues, etc. Everyone should read the book of look-ahead papers; identify things they think we should pursue; and add ideas — especially creative and far-reaching ideas — on top of what's contained in them.

We propose the following roster:

Jim Jack Bill AMS Derek CDM Jake Rich Kurt Judith Harold

Let us know what you think.

Jake

subject: TRANSCRIPT: 5/24 Background Briefing
text:
Wendy did a terrific job, one line captures it all: "So let me stop there, and I'm happy to take questions. I probably won't give you answers you want. (Laughter.)"

And indeed, Wendy provided the answers we wanted that provided valuable context while deflecting trouble. We'll see how tomorrow goes. As usual our Euro brethren have been habitual leakers but the press coverage so far from today is solid.

For tomorrow, after the expected Ashton on-the-record press conference at the conclusion, whenever that comes(we'll get to you her prepared statement worked out among P5+1), we are planning to do a another backgrounder to frame the outcome. And, we will pass along the transcript. Cheers, Mike

subject: DAR
text: Extension of the Designation of Haiti for Temporary Protected Status - DHS will announce tonight an extension of the designation of Haiti for Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for 18 months from January 23, 2013 through July 22, 2014. The extension will allow currently eligible TPS beneficiaries to retain TPS through July 22, 2014. DHS, in consultation with DoS, determined that an extension is warranted because the conditions in Haiti that prompted the initial 2010 TPS designation and the 2011 redesignation continue to be met. OMB will publish a notice in the Federal Register on this in the next few days.

subject: If we go to Paris
text:
Also, if we go to Paris, I assume I will come back that same night. If that's right, can I either land at Westchester or fly up from Andrews?

If I don't go to Paris, how will we add one more trip since I doubt I can go to Haiti?

Are we now thinking of flying to Munich Thursday night instead of Fri morning?

When I go to Hawaii for APEC, Huma has contact info.

Is there a set date for the Friends of Yemen in Saudi Arabia?

Are we still thinking of a speech about Latin America? If so, should do before mid-March. What's status of Brookings event for former Lat Am leaders?

Sending you copy of letter from Dick Blum inviting me to speak at his poverty center at Berkeley. •

Also need to find out dates for Japanese PM visit from WH.

Cheryl-- don't know if you remember me. We worked together in the Clinton WH. I worked at the NSC for Sandy and Tony and worked a lot with Pat Griffin. I kept a Dem foreign policy list for the past 8 years or so, circulating national security op-eds and articles by Dems to Dems. I'm now working for Leon Panetta at the CIA. but I am not writing to you in that capacity. This is my own initiative

He is a terrific officer and person. He has spent his career in WHA. He was born in Puerto Rico and is fluent in Spanish. He is smart, level headed and very loyal. He would do an excellent job. I am not trying to interfere, but he is such a superb officer and good person that I thought it was important for you to take consider him seriously. Please let me know if you need any additional information. I have know Alex for 35 years, so I am sure I can answer almost all questions. Hope all is well. The Secretary is doing a great job. Bill Danvers

Beihl called me from the plane just before departure. De facto negotiating team will return to DC Wednesday for several days talks. While ministers were discouraged by de factor regime intransigence, Beihl said that Zelaya had also lost some support. He said that all the ministers were shocked by Zelaya's behavior in a telephone conference call just before their press conference this afternoon. Zelaya spoke of people dying by hundreds, being thrown in jail and tortured. Zelaya appeared to be very out-of-touch, Beihl said. He added that "even" the Argentine FM was questioning whether Z's return was the correct course. Beihl said that while a democratic solution was needed, perhaps Zelaya was not the right option. I again expressed our position that the problem was not who replaced Zelaya, but that he was removed unconstitutionally. News conference was straightforward. Only one minister spoke (I don't know them by face), said that the solution was return to democratic order and the regime not prepared to accept Si. I haven't got hold of transcript yet, will do so asap. Beihl again expressed thanks for our move on visas (as well as our logistical support), saying that all the ministers thought it a good move.

subject: Update
text:
The Senate goes back in at 930 tues am. The Cloture vote on the cr will be at 1015. Alexander will also be recognized for a 10 minute statement - most believe so he can announce his support for START.

Brown also announced his support for the Treaty this evening. With Alexander, that should put us at the 9 needed Republicans (Alexander, Bennett, Brown, Collins, Gregg, Isakson, Lugar, Snowe and Voinovich). There are several others in play (Corker, Chamblis, Cochran, McCain and Murkowski). Moreover, there are bound to be some "sleepers" as the vp called them. This could be Roberts, Crapo, Kirk or others.

We have a meeting in the morning with Kerry, Lugar and Kyl to discuss the remaining amendments. Reid is encouraging Kerry to offer to vote on a handful of R amendments post cloture, but then move fairly deliberately to a vote on ratification.

The end is in sight....

subject: CODEL Cantor - Aug 14
text:
S/HSC has both briefed Cantor's staff and is providing materials (which H is clearing on). Regardless, it doesn't hurt for us to provide a briefing to Cantor (phone or otherwise), and I'll call his office now to make the offer.

Regarding what Cantor's interested in, his staff has always indicated that he wanted to do some "work" while his family was on a cruise in the Caribbean. The only detail we have ever gotten from his staff is that he would like to see "projects" near Cap Haitien, but that they indicated that the choice of Cap Haitien was based on logistics (the closest to where the cruise ship was sailing) not for any other purposes. We've asked about the trip and have been working with his staff on the trip, but this is as much as they've commented on. It is worth noting that Cantor has not generally expressed a strong interest in foreign policy matters.

I will offer the briefing to Cantor today and let you know if they take us up on it.

subject: Sad news Hillary,
text:
I am once again so sorry for yet another devestating loss. You and Lissa are bearing more grief than I can imagine. I hope she and you are bearing up while letting go.

Africa was overwhelming on every level. I'd love to talk w you about what I saw and learned. Let's commit to dinner after Labor Day. What did Lissa decide to do about school?

How's Jinnet? Is she Peace Corps bound yet? So, my dear, I am sending you and Lissa love and strength from afar. I really believe there is a purpose and meaning in all of this. We just have to figure it out, or, short of that, accept where we are and live w faith and gratitude for the gifts we've been given. Amen and onward---H

Madam Secretary -

One of our Mexican staff and the husbands of two Mexican employees were killed last night in Juarez.

In one case a Mexican employee and her husband were leaving a party hosted by another Mexican employee. They were in separate vehicles. He was stopped by a hit squad and killed before her.

In a second case a Mexican employee and her husband were killed leaving the same party. Their 3 month-old baby was left alive in the back seat.

We have activated all investigative and intelligence channels to learn all we can. The head of Mexico's intelligence service called to express President Calderon's condolences and to offer any support we need. Patricia Espinosa is aware. She may call you. We will let you know if there are any leads on why this tragedy occurred.

Carlos Pascual

This message has been sent via BlackBerry

subject: General Honore phone call - FYI ONLY
text:
Secretary Clinton,

I just had a good conversation with General Honore. Call notes below are FYI only, but I hope they are helpful.

His advice: Specify technical problems and communicate widely so the private sector can bring the best technology to bear against problems (eg building the port, logistics, etc.) The Comfort will fill quickly so will need a plan B for overflow. Medical needs will go on for months and it is not possible to build local capacity to meet needs. Focus security efforts on security for the distribution network I shared our thinking on jobs programs and he felt this was critical

- Felt Pres Preval needed to be more visible as the leader. We should get him a helicopter so he can be seen as surveying his country.

- Create a rule that 60-70 percent of reconstruction is done by Haitians - Task DOD to build the toilets / keep pushing military and be specific

Very good conversation and I found it helpful. I also described our approach and felt he was quite supportive.

Thanks, Raj

subject: FW: al Jazeera "Palestine Papers" document leak -- initial analysis of documents posted
text: Former Secretary Rice called Bill to inquire where matters stood with the release of alleged Palestinian negotiation documents by Al-Jazeerah, noting that she was saying nothing publicly. Bill described our public posture (as per below). Rice said she would adhere to that approach. If matters deteriorated and she could say something useful, Rice asked that we let S know that she was prepared to help, but that she would take her cue from S. Bill thanked her for the offer and said that we would stay in touch. David/Jake, Bill asks that we keep Rice's staff updated as appropriate. Thx,

Dear Hillary, I hope this finds you well and less exhausted, but I doubt the latter, knowing the pace you are keeping. I am writing to introduce you to our dear friend, Kirk Ellis, the writer of the John Adams PBS series, whom you will meet on May 24' at the Fine Arts Committee meeting on the 8th floor. He is brilliant, witty, entertaining, a true Renaissance man He is a leader in the rich cultural and art world here in Santa Fe and a genuinely nice person.

I know that you will enjoy his company, however briefly your paths cross.

Valerie joins me in wishing you all the best.

Joe

subject: Ensuring Energy Transitions
text:
Hi Cheryl, Thanks for your email. I am on a plane now — headed back from Istambul. I have not has any time to address this. But I will certainly work on it shortly. And in fact am meeting with David this week to do so.

But I also think it is essential to take into account the concerns of the Hill. In Jose's hearings and mine, the committee quite explicitly and directly said they expected us to play significant roles in energy. David should certainly have the lead role, as the secretary has said and as the legislation clearly spells out, but we also need to figure out how we can work together. And I am sure that can be done amicably under david's overall leadership in this area. But H should be consulted and talk to the SFRC before any changes are made to avoid any surprises and be sure they understand what is being done. And, of course, I want to be sure we bring in Jose on any discussions, since he has important interests in this.

Regards, Bob

subject: France deploys soldiers to protect embassy in CAR (Reuters)
text:
Just to add more on this: the French deployed 30 soldiers to their embassy; the remaining 170+ remain at the airport. (We had heard the total was 200 soldiers.) Those 30 would also be used to protect our staff at the Chief of Mission Residence (CMR), which is adjacent to the French compound and the PAO residence, which is next door to the CMR. Those soldiers are not currently deployed to our properties, but would come over if necessary.

Separately, the CAR government has dispatched some gendarmes (4-5) to our embassy and have also promised to deploy gendarmes to the CMR.

Madeeha Ashraf P Staff 202-647-5944

subject: FW: URGENT MESSAGE FOR SECRETARY CLINTON --- Amb. Kamara, PR/Liberia called for Amb. DeLaurentis -see message below
text: Huma and Ted: To close the circle on this issue, I spoke to President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and the Liberian Perm Rep yesterday afternoon (9/26). President Sirleaf wanted to alert us that an American citizen had been engaged in suspicious activities and would not be allowed to leave Liberia until a police investigation is completed. President Sirleaf asked that we not interfere in the Liberian legal process. I told assured President Sirleaf I would contact our embassy (which I did) and that we would not do anything that undermined Liberia's investigation/legal system. The embassy believes that the liberians are handling this case appropriately and we have informed the Liberians we do not intend to interfere will their proceedings. Johnnie

subject: Meeting with Foreign Secretary Rao
text:
Hillary:

I note that you are meeting with Foreign Secretary Rao tomorrow. I am on my way back from India, where I had a very positive meeting with FS Rao and the Indian Election Commission about the prospects for increasing India's role in elections globally and collaborating more closely in third countries. FS Rao is discussing this proposal with the Election Commission, which is very interested in greater collaboration with American institutions. Bob Blake and I will be following up with India's Chief Election Commissioner when he travels to Washington, DC next week.

Best, Maria

Dear Jack, Anne-Marie and Jim:

Without prejudice to the deliberative process now underway, I owe you my unvarnished and very frank views on the QDDR process -- and how the U.S. Government must best organize itself to anticipate and respond effectively to crisis and conflicts. The stakes are huge, and because we are at the point where the working group I co-chair on this issue has to generate recommendations, this is the time for me to offer some basic perspectives directly to you -informed by my experiences working on these issues at the NSC, at State, at the United Nations and in the NGO community, as well as writing and teaching about them over the course of the last decade. The QDDR process itself has also impacted my perspectives and, more importantly, raised serious concerns for me about mistakes we must avoid.

I also realize that current bureaucratic and political realities may impose limitations (or compel adjustments) to the kinds of organizational arrangements we might make. But the starting point for me is what makes the most sense.

My propositions:

Best, Eric

• Nominations for Egypt's presidency will open in April, Egypt's newly-appointed Minister of State for Parliamentary Affairs, Mohamed Attia, has revealed.

• The constituent assembly that will be elected by the parliament will draft the country's new constitution within a month, before subjecting it to a public referendum, Attia said in statements quoted by state-run Al-Ahram on Sunday.

• Presidential elections will by organized following the constitutional referendum, the minister said. A constitutional declaration issued by (SCAF) in March stipulates that the new parliament will elect a 100strong assembly to draft the constitution. Attia explained that the constituent assembly will be formed in a joint meeting by both houses of parliament after the end of the parliamentary polls.

• In an interview with satellite channel Al-Arabiya, aired on Thursday, the head of the advisory council, Mansour Hassan, said Egypt has experts who can draft a constitution within one week. Hassan told the channel that if the constitution is not concluded on time, presidential elections will be held as scheduled, and the SCAF will hand over power on the first of July. (AMAY)

• All local media also announced today that SCAF has officially issued a decree to hold the Shura Council elections on two phases only instead of three. Phase one will be held on Jan. 29 and 30 and phase two on Feb. 14 and 15.

subject: Japan Open Skies
text:
We initialled the text of an Open Skies Agreement with Japan at about 10 tonight. I owe enormous thanks to so many of you for a true team victory. From Secretary Clinton on the seventh floor to my tireless secretary in EEB, Tucker Richmond Stewart, we pulled together to make a bit of aviation history and, much more important, to do something good for our consumers, communities, and national economy.

I was able to contact the offices of about ten key Senators and Members of Congress before the signing, with a focus on those who, with a strong Delta presence at home, had expressed concerns about proceeding. I stressed that we'd negotiated provisions that offer Delta assurances of fairness and the potential to grow. I also emphasized that the decision to proceed was taken only after careful consideration at very senior levels of State, DOT, and White House.

Thanks, again, to all for your support.

John Byerly

With help I'll make more calls next week and will arrange briefings for all who are interested.

subject: RN: HRC re Jones
text:
Cheryl,

HRC called me understandably upset with the section of this NYT story regarding General Jones: http:fiwww.nvtimes.com/2009/05/02/world/02clinton.html? r=1&hpw=&pagewanted=orint

She made it clear that this in no way reflects her feelings or anything she thinks about him, let alone anyone "in her circle" would say. She wanted me to make that clear to the reporter. I just spoke to Mark Landler, told him on the record (which I reiterated below via email) that Secretary Clinton holds General Jones in the highest regard, she has nothing but the highest praise for him, and that I was more than happy to put her on the phone to make herself clear on this point — since they did not speak about their relationship during her lengthy interview for the story. I especially made the point that identifying this person as someone "in her circle" was incredibly misleading. Someone in her circle is someone like you, or a Jake, or me. And none of us would ever say anything like that. Someone who was slated for a position at State irrespective of the choice of HRC as Secretary should not be allowed to be identified that way. Mark conceded that point and let me know he will be changing the sourcing to read, "But State Department officials, and others in the administration..." It's a small consolation, but I think a very important one.

subject: h: Memo, St pat's, Shaun request.
text: I thought the piece today in the Post was as good as it could be for where it was. But for the other pieces being done from 60 Minutes to NYT I'd turn it away from personnel (and "Hillaryland," etc) to substantive policies. I'd organize it thematically, too, off top of my head: 1. strategy replacing inherited chaos (AfPak, Mideast, Iran, Iraq, etc.); long-term view on results. 2. Defining new global geopolitics: energy, Africa, Russia, China; 3. Achievements: NI, whatever else; 4. 21st salience of women. I'm sure there are more or other ways of doing this, but something like this. But get it away from personnel (they're drilling for poison) and potential gossip about your relationship with Obama, which is what they really want. then there's another subject about the power of diplomacy as a tool of national security policy. Sid

subject: NBC interview taped this am
text: Toria did a terrific job, actually a fantastic job. She struck just the right tone, conveying forcefully the Secretary's no tolerance policy and that S mandated that we fix problems, which we have been doing. Toria expressed great sympathy with the victims and acknowledged we are not perfect and are working hard to do better — outlining the many steps we have taken to improve the program. Toria also gave a nice riff on the value of the program. NBC reassured us they will give Toria ample air time and will air the interviews with kids who have wonderful experiences as part of their exchanges. NBC seemed fixated on one of the companies we work with — Educational Resource Development Trust (ERDT). NBC questioned why we still use ERDT since ERDT failed to take appropriate actions in the 2005 case. We are double checking with ECA on this one. Story will be ugly but Toria put us in a much better place and gave us the hook for balancing the piece, a bit. We'll see on February 8.

Madame Ambassador, dear Capricia,

Having returned from another unforgettable trip within the Experience America program, I would like to thank you and the 17 protocol officers who accompanied us on the trip to Arkansas wholeheartedly for a truly special experience.

I said to Larry Luxner that the trip should be headlined "Experience the Unexpected".

I so much appreciated our group being hosted at the Clinton Presidential Center. I loved to see the beautiful countryside on our bus trip from Little Rock to Fayetteville. I may have been the only member of our group to see The March of the Ducks at the Peabody Hotel across the Street from our hotel in Little Rock. I was deeply impressed by the number of Fortune 100 companies that have a significant presence in Arkansas. I have found my new favorite painting at the breathtakingly beautiful Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art: Rosie the Riveter by Norman Rockwell. I will never forget meeting two of the Little Rock Nine.

You all did such a wonderful job in organizing the trip meticulously, paying attention to every small detail, enable us to have encounters that we ourselves would not even have thought of and, most of all, you were patient, gracious and untiring in making this a unique trip for all of us.

Thank you so very much!

Warmly,

subject: Gallup shows Romney with a Seven Point Lead - What Does This Mean?
text:
Republicans are overjoyed. Democrats are tearing out their hair. Twitter may explode.

A couple thoughts and some perspective:

1) The latest Gallup poll covers the dates of Oct. 11-Oct. 17 which means it is only capturing one day of post-debate sentiment. We won't have a full post-debate sample until Tuesday (Oct. 16-22). I will leave it to Gary to explain any other details about polling methodology etc.

2) There is an expectation by many that the race will tighten back up next week, thanks in part to an expected boost in Democratic enthusiasm.

3) That said, if Romney retains a lead in this poll — or any other airworthy poll, it suggests that Romney's big win in Denver and his solid performance at Hofstra helped him to finally clear the "acceptability" bar with those wavering Obama 2008 voters he needs to win over. The Romney campaign has long held that this race will resemble 1980 where the race remained very close until the very end when it broke dramatically in Reagan's favor. Like Romney, Regan's big break came from a solid debate performance. However, the political polarization in this country is much more intense and solidified than it was in 1980.

Sandro deBernadino called my cell this morning under instructions from his minister to ask that Italy be included in any meeting being arranged with Russia. They had heard meeting would be P5, AL and EU. Sandro enumerated all that Italy was doing, all it's interests and that criteria for meeting should be clear. I told him that if meeting happens, and we hoped it would, that Special Envoy Annan for UN and AL would determine participation. We understood it would be small to focus on outcomes and not be a large conference event. I thanked him for all that Italy is doing to help and urged them to be in direct touch with Special Envoy and his office. He returned to his points several times and I pointed him to the Special Envoy. He finally said they would do that and also said he hoped if we gave advice we would include Italy. He also asked that I pass message to the Secretary. Jake, please let S know. Thanks all.

subject: Farewell
text:
Dear Cheryl,

I know that you'll be heading out soon and have a million things to do, but I wanted to tell you what a joy and honor it was working for you and the Secretary's team during my year on S staff — I never properly thanked you enough for selecting me and for giving me the opportunity.

I also wanted to mention that my wife and I watched all of the Secretary's testimony last week and needless to say, we were both incredibly impressed by her performance (as were millions of others). But I also was so happy to see you right there next to her — made me proud all over again that I had served as part of your team.

Please send my best to the Secretary and to all of those departing -- you were all fantastic, friendly, and fun (not to mention brilliant) and the place won't be the same without you.

Wishing you all the best on your next adventure, Zia.

Zia S. Syed EU Enlargement/Balkans Unit Chief Political Section U.S. Mission to the European Union +322811 5862 (office)

subject: Mexico update
text:
Following up on our Monday conversation re: Mexico, here is an update on where things stand and next steps. IPC:

Carlos followed up with a classified email to 7th floor principals on Friday night, which stressed the urgent need to implement the intel recommendations in his paper. Next steps with interagency:

Higher-level interagency engagement: Now that the issues identified in the DoD/DHS proposal are being discussed

Ed in my office will stay in close touch with D(S) to make sure none of the issues are dropped as the Mexico coverage shifts back to Jim and will continue to support him on the issues that we have been working on.

Jake, Alice — Would one of you pass the floor update below to S? Thought she'd like an update on that status of our bill. Thanks. Dave

Madam Secretary — As expected, Senator Reid moved today (11/15) to amend the pending Energy and Water appropriations bill to add our bill plus the Financial Services bill to create the second "minibus" appropriations package. Senators Menendez, Nelson, Rubio all objected to the motion because of language allowing bank to bank transactions between Cuba and the United States contained in the Financial Services bill.

Senator Reid then offered a modified motion that removed the Cuba language. Senators Moran (KS) and Vitter both objected. Moran because he supports the Cuba bank transfer language and Vitter because of Mexico City policy, UNFPA and what he described as language permitting abortion on demand in Washington DC.

Senator Reid then proceeded to fill the amendment tree on the underlying Energy and Water bill, essentially freezing action on the Senate floor until some sort of agreement is reached on the universe of amendments to be considered. That agreement could encompass amendments to our bill or simply to Energy and Water. So we are in a holding pattern until Senators figures out how they would like to go forward.

Senator Reid has made it clear that he intends to complete the conference report on the first "minibus" which contains the CR through December 16th as well as the Defense authorization bill before adjourning for Thanksgiving and has already threatened to keep the Senate in through the weekend and into early next week.

Dave

This reform will likely be criticized by some who think that putting more money in the hands of local actors will expose USAID's programs to more risk. But this is precisely the point; only by supporting local change agents—both inside and outside developing country governments—can we actually strengthen the hands of people in poor countries who are working to change their own societies for the better. That means managing risk wisely, rather than trying to avoid it altogether. And in our field research, 36 of the 39 activists we interviewed said they want USAID to support their government's directly, because it would make it easier for them to hold their governments accountable and prevent corruption.

What does all this mean? It means better aid, aid that strengthens the capacity of reformers in poor countries. And for the millions of people across the world who have been demanding these reforms, USAID has shown it is actively listening.

Sincerely,

The Aid Effectiveness Team

subject: Secstate with Spanish FoMin
text:
Mark, You've probably heard that a bomb went off thisd morning in Laghman province, Aghanistan. The Governor of the province is in Madrid at the end of a one-week visit to Poland, Germany, and Spain.

His message has been of support for ISAF and international development, which is helping Afghanistan defeat the enemy, confront radical terrorists, and rebuild.

The Governor is considering release of a a statement from Madrid to news outlets this afternoon. We have offered assistance in reaching media. Will keep you posted.

Please share this info, as appropriate, with those who should know in the Dept.

FOR KABUL: While it appears that Insurgents hoped to capitalize on the NATO summit to send a message, and likely chose Laghman because of it has been relatively peaceful and secure, this incident underscores the Governor's talking points that, while Laghman has been peaceful and made great progress on all fronts in the past 9 years, Afghanstan still needs security and development assistance to defeat the terrorists, who only bring destruction, fear, and oppression.

Tom Genton, PAO Madrid

-Tom

Dear Cheryl:

I wanted to inform you about the current status of the nomination process for my re-election as President of the Bank that began on 10 May and will remain open through 24 June.

As of this date, I have been nominated by 24 countries, 20 of them regional member countries, representing 48.894 % of the voting power.

The list of countries is as follows: Argentina, The Bahamas, Belize, Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Dominican Republic, El. Salvador, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Jamaica, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Portugal, Uruguay, Trinidad and Tobago, Korea, Japon, Netherlands y Canada.

Consequently, my nomination fulfills the first requirement of nominations by at least of 15 regional member countries;

The second requirement, a majority of the total voting power of all the Bank's shareholders, is almost fulfilled as of today.(51 %)

Further, no other candidates have been nominated as of this date.

Jess

subject: Hey boss... from Kay Warren...
text: Yes, we all agree. I've already been in touch with the Norwegians. I think there's been misinformation or misinterpretation driving this. The Norwegians promised to discuss next week when their key folks are back in town. I responded to Kay and Lynn's emails in the last couple days and assured them we would try to make this all work out in a way to help Heal, not the opposite. Also, we have a USAID mtg scheduled with all the key parties on DRC assistance both to ensure new monies will be spent properly based on needs and to try to understand what is driving some of the complaints I got about USAID when we were in Goma.

Below are my notes on Dennis' 14 points, which involve 6 parallel steps each and then #13 and 14 are combined, joint action by the two sides.

*ISRAEL* 1. Israel should offer voluntary compensation to settlers to leave the West Bank. (NB not unilateral, part of orchestrated interaction) 2. Build housing now within Israel to show you don't intend permanent occupation. 3. Only build future settlement housing within the blocs - not beyond them. 4. Open Area C to economic activity for Pals. Just 120k pals live there, but -- alongside Jewish settlements-- all the rock quarries are there, and Pals have no access. 5. Increase Palestinian police presence in Area B, and increase their areas of responsibility. 6. Work out security criteria to limit incursions into Area A.

*PALS* 7. Put Israel on their maps 8. Acknowledge historic Jewish connection to the land and to Jerusalem. 9. Stop incitement / de-legitimization. (No more hiding behind local officials on this). 10. Condition your public for peace. (ie returning to Arafat's "peace of the brave" rhetoric). 11. Start building permanent housing in camps for refugees. 12. Make major investments in rule of law/anti-corruption efforts.

*BOTH*

13, 14. Youth on both sides should have an exchange of classrooms. Create a forum for kids to be together. "Dialogue of the deaf" right now.

Jean-Louis and I had a lengthy conversation today covering a broad range of subjects relating to your interest in supporting textile and apparel activity in Haiti. He has subsequently shared with me a number of specific materials on the Haiti project, including an email of yours which highlights the objectives of the project and a suggested timeline, as well as the business proposal made by Hansoll. When I digest these latter materials, I will consider myself in a much better position to make responsive recommendations to you.

As I communicated to Jean-Louis, I am happy to be helpful to you and the State Department on this project. I can make myself available a couple of days a month for meetings and pretty much on an as needed basis for phone conversations. I retain my affiliation with Warburg Pincus, the global private equity firm. This requires my presence in New York (generally) a couple of days a week. As I think you know, I am also Chairman of the Board of Campbell Soup Company. This entails three or four days a month.

Fortunately, I am not really "retired." This means that I have some flexibility in how I spend my time. You should feel free to call on me.

I retain my interest in and connections with the retail and apparel industry. While I am far from an expert on sourcing and production of apparel and textiles, I have some relevant experience and many friends who will do their best to keep me from looking foolish.

I will be in Baltimore and Washington for the next few days. Either you or Jean-Louis should feel comfortable in calling on my cell phone

In the interim, I will review these materials and speak again with Jean-Louis.

Regards,

Paul

subject: UNSC elections reporting
text:
All,

Below are the results of the 2nd round:

African Group (1 seat available) • Mauritania 72 • Togo 119

Eastern European Group (1 seat available) • Azerbaijan 90 • Slovenia 97

Bottom line: results inconclusive. Since none received the required two-thirds vote of members present, voting and submitting valid ballots (which is varying in each vote), the General Assembly is immediately proceeding to a third round of voting. The third round is again restricted to the above countries.

If the third round is inconclusive, the fourth round (and 5th and 6th) will be an "unrestricted" round, whereby votes may be cast for any eligible Member from the respective regions, including those that were part of the first round but not part of 2nd or 3rd rounds, i.e. Hungary could get some votes.

Voting for third round has occurred, ballots are being collected, and the General Assembly will soon be in recess again to count the votes.

Dan

Please flag for MG

As they committed during Indian Commerce Minister Sharma's visit earlier this month and projected as far back as Minister Fahim's September 2011 visit to India, Pakistan's cabinet approved a new negative list with India today (before the end of February).

The new negative list of 1209 restricted product lines (of about 6800 tradeable categories) replaces the previous positive list of about 1900 allowable product lines. This more than doubling of tradeable goods roughly meets my expectations but may be a disappointment given the wild hopes of some in New Delhi, especially given that the negative list rejected by cabinet two weeks ago included only 636 products. The late additions reflect last minute pressure from the autoparts, machinery, and textiles industries. Implementation is set to occur within one month, and the goal is still to phase out the list by end 2012 and to announce Most Favored Nation status at that point. (Comment: Though I am skeptical that they will be able to move that fast given the political calendar and industry pressures. Other countries,

including India, maintain a limited sensitive list and are considered technically WTO. compliant.)

This is real and historic progress for Indo-Pakistan relations, a big victory for Zardari's government, and a real achievement for the New Silk Road vision.

James C. Schwemlein Office of the Special Representative for Afghanistan & Pakistan

Tony, et al: Just back from a good 70-min meeting with Pres Karzai. Made the points I noted I'd lay out in the email below, and had a good discussion. Provided a lot of specifics for each issue to show where we've made changes in recent months, provided detailed assessments of what the targeted

operations have accomplished, agreed with the need to ensure that our actions, together with those of our Afghan partners, garner support of the people, and so on. And did underscore the need for a united front as we go forward.

Again, productive session. Vr - Dave

subject: Northern Ireland
text:
Gordon Brown called Lou Susman a short while ago. Brown believes you should make a call to McGuinness this morning around 830 am (Declan and I agree that if you call McG you also must call Robinson). Brown proposes to speak with you at 820 or so to bring you up to speed before those calls.

The current situation is that Brown and Cowen are in Belfast, and met with Robinson, McGuinness, and other parties until 330 in the morning Belfast time. They have now resumed today. The sticking point is parades. Robinson wants the current parades commission abolished because it gives Republicans too much say. McGuinness refuses to allow the parades issue to be tied to the devolution issue.

The key message to McGuinness is to keep working this thing through -- not to take any drastic action that would bring down the assembly or collapse the process.

Declan agrees that this is the moment to make calls.

If you agree we can have the ops center set up the Brown call as well as the other two.

We'll get you some more background before the calls, but talking points will be fluid and shaped in large measure by Brown's report.

Jake, Kurt, Dan:

Cambodian State Secretary Ouch, traveling with FM Hor Namhong, called me just now, saying that the FM wanted to pass a message to the Secretary. According to Ouch, the BKL group of13 women, convicted for protests involving land rights, will be released. He wanted S to know this, as she had raised it yesterday with FM Hor Namhong.

I also talked with Ambassador Bill Todd. He said there had been some correspondence by the Cambodian Ministry of Justice, asking the court to review these cases. He will let us know tomorrow whether this meant the BKL group would be released.

Joe

Mark Toner Deputy Spokesman Department of State w: (202) 647-8406; bb:

After some more thinking and conversation today I have another suggestion for the link b/w diplomacy and development on the QDDR. Suppose we say that the point is to elevate both diplomacy and development relative to defense and thus to look at how development can strenthen our diplomacy and how the tools of diplomacy (direct negotiations w/ govts, work thru international and regional organizations, tools of 21st century statecraft) can strengthen development. If we emphasize the tools of diplomacy it is more tied to resources -- eg what we fund and develop and what we don't.

I think that w/ that formulation jack has to be a leader and S/P is his natural partner given that this is really a policy planning exercise w/ very big implications for how we allocate our resources. If I co-lead I can also make sure that we keep pushing the ball forward by convening meetings when jack is inevitably swamped w/ more operational issues. Best, AM
