subject: DCG Wrap Up
text:
Marc, The DCG wrapped up today with sessions on security assistance and CSF. Key points:

-- the overall discussion and mood remained positive and productive, despite both sides leveling some difficult issues.

-- from our side: we gave them a very sobering picture of fiscal constraints and Congressional scrutiny and skepticism that will impinge on our assistance for at least the near term;

Nevertheless, the DCG:

There was no reference in the DCG to the conversations in Brussels. We very much appreciated the read-out from there; we were the only USG agency represented that had a read-out heading into today's discussions. So thank you. The embassy provided outstanding support to a huge contingent of Washington visitors (juggling Robin and Sarah Peck's visits and David Pearce's upcoming travel simultaneously). We are drafting a note from you to S that will capture and elaborate on the above points. Ditto for points for your call with Sedwill.

subject: PLEASE PASS ALONG TO SECRETARY CLINTON
text:
Dear Secretary Clinton,

Deputy First Secretary of Northern Ireland, Martin McGuinness, arrives in DC this week, and I understand you will be meeting with him. As one of your Observers to the International Fund for Ireland, I have concerns about the situation on the ground in Northern Ireland and would welcome an opportunity to discuss this with you.

My principle concern, based on my observations, is the degradation of, and lack of respect for, the rule of law. I fear that, acting out of self interest, Unionists and Nationalist politicians in Northern Ireland are presenting a rosier picture than what is warranted. With the British and Irish governments distracted by by their economic difficulties, renewed American attention and energy is very welcome.

Your meeting with Deputy First Minister McGuinness illustrates America's dedication, not just to the letter of the Good Friday Agreement, but to the spirit of the Agreement as well.

With deep appreciation for all you have done, and are doing, to sustain the peace in Ireland.

Sincerely,

Stella O'Leary

subject: loved your speech tonight, truly
text:
I have been singing exactly the same tune as below in every speech I give, but your speech tonight was particularly eloquent.

In the 21st century, the material conditions of people's lives have greater impact on national stability and security than ever before. The balance of power is no longer measured by counting tanks and missiles alone. Now strategists must factor in the growing influence of citizens themselves -- connected, organized and frustrated.

There was a time when those of us who championed civil society, worked with marginalized minorities and women, and focused on young people and technology, were told our concerns were noble but not urgent. That is another false narrative that has been washed away. These issues — among others — are also at the heart of smart power — and they must be at the center of any discussion attempting to answer the region's most pressing questions.

Best, AM

subject: generals talking about importance of development
text:
Kurt, Jim, Michele Fleurnoy and I had lunch with the Singaporean Defense Minister today, who twice emphasized the importance of "walking on two legs," which he said he got from a Thai general talking about the Thai strategy toward insurgent groups. One leg is security and the other leg is "economic development and welfare of the people." Step forward with security, and it becomes possible to take a step with development and human welfare, which allows another step toward greater security, which allows another step toward prosperity for the people — soon you are walking and then running. I don't think it was exactly the pairing that others around the table expected, but I was delighted to hear it.

Anne-Marie Slaughter Director of Policy Planning U.S. Department of State (202) 647-2972

subject: A/S Carson thoughts on PDel for Meles funeral
text:
Hi all. Copying in Protocol Officer Nick Schmit and Embassy Addis control officer Shannon Cazeau.

I confirmed with the GOE this morning it is likely they will ask Amb Rice to speak for 5 minutes at the funeral — probably at the first portion of the service at Meskel Square, which is a large open area in the center of the city where mass events are traditionally held. Following that event a smaller group (including the USG del) will likely travel directly to the Holy Trinity cathedral.

•The GOE is looking for our delegation list as soon as possible to facilitate with planning. Hadisse Tedesse, the head of the Gates Foundation office in Ethiopia, told me that Bill Gates will not/not come as originally suggested, but Joseph Stiglitz and Jesse Jackson are still in play as other distinguished Americans planning to attend.

Thanks and best regards, Molly

subject: Congratulations!
text:
First of all, Happy Birthday! I hope you are getting some well deserved R and R today because your schedule tires me out just seeing it on television!

And thank you for your kind wishes and offer of help. I may ask your press shop for some small assistance in the next week. But much more importantly, I hope you will share with us your ideas on all issues, including economic and domestic - no one better understands the environment and the levers to change it than you. I realize you have a few things that keep you busy (and I know that will remain true even when you're a "former"), but I also remember sitting in the living room of the White House two days before President Bush's inauguration, plotting the creation of a progressive think tank with you. So to the extent we can tap into your strategic brilliance because after all, this was all you idea well, I know how lucky we would be.

Gratefully,

Neera

subject: Book about your Puerto Rico campaign
text:
Our Co-Chairs, now Sec. of State McClintock and Dem. Comm. Chair Prats, have written a book about a campaign that was historic in terms of a majority in PR and cooperation between statehooders and commonwealthers.

They want a foreword by you & WJC and pictures of your visits. I'll follow up with Cheyrl and Laura Graham on the foreward and can do a draft if one is OK.

On Palau, I'll be following up with Jake. State's proposal would cut per capita income 20% over six years and 10% over the 15 of the agreement being sought.

Jeff

Jeffrey L. Farrow

subject: FW: Amelia Earhart Project
text:
Dear Evelyn,

We just had a good meeting with the General and his team. I found it very encouraging and I was impressed by the dignity and care in which General Dailey handled the matter. I will let your team give you their own judgment, but I at least am feeling more comfortable. We will be meeting later here at the State Department to ensure the event on Tuesday is handled with the utmost care. The NASM team is very grateful that the expedition has negotiated a provision in the agreement with Kirabati to publicly display any finds from the expedition. Please let me know what you think. I know the Secretary will value deeply your views on the best way forward.

Thank you for all you do at the Smithsonian. Washington would not be the same, either for our children or us, without your wonderful institution.

Best, Kurt

subject: International Strategy
text:
I thought the roll out — and particularly the Secretary's remarks — went very well. It's generating some good buzz both in the press and among the relevant diplomatic corp. It was great that the Secretary was out in front on this. As one blogger noted: "the choice of State and Secretary Clinton to present the strategy is encouraging, giving ownership to the most visible arm of administration Internet policy and situating coordination under one roof..."

The next challenge is cementing the Department's leadership role in implementing the Strategy. We are working closely with PA to amplify both the Strategy and the Secretary's leadership, following up with posts on the cable we sent on Friday, reaching out to key foreign counterparts, and working to convene appropriate groups of stakeholders — including embassy representatives, the private sector and NGOs — on the way ahead. I will keep you apprised of these activities as we move forward and, as always, I welcome any thoughts you have on how we can be most effective. Thanks.

Chris

Jeff did some digging here is what he found.

He's Druse, from the Chouf town of Bakleen. So he's not a Hizballah guy. Turns out I'm friends with his cousin, who describes ZT as "a real mafioso." He is apparently one of those Lebanese who lives in the shadows and does arms deals. He was the go-between between the French and Q, when 0 was buying Mirages. He also was the broker who got the Pakistanis to purchase French submarine(s).

Google search his name and something interesting comes up: he was detained upon arrival in France from Tripoli on March 7 (ie, after clashes broke out but before the no-fly zone) with an undeclared 1.5 mil EURO from Q, which he was allegedly going to use to buy influence for Q.

Cheryl,

Per our prior discussions I would like to attend the morning mtgs w S and was hoping to start that practice this coming week if you agree.

I fully understand the confidentiality issue and will manage that issue super carefully.

I also have thought through my prior request for a little office space on the 7th floor and some focused support from Caitlin/Steve. While I still think those things would be helpful, it feels less urgent and we could try my joining the morning meeting and then explore the issue of space etc...

Are you comfortable starting this on monday? I would be changing my morning mtgs at AID so wanted to get going w this.

Thanks, Raj

Todd--

First, thank you for your success at Cancun. It was certainly hard won! You played the hand you were dealt superbly and we are. all the better for it. I would like a full debrief when you have the time this week.

I am on the way to Canada for a US-Can-Mex trilateral and will praise Mexico and Patricia both privately and publicly-they earned it and saved the international process.

I'd like to thank your entire team again so we'll work to set up a convenient time. Until then, I hope everybody gets some well-deserved rest.

All the best, H

Apparently Secretary Clinton got Mubarak's agreement to release the boys. The father is headed to Cairo on Monday to pick them up at the embassy. Staff at the embassy and at the State Dept is now saying that this is only a visitation. As you can imagine the family is really upset and the supporters are livid. They are expecting that Colin will be headed back to the states with the boys Tuesday. The press wants to know what is going on. Any advice here, because I have no idea what is going on? Many thanks to you and esp to Hillary for getting us this far. Howard Sent from my Verizon Wireless BlackBerry

subject: WSJ piece
text: I agree. I had not seen the article, but I just went and found it. Clearly, it's not favorable from either the VoA or DOS perspective. It's mainly an attack on the VoA decision to shift resources from China shortwave. I will stress publicly and privately that we are all working toward the same goal. I said this at the meeting last week. And privately I will emphasize that any further sniping will make me very, very upset. I truly do admire what State, from the Secretary to the folks at DRL, is doing on this front, and will say so vigorously. (I'm sure Ensor will say this as well.) Thanks for bringing this to my attention.

Cheryl,

As you know, I had planned to attend the Summit of the Americas April 1446 in Cartegena. It now appears that Helga Schmid, the EU political director, having looked at Cathy Ashton's schedule and pulsed other political directors schedules, would now like to offer the Iranians either April 13-14, 14-15 or 15-16. Those talks will likely be in Oslo or Vienna. Checking flight schedules, it is virtually impossible to do both. I assume that given the Secretary's participation in the Summit along with Roberta, Carmen, John Feeley and Ambassador McKinley, that the Secretary would approve my releasing the dates to Helga to schedule talks during that time with my attendance. I very much wish I could be in two places at one time but Star Trek is still only a television show. Please let me know as soon as possible whether my assumption is correct. Helga hopes to get back to her counterpart as soon as possible. Thanks you.

Wendy

subject: Anything to report?
text:
Not too much. You've seen Jeff's readout. He and Bill and I conferred on how to approach Monday - we're working on points for Lavrov that try to lock in the small gains made today. Getting Kofi pointed in the right direction is an important task; we'll have to figure out how to do that.

Dan B is working on your remarks for Monday and will send them tomorrow.

Bill T is trying to herd cats on the FMF designation; I checked in with Toria today to get her advice on how to frame it most effectively for the Egypt working group crowd (Kagan and Diehl and Abrams and those types who will raise hell with Leahy). Bill will meet with them this week.

Nothing else urgent.

subject: Wes Clark on Libya
text:
Wes Clark called again. He has been approached by his same contacts, pushing for more meetings. They now want him to negotiate a ceasefire, leaving Q in country. He knows that's a non-starter and knows he can't/shouldn't play that role.

But he was in an expansive mood with me nonetheless. He thought we should consider an option where Q would have to leave "temporarily," while ceasefire and political process and dialogue issues were worked out. But we hold the door open for a possible return of Q if "the people demand it," as Mohammed Ismail keeps telling him is the case.

He also thought it's time for us to expand upon the UNSCR 1973 language and "call Qadhafi's bluff' by establishing detailed performance benchmarks that would be nominally consistent with Q's offer of a ceasefire and political process. I noted that Q's previous words about a ceasefire have been at odds with his actions on the ground. That's the point, Clark argued -- make him perform or demonstrate clearly his failure to do so. Jeffrey Feltman

HRC:

You may remember many years ago when olympic champion swimmer diana nyad tried to swim from cuba to florida and failed. Diana wants to try again as part of an ongoing commitment she has to promoting fitness among older people. As you can see from this email she needs your help to get clearance. I wouldnt ask if i didnt think taking it to your level is the only way to get it done.

Thanks so much in advance for looking into this. I know it is a busy month for you. You are just the best!!!

Hilary Rosen

Dear Cheryl,

After what had to be a pretty trying week I thought you might enjoy this. My two other very favorite people at State are Eric Goosby and Zeenat Rahman. Well, last week I got in kind of an argument with one of them. Eric and I were debating who thought the most of you, he or I. He threw me a curve ball when he brought up how great your husband also is and probably thinks he won the day, but he would be incorrect. In thinking about it I don't believe I've ever heard anyone say anything negative about you (of course, my wearing the "I like Cheryl Mills" pin might inhibit some people from being too negative C)). I've asked Shannon Smith to look out for Zeenat when her boss comes over. Have a great weekend and get a little rest.

Best wishes, Shepherd

subject: NI
text:
Just saw the email from Sid - was working on the below report. Shaun apparently had a much more pessimistic view of what Cameron would do than all of our Parliament watchers, who felt confident from the get-go that he would support the deal.

PM Brown praised all parties involved; stressed the need to adhere to the dates laid out in the agreement several times; welcomed the supportive Westminster interventions during the Q and A of SDLP Mark Durkan and DUP Peter Robinson and Nigel Dods, but pointedly expressed hope that other parties (read UUP, whose MP was either not present or simply didn't speak) would express their support as soon as possible.

As expected, David Cameron praised the agreement and all parties; raised the desire that all parties (read SDLP and UUP) be given time to review the document; and pointedly asked the PM what issues that were not expressly mentioned in the agreement would be addressed by the Working Group -- to which Brown responded, "all the issues outstanding from St Andrew's."

Cameron and Brown praised the U.S. role, singling you out. Brown also twice referred to your offer to host an investment conference.

Overall, nothing concerning from the Tories...on the contrary, full support, a request that the minority parties have a chance to review and some questions on outstanding issues.

UUP MLAs meet tonight to review.

Note: DUP interventions were balanced.. .Dods raised parades and decommissioning as reminder of outstanding issues, but stressed desire of all parties "not to go back" to the bad old days. Minor dig at previous Sinn Fein "threats." Robinson stressed cooperation in the negotiations. Struck a statesmanlike tone.

subject: HRC friend
text:
Ill have to defer to Gene on this. It's a fascinating read, and some stuff mentioned has already happened (such as the appointment ofiuwaili as Minister of Defense Juwaili is close to the UAE, incidentally). But I simply do not know the ins and outs of the new Libyan politics in sufficient detail to give a view as to the accuracy of this report A few bits seemed off key (e.g, the reference that both the misrata and Zintan Brigades once reported "loosely" to BelHaj I don't believe is true, since Juwaili and the IJAE supported the latter and Qatar the former).

The comment about Belhaj staying out of govt and thus retain the flexibility to carp and make trouble: Jake, you may remember that AbZ warned exactly of that danger in that weird mtg Qatar insisted upon on the margins of UNGA.

Gene? Jeffrey Feltman

subject: FW: Insulza on Cuba and the Summit
text:
Statement of the OAS Secretary General on the Summit of the Americas

The Secretary General of the Organization of American States (OAS), Jose Miguel Insulza, today recalled that in April 2009, "at the conclusion of the Fifth Summit of the Americas, its Chair, the Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago, Patrick Manning, remarked upon the existence of a clear consensus that the reintegration of Cuba in the inter-American relations is an essential step toward the building of a more cohesive and integrated Americas."

Insulza added that "in fulfillment of that consensus, the 39th OAS General Assembly in San Pedro Sula annulled the Resolution through which the Government of Cuba was excluded from participating in the inter-American system." The Resolution of the 39 GA/OAS established that: "the participation of the Republic of Cuba in the OAS will be the result of a process of dialogue initiated at the request of the Government of Cuba, and in accordance with the practices, purposes, and principles of the OAS."

Secretary General Insulza noted that "that request has not been made."

For more information, please visit the OAS Website at www.oas.orq.

Hilary,

You may know but for the last four years I have been working with the Qatari's and in particular with Sheikha Moser on disability issues in Qatar and I have built up a good relationship with them

Sheikha Moser has approached me privately saying they are keen to get their relationship with the USA onto a more positive footing and she was hoping for a "women-to women" one to one private meeting with you. She is happy to come to Washington if you could make some time available.

Is this something you would be prepared o do. Sheikha Moser is someone who has real influence in Qatar and she has made a lot of difference already with her education city and with the Shaffalah Centre for people with Disabilities in which I am involved as the Co Chair of its Annual Disability conference. I am sure the conversation would not be confined to these issues but would be about the US/Qatar relationship generally.

Cherie Blair

subject: Sec. Clinton
text:
Tamera - - I would be very grateful if you could pass on the following message to Sec. Clinton:

Dear Secretary Clinton,

Phyllis and I have been very concerned since learning of your fall and concussion several weeks ago, and are now more acutely alarmed over your hospitalization for a blood clot.

Please know that we are thinking of you and that you are in our prayers - - and praying is one thing that I am pretty good at!

Most sincerely, we wish you a full and speedy recovery and hope you are able to return to your regular routine in short order.

Please accept our best wishes for a 2013 filled with good health, joy, success and peace.

Warm regards and Shalom,

Michael

Michael S. Miller Executive Vice President and CEO Jewish Community Relations Council of New York 225 West 34th Street, Suite 1607 New York, NY 10122 W: 212-983-4800, ext. 130 F: 212-983-4084 www.jcrcny.org

subject: Congratulations
text:
Dear President Martelly and Prime Minister Lamothe,

I wanted to send a quick note to congratulate you on your announcement today regarding the publication of the constitutional amendments. On behalf of the United States, we look forward to supporting your decision and to assisting as appropriate in its implementation. You have set the stage for all of the election donors to do their part in supporting the preparations for the upcoming elections; we look forward to coordinating with you and Haiti's international partners to fulfill your goal of holding municipal and senate elections by the end of November.

I wish you a safe trip to Rio and look forward to our next meeting. We remain fully committed to your government's efforts in support of Haiti's economic and social development.

Best.

cdm

Sent from my BlackBerry® device from Digicel

subject: Peter Erlinder
text:
Dear Mr. Koh,

I am a colleague of Professor Erlinder and also a graduate of Yale Law School ('79). I invoke the latter connection in hopes of obtaining your attention to a plea on Professor Erlinder's behalf.

Professor Erlinder and I agree on very little politically. Indeed, we disagree on almost every issue. However, I want the U.S. government to do everything it can to speedily obtain Professor Erlinder's release.

But those merits are, in my opinion, entirely beside the point, as is the question of whether Professor Erlinder was foolish or brave to return to Rwanda. I respect both Don Quixote and Clarence Darrow. The point is that Professor Erlinder put himself at risk to "walk the walk" of a fundamental principle of any free society — the right to counsel. The defendants at the Nuremberg trials had counsel. The Israelis accorded Eichmann counsel.

It now appears that Professor Erlinder's detention may turn into a covert execution. "Under intense interrogation from detectives, detained American Prof. Peter Erlinder swallowed up to 50 tablets meant to treat hypertension and other medical conditions — which the Police now says is also another crime, RNA can exclusively reveal." Rwandan News Agency - Wednesday, 02 June 2010 13:28 by RNA Reporter http://rnanews.com/politics/3496-distressed-peter-erlindertries-to-commit-suicide—police-

Please use all the skills and resources at your command to cause our government to help Professor Erlinder to freedom before it is too late.

Thank you.

Professor Daniel S. Kleinberger Founding Director, Mitchell Fellows Program William Mitchell College of Law 875 Summit Avenue St. Paul, MN 55105 email: phone: 651 290-6387 fax: 651 290-6414

All- we've analyzed the document and conferred with SD and CJCS. Appreciate the effort of all. The text as far as the Iraqis are willing to go today falls well short of the features we discussed last night. We therefore plan, as discussed, to issue the EXORD at 1500 EST. This order begins a movement of people that is reversible and temporary, as negotiations continue.

Jeh Johson and Bob Taylor are prepared to explain the legal shortcomings for further negotiation. Jim Miller will choreograph, with JS and CENTCOM and State, the unfolding of this action to mitigate disruption.

Appreciate the continued efforts of all. Ash

subject: Opposition leader
text:
Hi Jake,

In several ways,

The example of Kim Dae Jung in Korea is a good one: as a candidate for pres he bitterly opposed the IMF program. But then supported in the national interest -- which not only saved the economy from bankruptcy but lead to its dramatic revival. And he came across as a hero for putting the national interest above party interests and for the ultimate success of the policy. I was financial advisor to Korea at the time -- and the national unity this produced had a profound impact on markets and respect for korea around the world.

See you soon, Bob

Dear Madam Secretary: It has been a pleasure and an honor to serve you and the President

in Afghanistan. We have seen extraordinary developments over the past year, including the conclusion of the Strategic partnership Agreement and its associated Memorandum of Understanding.

It is with great reluctance that I must ask that you and the President accept my resignation this July at a date convenient to you.

Once again, it has been an honor to serve. Sincerely,

Ryan C. Crocker Ambassador

The Honorable Hillary Rodham Clinton Secretary of State Washington, DC.

Cody,

Realistically the UN will not authorise a no fly zone while Gaddafi continues to hold off bombing and strafing but keeping it up front and on the military agenda keeps him worried. Yet for a few frustrating months that ambivalence kept the Serbian aeroplanes on the ground before we acted. My hope is that preparations continue with visuals of planes flying off carriers, airborne early warning planes flying and people with clout outside the Administration demanding preparations. But and it is a big BUT what else can and should we be doing? Encourage humanitarian ships and convoys from Egypt to bring in supplies since we must ensure the cities in the East can hold up living standards, maybe for months. More adventurous, Egyptian Special Forces to go in and advise, even supplying hand held missiles. It appears they have few missiles; the military in the East having been deliberately kept ill-equipped. There is old Nasserite sentiment for a Federation of Egypt, Sudan and Libya. I know some will say Egypt has enough problems and they should stay resolutely focused on domestic reforms. it is delicate but words alone and the balance of advantage will slip to Gaddafi. A Gaddafi victory is possible and needs to be weighed in the balance now when deciding what to do.

I'm more worried than I am ready to say publicly.

Yours David

subject: MG in Ibad - quick rundown
text:
Marc was quite pleased with his conversations with Kayani and is likely to go back in October with the same time (Grossman, Lute, Lavoy).

Panetta called Karzai at 1 am and bought another day at least. Grossman and Lute will meet with Karzai tomorrow to try to make progress. This continues to be difficult. Cunningham is conveying your message that now is not the time for a confrontation.

Looks like another green-on-blue attack today with two Brits killed. Will keep you posted.

You may have seen that Japan has gone public with its new nuclear policy. Big anti-Japanese protests in China today.

That's about all for now.

subject: Corker
text:
He is calling to complain about Ambassador Holbrooke. He feels that Holbrooke is condescending and not forthcoming, including at this week's hearing. He also has broader concerns about the lack of a clear end state and metrics for our Afghan policy, but the main reason he wants to talk to you is about Holbrooke.

Holbrooke tried to faithfully answer his questions and frankly Corker was looking for a sound byte and he got one. We can offer him additional briefings and a readout after your upcoming trip if that would help.

You could use also this opportunity to thank him for sitting down earlier this week on the New START Treaty; to note that we received and are following up on his July 14 follow-up letter; and that we want to continue working with him to get him to a place where he can support the treaty.

Just saw a portion of S interview with Jorge Ramos. She hit the ball out of the park on the question framed around Enrique Krauze's NYT op-ed today about US moral hypocrisy. I don't think he was expecting her to give a categorical answer and address the issue head on. They teased her response to a question about Chavez's comment that Obama is ignorant. They will air it in Ramos' Sunday talk show. My mom saw the Telemundo interview with Sevcec. She said that one was more personal and friendly.

Meanwhile, the coverage out of Mexico City featured Espinosa welcoming the WH announcement today as consistent with the overall policy goals while calling on us to do more.

Did she do Patricia Junot of CNN en Espanol?

You've prob seen the promo: Anderson Cooper is reporting from the border 'the war next door" for the next two days. They had a pretty dramatic set-up piece today.

Great. Will keep confidential and appreciate your doing that w this note.

Just reviewed. Will miss Matt. ©

One missing piece here is leadership. Who can attract/retain/manage/hold accountable a team at the highest level. I just don't see who would be on par with Sec. Clinton in terms of that aspect.

The other missing piece is coordinating Treasury and multilateral engagement. WB and EU are probably bigger ag funders than US govt even after we start spending real money in these countries.

This is particularly true on the research, education and extension areas — and that is an area where USDA has CDC like capacity that should be leveraged aggressively. It's true that until recently USDA didn't offer this real capacity it has to anyone -- forcing people to work through the foreign ag service which is a completely different way to engage. But that is changing rapidly.

It's also true on agricultural infrastructure and marketing, where MCC brings more to the table than anyone — especially in the area of ag infrastructure.

USAID's strength should be in the country planning and country level implementation — and in this respect this initiative (even housed outside of AID)

I also suspect that in early countries we will need to identify strong leadership — which could be existing AID staff but it may be helpful to being open to finding new people at that level if needed.

This is very similar to the initial PEPFAR debate.

We had a little fun at today's briefing. Our friends in the media have been bugging us regarding your holiday plans, so we announced your departure from Washington in the following way:

"...And finally, a few of you have asked about the schedule of the Secretary of State over the next few days. I can tell you this morning the Secretary departed Washington and she stopped at the North Pole for an important bilateral meeting with a well known international figure. During the meeting, in a formal demarche, sung to the tune of Twelve Days of Christmas, the Secretary outlined her aspirations for the new year. They include, and feel free to hum along: open and accountable governments, Middle East negotiations, more civilians in Afghanistan, empowerment of women, fewer nuclear weapons, respect for human rights, resolution of historic grievances, treaties through the United States Senate, Six-Party Talks, dialogue with Iran, enough food for people of the world to eat, climate change legislation, and lastly, a championship for the Boston Red Sox. Okay, that last one's not on her list, but Harold Koh and I thought it was important that we mention that here."

It is a privilege to be a part of your team. We wish you, the President and Chelsea all the best during the holiday season and look forward to great achievements in 2010, with one tiny exception.

H, May I have your permission to speak with someone on your staff regarding this new Water Partnership ? If yes, who would that be ? I have been in the trenches on this topic in the US, and to some degree in the UK and elsewhere, for over 4 years and have learned a great deal about specific vulnerabilities, possible better and less costly systems, pitfalls, barriers, etc. Includes many US cities, some water authorities, some water associations, etc. Would love to 'noodle' and strategize this with the right person. Won't get in the way, may be able to help & will be low profile. As always, thanks. M

I have just received this email on my personal account, which I check much less frequently than my State account.

I have not received any emails from you on my State account in recent days -- for example, I did not get the email you sent to me and Feltman on the Egyptian custody case. Something is very wrong with the connection there. I suppose a near-term fix is to just send messages to this account -- my personal account -- and I will check it more regularly.

I have a written readout that I will send home tonight for you. I spoke with Cannon's guy yesterday and told him we'd come back to him Monday or Tuesday. I'll have CDM follow up with Rangel and then take it from there.

Raj:

The Secretary has asked for a review of our economic assistance to Egypt; she understandably wants to ensure that what we are doing is focused; aligned with current priorities and opportunities; and produces some high-impact, highvisibility results in the near term. This is consistent with her desire to demonstrate that we are changing the way we do business, and that the US get some credit for what we are doing.

I understand from Jake that he, Bill and Rob are working with your team and Cairo to do a rapid review, including of our ongoing programs. Given the difficulty and priority.of this, the team in Cairo may need some moral and technical support to get there — particularly when they have to make some tough decisions.

The Secretary, as we all are, is looking for the best way to position ourselves in the new political landscape, which may mean as it has in other places that we have to stop doing some of what we are doing now to focus on higher priorities and emerging opportunities.

Can you connect with Jake and Rob so we have a process to prioritize this activity and to ensure as we step through this we get the best from the team on the ground. And if needed, it may appreciated if we offer Mara and the mission in Cairo some extra help as well.

Can you address?

Thanks.

cdm

Hi Huma,

Per your earlier request, we'll need to prepare a memo to Nancy Powell for the Secretary's signature asking that Jim receive the Distinguished Service Award, including a suggested citation. Is there anything in particular the Secretary would like to emphasize? We could have it be something along the following lines:

or, I could pass to the speechwriters to come up with something.

I assume the Secretary will want to present the award at the event on the 20th; if so, we should probably look to get this into DGHR by early next week so we can get it printed and framed, and the medal engraved.

Many thanks, Steve

Stewart,

I went for news and indeed Guy is right. The meeting occurred yesterday and the decision was made to revoke the government on October 29. I wonder what happened with the initial decision which was strictly concerning Minister Dorsainvil and which was for November 20th or 21st.The idea had been sold that Michele should not be touched as the President did not care to have a vacuum in these electoral times. Plus, Michele was finally regarded as ambitionless (not seeking presidential powers) which is not a bad thing under the circumstances. Apparently, she, not being amenable to sacrificing some of her Ministers...and again, she being the one to name their replacements, has brought about the decision to do away with her altogether. The trouble is that nobody seems willing to counter the President with whom the instructions have originated. It is a head to head match between the Prime Minister and the President. That is obviously not good. Nobody will stand against the President elect for the Prime Minister appointed.

I will have two meetings with separate parliamentarians tomorrow. On one end the ones voting to oust her on the other the week opposition. The frustrating thing is that none have allegiance to her, just as none have the individual power to stand against the vote for which consensus is being secured.

• The UN and other international players (at least locally) after having cried victory, success and democracy are reluctant to openly and publically denounce the matter. After announcing a week or two ago that Haiti is the new place to invest, how can they say anything but whatever is done, reflects good governance.

Frankly, I did not see this one coming. We need to think.

In touch tomorrow for updates.

subject: Einhorn Visit Postponed
text: Colleagues, MFA Arms Control Dept. Director Sun Lei informed me at 1830 pm that, "in light of the current situation, China has decided to postpone the consultations with Robert Einhorn" scheduled for July 20-21. Sun added that China attached importance to these consultations but the U.S. should clearly know why China is postponing them, and that "the responsibility is not on the Chinese side." He said that we cannot request cooperation on issues of concern to the U.S. while not cooperating on issues of concern to China. I noted that the issues Mr. Einhorn would discuss are of concern not only to the U.S., but also to China and many other countries.

subject: Grapes
text:
Just had dinner with Chilean FM Moreno at Insulza's house. Moreno said the USDA deal is: that Cat 1 grapes can come in after April 10; others nit April 10; USDA will send more APHIS inspectors to do on-site inspections in Chile so that grapes that do not make Cat 1 can be sold elsewhere and not get rejected in US.

The real USDA give here is on beefed-up on-site inspections --the Cat 1 / Apr 10 stuff was standard. Moreno has already spoken with Chilean exporters and seems ok with it. Not perfect but better than it could have been. He said he was not aware that there was a Mexico angle as well in this issue.

ck

I understand that South African Foreign Minister has placed a call to the Secretary on the proposed World Bank loan for a coal-fired power plant. Wanted to give you some background on that (beyond what will be in the call sheet), in case the Secretary ends up returning the call. I've pasted below a DRAFT IM that was prepared for the two Ds. It gives more substantive background on the project, which I thought might be helpful. It does not yet fully reflect building views, so I've tried to summarize those here.

Don't hesitate to reach out if you want more information on any of this. MS

subject: Ms. Marie Colvin
text:
Dear Senator Whitehouse,

My apologies for not responding sooner to your message last night. We've received very sensitive information, the key elements of which we have been allowed to share only with the family given our contacts' security concerns. While we very much appreciate the offer by you and former Senator Specter to intervene with the Syrian leadership, we concluded that such outreach would be better left to Kofi Annan in his new capacity as UN/Arab League Special Envoy for Syria. The humanitarian situation is part of Annan's mandate, and we do not want to risk crossing wires with that effort. We were also concerned that the regime might misinterpret outreach by others as a USG attempt to open a channel of communication.

I hope this is useful, and please feel free to contact me if you have any other questions. Best, Michelle

subject: John Kerry
text:
I will have with me a big file on this; I raised the case on the margins of Aboul-Gheit's meeting with you on August 30. We will work with CA to have a letter prepared to take.

The case is typical in that the U.S. parent has custody that the Egyptian courts have not yet recognized (case is pending). But it's atypical in that it's the mother who took the kids to Egypt and the father who is in the U.S. We're in touch with Senator Kerry's office on this.

Jeffrey Feltman Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State 202-647-7209

subject: Changing Political Situation in Pakistan
text:
Jake

In the past 48 hours, the political situation in Pakistan has entered a new phase. The Supreme Court ruled the NRO illegal and paved the way for prosecution of several government officials, most notably Interior Minister Rehman Malik. Malik has been summoned before the Court and the Defense Minister (along with 247 other officials) was barred from traveling to China on an official visit. Vali Nasr has been following the fast-moving and still unclear developments closely.

In addition, the Supreme Court has opened the door to new petitions to be filed, questioning Zardari's eligibility to have run for president in the first place. The Court could use those petitions to force Zardari from office in the near future. It is clear that Zardari's fate will be decided by the military, which has been gaining prominence and will be in an even stronger position after this shake-up.

In the past two days Gilani has come to Zardari's defense, suggesting the two have reached an agreement over transfer of power from president to prime minister.

Hi Cheryl & Huma - As you may know, since concluding my Shanghai role, I have been giving my all to building a Mexican American diaspora project aimed at helping build a civil society infrastructure in Mexico. Along with Henry Cisneros and Maria Echaveste, who have joined me on the board of the U.S.- Mexico Foundation, we have been traveling around the country to build support in the Mexican American community for our efforts.

I am pleased to say that we will publicly launch this project on May 17 with a series of events in DC, including a national press club event that Henry C. will headline. As you know, our efforts have been inspired by Secy Clinton's charge to us to find ways to engage in Mexico. Part of the success of our efforts has been our ability to tell people that Secy Clinton is deeply committed to this project. I truly believe that this is an HRC legacy project. Nothing like this has ever been attempted in our community. We have been involved in precedent shattering conversations with Mexican civil society leaders, including the most prominent business leaders. We have reached deep into our pockets to demonstrate financial commitment. I personally gave $10k to this effort. I am not alone.

Now the ask: we'd like Secy Clinton to be our lunch keynote on May 17. As I mention, this is her baby - a wonderful legacy project that she can be proud of. I wish I could say that this is the last time that I'll ever ask for something but I'd probably be lying. Please try to make this happen. Her key Latino advisors/supporters are leading this.

I do NOT know how she does it, but listening to her speak about the issues that we all care about so much, with such passion and depth of knowledge, made it all worthwhile many times over, and I honestly did not think I could ever say that. That is why we do what we do. I looked over and saw the three of you standing there — I'm sure I must have looked like a proud parent — and was very proud to be part of the team. We did something really important. AM Anne-Marie Slaughter Director of Policy Planning U.S. Department of State (202) 647-2972

Jan and Nancy: 

As we are winding down the first year for Hillary, I wanted to reach out and say a belated but sincere thank you for all the work you put in to get us off to a great start with staffing her team.

I am sure as you look across it you see a number of the faces you recommended, all of whom are doing yeomen's work given the challenges this administration faces in foreign policy.

A special thank you as well for Margaret. She has been the gift that keeps on giving (indeed she is focused now on ensuring USAID has the team it needs to assist Hillary both in revitalizing the agencyand producing the development outcomes that will last for a lifetime).

I hope you have a great holiday season — I know there are many who will be giving thanks for you being among their blessings — I just wanted to add my voice.

best.

cdm

subject: Response to Turkish Earthquake
text: You will have seen that there was a very serious earthquake near Van in eastern Turkey this morning, with recent estimates putting it at 7.3 on the Richter scale, and initial reports suggest there are hundreds of fatalities. Embassy Ankara has convened an Emergency Action Committee and formed a command post to monitor the situation and coordinate any USG response. The Embassy has been in touch with the Turks to determine whether they are seeking outside assistance, and OFDA has put the Fairfax and Miami/Dade County search and rescue teams on standby for possible deployment to assist in recovery efforts. Ops Center will update through the day as required.

subject: Moment w Lebanese school girls I had to share
text:
Cheryl,

Am about to depart Beirut. Was in classroom yesterday in working cl town in southern Leb w classrm of 12 year old girls. (We had done a bunch of much needed physical repair work at school.) Asked how many were going to university. Almost every hand went up. Asked how many knew what they wanted to do after university. One after the other, they started volunteering: doctor, graphic designer, journalist, teacher, media specialist, pilot. So I said that our boss, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, would be so pleased to hear about all their future plans because it was so impt to her that girls all over the world committed to their studies and like them, made plans for their futures and worked toward them. Huge smiles in the rm. Then I added that Secretary Clinton also wanted to hear from all of us (I pointed at me + our Amb + the various usg staff in the rm) what we were doing to help them achieve their goals. Even bigger grins. Definitely one of the (too rare) purely fun moments in the job. So I thought you should know. --m

Hey Hillary- heard through the grapevine you're going to be sitting down with a good friend of mine this week for an interview- Abigail Disney. She has been an incredible resource and coach over the last few months as I push forward to finish my film. Her project on women, war, and peace is also incredibly powerful. We now live in a time when it is more dangerous being a civilian in war than it is being a soldier- all the more reason her project is so important. Hope you had a good fourth of July and got my fingers crossed we get to catch up soon. You're deeply missed. xxooz

Sent from myyerizon Wireless BlackBerry

subject: Heads up on call
text:

It isn't clear who/ how many are on the list . We were in touch with the Deputy Minister at the MFA today about this, but obviously they didn't, or couldn't, do anything. We were told that IRI had someone leaving on vacation, but we didn't know Sam himself was departing. Lorne got in touch with me directly when he heard about Sam.

I am sure that Secretary LaHood is worried about his son. Sam is back at his apartment. We are trying to get our friends in the SCAF right now and believe we can find out tomorrow if Julie and other principals are on the list.

We will also work on contingencies.

Ambassador -- Yes, I agree. I just came back from spending about an hour with Jeff, who is now here at BAF.

, but as things now stand, he will not go to Germany until sometime tomorrow, so there will be a chance for you to go and see him at the hospital after the ramp ceremony. (COMISAF and COMIJC are also planning to attend the ceremony and then go to the hospital.) We have it all worked out. Will confirm that this is still the case in the morning.

I am now going to call Jeff's wife, but I after that, I am reachable at ext 2270 or 2276.

KD

To the editor:

As a human rights advocate who over the years has both agreed and argued with State Department Legal Adviser Harold Koh, I felt that Paul Starobin's suggestion that Koh has betrayed his principles ("A Moral Flip-Flop, August 7) left an unfair impression. Koh's problem is that when he associates himself with an administration policy that troubles his friends, we know about it, since of course he is free to agree publicly with his president (and since the administration is likely to roll him out as a spokesman on precisely those occasions). When he pushes to change or strengthen a policy in ways that champions of human rights would cheer, we are less likely to find out, because he has to be discreet in such efforts to remain effective. But whatever one thinks of his arguments about the War Powers Act and Libya, Koh has remained a dogged champion of many causes to which he has dedicated his life — from urging the administration to stick to its guns on closing Guantanamo, to advocating civilian trials for terror suspects, to elevating the promotion of human rights and justice for war crimes in American foreign policy.

Tom Malinowski Washington Director Human Rights Watch 1630 Connecticut Avenue, NW Washington, DC 20009

Tom Malinowski

Deputy Secretary Burns, Jake, Alec,

Please keep close hold, but my team is planning to launch a tool on Sunday that will publicly track and map the defections in Syria and which parts of the government they are coming from. Our logic behind this is that while many people are tracking the atrocities, nobody is visually representing and mapping the defections, which we believe are important in encouraging more to defect and giving confidence to the opposition. Given how hard it is to get information into Syria right now, we are partnering with Al-Jazeera who will take primary ownership over the tool we have built, track the data, verify it, and broadcast it back into Syria. I've attached a few visuals that show what the tool will look like. Please keep this very close hold and let me know if there is anything else you think we need to account for or think about before we launch. We believe this can have an important impact.

Thanks, Jared

Jared Cohen I Director of Google Ideas I Google I Tel: 212-565-9494

Follow me on Google+ Follow me on Twitter

subject: Update on marking strategy for USAID grantees in Pakistan
text:
Mark,

Who can give me a brief summary of the particular marking strategies of each of the grantees?

Now that I'm a seasoned veteran (in Islamabad for a month) I'd like to see an American flag on every item/project. Nothing else. Just the flag. Every Pakistani with whom I've spoken has told me that fancier logos, including the USAID logo, dilute the clarity of the marking, contributing to the overwhelming message I've received all over the country: "America announces repeatedly its billions in assistance. We see none of it. Therefore it's going directly into the coffers of corrupt Pakistanis." Or worse: a cabinet minister told me two days ago that "KLB money is being taken from the Pakistani people to build a new embassy compound in Islamabad."

I know these are simply impressions, and wrong ones; and we'll work to correct them. But I'd like to know what the grantees plan.

Thanks,

Cameron

I'm very pleased to announce that we've had a breakthrough in negotiations in Honduras.

I want to congratulate the people of Honduras as well as President Zelaya and Mr. Michelleti for reaching an historic ' agreement. I also congratulate Costa Rican President Oscar Arias for the important role he has played in fashioning the San Jose process and the OAS for its role in facilitating the successful round of talks.

As you know I sent Assistant Secretary Tom Shannon and his deputy Craig Kelly, and the White House NSC representative for the Western Hemisphere Dan Ristreppo to Honduras yesterday after speaking with both President Zelaya and Mr. Micheletti last Friday to urge them finally, once and for all to reach an agreement.

I cannot think of another example of a country in Latin America that having suffered a rupture of its democratic and consitutional order overcame such a crisis through negotiation and dialogue.

subject: Goldman Decision - update as of 01:30 local time - NO RETURN TONIGHT
text:
Dan,

I just got off the phone with Embassy Brasilia Charge Lisa Kubiske, who provided a recap of current developments in the Goldman child custody case. Summarizing:

-- David Goldman's Brazilian lawyer and the family's attorney are currently attempting to negotiate an "voluntary return." --If those talks fail, Goldman will request the Brazilian police execute the involuntary return ordered yesterday by a Brazilian judge. This outcome would create a negative PR climate. --Brazilian police "think" they know the boy's whereabouts. --Return to US likely will occur on an NBC News-chartered aircraft, as Goldman has inked some sort of exclusive deal w/ NBC for the story. --Post has been working with WHA and PD on a possible S statement.

subject: Constitution, Presidential elections, Shura Council, Advisory Council
text:
More on the Presidential Race:

The Freedom and Justice Party, the political arm of the Muslim Brotherhood, plans to support Advisory

Council head Mansour Hassan as Egypt's next president, sources within the group told Al-Masry Al-

Youm on Tuesday. Hassan, who served as an information minister during the rule of former President Anwar al-Sadat, has not shown any desire to run in the presidential election. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, added that the party chose Hassan due to his wide acceptance among different political factions. The party is still discussing the matter with different political forces, said the sources. A campaign, led by an FJP member of parliament and other political forces, to support Hassan will be launched online in ten days, the sources added. In December, the group announced it is looking for a candidate to support in the presidential election scheduled for June. The Brotherhood is looking to back a strong figure, but not someone whose name has already been floated as a potential candidate, the group's spokesperson Mahmoud Ghazlan said in a statement to London-based Al-Sharq Al-Awsat newspaper.

Several months ago, the Brotherhood banned members from running in the election and announced that it did not intend to nominate a candidate. The group expelled Abdel Moneim Abouel Fotouh after he announced his intention to run in violation of the decision. Other likely presidential candidates include former Arab League chief Amr Moussa, founder of the Karama Party Hamdeen Sabbahi, Salafi sheikh Hazem Abu Ismail and Islamic thinker Mohamed Selim al-Awa. (Al Masry Al Yom)

subject: OSC: KCNA report on detainees .
text:
I spoke with Mr. Gore a second time today; I called him this afternoon after we had seen some brief wire stories appear, referencing the KCNA report below. Explaining that this was my personal view, I said I was encouraged that the term "espionage" did not appear in the KCNA report. I also mentioned that we were not aware of recent cases where previously detained Amcits in the DPRK were "indicted" and "brought to trial." I said I wouldn't read too much into terms such as "illegal entry" and "suspected hostile acts"; I was still convinced that the track we've been pursuing, i.e. gaining consular access through the Swedish Amb. in Pyongyang, and contact via other diplomatic channels, offered hope for a resolution.

Mr. Gore said he very much appreciated the call. He asked that we convey as much of this information as we could to the family members. I told him we would do so through CA.

subject: Latest from NBC's contact
text: Jake: I have been reading this over and over and it just seemed a bit odd to me. I finally figured out that I think the source has somehow confused two Bel-Hajs: One is our boy who accused us and the Brits of rendition-Abdul Hakim BelHaj and a second one is Larnin Bel Haj, an Islamist leader who I believe had previously I believe somehow been involved In Sudan but was now back in his native Ubya. The latter is the head of the JCP and MB. The former is of the former LIFG and now the Libyan Islamist Movement for Change and the premier Western Brigade commander whose group had control over Matega Airport for several months after October 23 and who tried to make himself the Supreme Military Council Commander of Tripoli before the TNC leadership stepped in several months ago. Let me try to untangle this and see if any of it jibes with the reality we are seeing.

Hi Jake, This does not have a direct foreign policy bearing, but I think S would be interested — because it is an enormous and growing problem. These stats come from a NYT Op-Ed piece:

• Over 20% of California's debt issuance during 2009 and over 30% of its debt issuance in 2010 to date has been subsidized by the federal government in a program known as Build America Bonds. Under the program, the U.S. Treasury covers 35% of the interest paid by the bonds. Arguably, without this program the interest cost of bonds for some states would have reached prohibitive levels.

• "California is not alone: Over 30% of Illinois's debt and over 40% of Nevada's debt issued since 2009 has also been subsidized with these bonds. These states might have already reached some type of tipping point had the federal program not been in place."

• "Today, more than 28% of state funding comes from federal government transfers, the highest contribution on record. These transfers have made states dependent on federal assistance. New York, for example, spent in excess of 250% of its tax receipts over the last decade. The largest 15 states by GDP spent on average over 220% of their tax receipts. Clearly, states have been spending at unsustainable levels without facing immediate consequences due to federal transfer payments and other temporary factors."

Bob

subject: wonderful story I heard a wonderful story last night praising Hillary Clinton for her work on behalf of children.
text:
Last night I met Don Graves, he runs the Independent Living Skills Program (ILSP) in Contra Costa County. The program helps children in the foster care system, and among other things, teaches them skills needed to live on their own as adults.

Don told a heart-warming story of how then First Lady Hillary Clinton came out to visit with the kids in the program and hear their concerns. A major concern was that resources for kids coming out of foster care ended at age 18 and 6 months -- they needed more help. Within two years of the visit, President Clinton signed the Foster Care Independence Act, providing more money and more resources for ages 18 - 21. I think it is widely accepted that Hillary championed this legislation, and this was surely echoed by Don. He was beaming with admiration for her and what she accomplished to help the kids.

He went on to say that one of the participants in the program, Alfred Perez, who was part of the original discussion with the First Lady, was invited to the White House to see the bill signed. Alfred Perez later served on the Pew Commission on Foster care and is now teaching at the University of Chicago. http://www.ssa.uchicaoo.edu/facultv/ptlect/Derez-a.shtml

subject: Post 2015 panel update
text:

Esther

He pressed Robert for his view on whether we should, as a normative matter, send more arms in. He also asked about the radicalization of the opposition and how we can mitigate this trend.

Bottom line, sounds like Corker is trying to figure out his position on this issue, and he's looking for guidance from us on how to think about this, and what our policy should be.

Anyway, not sure if S connected with him, but wanted to flag this for you.

Hillary:

I met with Eduardo Stein, former Vice President of Guatemala and head of Truth Commission for Honduras, quality guy, who reports that POTUS trip to El Salvador and the decision to make it solely a bilateral meeting is receiving a negative reading in the Central American region. Stein states that the US's "favorite treatment" to El Salvador also extends to supposed preferred treatment in financial and political support to that country. Stein interprets that this is creating unnecessary bad feelings in the region. Primarily he was referring to Guatemala, Costa Rica and Honduras.

Best, Maria

subject: Latest on Goldman Decision
text:
Dan —

I just spoke with Marie Damour, CG at Embassy Brasilia, who provided an update on the Goldman case.

A scheduled 1100 EST press conference by the attorney for the Brazilian family did not take place. Damour reports the attorneys from both sides are still negotiating the details of the handover, as is the attorney for the Government of Brasil. According to the 2nd Regional Federal Court, the deadline for the turnover at the Consulate falls at 0600 local on 12/24. However, there may be a push to turn Sean over to the consulate today in order to permit him to travel to the U.S. on an overnight flight.

Damour will continue to update as events progress.

-Ph ill

I'm so devastated by Holbrooke's terrible health situation. Several of his staff have told me that you've been such a support to them. I only hope that his feisty spirit will help him now. It's hard to imagine him down. Mrs Mubarak has done a magnificent job with the conference. She asked me to go to a couple of the schools she has renovated in the poorest neighborhoods of Luxor as part of her schools' program. They are state of the art and become magnets for redevelopment. She sends her best. You have been mentioned with great affection repeatedly here by so many. I also went to a huge community renunciation of FGM in a rural area -- some 2000 villagers with men speaking eloquently about why this practice would be no more. This is another great effort they are making here to end FGM through community education. So amidst bad news, there is also the good. We also managed to dodge the latest wikileaks story here. Heading back tomw.

I just wanted to bring to your attention -- as you work with your budget team -- that there is only a very small amount for women, peace and security designated for the DOS '14 budget.

As you will recall, Leahy's people had put 50m in the '13 appropriations for DOS and felt that they would get the House to agree, given bipartisan support for women, peace and security.

If the Senate doesn't change, Congress may be able to salvage the 50m or something close to it, exclusively for State in the post-CR '13 appropriations.

Separately, there is 20m proposed for DOS (and 20m for AID) for a fund to implement the gender guidance under QDDR. It's ironic that tomorrow we are rolling out the DOS and AID plans for implementing our national action plan.

I think we are all set with the women's event at the Cook Islands with brief remarks from PM Gillard, the NZ FM, and a Pacific women leader. You will open the event and they will follow. Wenchi from our staff is en route to help with the event and your remarks look good. Also, Greta from our staff will be at APEC to support Hormats who will be participating in the women and economy intervention at the FM meeting and she will stay on for your events. (She worked closely with the Russians to help them pull off the St. Petersburg conf). I'm off to Morocco and Bangladesh and will be following your journey from afar. It's another marathon for you. Bon voyage!

subject: Last Night
text:
Dear Huma and Jake:

If there is an appropriate way to do so, I wondered if you might convey to Secretary Clinton how much it meant to me personally and to so many of us that she led us last night for cathartic story-telling and laughter. It was such a terrible evening, but she managed to ignite warmth at a moment when everything felt frozen still. Her ability to lift us all up after a trip to Canada, hosting a huge reception, and on top of her own loss, was itself a rallying cry to soldier on the way Holbrooke would have insisted we do. She helped fill the tremendous sense of void with funny memories and an appreciation of how deeply he touched so many of us. I felt better by the time I left, and still do.

Many thanks,

Suzanne

subject: Cairo readouts
text:
I'm not getting too much from Cairo yet. just texted me that the Arabs "are looking for something solid from the EU to consider dropping the SC bid and go for GA" with implication that they had not g6tten it.

Rob Danin, staffing Tony Blair, told me he and Ashton spoke this evening, and will meet at 10 pm tomorrow. She is pursuing a "Quartet+" approach with a proposed GA resolution that would fall short of actually elevating the Palestinian status, but would speak positively of the fact that Palestine is on the road to statehood.

Helga is not answering the phone, SMS or email. If Tina knows how to get her to respond, go for it.

David

subject: Dolores Huerta Medal of Freedom
text:
Dear Ms. Mills,

Thought the Secretary might like to know that a group of us through labor, womens organizations, environmentalists and Hispanic organizations are working to obtain a Presidential Medal of Freedom for Dolores Huerta, a good friend of HRC. President Clinton awarded one posthumously to her UFW co-founder Cesar Chavez and we thought it would be nice if Dolores could receive hers while she is still with us. The letter which is circulating is appended.

Sincerely,

Martin Chavez

Martin J. Chavez Executive Director ICLEI Local Governments for Sustainability USA 1331 F Street, N.W., Suite 975 Washington, D.C. 20004 202.629.3591

Will I receive a full notebook for approps hearings tonight?

I'd like a call this afternoon or evening to go over the draft Af-Pak regional strategy. Who should be on call? It is quite good but lacks "milestones" and budgets for each section.

Re the required report for Kerry-Lugar, I want to be sure that the language in both our report and this one echo the same language.

I never called Patricia Espinosa--should I?

Also, have we rec'd a memo from Shaun Woodard for Robinson and McGuinness calls?

There will also be a PC on Af-Pak Tuesday and I want to be sure our report is ready.

Cheryl/Pat

This is probably already on your radar, but wanted to make sure I flagged.

Beth Jones was designated as Acting A/S for NEA on June 1 (the day after Jeff vacated the position). As I understand it, under the Vacancies Reform Act, she can only retain the Acting title for 210 days unless a nominee is pending before Congress.

Her 210 days will run up on December 28th but can be extended if someone is nominated when Congress gets back early January.

I know this is odd timing given the transition. PPO has not said anything to me about this yet either.

I can speak with L about whether there is any leeway in extending the 210 days particularly given transition. Also I will confirm that under the Vacancy Reform Act, if Beth's clock does run out, then Liz Dibble in her capacity as PDAS can automatically serve as Acting if we want to go that route.

Thanks. Heather

subject: Thanks so much for the talk
text:
Dear Hillary,

Spoke to the person you recommended on Friday. Sounds like he is comfortable and even surprised that Pakistanis are doing more. And maybe he will find some more ways to help, like the helicopter leasing. When I mentioned that someone deep in the ISI must be happy that Al Qaeda's alive, so we don't abandon Pakistan again, he chuckled.

I talked about the "vetting" for intelligence. I also talked "defeat strategy," and the need for something more than just deploying more forces and hoping the training for the Afghans will work.

I continue to be struck by the parallels to Vietnam, and especially Johnson's inability to resist escalation, and his advisor's continued "incrementalism."

But I'm encouraged by the pace of the review. Seems that there's sufficient time to consider this from all angles.

I can imagine there are those arguing that we just need to fill the gap while we enlarge the Afghan army. That we help the Pakistanis but not press them to the point of being unpleasant. And that too much focus on Osama and al-Zawahiri raises the risk of public failure if we don't get them. There is much logic to this, but it has a strong tint of incrementalism.

Hopefully, we can be more decisive: lean harder on the Pakistanis, provide more troops to McChrystal than his "moderate risk" and raise the heat on al Qaeda - then do all we can to push economic development in Afghanistan, restrain Indian meddling, and prepare to do more against Al Qaeda in Pakistan, directly if necessary. Ultimately, it seems that our best exit strategy would be to take down the top leadership of Al Qaeda in Pakistan, and then gradually draw down in Afghanistan.

Wish I could do more to help

All the best, Wes

All is quiet here. Iraqis have done a great job at least so far covering the masses and churches. I went to a mass in Eastern Baghdad, Nuncio and Catholic Archishop of Baghdad 'presiding.' Church was about 2/3 full. Homily directly targeted the terrorist threats, pleaded for understanding, and hope for a change.

The Iraqi security at the site itself was extraordinary. (Security at a Christian hospital I visited yesterday less so, but there certainly was security provided by police.) More generally, streets were about as deserted as on Christmas day in the Irish-Italian neighborhoods north of Boston. Some of this is traditional Iraqis also 'celebrating' Christmas, but some of it was the extraordinary 'Iockdown' which the security forces had in those parts of the city I saw. Jim J

subject: IG Report
text:
Jack—

Thanks for flagging this. We actually saw this last night, and Vikram and I had a conversation with Richard about it. The report was based on interviews conducted in May-June, before the new policy change was implemented, so much of the report is already OBE. OIG gave us the draft report in October, and SRAP/SCA/INL immediately sent a joint response to OIG (attached), highlighting that we were already working on many of the issues highlighted in the report.

Given the change in policy and our letter to them, we found it pretty egregious that the OIG didn't report on the changes underway or adjustments already made, as the report is being portrayed in the press as currently applicable. Michael Keays on the Afghan desk and Peggy, who both help to oversee CN issues, are already working on a letter to OIG expressing our strong concern about the report and the process which got us to this point, and Vikram and his team are ginning up press points which also note that we have already begun to robustly address many of these points (I've cc'ed them all on this).

If you'd like to talk further, I'm happy to come up to your office at some point this morning to discuss.

Dan

subject: Judeh's Readout
text:
He'll send me an email and will call the Senator later this evening.

He described the evening as unpleasant, but Abbas did what NJ told the Senator he would do, viz emphasized he was and wanted to remain engaged with us in efforts to preserve the direct talks based on a moratorium, but outlined the options as described to us for consideration if talks do not continue. There was an effort to include those options in the communique, but that was blocked by our friends. Judeh says key pt in stmt is support continued US led discussion with all parties to create conditions conducive to continued negs.

We should get text before reacting - do any press contacts have it? - and if Judeh is accurate, focus on that line and affirm we continue our efforts.

I hope someone in the Administration can say something to make me feel better about today's outcome on the ATT negotiations.

In 2008 I walked up and down the streets of my rural, mostly Republican community in mid-Michigan, trying to persuade my neighbors to vote for Barack Obama. That won't be happening this year. Though I can't imagine voting for Romney, I'm so upset over the ATT outcome that I may just sit out this election. Unlike Guantanamo and the wars, this one was so easy. And they still managed not to get it right.

Somehow I hope the outcome looks better from where you sit. Susan Waltz

Susan Waltz Professor Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy University of Michigan

Folks,

I have roughed out a document in the right format drawn on the action plan (with USAID edits). I will continue fine tuning it until Joe or Saba arrive and can take over. Saba — did see the version from Melanne. We don't need to worry about Pakistan in this document. In our stabilization paper that went public, there are Afghan-specific papers and Pak specific papers. If/when we have a Pakistan strategy, we can include that as well.

We will get something pulled together in the next hour to send around for everyone's review.

Peggy

subject: Micheletti Stepping Aside
text:
Following is close-hold please.

You will have seen press reports that Micheletti is stepping down — reportedly it will be a "leave of absence" for legal reasons. If this holds, it is an important development that we have been pushing to allow space for Pepe Lobo to get off to a good start and encourage greater attendance at the Jan 27 inauguration. This was the point of my Jan 5-6 trip to Tegucigalpa, Hugo's consistent efforts and our follow-up visa revocations. Two nights ago President Martinelli of Panama called me saying Micheletti wanted to find a way out and would he, Martinelli, talk to me. I spoke with Martinelli about ten times over the last two days to discuss specifics. Micheletti wanted to depart Friday but I told Martinelli that it had to be today because regional leaders need time to make their plans. Micheletti wanted assurances that visas would be restored, but we simply forward to Martinelli our standing press guidance that we continuously review visa decisions based on the situation on the ground. ck

subject: Thank you to S
text:
Dear Cheryl,

The Secretary's video message was played today on a jumbotron during the memorial service marking the first anniversary of the Christchurch earthquake.

The service was held in Hagley Park, a two-minute walk from the George Hotel. Present were the Prime Minister, the Governor General, most of the Cabinet, families of the victims, and approximately 20,000 Christchurch citizens.

The video was extraordinarily well received at the event, and it was prominently featured on the evening news reports and related websites. I received dozens of expressions of thanks at the event, including from the Prime Minister, followed by many more expressions of gratitude on our electronic media platforms.

I would be grateful if you could convey those and my personal thanks to the Secretary for recording the video despite all the other demands on her time. Her message was pitch-perfect, personal, and powerful, and it will be long remembered and appreciated here in New Zealand.

Best regards,

D

Jake: Madeline Albright very kindly called to provide a readout of a call she had today with Roza Otunbayeva, the head of the Kryrgystan provisional administration. She characterized it as a good call. Otunbayeva was pleased to talk, said she wants to restore democracy to Kyrgystan and have a government that is responsible to the people. She said she personally wants to have a "high reputation" as a result of her democracy efforts. MKA offered NDI's full assistance in organizing the elections Otunbayeva has pledged to hold in six months. Otunbayeva expressed her appreciation, but did not make any specific requests. Interestingly, Otunbayeva volunteered that Kyrgystan would keep Manas open. That is more forward leaning than what she told our Charge yesterday; she told him that they would need to review the Manas agreement but would keep it open pending that review. I thanked MKA for the readout and promised to pass it on to you. A memo and call sheet will be on its way shortly to the Secretary for her to call Otunbayeva tomorrow. Best, Bob

subject: She's asking if craig has an update.
text:
Huma: I was just typing one. Not surprisingly, the hardliner supporters of the regime, when they got wind of the deal today, mounted a counterattack, urging M not to leave. We are pushing back as we speak, and our de facto sources who support the deal are working to nail it down.

We are making the point that M's agreement to us to step aside fueled our successful efforts over last couple days to keep Euros and many Latins in the game but they need a change on the ground to support elections. M cannot pull rug out now. Moreover, we said since the de factos claim moral authority (over Zelaya) for carrying out the Oct 30 Accord, they cannot go back on this deal with us.

Will give you updates. I have an open ticket to go back down at any moment if necessary. Will let you know if an S call would help.

Best,

ck

Dear Ms. Adashek,

Please pass this message on to Vernon Jordan as soon as possible.

Dear Vernon,

I hope you are well.

This week Hillary Clinton will visit Hungary. I suggest that she should be very careful to avoid an embarrassment. The press is already full with remarks that her visit will be seen as an approval for the Hungarian government and Prime Minister Viktor Orban.

She should be aware that Mr. Orban's government is demolishing democracy in Hungary and is introducing a harsh system with disregard of human rights and freedom of speech. For her information I attach two articles:

http://www.washingtonpost.com/wpdyn/content/article/2010/12/26/AR2010122601791.html?referrer=emailarticle

http://www.nybooks.com/artic1es/archives/2011/apr/28/hungary-threat/ Please warn Mrs.Clinton before her trip to Hungary (planned for June 30). I am always available for help or information. Unfortunately I fear that the US Ambassador in Hungary, who is very close to Mr. Orban may not give her a full, balanced view of the dangers involved. Unless she makes a public statement about worries of dictatorial tendencies in Hungary, her visit will be seen as supporting an autocratic regime. With warmest regards to Ann and you, Ivan Fischer

subject: Your Phone Call with Tony Burman
text:
Just had a 30 minute call with Tony Burman head of Al Jazeera English. I registered our complaints in the strongest language possible. He started to respond by saying he knew I was concerned about their reporting of the "American" position. I interrupted him to say my concern was not about representing the American position but rather the "accurate" position of what was actually going on in Haiti. I referred him to the Sebastian Walker interview and Hs interview with Anand Naidoo. I said the former was almost laughable if it were not so serious. He promised to take a look at it and email me. He then told me that they had made an effort to broaden the coverage. He also referred to pieces in the NY Times and International herald tribune which also focused on comments from Brazilians and MSF. I pointed out that perhaps the bigger story was that with so many international organizations involved it was astonishing that so few had complaints. I reiterated the points that everything is being done in cooperation with and at request of GOH; that security is being handled under direction of UN; that we would make USG reps available to them for on record comments; etc. He said that Walker had tried but been unable to get comments from US Military. Frankly I think we need to be careful about making military available to them since that may reinforce the negative perceptions but PJ and Price should make that call.
