Can someone please email me Gordon's contact info in PoP so I can email it to Burman. Also names and info of anyone else in PoP they should contact if they need comments.

JM

Hi Cheryl,

I just wanted to write you a quick email thanking you for all your help during my job search. I've really appreciated all your assistance and patience throughout the entire process.

Over the course of the last several days, I've had a couple of really good conversations with Rich Verma and am looking forward to joining his team. He seems like a great guy and I'm eager to learn from him.

Also, I wanted to single out Laura, Heather, and Pat Carter from HR, each of whom have been tremendously helpful and patient as well. They've been great to work with.

Thank you again, and I look forward to joining you all next week.

subject: FW: Revised HAK LOC Importance: High
text:
Dear Jeff

I am following up on our conversation on Sunday. I am copying Ted to whom I had first raised this potential approach on a call two weeks ago.

Please find below the draft of the proposed approach I received.

After reviewing it and discussing as you deem appropriate internally, I would welcome a discussion regarding: 1) whether to proceed; 2) the mechanism for the coverage of these expenses consistent with our regulations and guidelines; 3) timeline for proceeding and 4) assurances that this satisfies the issues that have been raised by HAK regarding his historical materials.

Many thanks — hope this gets us there.

Best.

cdm

subject: Iran
text:
The EU meets in the coming days, and we are hoping for a strong public - and private - position on Iran. Bill has identified 5 countries that need touching to help drive a good outcome:

I know Huma has discussed with you, but a 2-minute discussion with each that underscores the key points reflected on your card would do the trick, if you can swing it.

Tx. Also, the intervention, with your modifications, turned out well. The process, in this case, did not generate a good • enough product -- I tried to make it clearer and stronger this morning and your amendments helped a lot.

I tried to get them to switch the agenda to include Egypt instead of China — they are determined to raise China but we agreed that it will come last — so right now there will be a quick mention of Egypt at the top by Elisa Massimino from Human Rights First (who will open the meeting and serve as traffic cop). Then Karen Ryan from the Carter Center will raise DRC, followed by Ken Roth of Human Rights Watch who will raise Af/Pak issues, then David Kramer (former A/S in DRL now at Freedom House) raising China issues. The goal is to allow 15 minutes at the end for S (along with Dan Friend and Harold ) to raise Gitmo issues and ask for their support. We now have 45 minutes for the meeting

subject: wow!!
text: It is the top academic honor other than being in the National Academy of Sciences; they also have a small and very elite category for public servants. There is a beautiful Japanese style building in Cambridge where it is headquartered; they run study groups and projects on important academic and policy issues. You can be a member of a study group without being a member of the Academy, but they are run by members of the Academy. I don't think there are dues; they publish the magazine Daedalus which you get for free. But really, it's all about the honor of the thing. They have an elaborate induction ceremony at some point in the fall, but unless you wanted to give a speech there, I doubt you would go. I'll send you the list of people admitted this year. I just love the idea of being fellow members.

subject: Message for the Secretary
text:
Cheryl - could you pass this note to the Secretary for me? Thank you. Carlos

Madam Secretary,

Patricia Espinosa will likely see you in Montevideo and mention your trip to Mexico on March 23. One of her concerns is to make sure that other cabinet members who belong to the High-Level Group on security issues also participate. On our side the other two key players are Secretaries Napolitano and Gates. Espinosa will try to make sure their counterparts are there. It would be helpful if you could call Napolitano and Gates and encourage them to come. Napolitano's role on Juarez and the border is especially critical.

I am on the way back to Mexico City from El Paso following the de-brief from an intensive week-long planning session that involved all key US and Mexican security agencies. We have a strong plan. Calderon now needs to make important decisions on command and control, force deployments, and prosecutorial capacity. We are still working on the socioeconomic plan. They can turn the violence around, but they will need to be resolute and clear about responsibilities and authorities. It would be helpful if you could tell Espinosa that you are aware of the plan and affirm the importance of establishing a unified command structure for the security operations in Juarez.

Carlos

This message has been sent via BlackBerry

It's a very New York crowd and very Diane style event (i.e. unconventional) Last year, it was held in one of the big delegates' lounges at the UN and she redid all the chairs, etc in her patterns. The awards are all serious and DVF is the moderator. Each awardee receives 50K for her ongoing work. The event bears no resemblance to a typical foreign policy event, but if you were in NY, you could arrive for the awards and leave. I have no doubt you would be very warmly embraced and DVF and Barry are so fond of you. I would only do it if could be easily done.

subject: Memo following up on President's speech
text: You will note that I put something in there about her big speech following up on his. She said on Monday that she really does want to give it, and I think it is critical that she does. More and more I am hearing things about how the White House is setting the agenda and she is just the implementer. For her stature and and longer-term impact she has to seize this moment to flesh out a real foreign policy strategy rather than just a set of proposals, as important as they are. The president has given her the opening. But she has to do it b/w now and July 15, and I see only 1-2 possible days. Any chance it could be on the 231d? Jake — I ran this by Les Gelb showed him the most recent version of the draft I had done — he had lots of comments but thought it had a lot to say and also absolutely agreed that she should give such a speech.

Hi Jake,

I will be in Cairo on August 27 and 28 to lead an economic delegation to pursue the commitments made by S and the President for economic assistance to help the Egyptians close their $12 billion budget deficit and foster economic growth throughout Egypt.

I will be joined by Bill Taylor, Caroline Atkinson, Assistant U.S. Trade Representative Dan Mullaney, OPIC Vice President Robert Drumheller, and Treasury Deputy Assistant Secretary Andy Baukol.

I am coordinating closely with Anne Patterson on private and public messaging and other central elements of the visit.

We expect to (1) begin to deliver upon U.S. bilateral assistance to financial relief to Egypt from its current fiscal and balance of payments pressures; (2) support multilateral funding for Egypt, including an IMF agreement; and (3) promote a closer commercial relationship between Egyptian and American businesses to expand two-way trade and investment.

Bill Taylor and AID Assistant Administrator Mara Rudman will stay on after our ministerial meetings to negotiate the conditionality and benchmarksfor the cash transfer before we submit the congressional notification.

Dear Kurt,

Thank you to you and your team for your leadership in setting up today's video conference with the Secretary.

Please convey to the Secretary my personal thanks - and the deep gratitude of everyone here at US Mission NZ - for her generosity with her time and for the graciousness and power of her words.

Today's event energized our Mission colleagues, who had been feeling the usual post-crisis letdown but are now walking on air. The event also had a significant impact on our GNZ friends, who left the Chancery beaming and commenting among themselves about the extraordinary honor of being invited into the call as part of our team.

FYI, immediately upon conclusion of the call we held an awards ceremony to further thank our Kiwi friends. In front of the full Embassy audience, we called each GNZ attendee forward individually, shared an anecdote about the person's unique contribution during the immediate aftermath of the quake, and presented each Kiwi with the American Ambassador's Honor Medal. (Michele Petersen was previously presented with the Medal, and I believe she has it in her office.)

Thank you again. Today's video conference was of immense value to everyone here, and I appreciate the tireless work in DC that made it possible.

Warm regards,

subject: Thank you
text:
Cheryl

A quick note of thanks for including Laurent and me among the Haiti delegation. It was such. a good experience for both of us and really helped solidify their interest and, hopefully, will fast track their plans. Loads of new relationships and connections.

Huge congratulations, I hope you are proud of what you have accomplished. I know there is so much more to do but we don't often take a minute to recognize how extraordinary our accomplishments are. I hope you do!

Many thanks. Hope to see you soon. Want to sit and talk with you about post Jan!

Whitney Williams President, williamsworks CEO, Eastern Congo Initiative

www.williamsworks.com

subject: What did you find out about the '67 language?
text:
Sorry -- just seeing. In short, they might have made a bad word choice. They should have said "reconcile" instead of "achieve both." But having done it, they've got to play out the string with the Pals, who would be suspicious of the change. But if AM says no on Monday, Mitchell is open to changing it. If AM miraculously says yes, then they'll have the leverage to push it through with BN. Can elaborate on plane.

They didn't admit they made a bad word choice - that's my interpretation.

subject: I am sorry that I didn't get a chance
text: To tell you in person today what an honor and a pleasure it has been to work with you over these last four years as Feed the Future has evolved. Today's event was a terrific pulling together of threads, like country driven strategies, that we have been working on since literally the first day of the Administration. You and the Secretary are both rock stars. Over this term, you have both done an incredible amount to help hundreds of millions of the world's most vulnerable people, including most especially young children. As you begin to think about your next adventure, I hope that I get a chance to say goodbye and to assure you that there are many career folks at State who want to see this effort continue on into the future With highest regards, Bill Craft.

subject: 2 passages from maiden speech of Britain's new sec for development
text:
Overall the speech is worth reading; if you like I'll have it put in your weekend book. 2 passages particularly worth noting.

1. "Across the Atlantic, Hilary Clinton has pledged to put women 'front and center' of the American development agenda. That is the right choice. As David Cameron and Jeff Sachs argued earlier this year, women can hold the key to development in the world's poorest countries — in education, enterprise, micro-finance and healthcare. Investing in women pays dividends throughout the entire community."

2. "I see DFID as a key, joined-up, integrated department, a bright star in the Whitehall constellation, a department of state for development in the developing world. That's why DFID has a seat at the Cabinet table and it's why I won't be satisfied until our message rings down the corridors of each and every department in Whitehall."

We obviously don't love the "dept of state for development language," but what is most noteworthy is his emphasis on "joined-up" and "integrated" dept — underlining the fact that DFID as a separate cabinet department has been almost divorced from the rest of the government.

Anne-Marie Slaughter Director of Policy Planning U.S. Department of State (202) 647-2972

subject: Fwd: 5635
text:
Sorry to bother on the Sunday before Christmas but the Echumenical Patriarch's crowd are extremely worried that he may get arrested or otherwise harassed/attacked as a result of the 60 Minutes interview he gave which airs tonight. Thought it was worth passing along and that you might want to get someone to pulse the Emabassy in Turkey.

Hope you are getting a little rest after one hell of a week. Notwithstanding some press whining, I thought BHO and HRC did a fabulous job in Copenhagen and that the schedule structure has a much better chance of success than sticking with Kyoto architecture. Congrats to all..

subject: HAK Papers
text:
Cheryl and Peggy,

We have not forgotten you! Thanks again for your back channel discussion of a possible solution. We (Kissinger and Yale) have been discussing how to approach this.

A preliminary concern is, if we raise private funds can we assure the accelerated declassification of all of the HAK documents in the Library of Congress, not just those that have been referred to State by the Archives?

I spoke to HAK yesterday and have some instructions. He also asked me, once again, to say how very much he appreciates the effort Hillary and you gave made. Please pass that on to the Secretary. He very much wants to get this settled during her time as Secretary.

We need to do a bit more homework and hope to get back to you very soon after Labor Day.

I hope you both were able to get some time off this summer.

Best regards,

Jeff

subject: Heads up on comm farming etc.
text: I would be careful with the commercial farming. Many African leaders support it because it's good for their cronies. Paul Collier has been one of the most vocal supporters of commercial farming - mostly because of the success of Brazil. Our USAID colleagues are much less supportive because historically it doesn't have as much benefit for the poor as working directly with rural farmers. I think the best way to frame this issue is to say: we support small holder farmers and that's what our programs will emphasize; but, if we see an opportunity for commercial farms to also help achieve our goal of lifting 100 million out of hunger and poverty, then we will support it. In general, commercial farms usually benefit those who are above the poverty line - not those below it. Best, Matt

I wanted to tell you a couple of things for Chicago, if useful.

Norway is going to be funding and staffing a new NATO Special Rep on Women, Peace and Security and the position will be in the NATO Secretariat, which is quite significant. Moreover, Sweden is making available to NATO the Nordic Centre for Gender in Military Operations. These are both tangible new steps in promoting WPS in military operations. You have no idea what you unleashed when the US launched the National Action Plan!

Also FM Store is interested in raising the following issues with you in Chicag: Burma, Libya and Afghanistan; broader trends on women and mediation/engagement in international dialogues and peace processes, the important link between global health and efforts to address conflict-related sexual violence and ensuring that sexual violence and women's participation remains part of international dialogue with Syria.

Finally, we are looking for ways to focus the US Burma human rights groups (from simply raising the issues of on-going violence in the areas, some of it targeted on women) to actually supporting women in the ethnic conflict areas by focusing on concrete ways to enable the ethnic women to play a useful role in efforts to end the conflicts and participate in future peace agreements.

subject: My departure
text:
Hi Huma: I'd be very grateful if you'd pass this to the Secretary. Best, Eric

Madam Secretary:

I will leave the Department on October 8 (and begin at the Humphrey School on October 10). The transition at PRM is on track: Anne's name has just gone to the White House, and our PDAS, Dave Robinson (whom Anne knows well) will be Acting until Anne is confirmed. I have a wrap-up note or two that will be coming your way — focused on progress we've made and key challenges that remain (including concrete recommendations along the lines we discussed). And I will give a final public address at USIP next week, on our efforts on international humanitarian response.

I'm trying to get on your schedule before I leave and very much hope that will happen.

Finally, the Bureau will have a farewell reception for me on the 30th in the Department. Should your schedule permit, I'd be honored if you could attend — though I know that demands on your schedule may make that impossible.

Kind regards, Eric

For your reading pleasure on the way home, S/P has been working on a project that I discussed with Jake a while back -aimed at figuring out where we could do better and above all create more leverage to achieve our goals. The papers are blunter than anything you would see from the bureaus -- they should not necessarily be read as policy blueprints but rather as illustrations of alternative strategies. We have made sure that the special assistants have them on the plane. I will also share the individual papers with the relevant assistant secretaries. We will then be happy to take the project further if you approve.

You will be happy to know that rain has stopped at the Expo! AM

Translating these principles into action, on December 6-8, the Government of Rwanda, together with the Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Program, hosted a technical review of its Agriculture Sector Investment Plan and convened a high-level stakeholders meeting. At the meeting, development partners and the African Union/NEPAD endorsed Rwanda's plan and agreed to mobilize support for scaled-up financing. The African Union/NEPAD and representatives from the World Bank, UN, donor countries, the private sector, civil society organizations, and NGOs attended the meeting. The United States was represented by a whole-of-government team led by Special Assistant to the President Gayle Smith that included representatives from the Departments of State, Treasury, and Agriculture, USAID, and MCC. Our team committed to improve the quality of our aid; to provide robust financial commitments and technical support; and to work to mobilize additional financing of the Investment Plan. In the new year, we will continue to engage all stakeholders, work with the international community, and build on our experience in Rwanda as we move forward with plans to implement our initiative. Please continue to visit our website: www.state.gov/s/globalfoodsecurity to stay informed of planning for the initiative and to provide input. We wish you a happy new year and look forward to continuing to work closely with you. The Global Hunger and Food Security Team

CODEL McConnell will be in Pakistan the end of next week. He will be traveling with: Senator Richard Burr (R-NC) Senator-elect Pat Toomey (R-PA) Senator-elect Marco Rubio (R-FL) Senator-elect Ron Johnson (R-WI) Senator-elect Kelly Ayotte (R-NH ) Mr. Thomas Hawkins, National Security Advisor, Office of the Republican Leader Mr. Roy E. Brownell, Legislative Assistant, Office of Senator McConnell

Due to the tense political situation over the past few weeks in Pakistan, the Embassy remains concerned about managing the press around the trip given Pakistan's volatile media. SRAP is working on a phone call from Dan Feldman to McConnell's senior foreign policy staffer and will raise the issue. We are also consulting with the embassy to see whether a pre-trip phone call from Munter to McConnell would help to give the traveling party a sense of what they're heading into before they hit the ground. As side note, Amb. Eikenberry will be traveling back to the U.S. and wanted to brief members before their trip but will not arrive until after the CODEL departs.

-Chris

Chris Hensman Special Assistant Office of the Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs (R) U.S. Department of State 2201 C St, NW Rm 5932

W: 202.647.91301 M

subject: CODEL Cantor - Aug 14 Do we know anymor on what he is seeking to see/learn? Joy - Should I/we offer him a pre-brief call? Cdm
text:
S/HSC has prepared briefing documents for this visit and Tom spoke with Cantor staffer Robert Story Karem before going on vacation. Depending on Joy's views, we can do a verbal briefing at Mr. Cantor's convenience although he is probably back in his District, but we can certainly do this over the phone.

Our understanding thus far is that he and his family are on a cruise that stops in Labadie and he is using the opportunity to do an official event which will be supported by the Embassy. DCM Desjardins and Carl Anderson of USAID (control officer) will be meeting with Cantor and doing the briefing and escorting. Staff accepted the rational that since Ambassador White has just arrived, it was preferable to have the DCM handle this visit.

John Boris has been collecting the briefer working with the Embassy and our office to give him a comprehensive view of activities in the North but the focus will be on visiting operations at the Caracol Industrial Park.

Joel

subject: Latest Iteration
text:
Cheryl, Jake, I owe you both an apology. I had a very productive flight (8-10 hours in a darkened quiet cabin is just what I needed) and finished Les Gelb's book -- it is astonishing how close our analyses are -- he says that foundation of US power is to catalyze others to get problems solved. HRC wanted me to make the speech harder and I see some very good ways to do that -- talking about assembling power coalitions to deal w/ troublesome states, a term Les uses.

But I also had a chance to reread the frame that you put together, much more carefully. There are a number of very good things in it that I am going to try to work into a revision, or at least flag for how we can build off of this speech in subsequent speeches. I am sorry that I didn't see that in the press of trying to get to this point.

I will have a revision by Sunday afternoon China time, which would allow her and you to see it Sunday morning.

AM

subject: Corker
text:
He allegedly has 2 remaining concerns:

1 - getting an updated 1251 report (10 year plan) (she can tell him we will do some kind of update...may just be a letter but we will agree to udpate);

2 - and he still has concerns about verification. For the last 30 days, we have tried to connect him with rose g and ted warner from DoD. Looks like that will finally happen next week. They can and will alleviate his concerns (we hope).

That's what I know. I am sure he will be pleased to hear that we had a constructive meeting with Senator Kyl and are moving to meet many of his funding concerns.

Looks like it's happening. No contact with activists inside for last 18 hours. Before that shells falling every 20 seconds or so. And reports of ground forces moving in. I don't think there is much to be done now apart from deploying all assets to expose what is to come (unless Annan can convince the Russians to secure a pause to get wounded out at least, though I'd be surprised if that happened.) Once they finish off Horns, they will likely move to Idlib, maybe Rastan. So this could repeat itself, with all the same dilemmas for us.

You all are probably hearing the same, but please pass on if not (I'm on my mobile).

Tom

Sent from my Windows Mobile® phone.

subject: RE: from GOH - Montreal meeting talking points
text:
You and our secretary share similar concerns about making sure Haiti's future is decided by Haiti.

When we met with PM and P, they both indicated they wanted US to play a large coordination role on their behalf to ensure their voice, plans and goals were accomplished. We are committed to doing that as they requested.

I do think fast will mean some will make money they shouldn't — but goal is to have balance so we move with enough alacrity to build confidence that things are getting done.

Who are the Haiti "operator" types of which this concern is being spoken?

subject: To Cheryl Mills: Rep. McGovern Letter to President Obama, DHS Secretary Napolitano and Secretary of State Clinton
text: Dear Cheryl — It's our understanding that the review of the terrorist list undertaken at the beginning of the year is reaching completion, imminently. Jim asked me to shoot you a note that this continues to be a very important issue for him and Bill Delahunt. The list needs to be purged of political manipulation — and quite frankly, the current status quo with Cuba needs to be broken, not further reinforced — for the sake of Alan Gross, those on the island needing space to voice their views, and indeed, all of us outside who know change is coming. It's time to do something bold and constructive — and in our very best interests — Let us know if there's anything we can do to help — Cindy

subject: Palestinian aid overview
text:
Colleagues —

Wanted to provide a quick update on Palestinian assistance. D(N) today decided against moving forward with the cash transfer using FY12 funds. This will mean that the $200 million on the Hill will no longer be available as a cash transfer. The money will not expire until September 2013, and will be held in reserve for the moment. The F team is working up options for a possible FY13 cash transfer that could potentially offset the FY12 funds that will not go to the Palestinians, but nothing has been finalized yet.

NEA/USAID — any chance your teams could work with H and F to pull together points for the Hill and press on this? Believe the mechanics may require us to pull the CN, which may invite questions. Recommend a focus on the procedural nature of the move, noting our continued desire to support the Palestinian people.

Best, -Jim

Jim Holtsnider Special Assistant Office of Deputy Secretary Thomas Nides U.S. Department of State 202-647-5094

subject: Heads Up Sunday
text:
FYI, there will be a major piece in Sunday's New York Times Magazine on the Iranian election written by Roger Cohen. Roger spent several weeks in Tehran in the run-up and immediate aftermath of the vote. It will touch the implications of what happened on the prospects for engagement. A small part of the story will focus on Dennis Ross, who spent time with Roger both before he traveled and after he returned. Dennis laid out for Roger the basic premises behind our offer to engage and the questions that remain even today. Bill Burns and Ray Takeyh spent some time with him as well. We expect it to be a straightforward piece and did a lot of work to help shape it. Obviously its publication will ensure Iran questions when the Secretary appears on Meet the Press.

Pi

HRC,

-- The objective is to try shift the fulcrum of our current relations with Bibi from settlements -- where he thinks he has the upper hand -- to ground where there is greater understanding in Israel of the American position and where we can make him uneasy about incurring our displeasure..

-- .Ironically, his intransigence over 67 borders may offer us that possibility -- to turn his position against him.

-- What the President would say in NY (whether or not there is a trilateral):

- Despite Senator Mitchell's efforts, the conditions don't exist at this point to maximize the chances of successful negotiations.

- Sending Mitchell back to to try to get the parties to agree on a common basis to relaunch negotiations. This includes:

o a safe, secure and recognized Israel living side by side in peace with a safe, secure and sovereign Palestine o and an end to the occupation that began in 1967.

-- This 67 formulation was used in the Road Map, by Bush, Sharon and Olmert.

subject: UN speech
text:
ireland

Ma'am — Jake tells me that you are tired of the Lamplighter story. I'm sorry, I didn't know. But the Belfast people have come up with a FANTASTIC story -- apparently, as per your request, they have tracked down the two kids who won the peace essay contest in the 90s, and they are doing great things -- one is a teacher, one is a police officer. They are now reaching out to get permission for you to tell their stories tomorrow night; assuming they will grant it, I am writing up their stories now and will fax a revised draft to you shortly.

Sorry for the Lamplighter redux; I'll let Lissa know it's off-limits for at least a few years.

subject: Left you a vox on your cell
text:
Cheryl,

Thank you very much. That is great news. Indications from the Ecumenical Patriarch also suggest that this subject may possibly be ready to improve but your reading gives us more hope. It is amazing what the Secretary has done for the head of the second largest Christian Church in the world. From getting the first sitting President in history to visit the Ecumenical Patriarch to these incredible developments now, it is incredible. Thank you very much.

PS Sorry that for some reason my cell phone has not rung when you have called.

Andy

we can safely presume we (USN) will not be able to provide much if anything by way of un-crewed equipment, or anything at all any time soon.

But as we are checking avail of USN resources, we will gently try to lead GoT to accept reality that this proposition is far

harder than a needle-in-a-haystack search, and that lining up the EN Nautilus now for early Sept would make for the best they can do by way of placating public sensitivities. I suspect they will reach that conclusion in due course anyway. So we might start looking at a modest contribution of funding (perhaps from Nautilus co-sponsor, USN?) for fuel costs.

Francis J. Ricciardone US Ambassador Ankara, Turkey

subject: Article you asked for - hope this is it?
text:
Carleene — the Secretary saw this article and is asking if there are really six ambulances tuck in customs and the port. I suspect the answer is yes. I want to get back to her with any information on this situation, which I suspect is pretty static. I do know you are funding two customs officers to come down and work, along with the Canadians, to try and improve Haitian Customs. Are there any other glimmers of hope we can point to on this?

Think it's great that the Nazon rubble Removal came in under cost. I understand a Haitian firm won the bid. As you know there is constant criticism that we don't contract with Haitian firms so if we can show that this is changing somewhat as we move from pre-competed OFDA contracts to the ones you are doing, that would be great.

I have gigged Cheryl on the AAD's and on Staffing and she always promises to review by morning and then glares at me when I ask her about it the next day.

Sorry I did not see you on Sunday's whirlwind visit. Will be back for the IHRC Meeting on the 15th (when you will be entertaining Don Steinberg) and hope to stay on a few days to do some country travel and meet with you and others.

All the best,

Tom

subject: PA HAITI EARTHQUAKE RESPONSE 1-19
text:
The Embassy Consul General and I gave a 45 minute press conference in French to Haitian media yesterday. There were 12 reporters there. Two FM radio stations carried the whole conference live. We got questions on evacuation, rumours, TPS, use of American military and reconstruction efforts.

Ambassador Merten will have a press conference for Haitian media today. he may be joined by the Minister of Health.

Haitian media is a rather grand term at the moment. Radio is working and some internet sites. We are working them hard. There is no TV and there are no newspapers.

Gordon Duguid Joint Information Center U.S. Embassy Port au Prince

subject: CTV Update: 3/21 Here are the main updates for today:
text: The CTV opened at 6am, but started processing PVs in the early afternoon. Initial tests were run in the morning to adjust the threshold number of votes used for referring a PV to the legal unit. This adjustment was necessary because the initial threshold, based on first round turn-out, was too strict and quarantined 80% of the PVs. The new number was determined based on how many of the initially quarantined PVs were deemed valid by the legal unit after review. (Note: Observers have not been informed of the thresholds used.) - Each department will have a threshold number that can be adjusted over time as more data becomes available on voter turn-out. This is in contrast to the first round when the threshold number was fixed and used for all departments. The database will automatically refer any PV to the legal control unit based on this threshold number. - We were pleased with the diligence of the lawyers and the smoothness of the process thus far. In addition, OAS observers and CTV staff indicated to us that the CTV was much more organized this round. Their impressions were that key deficiencies in the process had been addressed. - Progress reports will be posted daily on the CEP website and daily briefings will be held with CTV leadership. Best, SK

CDM:

When can we talk today? I would prefer that it be after 5:00 p.m.

Subject of discussion: ailed me this morning to spell out for me in detail the direction in which he is now willing to go on the

elections, his rationale and his timetable for a process that would conclude with a legitimately-elected President and Parliament before mid-May. It does begin with the cancellation of the Presidential elections of November 28.

He expressly asked that I contact you directly this afternoon to discuss it. He himself will be unavailable most of the afternoon and told me that anytime before early evening for a report of our discussions would be fine.

Regards.

GV.

Team:

Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her delegation of three Burmese NLD members arrived today in Washington, DC on schedule and in excellent spirits. ANA gave her a complimentary upgrade from Tokyo to Washington, so she flew in comfort and security (which helped avoid the curiosity seekers who pursued photos and conversation during her Bangkok-Tokyo leg). Thanks to excellent DS and protocol work at Dulles, the arrival, per ASSK's druthers, was quiet, efficient, and devoid of paparazzi and the legions of supporters who had hoped for a more raucous entry.

ASSK and her team settled into a superb hotel suite, began receiving off-schedule guests (supporters and friends), and launched into preparations for a very busy Tuesday tomorrow: meeting with the Secretary, DOS Rule of Law roundtable, HIV/AID discussion with USG agencies, Asia Society/USIP award event (with the Secretary's participation), visits to RFA and VOA, a bilateral with World Bank President Kim, and a private dinner with the Secretary.

We'll do our best to provide you with occasional updates on her visit: 17 days, ten cities, 60 events. As the pace quickens, this may be irregular — but we'll certainly apprise you of any major developments or issues.

Thank you for the excellent intra-bureau cooperation and support in helping put together an usual and complex visit.

Regards - Patrick

W. Patrick Murphy Special Representative and Policy Coordinator for Burma, Acting US. Department of State (202)647-4700

Cheryl, Jake:

Despite the nailbiting finale, the Human Rights Council reentry has been remarkably successful. The tally, with returns still coming in:

1. Goldstone-report deferred through extraordinary political work by all of you 2. Freedom of Expression--tonsensus--a landmark achievement in suggesting that there is indeed a universal understanding of freedom of expression that can cut across cultural lines 3. Honduras: consensus 4. Womens' Equality-consensus 5. Human Security issues: US took forward leaning posture USG engaged across the board and got the results it wanted--5 for 5--plus appeared principled and balanced To be honest if we had gotten any 2 of these, I would have felt relieved. Instead we ran the table. There was a stunning performance by 10-DRL-L-AmEmbassy Geneva and various regional bureaus, particularly NEA and WHA and AF, as well as EUR. The State Department at its finest and multilateral diplomacy executed at a macro and micro level. Brimmer, Nossel, Posner all were outstanding as were our folks in Geneva.

And this is in our first reengagement. It should get better as we gain more experience.

Harold Hongju Koh The Legal Adviser U.S. Department of State 2201 C St. NW Washington, DC 20520 202 647 9598 o

subject: Core email list
text:
Correcting subject line. Update on efforts to secure meeting with MFA to discuss passport/access issues:

MFA has agreed to meet with DCM Bob Wang and me tomorrow at 09:30. MFA rep will be DDG Lu Kang, who served as VFM Cui Tiankai's deputy throughout the Chen negotiations.

Lu Kang provided a "preview" of China's official message tomorrow: the more we (and Chen) be quiet, the greater our chances this all works out in a way all sides are pleased with. PRC authorities cannot be seen as moving under US pressure, I was told.

I'll prOvide a few more details from Lu on the high side, and we'll then do a full write-up tomorrow.

Regards, Dan

subject: Thursday 7/28, Al Solnit, Moscow, book
text:
Hi Hillary,

Enjoyed your valuable Hong Kong comments.

Here are notes on new things and followups.

1. Thursday, 7/28, there will be visitors to your place

It is Project Common Bond, run by Tuesday's Children (as in Tues 9/11), a program for young people from around the world whose lives have been specifically impacted by terrorism. The group includes several from 9/11 and a number from 10 other countries. They're working in groups with various therapists, conflict resolution trainers and others to make their ways, make connectionsand understandings, forge bonds and bring good things home. They were told they are meeting with a senior official in yr bldg and are obviouysly hoping it's you.

2. Yale Child Study Center (where I am a lecturer) is honoring Al Solnit with a program and room dedication in late •

October as part of their centennial celebrations. They are very eager to have a dvd visit from you. I have spoken with Lauren about this and am sending her the requested details. Will stay in touch with her and whomever she directs me to. 3. Gabriella went to Moscow for second part of State Dept theater conservatory LA-Moscow exchange. They created and performed a piece called Old Boyfriends to several packed houses. Several parts, including Gaby's, were wordless; her's was a last dance of a divorcing couple. Here is link (5 minutes) so you can see your department dollars at work. here it is 4. Working away on Morrison book. Can show you first chapter and full chapter outline. Best to email or send to Lauren for printing? 5. You do great honor to yourself and your country, dear friend. Penn

We woke Jeff up at 3 am and he helped us to adapt the formulation Sung Kim joined us this evening and was extremely helpful in wordsmithing the North Korea section. Please take a look at the attached ad ref final text. I am scheduled to meet with VFM Cui on the White House lawns at 0830. We have set up a process to make final edits if necessary. Our teams are working on ensuring that a properly formatted document is ready to launch pending final formal approval. We are also coordinating with the Chinese on translation issues, as well. We are all pretty tired. 

Kurt 

Dr. Kurt M. Campbell Assistant Secretary of State East Asian & Pacific Affairs

subject: Isakson
text:
Senator Isakson was incredibly helpful to the Department and USAID yesterday, not only pressing for Wendy Sherman's nomination to move out of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee but also in getting Mara Rudman confirmed by the larger Senate.

Any chance we could ask S to write Senator Isakson a quick note thanking him for all his efforts and support? He has been incredibly helpful on a host of things, and we increasingly need him on a number of our priorities. And the relationship is genuinely a good one, as evidenced by the exchange they had last week when they bumped into each other in the Capitol.

Thanks for considering.

subject: Please Pass On
text:
Kate:

Could you please pass this note on to Kurt, Joe, and Patrick (I know Joe is away , and I talked with Patrick earlier this morning).

Kurt:

I want to congratulate you and your colleagues on what I regard as a brilliant (and I do not use that term loosely) move that Secretary Clinton will go to Myanmar. I was concerned that the U.S. response to the changes in Myanmar, and what I regard as almost a plea from the Burmese for support to the reforms, might not get more than simply a verbal response. But this indicates the seriousness of the U.S. intent, and I hope will prompt the further positive actions from the Burmese that we all want. This State Department action avoids any congressional issues and yet is a strong signal and so is tactically and strategically important.

Thank all of you for your efforts, because I believe they further U.S. national interests and could assist the Burmese people as well.

By the way, we have approval from the MacArthur Foundation for our Track 1.5 initiative, and will be working with Joe and Derek on that.

Best wishes,

David Steinberg

subject: THANK YOU.
text:
Dear Cheryl,

It has been a while since I've contacted you directly. Happy New Year to you and your family. I've been pleased to communicate directly with Ambassador Thomas Adams. His approach and willingness to work with unusual suspects in the Haitian diaspora is refreshing.

Please extend my deep appreciation to Secretary Clinton for filling the vacuum in leadership that exists in resolving the haiti election debacle. Her leadership is moving Haiti from the self imposed paralysis imposed by the first round of elections.

Her clear public message endorsing the findings of the OAS Report gave Haitians/ Haitian Americans here and abroad confidence that a rational resolution was at hand.

The Secretary's personal visit to Haiti, this week in the midst of the crises now unfolding across the globe told many of us that Haiti remains important to her and this Administration.

The Secretary's leadership and personal attention to Haiti sent a message a dozen policy statements could not have conveyed. Building a new Haiti requires all our intellect and labor.

Along the way we will have many points of disagreement. However, decisive, positive leadership and direction in Haiti is welcome. Thank you and your team for making it happen.

Warm Regards,

Marie St. Fleur Chief, Advocacy &Strategic Investment, City of Boston

The substance of this message, including any attachments, may be confidential, legally privileged and/or exempt from disclosure pursuant to Massachusetts law. It is intended solely for the addressee. If you received this in error, please contact the sender and delete the material from any computer.

subject: Full Foreign Affairs OK of Palau Bill
text:
Heard from Chm. Ros-Lehtinen this aft. that she was discharging the Palau Continued Free Association bill with the substitute offset we suggested that I understand State supports (regarding denial of passports to individuals with seriously delinquent tax debts exceeding $50,000) from the full Foreign Affairs Committee. As you probably know, it passed the Subcommittee yesterday. It came at the right time, Palau was running out of patience after 22+ months! Hope we can work together for the expeditious Natural Resources Committee approval Chairman Hastings pledged when I took Pres. Toribiong in, making substantial progress before the August recess (and your stop in Palau).

Jeff Farrow

subject: KAL still meeting in Erbil
text:
Here's how things look out here.

We have heard some rumors that this may have been successful. i.e., that the Sunni majority of Iraqiyya has been bought by some other package and will dump allawi (and the Presidency). On the other hand from Ali Debaggah with Maliki earlier today it sounded like the Turks were encountering hard sledding getting their plan B sold to Maliki.

I will see Allawi and (separately) Issawi and Saleh Mutlaq (!) here tonight, along with Adel Mahdi, and then I will have a better sense of what is going on. Then will see Maliki (in'shallah) and for sure Barzani tomorrow. We will know better at least what is in play and where the fault lines are.

subject: Thank you
text:
The COM conference was just fabulous and the Secretary so darn impressive - by FAR the standout star of the week.

I found the reports and follow up conversations from the breakout sessions extremely useful. And who could not love the presentation on "purpose"? If someone videoed him at the conference, I would love a copy to share with my staff. And the White House - fires blazing, band playing, champagne flowing AND AND AND the President himself taking individual pictures. You would have to be a lot older and a lot more jaded than me not to have been impressed! And I was. But I thought the shining hour came with the SS answering questions from the audience - so professional and competent. I am so proud to work for her.

So THANK YOU - for everything.

USG Ambassador Pamela White The Gambia IVG: 591-2010

subject: URGENT Kabul Bank/OIG Audit Info
text:
Cheryl,

The OIG report is a little sensational, but overall accurate. Technical advisers had indications of serious problems, and did not take adequate steps. Blame will accrue first to bearing point / deloitte, then to USAID mgmt in the field. The OIG recommendations are fairly reasonable, but it would be a stretch to say that these advisers could have somehow stopped the KB fraud (the report does not say this, but the press likely will). Bottom line, this mainly hits AID.

Does this sound right to you? We'll try to make sure AID's points account for all of this. But this will not look good. V-

Statement

Bombings in Moscow

Our thoughts and prayers are with the victims of this morning's bombings in Moscow, their families, and all the people of Russia. This brutal assault on innocent civilians is another reminder that terrorism is a threat to peace-loving people everywhere and must be met with unwavering resolve. I will offer my personal condolences to Foreign Minister Lavrov later today in Ottawa. Together with our G8 partners, we will discuss how to improve international counterterrorism coordination and cooperation. I was in Moscow earlier this month, and I know the resilience and determination of the Russian people. The United States stands with them today and everyday in solidarity against violent extremism in all its forms.

subject: Fw: Sujay
text:
Senator DeMint is insisting that he and Sujay sit down to personally review her post-hearing QFR answers. This is highly unusual. We offered Sujay up right away, but DeMint's staff insisted that the Senator was only available to meet on December 16 (the Senate target adjournment date is December 17). This effectively scuttles any chance Sujay has of getting confirmed this Congress.

Unfortunately, we don't have much recourse. Sujay's nomination will remain on Tuesday's business meeting agenda, but given his request, DeMint will exercise his prerogative and ask that she be held over. With no other business meetings scheduled this year, she'll remain stuck in Committee.

There's another factor at play here too. We learned yesterday afternoon that Sujay has taken it upon herself to reach out to different Senator's offices. I don't know what exactly she's been saying, but the leg officer (a State Department fellow) handling Sujay's nomination got an email from Hatch's office. He has been supportive of her and we have a good working relationship with them. I don't know what Sujay said, but the message back from Hatch's person is that "while we do support her, this really makes us question her common sense and judgment." We obviously told her to stop her outreach campaign.

Finally, Hatch's office also informed us that Brownback is rumored to be considering a hold on Sujay's nomination if DeMint for any reason relents.

MB MP Khaled Deeb informed me today that MB will push to review Camp David and put it to a referendum. The argument is that this would still be "respecting" Camp David, because it is Israel that supposedly violates Camp David, and the MB/Egypt will no longer tolerate it. (People who say this never cite specific examples of Israel breaking the treaty, naturally.) Making matters worse, the MB MP said he believed the reports of attacks on Israel from Sinai were invented. So walk through the chain of foreseeable events: Israel will be attacked from Sinai (this is an inevitability); it may respond; MB will claim that Israel fired first, and therefore broke the treaty, "like it always does," etc. And then the treaty, the MB will argue, is broken.

And making matter even worse: the Egyptian MFA official that I hung out with last night made the exact same argument, and similarly believed that the reports of attacks on Israel from Sinai were invented. (This particular official will be Egypt's next mission chief in Tehran, and is an ambassador.) So the MB's views on Camp David have at least some support within Egypt's diplomatic corps.

subject: from rome... Sid
text: Hillary: In Rome, on way to Florence to NYU Center on Law and Security Conference. Here's the point: While here, I had dinner tonight with Shaun Woodward (meeting with Pope on N. Ireland). He told me he's meeting with Jim Steinberg on Friday. He told me things you would in my judgment want and need to hear because they will likely involve your personal role. I think you should step in and ask him to tell you directly. I also should relate to you when I return information about Brown government re foreign ministry: Meetings here with former PM Amato, former amb. Saleo, key journalists for Correire, Repubblica, Europa, RAI, etc, new re Berlusconi, as usual the real story is not what's public. Sid

subject: Merry Christmas
text:
Thank you. I will spend next week reviewing the recent IG report of my bureau. Gave us good marks on the technical side of what we do, but there is definitely work to be done on our organizational structure, some leadership issues in specific offices and how we interact and communicate across our various functions. On the planning side, thanks to the 2010 look ahead memos that the bureaus prepared for you, we will be more effective in creating media and outreach opportunities because our focus will be not just on this week, but looking ahead to the month and quarter as well. We have been briefing-centric in the past. We will be creating more channels to communicate our messages. I know Judith spoke with you on Monday about greater emphasis on international media. We will be restructuring part of my operation to be able to do that. Going through these issues, I'll either be well-rested or exhausted, but I am looking forward to 2010.

PJ

subject: Jackson Diehl Editorial
text:
Madame Secretary, as we understood on Wednesday, our conscious decision not to mention domestic Egyptian issues publicly was noticed at the Post editorial board. I had multiple exchanges with Jackson over the course of the day yesterday. Based on your colloquy with Aboul-Gheit and Jeff s follow-up, we are quoted in the piece which you see in the clips as having a direct and spirited exchange with the Egyptians and that there was no misunderstanding of the importance that we attach to these issues. So in the end Jackson grants some credit for the discussion, and we agree to disagree on the degree to which this discussion should be public.

PJ

ALL: I spoke to Vice President Bogran and later met with FM Canahuati who participated in the negotiations with Holguin.

Canahuati was confident that a deal was at hand. He also confirmed that Maduro had played a critically positive role.

He said ultimately Maduro intervened and accepted most of the Honduras draft response, which had been sent at about 2 AM. Maduro had responded to this draft with a draft of his own that had accepted nearly the entire GOH text with a few edits. Canahuati claimed that Argentina had indicated that it would follow Venezuela's lead. He said the information they were getting from Colombia was that Brazil was also turning around and that Bolivia and possibly Ecuador were being brought around to support Honduras.

Hugo Llorens Ambassador US. Embassy TegurOwdila, Honduras 504 236-9320 ext.

subject: Latest at Camp Liberty
text:
Good news: Quiet so far at Liberty today. No overnight reports of trouble.

Bad (but expected) news: the MEK is putting out the line that the transfer was inhumane and no more will occur.

Based on embassy reports and the UN draft report to UN HQ, my initial take is that (a) problems existed about personal baggage (the GOI principle that Ashrafis could take anything that any Iraqi could legally possess does not seem to have been followed in full, though much, much baggage was indeed taken to Hurriya); (b) the Iraqis seemed under orders to behave and compromise ( there are reports of one nasty Iraqi officer, but this seems to have been individual, not GOIinstructed); (c) the Iraqi search seems to have been too exacting and; (d) the Ashrafis/Hurriyaites made things more difficult through delaying tactics and deliberate confrontation, and are now playing their customary aggrieved victim role.

Adam Ereli alerted me a few minutes ago about a new SWT problem. The staff of one of Alaska's Senators called ECA this afternoon to say there is a group of Costa Rican kids working in a fish packing plant in Alaska under very poor conditions. Apparently some of the kids may have developed frostbite in their feet because the plant is so cold; presumably they did not have the right wardrobe to keep warm. The sponsor organization for these students was CETUSA, which had also sponsored the kids working at the chocolate packing plant in Palmyra. (FYI: CETUSA just this week agreed to withdraw its request for re-designation as a sponsor, when confronted with a 37-page brief from State about its many violations.)

ECA is gathering more details and promised to share them with us when they know more.

She has submitted her application to OFAC and OFAC is going to refer it to us. As soon as we get it, we'll work with EEB to send a positive response back to OFAC on foreign policy grounds. OFAC did signal a problem with her application, we said we'd be pushing hard, so would be helpful if they could be flexible. They got it, but we'll likely still have to nudge. They are directly in touch with Diana Nyad and working through the technical issues. She still doesn't have a boat selected to go down to Cuba and assist, which is going to make it tricky to get a Commerce license and USCG approval for a vessel (both authorizations go to the vessel and crew, not to Diana). It will be tight, but still think we can get it done by her late August/early September date.

subject: Updated Information Regarding US Direct Hire Christopher Norman Bates' Death in Johannesburg
text:
Colleagues,

For your situational awareness, per a telephone conference call between AF and Embassy Pretoria, Embassy Pretoria reports the incident was a criminal act and there were no political/terrorist elements associated with the incident.

Post will send a text message about the incident to Embassy employees.

Post has let direct staff know, and Embassy Pretoria reports the incident has hit local newswires. The suspect will appear in court on January 14. Post has requested in writing that the S. African police do not conduct an autopsy yet. Ops also understands DS intends to send a special investigative team to Johannesburg to assist with the investigation.

Please let us know if you need any further information,

Best regards,

Greg Aunt

Senior Watch Officer Operations Center (202) 647-1512

Cheryl, I can't imagine what this week has been like for you but wanted to write after attending the Andrews ceremony today. I was with some NEA hands who knew Chris well and they all noted the Secretary's visit to their offices earlier in the week and how pitch-perfect this has been handled. The remarks today were beautiful and moving. I did not have a personal connection to the four lost this week but the President and Secretary seemed to be speaking as well to those I did know and still mourn. So I wanted to write to say thank you This is among the most challenging and uncertain periods in our history -- and our nation is more fortunate than it knows to have such a steady team at the helm. Brett

Sent via BlackBerry by AT&T

PLEASE NOTE — I am aware of the intense interest back in DC about this case and will be passing information just as soon as I receive it. This means that in most cases, I will not be able to confirm the information. Will try to identify credible sources vice what rumor/press/others are saying.

Brazilian Central Authority (BCA) coordinating with David's attorney and the Federal attorneys in Rio to ensure that the President of the Regional Federal Court in Rio has a copy of the STF order and is submitting the official request to federal police to enforce. BCA says they still believe they can effect the turnover tonight and are at their office working to that end. If/when the Federal Police enforce, their stated preference is to go to the airport and effect the handover there. This is a scenario we've planned for.

BCA has mentioned the STJ motions filed by the Brazilian family as a potential obstacle, but thru their contacts in Mendes' office at STF, have heard that Mendes intends to reach out to the reporting judge at STJ to resolve that issue. As mentioned in an earlier update today, we have not had any confirmation that the STJ judge has accepted to hear the motions filed by the Brazilian family, and has the option to decline to hear them.

subject: Your speech at CAP
text:
Dear Hillary,

I want to thank you for coming to CAP. It was a fantastic event, everyone was blown away by your remarks and by you. And I know how much you are juggling, so we were really honored by your time with us.

And more broadly, I want to thank you for the gift of your example to me. As I now take over the reigns of CAP, almost every day I feel like I think consciously or subconsciously about your leadership example. Whether I'm speaking to an audience or negotiating a deal, I think of how you do these things so remarkably well. I am truly lucky to have been able to learn directly from you.

But I am very grateful to you. I know my debt to you will always be significant. Thank you. Neera

--- The post-election situation in Iran has reduced popular fear of the regime. At the same time, the Iranian people are not suicidal and seek ways of confronting the regime that do not put their lives at risk. Accordingly, a general strike or a strike among oil field workers that would, as in the period before the deposition of the shah, demonstrate the weakness of the regime domestically while also starving it of resources. As in the period of Solidarity in Poland, American or, even better, European non-governmental groups could work with Iranian popular leaders to provide training and money to help them organize such strikes. A call to Bernard Kouchner or another European with a similar background (grass-roots political activism tied to transnational organizations) might be productive in this regard.

subject: Shale gas
text:
Jake —

FYI ---- There is an increasing amount of environmental concern regarding shale gas. EPA has been concerned and I have now heard of a documentary that is quite critical. The science is not all worked out but the principal concern is in relation to the actual chemicals used to extract the gas and the potential hazard they pose to the water supply. I have mentioned this to David Goldwyn and EPA is invited to his meeting in August.

Shale gas exploitation is already taking place in the United States, but there is very little domestic oversight of the practice, and until recently, there were no data whatsoever on the chemicals used in the hydraulic fracturing fluids. Congress raised concerns over this in 2009 and appropriated funds for EPA to conduct a scientific study on possible chemical contamination of groundwater that might result from this process. The study is anticipated to be finalized in 2012. The Department of Interior has done a programmatic Environmental Impact Assessment on how exploration can impact public lands, and is allowing fracturing in some locations while deferring activity in others.

Best, Kerri-Ann

subject: Speech/Middle East
text:
HRC: Back this morning from Asia. Congratulations on the speech. I think it came out great. And the reaction I have heard today has been very positive. Let raise an idea about how you could present the arrangement on settlements that you are seeking with Israel as I understand it, i.e. a moratorium coupled with allowances to complete a number of housing units. There are two ways:

1. To describe it as an agreement, explaining why the US has accepted an Israeli completion of a handful of units whose construction already has begun. This raises some concerns. It would represent U.S. legitimization of some (however small) Israeli activity in the West Bank and it would trigger Arab and Palestinian complaints that we had compromised, sowing doubts about our effectiveness.

2. The alternative would be for the administration to say: a. We have come a very long way, as Israel has made unprecedented commitments to the U.S. in terms of a settlements freeze. This is a very welcome development.

b. We did not achieve all that we had hoped as Israel intends to complete a number of housing units. We have differences with the Israeli government on this matter which we have expressed to them..

c. That said, we are convinced that substantial progress has been made that warrants an immediate resumption of peace talks as well as Arab steps toward Israel that will help promote a two-state solution.

This latter option retains our credibility, does not compromise our oft-stated position and allows us to move forward. Of course, I am around if you want to discuss. Good luck in India. They are very excited about your visit. Sandy

subject: Luis Alberto Moreno
text:
Dear Cheryl,

Good morning as another full week begins for both of us, but particularly for you and the distinguished Secretary. Hillary's interview on Meet the Press was flawless as was the cover story in Newsweek. Her great pictures are matching her thoughtful words.

Cheryl it is my understanding that President of the IDB. Assuming this information is accurate (and I believe it is) I think this puts the US in a difficult and awkward position not to be agreeable to Luis' continued leadership at the IDB. We are simply unnecessarily complicating a relationship and situation in the hemisphere in my humble opinion.

I wanted to be certain you were aware of this development and would appreciate any thoughts or guidance you have as to how we might bring this matter to a timely and positive conclusion.

Personally, Mack

Dear Madame Secretary:

A major crisis has erupted in Abyei in the past 24 hours. A SPLA (south Sudan army) force attacked an UNMIS convoy carrying north Sudan (SAF) soldiers, wounding several SAF soldiers and an UNMIS member. This is the second unwarranted SPLA attack on SAF members in May, the last attack having killed eleven SAF. The SAF has responded to this latest attack by moving more troops into Abyei and reportedly bombing two villages. We are facing a threat of major war breaking out in Abyei, threatening the entire CPA negotiations.

If it is at all possible, we would like you to make some of these calls today. We are working with you staff to see if your schedule permits and to provide you with the necessary background and talking points. I will keep you informed of developments throughout the day.

Thank you.

What I am hearing:

--The S call to AZ went down quite well on their side, better than any of the others. It made them think there is "something to work with".

--Civ -mil relations remain very sensitive. Her bosses do not want US civilians meeting with senior military officials unless the MFA (Salman) is present. (This should be okay with us as wea re the ones who are trying to keep all elements of gov't together on both sides...)

--the Pak-Mil report on 26 November is due to corn out on Friday. It will be "different" from ours. The lack of a US apology for the 24 dead still rankles very deeply. An apology could help soften the tendencies of the Parliament t be strident in the recommendations to the government on bilateral relations.

--CT cooperation "redlines" are in danger of colliding. It is worth trying to find operational fixes, but the whole "redlines" narrative is not helfpul.

--the Pakistan side is looking for progress/gestures in other areas to help deflect hardline positions on the sensitive areas like CT cooperation. Something positive on the Enterprise Fund (like moving forward with a model that does not require legislation), or energy projects, would be useful. But it is important to avoid more empty promises like ROZs.

It occurs to me that we could be in danger of talking past each other, us demanding satisfaction on our CT redlines and them wanting an apology, enterprise fund,energy projects, etc. Best to be aware.

Thanks.

Hi Huma — I hope everything is going OK in NYC.

Attached is the latest version of Doha. As you can imagine, I'm getting edits from about 20 people, so this document will surely change in small ways between now and tomorrow morning. There are also placeholders where people are still getting me info, and I still working on the conclusion.

But beyond those minor additions and some changes around the margins, this is unlikely to change much (unless the Secretary wants it to, of course). I'm available all day and night for any edits from her or you. Please feel free to call.

Thanks Huma, Megan

Shaun regrets he cannot come here tomorrow. Here's the problem and the plan: Cameron is still quietly giving encouragement to the Ulster Unionists, which, led by Reg Empey, are trying to scuttle the agreement somehow. So the plan is for Shaunn to announce he will deliver a speech on Monday in the House of Commons presenting the agreement—except that at the last second Gordon will step in on the floor for Shaun, requiring Cameron to respond, theoretically forcing him to support the agreement. In his speech, Gordon will explicitly cite your role and support of the US—among other things further cornering Cameron (and Empey). Shaun would like to speak with you soon depending on how things are working out there, perhaps tomorrow (Sunday) or perhaps Monday (perhaps after Commons). Dinner will be on a rain-check.

subject: Fw: wow!!
text:
This prestigious addition to your otherwise thin resume, could really make THE difference when you're interviewing for jobs next year. But I still think Our Grammy is way cooler.

Learning more about the academy will be my research project for tomorrow (right after I get to the bottom of the hotel bathrobe mystery). But I'm thinking you could form a study group with fellow 2012 inductees Penny Pritzker and George Stephanopoulos.

Speaking of awards, here's what I was referring to from the NYT... "Mr. Gettleman nominated himself for the award, and he beat out other Times reporters nominated for their coverage of the Japanese tsunami. While 'some reporters might have felt his editors knew best' about the nomination, said Joseph Kahn, The Times's foreign editor, 'Jeffrey put himself forward for the Pulitzers = and for that, Jeffrey, bless your heart."

The Pulitzers release said he won for "his vivid reports, often at personal peril, on famine and conflict in East Africa, a neglected but increasingly strategic part of the world."

Lastly, Betsy explained their connection as... "My sister Terry's husband, Malcolm's brother Kenny's daughter Courtnay's husband. "

subject: Dream Act
text:
They got cloture on DADT. 63 to 33.

At the close of the 30 hours (or when they yield back) we are back on START. We were able to convince Reid this morning not to file cloture on the treaty, which would have played in to Kyl's hands. So we are likely to have one full more day of debate and some votes on amendments, then file cloture setting up a cloture vote early next week. Mccain and Graham are still in a grumpy place - Graham is worse than McCain and we may have lost him. But McCain is still very much in the game.

subject: Update
text:
Huma/Jake:

Just got further updates from a de facto rep and Amb Llorens. The de facto authorities have decided to turn this exercise into a sort of loya girga to get buy-in for M's departure. This evening the discussions included religious groups and business leaders. Tomorrow government officials and others. My de facto contact says results tonight were good although it was not easy for many to accept the logic behind M's exit. He said the US once again has been the catalyst for movement in Honduras. Thinking is now for a Monday announcement.

We'll stay on it and update you.

ck

The negotiators have concluded a text that has been approved by Micheletti and Zelaya. We are preparing the official minute that will soon be signed by the negotiators. Micheletti is announcing now on the television that the deal has been struck.

We will send more soon. The bottom line: I cannot think of another example of in Latin America where a country, having suffered a rupture of its democratic and constitutional order, has overcome that rupture through negotiation and without violence.

S can and should take pride that her launching of the SJA, her firm support of the OAS role, her constant outreach to the major players, and her willingness to send us here created the conditions necessary for this accomplishment.

subject: FA article
text: As you have probably figured out by now, it's not ready. We were prepared to send you something rough, but it's just not in a state where it makes sense for you to engage. I will call Jim Hoge tomorrow and get another week of need be; Lissa is going to take over the drafting tomorrow with the aim of getting you a draft by late afternoon that you can really take some time with; we will then take your comments Friday or Sat (if you need more time) and then not bother you again until we have a final. I'm sorry, but it is most important that this be good. AM

subject: Requests
text:
MS:

Caroline Adler is working on getting the copies of More Magazine. I will follow up with her.

As Huma already replied, the Women in World DVD is in train; Monica and I will work on securing a copy of the Cameron luncheon speeches.

As for the archiving project, I am making steady progress on the binders, and am up to April 2010. At this rate, I will be compiling the binders in real time come late June/early July. Lona has been working on updating the schedules on her own. I have offered to help her in the past to no avail, but understand, per Huma, that we are now telling Lona that we have to expand this to a group project. I am confident that we can add this step to my routine for each binder and still stay on track to get caught up to real time by this summer.

-Rob

Hi Jake,

I sent S a note last night bringing her up to date, in so far as possible, on the Fiscal Cliff and some issues surrounding it. Please make sure the line puts it in her material as it gives her a lot of necessary background info. I am sure it will come up everywhere.

We didn't have much time to put this together, but wanted to get her something to keep her current and explain the several dimensions of the subject.

We will regularly email you with updates on what is happening here and in the financial markets during your trip.

Dear Secretary Clinton:

During the course of the Fifteenth Anniversary joint Review of the Compact of Free Association between the United States and Palau, I had to convey disappointment at times with positions taken by some Department of State personnel. I am writing today, however, to compliment the letter that Acting Assistant Secretary Rodriguez sent Chairman Bingaman of the U.S. Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources April 5th regarding the Senate bill to implement the Agreement produced by the Review and also to compliment the efforts that Deputy Assistant Secretary Reed has made regarding the Agreement.

The letter and efforts have displayed deep understanding of the relationship between our freely associated states and the mutual benefits flowing from this special association as well as what is needed to approve the Agreement and continue the association.

Let me also take this opportunity to express great appreciation for the instrumental actions that you and members of your staff took to resolve Review issues, for work done by then Deputy Secretary Lew, and for the involvement of Assistant Secretary Campbell. This attention was absolutely critical to obtaining agreement. I took very seriously the advice given through Jeff Farrow last summer that the Review should be concluded so that an agreement could be approved last year and am grateful for the opportunity that we then had to finally negotiate the issues as well as for Secretary Reed being the negotiator.

Although the Agreement ultimately was sent to the U.S. Congress this year, I am confident that continued perceptive efforts, such as those by Secretaries Reed and Rodriguez, will result in a continuation of the free association between our nations.

Sincerely yours,

hnson Toribiong President Republic of Palau

SIGIR gets some things wrong in its report on the Police Development Program in Iraq. For example, the $6.2 million per trainer figure is inflated by the initial start-up costs. There are a lot of other "inaccuracies" and didn't incorporate many of INL's suggestions. But SIGIR was correct on a number of points. INL made things worse by refusing to meet with SIGIR initially -- at M's recommendation, based on questions about whether SIGIR had authority to investigate this sector. Turns out they did, so they weren't well-disposed toward INL. They viewed INL's cooperation in providing documents and information as insufficient. There are always two sides to that story.

I would say though that the PDP is an Achilles heel for us. There are many uncertainties surrounding it. There was no baseline assessment done (either by DOD or by State) prior to the program. There is no implementing agreement with the Iraqis. MOT's cooperation is not 100% (the ministry does not work with contractors on an assessment, preferring official employees). There is no comprehensive plan. (What we shared with SIGIR is a plan — called Core Work Requirements -- but not a comprehensive one. There had been an attempt to create a better plan, but it kept getting outdated by the situation on the ground.) To some extent, INL is building this airplane while flying it.

The program costs $860 million, making it State's largest undertaking there. Amb. Michele Sison, formerly of Embassy Beirut, is Assistant Ambassador for the PDP and rule of law programs.

subject: Secretary Clinton Testimony before the House Sent: Feb 28, 2012 3:45 PM
text:
Greg As an fyi, we have heard that two House offices may ask Secretary Clinton a question, either publicly or privately, related to Saudi Arabia's failure to pay its debt owed to Gibbs and Hill. Specifically, Chairwoman Ros-Lehtinen indicated her intention to raise the issue directly with the Secretary prior to the hearing. In this regard, please be aware that the Chairwoman previously raised this issue during an October 6, 2011 meeting with Deputy Secretary Nides, though no follow-up was taken according to the Chairwoman's staff. In addition, Congressman Chabot's staff has indicated that he may raise this issue during his question period. We will notify you should we learn additional details or confirm the Members' intentions.

Sent from my Verizon Wireless BlackBerry

subject: Urgent. Fw: Follow up for cheryl mills. Fyi
text:
Howard:

Thanks for this — I spent yesterday having folks in the region, our ambassador in Egypt, and our folks in Consular affairs at main state review and consult with each other. There appears to be misinformation circulating. While the GOE is sympathetic to all parties, the GOE has not indicated any willingness to interfere in the proceedings of the Egyptian courts that currently are considering Mr. Bower's challenge to the Egyptian custody decree. Including with regard to any of the matters flagged below.

We do not know when that judicial process will be completed, although the next hearing is scheduled for October. The Embassy is currently trying to ensure that Mr. Bower, who is en route to Egypt now, will be able to see his sons as called for in a current Egyptian court order.

I appreciate your sharing this for context — it is helpful.

Best.

cdm

Cheryl,

I am looking forward to attending the Chiefs of Mission Conference and I'm writing to request a short meeting with the Secretary.

Spain has recently elected a new government, and there are some pending issues that concern me, and I believe the Secretary, which I'd like to discuss with her. These include:

• A White House meeting between President Obama and President Rajoy • Palomares cleanup

• USTR 301 watch list • GOS interest in economic statecraft I know the Secretary has met the new Foreign Minister, Jose Manuel Garcia-Margallo, and I'd like the opportunity to share my own impressions of the new government. I've been invited to a working lunch later this week with Spain's Vice-President and Ministers of Defense, Interior and Foreign Affairs, to discuss the whole range of bilateral issues between us. My meeting with the Secretary, following that meeting, will be especially timely. I would also like to brief the Secretary on a major conference the Embassy will host in Madrid at the end of March on volunteerism and service. Assistant Secretary Stock and Special Representative Balderston have both agreed to attend along with a number of service leaders from the U.S. Because of the Secretary's passion for this subject and the emphasis she has give to it, I thought she'd be interested in learning of our plans. I know the Secretary's time is precious, and I can address all of these matters in a short meeting. Obviously, I'm available any time throughout the week of the conference if this meeting can be scheduled. Finally, I had a very productive audience with the King recently, and he asked me specifically to extend his warm regards to the Secretary. Please let her know. Many thanks, Cheryl. Alan

Alan D. Solomont

A group of 56 parties and movements from various revolutionary coalitions have issued a statement on Sunday regarding the continuation of the revolution and the transfer of power from the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces (SCAF) to a civilianelected government, parliament and president. (pls refer to Ahmed's earlier message for full details on this). Among the 56 parties who signed the statement include Al-Wasat Party, The Egyptian Current Party, the Maspero Youth Union, the Democratic Front Party and Al-Hadara Party. The 56 parties and movements put forward ten suggested actions necessary to achieving their joint revolutionary goals.

Please note the following two goals which were included among the ten goals mentioned in their statement: • Holding presidential elections by April 2012 and announcing the presidential elections' schedule before 25 January, 2012.
