As soon as the president is elected, all the executive powers of the SCAF must be transferred to the president. • Organizing a meeting, independent from the ruling military council, where all political and social movements are represented in order to discuss the specifications of the provisional assembly that will draft the constitution.

subject: Rankings
text:
Per your request, Nora asked me to look over the Partnership for Public Service's "Best Places to Work" rankings and come up with a strategy for what would drive up our rankings compared with other federal agencies.

DOS ranks #7, which is the highest ranking for a Cabinet-level agency. We rank #3 for Strategic Management and in the top 7 for Effective Leadership (#4), Support for Diversity (#5), Teamwork (#4), Training and Development (#6), and Pay (#7).

Our downfall is Family Friendly Culture/Benefits and Work/Life Balance, where we rate #27 and #19 respectively.

The family friendly culture and benefits category measures the extent to which employees believe family-friendly flexibilities are offered to them, including telecommuting and alternative work scheduling, along with personal support benefits like child care subsidies and wellness programs. The work/life balance category measures the extent to which employees consider their workloads reasonable and feasible, and managers support a balance between work and life.

I will get Pat's thoughts on both of these and set up a time to meet with someone at the Partnership for Public Service to get a sense of what feedback they received from DOS employees in the survey and programs that may be in place in other agencies who fared better in these categories. These two categories could also tie in with the work Jen/Rachel will be doing to increase recruitment, promotion and training women, so I will speak with them about this as well.

Many thanks.

We have talked to a number of liberals today, who are not inclined to return to the constitutional committee. Right now, Field Marshall Tantawi is meeting with all the parties in an attempt to mediate this issue and address a possible no confidence vote in the Ghanzouri government. We should have a readout of this meeting shortly after it concludes. (We sent in a cable about half way through our outreach today.)

Liberals believe the only card they have to play is embarrassing the MB. They are leaning toward participating in a parallel constitution drafting process, but don't rule out other options. These would include returning to the original committee (which is supposed to start work tomorrow) if there was broad agreement to include the Al Azhar "bill of rights" in the constitution. They are also asking the SCAF to revise the original decree that essentially Out the drafting of the constitution under the control of the newly elected parliament. (This is a real long shot.)

And some of the liberals are in direct contact with the MB (at the MB's initiative.)

subject: Secretary Clinton's remarks
text:
Jake:

This speech makes me very happy, not just because of the substance, but because this is precisely how I've always thought an effective foreign policy speech should be written: Laying out, explicitly, the hardest questions people actually ask about a particular policy, and then trying to answer them directly, one by one. In other words, naming the elephants in the room, instead of trying to ignore them, as State Department officials are trained to do! I've always wanted to see Hillary give a speech just like this. It would be a great template for addressing other issues as well!

Anyway, precisely because it does take on real questions in a direct way, it leaves us plenty to talk about. But that's the point of a serious speech. So congratulations all around.

Tom

subject: Sidney
text:
On a rainy, gloomy Sunday I write to you in the hope that we will have agreement from Secretary Clinton to accept the "distinguished Diplomat" award at VMI. I am assured by the Superintendent, General JHB Peay, and the department head of International Relations/Political Science, Colonel Jim Hentz that the award is hers if she will accept it. This is a "done deal."

All that is needed for her to receive an official letter from General Peay is for me to know that she will accept the award. They want to give her the award this year on a suitable day before graduation in late May. The letter will ask her to address the corps of cadets in a suitable on post (campus) setting. I would like to see it in Jackson Memorial Hall, a beautiful medieval revival building. An alternative setting would be the two story atrium in the Marshall Center for Leadership and Ethics. The award would be presented at the end of the address. Media coverage would be welcomed and assisted. She would be honored by being the reviewing person at a regimental review of the corps. A suitable dinner and or luncheon would be arranged.

If this is going to happen it would be a good idea to set the wheels in motion as soon as possible so that the staffs can work out the details.

Best

Pat Lang VMI '62

Talked to Mike and delivered the message, adding somalia to the other immediate operational challenges. Went into some length about not being able to be responsible for civilian deployments if there is any ambiguity about relationship btwn State and USAID. His reaction was to ask whether we should consider folding AID into State. I said we were proceding with the understanding that we all had when we signed on that a big part of our responsibility is to oversee policy and manage resources for both USAID and State. I said that I recognized that Gail has a history of believing in an independent AID, to which he responded that is not the basis of this exercise, but he did not challenge the characterization of past views. I made it clear that our suggestion on coordination was not intended to deny resources to the PSD process but to avoid the unintended consequence of sending a signal to AID that will make an already hard set of challenges impossible. He said he would think through and get back to us.

subject: FW: Help for dying patients
text: Tim, et al: I just spoke to Mark Hyman (the doctor with Paul Farmer) on his satellite phone. He is on his way back to the general hospital. He said given triage situation everywhere, when I asked him to prioritize his needs, he gave them as follows: 1. food and water 2. electrical generator to perform surgery - some source of power 3. surgical supplies 4. medical supplies He made one big point - that b/c this is the general hospital, there are more than 1500 patients with more coming in seeking assistance and the hospital is not operational on any level. That transport of these patients is not wise or a possibility. We need to establish this as working hospital given that folks seek it out first. Thank you all for what you are doing cdm

subject: Roberto Flores
text:
Llorens,

Insulza just called with the following: - Zelaya just gave a press conference and announced: - CFK, Lugo, Correa AND Insulza are travelling to San Salvador - Z in a separate plane, accompanied by Rodas and D'escoto, will attempt to go to Tegu and when unsuccessful will then meet the others in San Salvador - they are leaving very shortly - Z claims that the Presidents' trip with Insulza is a diplomatic initiative to encourage dialogue. I told Insulza that he should not go and that neither the GA nor PC gave him the mandate for this trip. He says since they're not going to Tegu it's a dip initiative. Frankly, if they know now Tegu is closed, they do not have to go to ES to say so. They can do so from DC. He insists on going and claims that he dissuaded them from going to Honduras. Insulza hopes this will help facilitate a favorable reponse from Mitcheletti to agree to dialogue.

subject: FW: READ THIS RE: TASKING TO UM AND PROJECT MEDICSHARE ON STANDING UP A 250 PREFAB HOSPITAL REQUEST WE MADE
text: Thank you very much I am aware that you have your hands full—and we want to be as helpful as we can be—we are a relatively small (14,000 private university) to be taking this all on but we have the world class medical talent and passion—Project Medicshare is actually a tiny 501C3 attached to our Global Institute(in the Miller School of Medicine) which is managing the gifts and personnel and logistics with Barth Green, MD as the leader. We have trained a lot of the Haitian docs and nurses over the years and have many on staff including a large number of students. I went to the Haitian church today to pay my respects. Give the Secretary my best and if we can host meetings for you here we have the facilities. Affectionately, Donna

Matt, Warren Buffett's family claims to be the largest private funder of food security and they're planning to grow the current level of investment. I'm going to introduce you to his grandson (who worked for me on the Transition and now at WH Office of Social Innovation). Some of the Buffetts going to be in town in a couple weeks and would be great for you and Mike Lurie to visit with them --- they want to smarten up further on the issue and asked for my help connecting them to right people here. Think about how their $ could be helpful to the Department's own goals in food security...

Look for email intro, Alec

Thank you!

I can't believe that the conspiracy around me worked! I was so mindful of your murderous schedule today that it never even occurred to me that you would tack on yet one more thing. Your showing up was a fabulous surprise, so emblematic of your generosity it so many ways and a wonderful reminder of the cause that you started me on and grew over these almost 20 years. Many thanks.

Should you talk to the new Dutch FM in Lisbon, you might thank him for their work on 1325. They are helping other countries, including in Afghanistan and we hope that they will continue in the new govt.

Good travels and heartfelt thanks. Melanne

subject: Re-engage with Asia, but carefully
text:
It is not surprising that the US wants to reconnect with Asia. After all, as Barack Obama said at the AsiaPacific Economic Co-operation forum in Hawaii, that is where the action is. Growth in the region averages above 7 per cent. With Europe in crisis and anaemic growth at home, the US wants to tap into Asian markets to meet Mr Obama's target of doubling exports and creating jobs.

After being distracted for a decade in the Middle East, Washington's "pivot" towards Asia — to use secretary of state Hillary Clinton's word — shows it has woken up to the region's rise. US re-engagement, in strategic as well as economic terms, is to be broadly welcomed. But there are challenges, even dangers. Washington will need finesse to get it right.

Its main trade initiative is the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Mr Obama wants the nine negotiating countries plus Japan, if possible — to sign a "next-generation" trade agreement by the end of 2012. The TPP is supposed to incorporate non-tariff issues, such as government procurement and intellectual property protection. Getting Japan to sign up to a meaningful deal will be extremely difficult, given intense opposition from farmers. Yet without Japan, the TPP would be a hodgepodge, bringing together countries as diverse as Brunei, Peru, Vietnam and Australia.

Thanks again for coming to the conference. It is really appreciated arid obviously a good cause and a good podium. Audience will be a mix of high-value donors to the museum and foreign policy elites from the Hill, think tanks, and college groups online and there. CNN is the media partner to the event so we have some good built in coverage.

If someone is assigned to work on the speech I should be happy to help with some points if you put me through Philippe or someone else to make some suggestions on it.

I've done a pro-bono poll on knowledge about genocide and I'll be presenting that to the conference and can get the results to you and whoever would work on the speech — so far in the early interviews the public wants more multilateral, not unilateral efforts when it comes to stopping genocide. Awareness of events was surprisingly high.

I'm doing a small reception at my home the night before for speakers and museum board, etc. and the should you be in DC, of course delighted if you feel in the mood to stop by briefly.

Ivo, thanks for the helpful response. From NEA's perspective, an operational liaison with the TNC does not constitute formal, legal recognition of the INC as the government of Libya. We don't consider Chris Stevens' presence in Benghazi to trigger formal recognition, and we've never broken relations with Libya despite suspending our embassy operations.

Without question, having a NATO liaison in Benghazi would have the appearance of NATO leaning in the direction of the INC. But NATO's operations already show a considerable lean away from Qadhati. Speaking for NEA, I don't mind the appearance. But the real purpose would be to avoid friendly fire incidents, of course.

Cheers, Jeff

Jeffrey Fettman Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State

subject: Ukraine
text: This is from Fr. Borys Gudziak, the wonderful priest you met in Lviv. He gave you a tour of the Cathedral and you had a wonderful chat with him at the time. Since then, much progress has been made there. He became head of the new Ukrainian Catholic University and has really come in to his own as a respected leader and scholar. Unfortunately, his situation and that of the Catholic community and academic freedom has come under siege since Yanokovich became president. I have a series of emails from the US Ukrainian community, in addition to this email directly from Gudziak, They are alarmed about developments. I've been in touch with John Tefft and sent him everything. He is aware of recent events. I will make a folder of the correspondence for you since the community here and in Ukraine sees you as their champion. This is not a good turn of events.

subject: Women on every UAE board, rules Cabinet
text:
It's so good to hear from you. I hope you're getting better every day with this enforced rest. You are sorely missed here (can only imagine what February will look like). I was with your husband in Little Rock and all the Club of Madrid leaders kept asking about you and sending their best wishes. It was remarkable to have the whole meeting focused on women's issues and Little Rock put out the red carpet. The library looks spectacular.

As for UAE, I didn't go when you had to cancel. I made it to Tunisia where the women's empowerment session went very well. As for the UAE, they are getting kudos for their decision to place women in high positions, and they are so way ahead of much of the world on this. With respect to their announcement of their gift to GU and your institute on women, peace and security, they would like to do a photo when you're back and get it out to the UAE press.

Don't overdo it and have a happy Christmas.

subject: Fw: Eagles over wolves in a rout Pam Sent this to you b/c of ref to liberia - and it's a great read
text:
Wonderful story — I saw the story on tv but didn't realize the boy was Liberian.

I am just reading The State of Africa — talk about depressing — geez! We seem to make the same mistakes over and over and over.

I have decided to call The Gambia "The Best Little Embassy in Africa".

I have the entire Embassy (100%) learning Wolof greetings — we started yesterday. Our instructor is one of the drivers who was a former language teacher at Peace Corps so there are no costs involved. ALSO we will start community projects next month — again 100% participation. You have to be creative with no USAID $$$$.

Madame Secretary

I participated in Melanne's LMI Women's Empowerment event in Siem Reap the last two days. Another example of the success of the simple power to convene. The reps from different LMI countries really seemed to be drawn to share information and practical examples of success.

I did a panel w Goldman Sachs, Coke, and Proctor and Gamble and although it was a good panel it seems from the questions that the participants need to be given permission to collaborate with the private sector. It follows the theme that GPI has been promoting of cross sectoral collaboration. Whatever you can do to push that idea would be great. Its is a simple and necessary message to say to these new entrants into the economy. Participants at both the ASEAN biz community and the women's empowerment group need to be encouraged to do this.

I sat w the Laos delegation of women and I cannot tell you how powerful your simple trip to Laos was. They were totally empowered. We have to keep that going. Btw, the Laotian/US Diaspora was present and quite creative.

Off to Burma.

Kris

subject: FW: More urgent this morning re TU PM Security Incident--TU Emb wants new Secret Service agent in care with PMi
text:
To (hopefully) close this out, USSS Director Sullivan tells me he has spoken personally to 1) his Turkish counterpart, who is with Erdogan's party, 2) the Turkish security detail leader, 3) Turkish protocol and 4) a senior Erdogan staffer. He believes they understand that this was a misunderstanding between security details, and that all sides now want to put this behind them. Sullivan has communicated all this to Rahm Emanuel. Sullivan does not know if POTUS will raise the issue with the Turks, or vice versa, at their meeting. Sullivan does think he succeeded in calming the Turks down.

Let's hope so.

Sullivan also admitted that he had an internal problem in USSS since his folks did not bring the issue of the Turkish outrage up to him before my call.

Personnel-Sensitive

Dear

Greetings from the State Department.

I am providing you the link below so that you may logon to the eQIP system to complete your security form. Pat Carter will be in touch to provide you some additional forms that you will also need to complete for the security process and the appointment. Once you have completed the eQIP form, please let Pat know.

To start the process, simply copy the following link and paste into your interne browser or click on it to begin completing your SF-86 using eQIP: http://www.opm.gov/e-qip/browser-check.asp. Please read and thoroughly follow the instructions for completing the eQIP form to prevent any unnecessary delays. Once you begin entering your data in eQIP you may save it and return to it, if necessary, at a later time. One you complete the application, please print and sign the three releases of the eQIP form (you will be prompted to do this).

Thank you, Sharon Hardy

Sharon L. Hardy

U.S. Department of State

Presidential Appointments Staff

Cheryl and Huma, As HRC requested for this weekend, attached is a draft base text for the big speech/FA article. I will be on a plane all day Wednesday heading for Asia to do policy planning talks, so it would be great to have her feedback either by phone on Monday or meeting with her on Tuesday — that way I could turn around another draft by Thursday to response to her reactons and then Lissa and I could work on turning it into a real speech draft and circulate more widely. I will also have plenty of time on my trip to work over a version that would be more suitable for Foreign Affairs, assuming she is comfortable with the overall frame and the different pieces.

Have a good weekend! AM

subject: Spanish Thanks
text: You may already be aware of this, but in the event you aren't: A Spanish helicopter based on their Navy ship "Castilla" disappeared in a mountainous region near the Dominican border shortly before noon. The Spanish Embassy called us, and JTF scrambled a helo. Chilean MINUSTAH helo had also been dispatched. The Spanish helo apparently crashed and burned in an area where rescue helos could not land, so a JTF helo landed in the closest area and US troops with stretchers hiked in. On arrival, they reported that the crew of four had all been killed. We are getting body bags into the site now and will remove the bodies today. This is the first fatality involving foreign troops engaged in earthquake response.

subject: Lucy Jarvis Visit
text:
Dear Cheryl and Huma:

Lucy Jarvis, a good friend of Secretary Clinton's from New York, asked that I notify the Secretary that Lucy will be in Morocco planning a positive documentary about Morocco. As you may know, she is an award winning documentary filmmaker and is going to Morocco at the ripe age of 95. I sent our Ambassador, Sam Kaplan, a more detailed note that explains her itinerary and trip.

I am sure that Lucy would appreciate your informing the Secretary, as would I.

Best wishes. Stu

Carolyn W. Keene Covington & Burling LLP 1201 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W., Suite 1117C Washington, DC 20004

subject: French initiative to be announced in approx 1 hour
text:
+ A/S Phil Gordon Update from Embassy Paris:

Sarkozy's Mid-East Advisor Nicolas Galey just told us the French will announce their initiative for Lebanon between about 4pm and 5pm Washington time, despite the fact that Syrian President Asad has not/not yet agreed to participate.

Galey said he had just received the fax from Liz Sherwood-Randall and was on his way to meet with Sarkozy Chief of Staff Claude Gueant to discuss the announcement.

As to Egypt, we re-emphasized the importance of their inclusion in order to create the necessary balance to make the contact group effective. Galey indicated he had heard the same from Washington directly but could not yet confirm the final French proposal for the group's composition.

He said the announcement tonight will be general, designed to confront Asad with a fait accompli while still enticing him to join. The Syrians are not enthusiastic about the initiative, Galey acknowledged, but they promised a response tomorrow. Galey thinks the Syrians are trying to buy time and doubts the French will in fact receive a clear answer from Damascus by tomorrow.

Best, Jamie

MS, I will join the chorus tonight and tell you what an amazing job you did today. Simply amazing.

At the hearing tomorrow, Menendez will give a short introduction followed by Corker. You will be the first official introduction at the table with Kerry. McCain and Warren will take your seat for their respective introductions after you depart. I wanted to mention Corker since I just became aware he would be between Menendez and your remarks.

Secondly, the 100K Strong event — this is the Asia 100K Strong. When we did the launch two years ago, it became an official State initiative. Tomorrow is the celebration of the launch as a non-profit, independent entity. I connected with Kathleen Kennedy Townsend and while they are close, they haven't reached the level of donations yet to launch 100K Strong Latin America. She and I have a call set up in the morning to see how close they are in terms of an event. My apologies for the miscommunication — we will have you in and out at the event tomorrow.

Thank you — Lona

Lona Valmoro Special Assistant to Secretary Hillary Rodham Clinton (202) 647-9071 (direct)

subject: PA Germany Restructuring
text:
During the past year we have discussed the size of the Germany PD budget and the fact that it did not reflect current priorities. EUR reviewed the budget and made the decision to cut the German PD budget by 30% and reallocate the funding to other areas, primarily Eastern Europe. As you will see from the email below and the attached memo, Mission Germany responded by reviewing all their PD operations and developing an entirely new approach based on the PD strategic framework we rolled out earlier this year. I think they did an excellent job and we will be using this as a model for other Missions as we go forward.

Let me know what you think.

jm

They have now accepted our bail money, thus removing the roadblock that has bedeviled us for the past two days. The lawyers and our people are going back to the court, then to the prosecutors' office for some final paperwork.

If this goes okay, we will stage our amcits and third country personnel in about thirty minutes to depart.

We had some back and forth with the plane last night and ended up paying a $8000 fine for our allegedly improper flight plan. (This sort of practice was common I understand during the evacuation, with "gratuities" even being paid to the air traffic controllers.) Our crew was hassled and slept in the plane. We paid the fine, and now the plane has permission to depart.

Two generals, one from Interior and one from Military intelligence, are at the airport, presumably to facilitate the departure.

subject: FW: Clare called again this morning
text:
All,

I received a call from The Atlantic today, and they forwarded me the below message from Clare Gillis's parents. Clare Gillis was able to call her parents again this morning; below is the mother's direct readout. The parents are not going public with this information, but felt it should be shared with people at the Department.

The Atlantic will be running a story on Clare, to keep the pressure on for her release. The parents will not raise the issue unless asked by the press; they will only focus on the fact that Clare has called again. Samantha

Samantha A. Carl-Yoder Special Assistant Office of Deputy Secretary Thomas Nides U.S. Department of State HST 7240 202-647-5094

subject: Points for S-Ban phone call
text:
All—

The SYG just spoke with Susan.

On Haiti - the SYG said that it was his understanding that SRSG Mulet had agreed in recent conversations to a coordination plan with Raj, Amb. Merten, and Gen Keen. He said that Mulet has forwarded this "approved" plan (hereafter "the Mulet plan) and the SYG intends to present it in Montreal for approval. The SYG said that the Canadians are also on board with the Mulet plan.

Amb. Rice was non-committal with the SYG noting that she had not seen the Mulet plan.

As far as I know, nobody in Washington has seen the Mulet plan.

We need to urgently track down a copy of this plan quickly before the SYG calls the Secretary.

- Erica

subject: MESSAGE FROM FRENCH ON SYRIA FOR S
text:
French called and asked us to pass on the following message to the US delegation heading to Paris for Syria meeting this evening:

--France believes UN Monitoring Mission needs to deploy immediately.

--We cannot bear the responsibility for interrupting the Annan process.

--The Syrian opposition wants the monitors.

--France cannot see strategically were we could go if we decide to delay a decision to deploy.

--Russians will use this an opportunity to reverse the Annan process and put the onus on the Western countries.

-- France will push for an immediate decision to deploy monitors.

--Russians have already portrayed the Paris meeting as an effort to derail the Annan process, delay will play into their hands.

We are working fast in the short run: we're talking about increasing the number of hooches, and doubling up staff in lodging. It looks a lot like what you'd see at Bagram or other military facilities in Afghanistan.

In the medium term, we need to improve the security perimeter — acquiring property adjacent to our current facilities in Kabul, which is now difficult to secure.

Long-term, we need embassies in these countries adequate to serve the mission. It's not so long ago our Embassy in Islamabad was torched, we need a facility which is structurally sound. In Kabul, we need facilities adequate to size the mission needed.

subject: The Sinai
text: Madam Secretary, Given the NYT and AP stories this morning on Egyptian tanks in the Sinai and Israeli concern; I wanted to update you on the situation. I just finished a secure call with Anne and have sent a secure communication to Dan Shapiro and others (Cheryl and Jake have copies). David Satterfield has worked this situation masterfully to date but there is reason to be concerned that we will reach a tipping point and that things will tip in the wrong direction. As a result we have suggested some steps forward for Dan as Anne and David continue work in Cairo. We will revisit the issue this afternoon in the Egypt DC as needed. Will keep you posted. Wendy

subject: SUBJECT: Update on Korea, Colombia, and Panama Free Trade Agreements
text:
The House and Senate have tentatively scheduled October 12 votes on the Korea, Colombia, and Panama free trade agreements (FTAs), the day before Korean President Lee Myung-bak's state visit. The House plans to vote to renew Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) and Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) programs on October 12 as well. The Senate already passed the TAA/GSP bill.

The House Rules Committee announced the House will have one hour of debate on the TAA/GSP bill and 90 minutes of debate for each FTA bill on October 12. The House floor debate will be followed by separate votes on each of the three FTAs as well as the TAA/GSP bill. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell agreed to limit debate on the three FTAs to a total of 10 hours. Barring any objections from Senators, this would allow Senate votes on each of the FTAs October 12. To accommodate the Senate vote, the Senate Finance Committee will hold a markup of the three FTAs on October 11. The normal layover requirement between committee and Senate floor action will likely be waived by unanimous consent to allow the October 12 Senate vote.

FTA supporters expect, and opponents concede, there are sufficient votes in both the House and the Senate to pass all three of the FTAs. Hill staffers expect the Colombia FTA to pass by a relatively narrow margin due to labor opposition. The Korea FTA is expected to pass by a comfortable margin, despite concerns about trans-shipment of goods from China and North Korea. The Panama FTA is expected to pass with little opposition.

I spoke w the Senator who is not ready to lift his hold yet. He spoke w the Charge in the Brazilian Embassy who told him there was a procedure in the Brazilian courts that could be used to give Mr. Goldman custody now and during the remaining time of the court proceedings.

Craig, can you find out what the Brazilians meant by that and if their govt is pursuing it?

Bob, can you and USTR contact your Brazilian counterparts to explain how important the Goldman case is to the Senator who can't understand how the father wins every case but never gets his son back and he has run out of patience and is willing to hold this critical bill.

Let me know what you find out. Thanks.

Just a few more points to add to what Miguel has already laid out.

Menendez has pushing for a hearing for Julissa next week, but it got pushed back a bit because of a Banking Committee markup on Iran Sanctions, which he wants to attend. At this point, its a scheduling issue for him as he is in cycle, but we are told that the WHA hearing should be the week of Feb 9.

With respect to Roberta, I've been in contact almost daily with Rubio's staff, Roberta and Wendy's staff. We briefed Rubio staff with Treasury on cuba travel licensing issues during the recess, and are waiting on a letter from the Senator charting a course forward (which will likely entail OFAC changing some of its travel guidance in return for the Senator lifting his holds). Rubio staff indicate we will have this letter by Friday, and that the hold issue will be resolved in the very near future. I understand they have communicated the same message directly to Roberta. I've updated Wendy's staff on this as well.

Happy to discuss further.

subject: Re; Camp Ashraf
text:
Cheryl

Just to let u know that David has made a tremendous impression on the people of Camp Ashraf. Although the situation remains dangerous and there's fear of another Iraqi raid, there's also real progress.

Carolyn Ennis of UNHCR has started to register residents as "People of Concern" and each of the residents is completing an individual application. Residents have started to be relocated, in modest numbers, to Italy, AUstralia, Switzerland and the Netherlands. There's a significant chance that Canada may accept additional people, including their own passport holders, in the near future. The hope is that this will create a pipeline to allow a larger exodus if the US FTO is lifted.

Both the EU and the UNHCR have used this progress to argue that closing Ashraf by January 1 is "unrealistic" and the relocation/registration progress are addressing Malaki's concerns. The immediate problem is to get the UNHCR the logistical help that they need and get some personnel in the Camp to make another attack difficult.

subject: Cutting exercise
text: I met with Dave Obey and talked to Nisha right before I left. Nisha said that they would want our priorities to deal with an allocation that is very low if there is no new budget resolution. The 2011 column of the 2010 resolution is $20 billion below the presidents budget overall. In comparison all of the cuts in the senate resolution totalled $11 billion below the pres bud (4 from us and 7 unallocated). I thought it was a bit early to start giving a list of what we would cut if the allocation is very bad, but will have people work on some recommendations for us to review while Congress is away.

Cheryl,

In response to your query about the possibility of going to Goma, I reached out to our colleagues in Embassy Kinshasa to see what has been done in the past. The only reasonably safe way to get to Goma is flying on a MONUC aircraft originating from Kinshasa. That would mean a two hour flight each way, leaving a very small window (probably no more than one hour) to work in events. Moreover, advancing Goma would pose a significant challenge for us for security reasons.

I also asked the Embassy to look into other ways of traveling to Goma — perhaps over land via Kigali (Lew and I had discussed this possibility earlier) — and the Embassy did not like the optics of approaching by land from another country.

We're still looking at ways to lengthen our time in Monrovia, including possibly staying overnight in another country, such as Cape Verde. Still no luck, but we're working on it...km

subject: FW: Friday Policy Review
text:
No — I wasn't invited to this. I can't anyway — I need to go over to USAID for an event we're hosting w/ IFPRI. S/P recently drafted a policy paper on Africa and I worked contributed a lot to that paper. I see one big issue missing from those questions —the issue of China in Africa. China is transforming the continent in a way not seen since the days of colonialism.

We should also think about China in the context of food security. There are one million Chinese farmers currently working in Africa! That's remarkable if you think about it. China has also bought nearly 3 million hectares of land in Africa and could become one of the largest sources of commercial farming on the continent. They are also building many of the roads that will transform transportation and the movement of agriculture products.

--Matt

subject: CJCS Quick Trip Status--21 Feb
text:
Sir:

CJCS completed his visit to Saudi Arabia with mildly downgraded visits with defense officials today:

- LTG Qubail, Deputy Chief of Staff, MODA - Sheik Mohsen, A/CDR of Saudi National Guard - Prince Khalid, Assistant Minister of Defense and Aviation

The meetings were all collegial. CJCS conveyed he was here to listen as 'he does not live here'. Counterparts conveyed they sought his advice. This mutual quest for counsel allowed for good, warm and open exchange about regional shifts, and Iran.

There was also good attention to Sudan. All interlocutors talked about Abdullah's reforms to date, particularly in education (e.g. the message was: not only are they for reform, they've been doing it for some time)

GCS throughout emphasized was that developments in the region ultimately undermine and discredit Iran's regime and AQ's message in the long run. And we are committed to KSA and its security.

Prince Khalid expressed very directly concern over the state of U.S. military support programs, complaining of changing expectations, insufficient performance, and incomplete equipment. He was pretty insistent. CJCS somewhat surprised, and not happy. Expect some RFIs and follow-up, I would think.

- Wheels up to next location. CJCS will be able to scan SIPR for next hour

- Tracking a NSS-requested call to Mr Donilon

Vr

subject: Luis Alberto Moreno
text:
Dear Cheryl,

Thank you for the update on the ongoing matter of thelDB and the hopeful reelection of Luis Alberto Moreno. I am pleased that you and Luis had a good opportunity to meet and discuss the current situation. Following up with Mexico strikes me as exactly the right next step. Assuming Luis' outreach to Mexico goes well I would hope and think we would be very close to resolving the situation in a positive manner. I look forward to our staying in touch in that regard.

Thank you and Secretary Clinton for your consistent engagement and usual good judgment on this important matter.

Personally, Mack

All-Per the Secretary's specific request, Mike Posner led a small team here in discussions with the Palestinians in Geneva to try to find a consensus approach on the Gaza resolution coming up tomorrow at the Human Rights Council. The attached captures much but not all of what the Palestinians have requested. It goes beyond what the Israelis have said they can accept in the way it treats the Goldstone report and follow up to it. At the same time, it is unlikely to go far enough for the Palestinians, who are still adamant about endorsing the report. They report that their instructions are to find agreement with us without compromising their core principles. We are meeting with the Palestinians again in ten minutes and will report back following that.

subject: See below from my Africa guy, who is very strong
text:
Jake,

I spoke with the key folks in AF. In short: Johnnie is ramping up the U.S.'s involvement on Mali AF drafted a Note to S today updating her on Mali that is making its way through the AF/FO right now. (Should I ask AF to send it directly to the S specials at the same time they send it to the Line so you get it quicker?).

AF demarched all key countries in West Africa and Europe last week (including France) seeking their support for specific actions to achieve four goals: 1) the return of a democratically-elected government in Bamako, 2) a mediated political solution to the instability in the north, 3) strengthened regional efforts to combat terrorist groups in northern Mali, and 4) improved humanitarian access to displaced populations. The actions include the return of interim President Traore to Bamako, with appropriate security assurances by the interim government, and the interim government to set an election date early enough that a new government can take office prior to the May 2013 deadline set by ECOWAS.

Johnnie held a SVTC today with US ambassadors in Abidjan, Bamako, Nouakchott, Niamey and Ouagadougou to discuss host government concerns prior to the upcoming African Union Summit.

The UNSCR referenced in the below news report did not endorse ECOWAS or AU intervention in Mali etc. DOD has approved seconding a military observer to ECOWAS to help with these efforts, and our mission to the AU is also providing planning support. There has been some tension between ECOWAS and the AU on Mali with respect to who has the lead, and tension between non-ECOWAS countries like Mauritania and Algeria and ECOWAS.

Jake,

It's looking likely that the Pakistanis will medevac Malala Yousufzai to the UK. We've confirmed this through both civilian and military channels in Pakistan as well as through the UK High Commission in Islamabad.

The High Commission received a formal dip note from the Pakistan MFA requesting assistance and specifying that Pakistan would assume all costs for her transport and care.

Pakistan has been in contact with two British-Pakistani physicians in the UK. They will most likely move her to the University of Birmingham Hospital sometime in the next day or two. The Brits are not disclosing the location at this time.

The Pakistanis have thanked us for our offer to assist. There were, as you know, several private offers from the U.S., including from Johns Hopkins, Gabby Giffords's physician, from within the Pakistani-American community, and from the UAE as well.

Let us know if you have any questions. Will keep you posted on further developments.

Jake:

A quick summary of what happened tonight in Dublin:

Cowen won the party vote of confidence tonight; the tally won't be made public (yet). Finance Minister Brian Lenihan publically supported the Taoiseach and looks to have improved his position in the party and for taking over FF having chosen the winning side today. Martin gave a strong speech in opposition before the vote and was congratulatory to Cowen publically afterward. He tendered his resignation (while stating he doesn't want anyone else to follow his lead), which Cowen "reluctantly" accepted. Both Cowen and Martin's remarks were complimentary toward each other and reaffirmed their friendship. Word is that the Taoiseach will take on the FM's portfolio.

I don't know who will travel to Munich in Martin's place--if it is the Taoiseach and Martin was on the calendar, we'd support a meeting with Cowen in lieu of Martin.

Best, Jason

Dear Madam Secretary:

I greatly appreciate your support of our efforts to improve USG outreach to the European Parliament (EP) and wanted to provide you with a brief update on our progress. We have worked very hard at USEU to deepen and intensify our relationship with the EP over the past several months. Specifically, we have,

(1) Increased the flow of high-level USG visitors to the EP. Recent visitors include Janet Napolitano, Dick Holbrooke, George Mitchell, Dick Morningstar and Ron Kirk. These visits culminated last month in a highly successful address by VP Biden to a Plenary Session of the EP. I hope that you will also address a Plenary Session of the EP in the near term. (Your town hall meeting at the EP with young leaders last year was well-received here.)

(2) Increased the flow and quality of EP interactions in Washington. We have facilitated a dramatic increase in the number of EP delegations visiting Washington and a significant improvement in the level of their access to high-level USG officials.

(3) Increased USEU outreach to the EP at every level. At the Mission, we are restructuring the way in which we interact with EP leaders by institutionalizing responsibility for key relationships and enhancing accountability. In the coming months, we expect to receive two additional FTEs at the Mission to improve our ability to cover the EP. We have also encouraged our Embassies in member State capitals to meet with European Parliament members.

Again, thank you for your interest and support for our efforts. Bill Kennard

subject: Sidney
text:
As we discussed on the phone, the VMI Distinguished Diplomat Award for Secretary Clinton has gone "agley" in the matter of a mutually doable date for presentation in Lexington. Some 50 dates have been proposed. None were workable because of problems with her schedule. As I mentioned to you, the yearly cycle has resulted in the selection of General Jones, for this year, but this in no way supersedes her selection. They await the time when they can honor her. If they have to wait until she leaves office, they will gladly do that.

At the same time, the Marshall Foundation which is located at VMI but is not a part of VW, is giving her an award on the 2nd of June at the Building Museum in Washington. Splendid idea, but this has nothing to do with VM!. These are two different institutions.

The difference in these two awards would be worth explaining.

Best

Pat Lang

subject: AMS
text:
Great idea. I wanted to do a mini-conference before the election on women's issues, and then a full conference after the election to decipher their role in determining the presidency. But perhaps we can mix it all up and add in these ideas, at least to the first one.

I'll keep you posted, but also appreciate you're juggling the world.

By the way, Susan Chira has an op ed in The Times titled To Have (It All) and Have Not, which is excellent. My cable is out or I'd send you the link.

Hope you are getting some rest soon -

Neera

Cheryl, Thanks again for your great help on the President's words.

Could you check to see if the following is even feasible. In light of our community's love for Sec. Clinton's we would love to celebrate her at our community's largest event -- our conference of the country's clergy and lay leaders from our 500 churches across America. Lead by Archbishop Demetrios, it is taking place in this summer in Phoenix, Arizona on July 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 5th.

If it is possible, we can accommodate her whenever she would like during those dates, although the grand banquet the evening of July 5th is the best.

Thanks again.

Andy

subject: Cuba
text:
You will have seen Verma's note regarding Senator Menedez desire to speak to S re direct mail talks with Cuba and our follow on talks with the Cubans and dissidents. He is upset tha he was not consulted and does not think he was briefed sufficiently quickly.

WHA and H had briefed immediately on the direct mail talks, and had briefed HFAC on the follow on talks. We had asked for time to brief SFRC but had not yet done so.

This should be a good news story. We engaged with the Cubans at the Vice-Minister level, breaking a several year shunning of our Interest Section by the Cubans, traveled outside of Havana to view hurricane damage (thus breaking through the barrier of no travel beyond a ten-mile perimeter), we pursued extradition of US fugitives in Cuba, and most importantly, Bisa Williams (my DAS and the head of delegation) met with a broad range of dissidents, civil socity reps, and bloggers.

This last point is worth highlighting. The last part of the trip came together late because we would not let the Cubans condition our meetings or determine who we could or could not meet with. The Cubans finally allowed us to meet with dissidents, something they have prevented EU and other visitors from doing. In other words, we have broken th mold and put real pressure on others to do the same.

That said, our briefing and outreach could have been quicker and better coordinated. This has upset Senator Menedez. We are sending Bisa up tomorrow to brief the SFRC.

subject: FW: [UNSIGNED MSG] RE: PAKMIL Request for Assistance ISO Avalanche
text:
For your situational awareness, the Pakistan military requested U.S. military assistance via the Office of Defense Representative-Pakistan (ODRP) at about 1245 EDT today for search and rescue operations to recover its forces trapped in an avalanche that occurred in the Siachen Glacier region of Pakistani-controlled Kashmir on April 6 about 2000 EDT (4/7 about 0500 Pakistan time).

The avalanche occurred at an elevation of about 12,000 feet and buried a headquarters building with more than 100 soldiers, possibly in more than 60 feet of snow.

ODRP passed the request for assistance to CENTCOM and the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) in Afghanistan, and ISAF has agreed to send a search and rescue team on April 8.

ODRP has also reached out to the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) for possible assistance.

Thank you, regards,

Alison Storsve Senior Watch Officer State Department Operations Center +1-202-647-1512

Just prior to your speech in Dakar, you will meet (in a receiving line) with Binta Diop and a few women from the women's campaign initiative. They have been recognized as having played a very crucial role in the outcome a peaceful outcome to the election (at a time when chaos could have ruled the day). Just after he was elected; the President went out of his way to thank the women for the role they played (they had established a Situation Room and excellent grassroots operation) in enabling a peaceful transfer of power. Binta is the head of Femmes en Solidarite. She is well known globally, and you may have met her over the years. She is a huge fan of yours. The Senagalese women's efforts are now being recognized as a model that could be replicated for elections in other African countries.

On another note, Binta told me that Zuma has recently reached out to her and is also consulting with Sirleaf, Banda, etc, on ways the AU can better incorporate women into its work and address some of the key challenges in Africa. I think you are tentatively meeting with Zuma.

Melanne S. Verveer Ambassador at Large for Global Women's Issues U.S. Department of State 2201 C Street NW, Room 6805

subject: Fw: Farewell to Secretary Clinton - Puvlic Servant and Friend, by Lanny.]. Davis (Version 2)
text:
See below - my goodbye. To be posted Thurs on Hill, HuffPo, Daily Caller, and Foxnews.com.

After written and submitted, had to write a last minute insertion when Accountability Board report came out Tues night.

I hope you enjoy the memories - especially mom remembering your sparkling yellow pants suit!

I sent you my best wishes thru cdm when I heard about your fall. Happened to me once - faint and hard knock on marble floor. Scary.

But your great husband and my great wife agree we are well protected - hard-headed.

Take care of yourself - and look forward to a long rest as I wrote at the end.

Best,

Lanny

(Josh is now a sprouting twig, taller than dad - and who, like grand-ma Fran, considers Hillary a hero. Hope we can come by for a minute for photo and a quick good-bye).

Pls keep track for me of two concert dates for Carole King and James Taylor: June 8 in DC and June 15 in NY

I'd like to meet w the columnist Tom Friedman--maybe for lunch?

Sometime in late spring I'd like to have a dinner at either State or my house for Admin women--including Michelle Obama. Just raising it to discuss.

Let's try to schedule dinner w Jim Jones and his wife and Bill whenever that can be.

I still want to go to West Point and just heard Hagenbeck is leaving in June so need to find date soon.

Have we offered date to McConnell yet? Let's look at overseas travel, make decisions tomorrow and be sure we get this done.

I need a date on a weekend for Mort Zuckerman's dinner for Elie Wiesel.

subject: Policy Directive on Gender Equality
text:
Dear Ruth

Jake and I connected today to discuss the Policy Directive on Gender. One of our key concerns is how we best to embed in FSI the type of learning and training recommended in the directive, and in particular, what will be the source for that curriculum. I also welcome understanding what the nature of the teachings that would be offered — classes? case studies? other approaches? principles?

I am sure you are in touch with S/GWI in this regard and I was wondering if you might share what ordinarily is the information and data you have to develop curricula, your typical sources for the material, as well as your thoughts for what would be serve your needs in developing this curriculum given its newness and uniqueness?

I also am inclined to seek some outside support for this effort and want to make sure this would prove helpful to you.

subject: Clare Gillis call to parents, April 26
text:
Former Congressman Curt Wheldon who recently visited Libya called me to say that he and Congressman Galegly of HFAC (vice Chair) were on a conference call with Saadi Qadhafi, son of the leader. Wheldon said he was maintaining contact with Saadi to try to get the 4 journalists released and to get

out of the country. Saadi was very positive that the journalists would be released very soon. He was taking a personal interest in seeing that Ms. Gillis had her own laptop and was going to be moved to a hotel. He acknowledged he is up against hardliners (including Saif el-islam) who are arguing what will they get if the journalists are released. Saadi promised to call Wheldon back in a few hours hopefully with good news.

Wheldon told me he and Galegly are willing to travel again to Tripoli to give the firm message to Qadhafi if the administration believes that would be useful.

subject: Newsweek
text:
You're very welcome. We've got a pretty good process in place handling the projects, and as always, we have a great product to sell.

And as a non-Methodist list maker, this project now comes off mine, and Caroline will be crossing it off our white board tomorrow, a very satisfying ritual. Esquire's should hit soon and will hopefully be as positive. Then it's just 60 left, and I feel good about that too.

I would say that the one thing that's going to continue to be annoying is people pressing you on how long you'll serve. When Tavis got you to say you probably won't for 8 years, that was especially stupid newsmaking on his part. Hirsh tried it with four, and I think others will.

Might just be easiest to say, I've learned not to predict the future - including my own - but I intend to and hope to. We have a lot to do, so much that we've started, and I want to see it through.

Or just a simple I hope to

If you don't you don't nobody's going to call you on saying you 'intended to' a year earlier. Again, the 8 years was especially dumb speculation

But these questions are really code for are you happy, are you being treated well, do you have enough juice? And no point to let people interpret the answer to their nefarious use.

Statement

The Passing of Victoria DeLong

This morning I spoke with the family of Victoria DeLong, the Cultural Affairs Officer at our Embassy in Port-Au-Prince who lost her life in the earthquake. I expressed my sincerest condolences on behalf of the men and women of the State Department and the American people. This is one tragedy among so many. The United Nations has suffered grevious losses. And the Hatian people have endured unimaginable heartbreak. For the State Department, we have lost one of our own. Victoria was a veteran Foreign Service Officer who worked tirelessly to build bridges of understanding and respect between the people of the United State and the people of Haiti. She served her country with distinction and honor, and she will be sorely missed. Victoria's friends and colleagues at the Embassy are working day and night to support vital relief and recovery efforts, and our thoughts, our prayers, and our deepest thanks are with them as well. Along with the military personnel, the search and rescue teams, and all the aid and relief workers now deploying, they represent the unwavering commitment of the United States to stand with Haiti in its hour of need and in the hard days and years to come. My heart is with the DeLong family today, and with all those in Haiti and around the world who have lost loved ones and friends in this disaster.

subject: Constitution, Presidential elections, Shura Council, Advisory Council
text:
Advisory Council Update:

The National Consensus Committee formed recently by the Advisory Council to communicate with Political Parties re Egypt's transition, met yesterday. The meeting was chaired by Hassan Nafaa, Head of the Committee. FJP, El Nour, El Wafd did not attend the meeting. The committee issued its first statement after the meeting stating the following:-

The committee agreed on the formation of two branch committees. The first will be responsible for studying the mechanism of the formation of the Constitutional Assembly that will draft the Constitution, while the second will be responsible for presenting a preliminarily vision of the Constitution.

Hassan Nafaa stated after the meeting that there were some logistical reasons that prevented other parties from attending and he confirmed that the FJP agreed on the statement.

On the other hand he said that the FJP knows well that a constitution should not be written by a majority but through consensus. (Al Masry Al Yom Arabic)

I'm enroute to Jordan but wanted you to know that the last day of the WPS Inst at Wellesley was very wonderful and truly inspirational, as so many of the participants spoke of their positive experiences. There were many grateful shoutouts to the Honorable Hillary. You clearly were the highlight of their time there. They are an accomplished group of emerging leaders and we will be hearing more about them in the future. Jane made the announcement about Wilson and hiring Rangita who did an incredible job with the training. I intend to see two of the Jordanian MPs who were in the program in Amman. On to the next installment!

I'm doing a strategic civil society dialogue with women from the region starting tonight. I'm sure to get an unvarnished view.

Nora,

Just to close the loop, I did meet w/ Jeffrey Romoff and his team on Wed afternoon. They gave a very impressive into on what the University Medical Center of Pittsburgh (UPMC) is doing in Southern Italy. They are already getting a lot of political support from our Emb in Rome and are grateful for it.

I gave them some practical suggestions on other levers in the USG that they could pull (TDA, OPIC, Commerce Advocacy Center).

They want the Secretary will make some positive reference to Berlusconi in Italy this summer of their interest in working the GOI to build a lab/production facility for developing vaccines for H1N1 and other infectious diseases. They also note the coincidence of the G20 mtng in Pittsburgh later this summer. I made no commitment. But I do believe this is a genuinely positive program and our Emb agrees.

I did pass their materials to David Thorne and urged him to be in touch. He said he would engage, once/if he is confirmed.

Stu

subject: A helping hand outstretched
text:
Phil and Liz

Thank you for giving this your most serious attention; you need a mature emissary with an expert translator to ensure full dialogue and that not one unnecessary life is lost or ordinance expended.

As you know, at this very moment there is a team assembled under our roof prepared to depart as needed, as am I, if the Secretary will privilege me to make this small contribution to her all embracing and effective efforts to realize the world for my children and grandchildren that my law professor friend Barack Obama spoke of one cold but clear January day, as the one that always comes first with open hand, not clenched fist.

God bless the America that remains our troubled world's best hope.

•Doug Amb. Kmiec

subject: Burns nom
text:
Bill called me Friday evening: he said Scowcroft called him to say that he had heard of hold on his nom. Scowcroft informed that he had shared this with GHW Bush, who had already called Senator to argue to release. Scowcroft could call, as might others (Armitage, Baker). Secretary Rice is also informed of the hold and can call.

Bill, who departs for Middle East today, wrote me yesterday re: Rice call, that his sense would be sooner the better -- on grounds of need to fill position, not getting into Taiwan stuff. Also recognizes that this timing is up to us.

I can tee up Rice call when we're ready to launch. Rice and HRC will see each other in Budapest later this week.

subject: American Legion National Convention August 30, 2011
text:
Hey Burns !

Please SEE ATTACHED LETTER. The Nalonai Headquarters would love to have Secretary Clinton as a key note speaker at the National Convention in Minneapolis this August if her schedule would permit.

The leadership loves Hillary !II This all stems from her visit and speech at American Legion Mall in 2008 when she won the Indiana Primary. She made a lot of friends here and always rerninises about her dad being active with the Legion in Illinois.

When talking to Hillary could you put in a good word for her corning to the convention ??? I guarantee you she would be the high point of the week and would receive a great reception. Attendance for key note speakers is usually around 10,000 members-a really good crowd.

subject: Article in the Daily Sun
text: This is a very thoughtful piece that identifies many of the same factors we are in our diplomatic chapter (and that is not just because the author – the former Bangladesh ambassador to the US—cites me). What is most striking is that it affirms that our analysis in the QDDR offers a set of questions that foreign ministries all over the world are grappling with. I had hoped to have time to do some traveling to broadcast the QDDR to key allies and partners around the world after the QDDR is in, but even if that can't happen, we will devise an outreach strategy re sending the report out to foreign ministers around the world and to our ambassadors that will greatly amplify its impact. AM

subject: Is this still your email address?
text:
Dear Hillary,

This is indeed still my email. I am sorry I missed your call. I listened to your message and tried to call you back but your cell did not pick up. I am honored by your invitation to join the new board you are setting up. Let me know when it would be convenient to schedule a call. I will be in the US through September 5, then away for two weeks, and then in NYC-DC during the week of September 19.

Have a wonderful vacation. I am delighted by the prospect of working with you.

Laura

subject: update
text:
I just wanted to tell you that the interagency clearances for the National Action Plan and Executive Order are completed, so we are on our way. Both will be released by the WH on Monday before your GU speech. We are inviting a large community of interest. You will be able to keep the commitment you made in the Security council a year ago!

Secondly, on a related topic -South Sudan. There are several women leaders from South Sudan participating in the Engagement Conference -- it is a first facilitated by USG. For the last 2 days, the women have been getting trainings and pounding out the recommendations they will deliver to the conference. These are impressive women who have long been engaged in the peace/independence movement. Tonight at a reception we hosted, Princeton Lyman and Don Steinberg both spoke eloquently about the critical importance of their participation. Tom'w you will announce deliverables to support their efforts. On Monday, they will attend your announcement of the NAP.

Hi Jake- You might let S know that the Turkey-Azerbaijan Agreement was signed today by the Ministers in the presence of Aliyev and Erdogan. I spent last week in Baku. During the week I met for an hour and a half with Aliyev on the agreement and a 45 minute one-on-one on our overall issues. I felt a bit like Dr. Phil. I told him what a big deal the FSN issue was and how important it was to get resolved. I will forward on the high side an e-mail describing the meeting. This was all fully coordinated with Phil Gordon. On the gas agreement, I am sending congratulatory letters to Aliyev and Erdogan, both of whom I have worked with directly on these issues. If you think it a good idea for S to send letters, I can send you drafts. Thanks...Dick

Dear Anne-Marie,

As we discussed during your salon dinner with Steve Clemons at Nora's, I am developing a practical strategy of "off-shore/on-shore balancing" that would involve key USG agencies.

As the attached proposal explains, the new strategy is substantially different from previous historical constructs in the literature on American grand strategy and offers important advantages to improve our position in Afghanistan and other regions in the world in the coming years.

Going forward, I would like make sure I have State's views correct. If you and your staff could meet with me later next week, this would greatly help.

I look forward to further discussion. Bob

Robert A. Pape Professor, Political Science Department Director, Chicago Project on Security and Terrorism University of Chicago

cpost.uchicago.edu

Reporting in

We successfully concluded our apec summit. Matvienka presided for Russia and the delegates competed with each other to show they were implementing the SF declaration. It's amazing to hear what's been achieved in just one year! Amb Klem who attended all the apec meetings this year said it was by far the liveliest and most constructive. The Russian dep FM closed the summit and apologized for all the scheduling challenges and said he hoped all worked out to your satisfaction in the end. This was a critical passage for the institutionalization of women and the economy into Apec, and I'm glad Russia was able to deliver. Thx for solidifying all of this. Many of the delegates referred to what you said in SF and how they were heeding your call.

(via Chester Crocker!). Last bit may be useful to our thinking of overarching principles as we approach a new ME strategy...

Obama should address the nation as if we are thinking adults who are capable of looking beyond breathless correspondents and combative cable news anchors to the hard challenges of coping with a region in turmoil. As Sen. John McCain observed on TV yesterday, these are momentous, historical events that could transform a region and bring it into the modem age, with potential global significance. The stakes are very high. And we are not in charge of the Arab awakening. Arabs are. Nonetheless, as a global power we can and should play a constructive hand and help shape events.

He should describe the reasons for the U.S. to respond and to act in a differentiated way - in recognition of the Arab world's tremendous diversity. He should explain why we need a differentiated strategy and why a cookie cutter won't work in such a diverse geography.

How to explain this? He should explain what the differences are in the Arab nations affected by this awakening:

-- they differ by the nature of incumbent regimes (transitioning, ugly autocrats, friendly autocrats).

-- they differ by the nature of the societies themselves and especially the opposition forces that are taking to the streets (sectarian, tribal, secular, Islamist, civil society-led, angry unemployed youth, etc.)

-- and they differ by the nature of U.S. interests in various countries, ranging from marginal to decisively important.

Obama should say why a global power must make choices based on interests and priorities, and why we must avoid childish conversations in which we debate whether the U.S. is showing "hypocrisy" or "inconsistency" when it reacts differently in different cases. Consistency is hardly a virtue if we are consistently wrong.

Timing of Commitment to the PA

Rob Goldberg has the paperwork in train so that we will be able to transfer funds by the end of October. I know that you are not inclined to commit the full $150 mm anyway, which is good, since until the CR is final we need to leave some room for the CR level to change. You can feel free to make a verbal commitment even now for a partial transfer, certainly on the order of $50-75 mm, at the end of October. In all likelihood we would be able to do more, and we will know for sure when the CR is completed later today or tomorrow. I will ask Rob to send you a note as soon as the CR is final so you know the exact limits.

Thank you!

You were marvelous and the women love you. I heard it over and over. They we're frustrated that they were told they had to be quiet when you came in the room. They finally couldn't stand it any more and started to sing. So glad you joined them and calmed down the FL! AWEP has become a great success. You should have heard the Zambian trade minister today tell them he'll do anything they want. I told them to hold him to it!

I visited some great projects in Zambia, good people but lots of challenges. Violence vs women and girls is a big problem, HIV/AID still high and more. Slowly, I think it's changing for the better.

I'm about to board and really sorry I had to leave. The calendar rules my life! Have a good trip.

subject: Movement perhaps
text: Madam Secretary, Hopefully Bill or Jake has been able to brief you on last night's (actually early this morning's) secure call. Today, besides the fact that a sandstorm has meant a closed airport, things appear to have moved things ahead. Ashton met for less than a half hour with Jallili and then we had plenary for a bit more than two hours. Plenary punctuated by Jallili approaching me at end to say hello and have very brief sentences. Outcome is a draft press statement we have drafted that will say nuclear core, agree to continue discussions on 20% that includes our ideas and theirs, experts meeting next week and political meeting probably June 14-15. We are asking Iranians not to contradict our statement. Many issues ahead and some work needed first in our govt and then with others. Likely PD meeting with Ashton around June 11 to prepare as well. Ashton due to have bilat shortly with Jallili to see if agree on way forward. Helga already previewed with Bagheri. Could all still fall apart and press management afterwards will be difficult. Nonetheless, looks like we will move forward. If the sandstorm does not abate, likely to do GCC meeting by conference call and then to Tel Aviv tomorrow. More when can talk secure again. Best, Wendy

subject: FW: S call with Meles Eric Can you call me re this?
text:
Cheryl:

Interesting exchange. Yellow Fever is a live attenuated vaccine that does cause mild HA, mild myalgias, low grade temperature (<38.5 or 101), in <5% of cases.

In infants < 9 month you generally don't give vaccine for fear of their immature immune response could disseminate the virus and cause an encephalitis (especially <4mo). People who are immunosuppressed from active lymphoma, leukemia, disseminated cancer, or on chemotherapy or post transplant immunosuppressors, should avoid. HIV patients in late stage disease (<cd4 <200) might not immunize, but I have doe it to HIV + with low CD 4 cells (<50) when they had to go into high risk areas and could not avoid mosquitoes. Someone with an allergy to eggs (if they can eat eggs them they should get immunized).

I would also note that protection from yellow fever vaccine is long. It is recommended you boost every by but "neutralizing antibody" is known to persist for > 30 years in patients with only one immunization and perhaps for life in those with one or more booster shots. He very well may hold immunity from his prior shots, almost certainly if within last 10y.

Eric

subject: Announcing $50 million in OPIC Support for Tunisian SMEs
text:
Dear Secretary Clinton:

Last week, I approved the Tunisian Franchise Loan Facility, a guaranty of $50 million in local bank lending to small and medium sized businesses and franchises in Tunisia. This facility was a direct outcome of your visit to Tunisia last year.

I am also proud to say that OPIC is nearly halfway there on fulfilling your commitment that OPIC provide $2bn in support for private investment in the MENA region as well as the President's commitment that OPIC provide a further $1bn in support for private sector investment and job creation in Egypt.

This Tunisia facility, like many other OPIC transactions in the region, would not be possible without support from USAID to help provide funding for the implementing agent and for technical assistance. In the Tunisia facility USAID is providing $5 million in grants over 5 years.

We are all very pleased to be able to deliver this tangible demonstration of US support for job creation and enterprise development in Tunisia

Warm regards,

Elizabeth

Elizabeth L. Littlefield President & CEO

OVERSEAS PRIVATE INVESTMENT CORPORATION

The U.S. Government's Development Finance Institution 1100 New York Ave, NW I Washington DC 20527 +1 202.336.8401 I elittlefieldPopic.gov I www.opic.gov facebook.com/opicgov I twitter.com/opicgov

Lissa Muscatine < Tuesday, August 17, 2010 11:44 PM

Most importantly....

I enjoyed our talk too, but forgot to mention the most important thing of all -- how much I appreciate your bringing me to State and giving me this opportunity. I have learned so much, meant so many smart and capable people, and hope I have contributed in some small way to what you are working so hard to accomplish.

I'll write a formal letter for "the file" when I leave conveying all of these thoughts„ but I wanted to say something in person too. Unfortunately, I got carried away on sports diplomacy and everything else and ....another senior moment!

I'll let you know when I have had a chance to talk to Judith and Ann about the ideas I'm putting together on sports. I do think there is potential to do much more than is being done now -- and more creatively.

subject: Parade
text:
Photo is gorgeous (and there are 20 more online, some are really great)

The article is good, just way too short, so it became very matter of fact, didn't include a lot of the great stuff he saw that day. They cut what he turned in in half.

But for this readership, that length is probably perfect. It supposedly gets seen by 70 million people. 69 million probably never open it up and just see it in their Sunday paper, so the cover is the ballgame. Story is basically an excuse for the cover. And the cover is a homerun.

In the end, I firmly believe it will be the totality all these in-depth projects like Vogue, National Geographic, Nightline, Time - which I know are annoying - that are going to create a collage documenting your success, especially in terms of style and work ethic, which I believe is what people are most interested when it comes to their perception and approval of you.

Shaun just called, 7:50 pm EST, to relate the latest sequence and to tell you that after near breakdown of negotiations on Monday they are back on track (maybe). Robinson went into his assembly on Monday thinking he could pull off the deal, but was shocked to discover the degree of opposition, centering partly on Reg Empey (UUP). (Cameron has tried to forge an alliance of UUP, elements of DUP and the Tories, on the agenda at the secret country house meeting last week.) But tonight, Wednesday, Shaun has got Robinson and McGuiness to agree to all points, pushing past the previous sticking point on the Minister of Justice and relation to the Executive. The matter now rests with Robinson and his ability to sell it tomorrow. He has told Shaun and Gordon he believes he can do it. He needs 75 percent of his party. So, the perils of peace continue.

Following is based on Erekat and other members of Palestinian delegation in Sine:

None of these options was referenced publicly in the Arab League statement itself.

The Follow-Up Committee blamed Israel for the halting of the negotiating process, praised POTUS's efforts, and left a door open for the USG to get the peace process back on track. They will meet within a month to review the alternatives presented by Abbas and decide next steps.

Since we have not seen the text of the speech itself, we cannot confirm whether he said anything on the question of resignation. However, the issue has already bled out into the press. A participant at a meeting of the Palestine National Council in Amman on Wednesday commented publicly that Abbas reportedly hinted at a possible resignation, and Akiva Eldar's piece in Ha'aretz alleged that he has communicated his intention to resign to the USG.

Senator Frist asked me to convey to the Secretary on his behalf that he has decided not to seek a second term on the MCC board when his current term expires this November. He's been weighing the decision carefully for several months, and ultimately reached the conclusion that because MCC is in good shape in terms of both Administration and Congressional support—compared to when we started in late 2007—he feels that it is the right moment to reallocate his time to some other initiatives and projects that he has had to decline or delay, many in the global health and development area. The September 15th board meeting will be our last.

He would have gotten in touch personally, but he is travelling with his family in Africa and the UK until next week, and he wanted her to hear the news from him first. He says that he of course looks forward to continuing to work with her on issues they have discussed.

He has let MCC CEO Daniel Yohannes and Senator McConnell know, and I have begun the process of informing other board members via Plus Ones. I was waiting to speak with you before contacting others at State, but will begin to do so.

Talk to you soon—

Mauro.

Mauro De Lorenzo Vice President, Freedom and Free Enterprise John Templeton Foundation 300 Conshohocken State Road, Suite 500 West Conshohocken PA 19428, USA +1 610 941 2828 office

http://www.templeton.org

Mullen did better than Eikenberry -- Holbrooke's we know it when you see it test is not helping. Need to tell a more compelling story of what we hope to accomplish in terms of civilian effort a.k.a. nation building. The standard needs to be more modest than open ended and sustainable in a context where US military presence is not a long term requirement if afghan army and police can be built up.

We have not thought about having any press on my trip, should we? Goal would be to show getting civilians in the right place at the right time and reliance on leveraging small number of us civilians to deploy large number of afghans. On the other hand not sure what we will find on the ground.

Paul Simons called me shortly after earthquake hit Chile (8.5 Richter-- stronger than Haiti). He was going to reach out to advance team. Marriott Hotel fine. Event frightening because of intensity of tremor. Epicenter near Concepcion-- third largest city in Chile about 400 miles south of Santiago (city of Cauquenes--- hardest hit).

Just heard Bachelet on TV-- casualties so far 16-- though because communications down and it is still dark information is preliminary. Some concern over risk of Tsunami though Navy deems unlikely. Fortunately, there is no collapse of dams. Considerable damage to highway bridges and infrastructure--that will affect traffic-- in Talca hospital evacuated for precautionary reasons. President declared zones of Maule and Bio Bio disaster areas.

Significant loss of life and damage unlikely because Chile suffered devastating earthquakes in 1939 and 1960 (the strongest in recorded history) in same area so most old construction is gone. Chile has strong construction codes and state of the art anti-earthquake standards. Also Chile has excellent first responder capacity. One concern of course are aftershocks. In 1960 (May 21) a second earthquake occurred day after that caused a Tsunami in Japan. Will have to evaluate whether trip to Chile should proceed. Precisely because of tragedy this may not be time to cancel - provided Chilean side can handle and are anxious for trip to proceed. Suspect that that will be the case. Should evaluate in morning after dust settles.

Arturo

subject: Thanks from Senator Klobuchar
text:
Dear Sen. Klobuchar,

Thank you for taking the time to send this message; you can be sure it will be read by many people. We know that we touch lives in the course of our work, sometimes during moments of unimaginable anguish, nearly always at a time of tremendous stress and worry. It is a privilege to be in a position to help. We never forget that the spirit and heart with which we respond to citizens in trouble matter as much as the actions we take.

We are all celebrating the safe travel to the U.S. of these six little children, and the hundreds of others we've been able to assist under the orphan humanitarian parole program. Thank you very much for your great work and for the valuable information you kept sending us throughout the past few days.

Sincerely, Michele Bond

subject: Call with Sen. Lautenberg
text:
Report on the Goldman case and GSP

Thanks to the persistent efforts of our charge' in Brasilia, I was finally able to locate and call my counterpart, Under secretary Pedro Mendonca.

I made the points contained in your email to me — and emphasized the seriousness of the issue and Sen.
