Lautenberg's frustration that despite the Mr. Goldman's victories in court, he is still unable to get his son back. I said that Lautenberg had told you that in light of this, he was continuing his hold on the GSP legislation -- which, if it continues, would harm Brazil and every other developing nation.

Pedro will speak to the acting foreign minister and other authorities in Brazil right now — and will get back to me with an update and an assessment of what more can be done.

I have also spoken with my USTR counterpart Demetrios Marantis throughout the day. They have discussed this matter with the Brazilian charge' in DC. They had also organized the meeting between him and Lautenberg that Craig mentioned to you in his email -- hoping that it would lead to a lifting of the hold. Demetrios will consult with Ron Kirk to decide what more to do.

I will email you again as soon as I hear from Brasilia and/or USTR.

And I will continue to coordinate with Craig.

Bob

I sent lanny a draft of diplomacy chapter to see how Doi is likely to respond to inter-agency piece. I thought you would like his response. Tim Rieser was also surprisingly complimentary on Friday — saying that he had seen many of these exercises but that this was the most thorough and thoughtful of them all.

"Thank you so much for sending me this; I am deeply grateful, and honored, to have the opportunity to comment. Let me begin by saying that, even apart from DOJ's interests in the QDDR, I think that this is a very impressive document; it is beautifully written, and compellingly argued."

AM

New intel, based on Tyler Drumheller's sources:

1. The army is staying out of the street fighting. The pro-Mubarak group provoking the fighting is a small group of former security and police, quite violent but not significant politically. The army is not getting involving. 2. The army doesn't want to humiliate Mubarak. They will not force him to do anything further. But a flashpoint looms. Egypt can only go for a few more days before there is a food crisis. The army is central to food distribution. Within days as a result of a food crisis the army will feel there must be a resolution. In the meantime, the army will do not anything else. Mubarak has dug in his heels. The army wanted him out, but will not do more against him. The army remains in touch with Muslim Brotherhood, which is not driving the revolution but waiting. The army is still in control.

New options

1. The old constitution established that the president could be president for life. Mubarak could call for a constitutional committee to be formed immediately involving all elements of Egyptian politics to amend the constitution abolishing that provision. Mubarak, in fact, mentioned this in his speech, but failed to include any mechanism to realize it. Calling into being a committee would build on what he has already said and begin to end his rule in reality. He could announce that Suleiman would be head of the committee and perhaps El Baradei would be vice chairman.

I spoke at length last night with Sam Goodstein, Senator Whitehouse's Chief Counsel. He appreciated all the efforts we have so far made on their behalf and understood the challenges of an expeditious public release of the Zelikow memo, especially as the issue is not solely within the State Department's jurisdiction. In fact, it would appear Senator Whitehouse is seeking public release of the memo, ideally before his subcommittee's hearing next Wednesday (the 13th) at 10:00 AM entitled, "What Went Wrong: Torture and the Office of Legal Counsel in the Bush Administration." (Zelikow is one of two witnesses.) Whitehouse's staff understands the challenges in getting public release by the middle of next week (and they seem resigned that this may not happen), but, at a minimum, they feel it should be doable for Senator Whitehouse to view the document (even if still in classified form.) (Note that Whitehouse is a Member of the Senate Intel Committee.) Dave

Madame Secretary

This afternoon I had a meeting with EAP, the China desk and Chinese officials (MOST, NRDC, MFA) who were in WDC for the SED planning meetings. It was an uncharacteristically great meeting. They informed us that China will join the Global Alliance for Clean cookstoves at the SED in Beijing. They invited me to attend some preliminary mtgs just prior to the SED (incidentally they always thank me for the Expo - who knew that would be such a big deal).

They also enthusiastically suggested that you and State Counselor Dai walk to a cookstove exhibit/demo/event right after lunch on May 3rd in Beijing. They said that he wanted to respond positively to your lunch discussion in WDC and your letter to him inviting China to join. They also said that State Counselor Madame Liu Yandong also wants to participate (bec of your and Melanne's entreaties). We concluded our one hour chat with a tour of the cookstove exhibit.

They are definitely in but they are still formulating their more defined role in the Alliance - donor vs implementor.

The EAP folks said that they want to use the alliance as a symbol of our ability to work cooperatively.

This of course is due to your consistent efforts and personal overtures with Counselor Dai. Thank you.

Kris

subject: bravo!
text:
Absolutely. Get some sleep! And don't you love how the stereotype of women who focus on soft peripheral issues like development and empowering women suddenly shifts to the stereotype of women as Amazons?

I heard from the president of the American University in Cairo tonight that the youth of Egypt represent a genuine seachange from their parents, and that they are all rooting for the Libyans. And when things cairn down a bit send u some really interesting stuff I've been collecting re how the Internet empowers women leaders/protesters in particular.

All best, AM

Jake --

I recognize that we're most likely going to have a gap in the COM slot in Baghdad.

So I think that people whom the Iraqis recognize -- Tom Nides, me, Tony Blinken, etc. -- will have to increase the tempo of our travel to Baghdad for a time.

But if S is seeing Jim Jeffrey, I wonder if she could squeeze him to stay on for just a few more weeks. Not indefinitely, but, say, another month, say until May 1. There will always be bad issues in Iraq that need to be addressed, but the Syria/over flight issue seems particularly important. So I'm all in favor of minimizing the gap, even if we still end up with one. I think the only way Jim would agree to stay a few more weeks would be if the Secretary or President would ask.

Jeffrey Feltman Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State 202-647-7209

Dear Jake: When I brought up next week's NPT PrepCom in staff meeting this morning, I was remiss in not mentioning Susan Burk's leadership role. I'd appreciate it if you'd put this note before the Secretary. Thanks. RG

Ma'am: When I mentioned the great work of our Geneva team in preparing for the NPT PrepCom, I was remiss in not highlighting the work of our NPT Special Envoy, Ambassador Susan Burk. She will be the head of delegation and has been putting in a terrific amount of "shoe leather," as she calls it, to ensure that the PrepCom will be a success. We are lucky to have such a talented and experienced diplomat leading our efforts.

With apologies for my omission,

RG

Mitch McConnell asked me again when I was coming to his program at Ky. I asked him if a Sunday would work and he said they had never done the program that day but thought it would work. I'd like to do when Bill would be out of town. Let's discuss.

There's a lawyer in Little Rock named John Gill who's doing a book about the Arkansas Governor's Mansion. He's interviewed everyone but me. Pls schedule a call w him asap.

I want to visit the non P bureaus--especially S/P (Anne-Marie says there is a tradition of a photo w the Secretary), T, CA. We need a schedule to try to do all of these in January.

I also have to meet w the Armenia Caucus after Congress is back.

I want to meet w Walter Isaacson this month.

Judith —

This is simply a quick note to thank you for the inscribed Mongolian-language copy of Secretary Clinton's memoir which just arrived. We look forward to delivering it to President Elbegdorj and know that he will be delighted. This was a terrific idea on your part — and the fact that it now has actually happened is really gratifying as well.

FYI, let me also attach a copy of a recent letter from President Elbegdorj to former President Bill Clinton. Although specifically highlighting the upcoming Nadaam festivities in Ulaanbaatar in mid July, I know that President Clinton would be welcome to visit Mongolia at any time, fulfilling the desire expressed in his "Foreign Policy" interview earlier this year that he really does want to "ride across the Mongolian steppes on horseback"!

Best regards, Jonathan

subject: Baghdad staffing thoughts (PERSONNEL SENSITIVE)
text:
PERSONNEL SENSITIVE

Madam Secretary, given your focus on Baghdad staffing issues, I would like to raise proposals regarding two specific components: 1) Covering the period of Iraqi government formation and summer transition. 2) Selecting Chris Hill's successor.

Iraqi government formation period and summer transition

The Iraqi government formation process will move into full gear in late March, approximately two weeks after the March 7 elections when the official election results will be certified. Embassy Baghdad (with a large number of Arabic-speaking officers) and USF-I will work with Iraqi leaders to promote the formation of an inclusive cabinet that doesn't cross any U.S. red lines. I propose Washington staffing support for the field as follows:

In addition, of course, we would have Washington phone calls, strategic communications messaging, diplomatic outreach to Iraq's neighbors and beyond, and VIP visits to help with the government formation process. But I have concentrated on what we would do to augment staffing in the field in ways that I hope will bolster Washington confidence in our efforts.

Chris Hill's successor

Given your meeting tomorrow with the Vice President where Iraq staffing may come up, I wanted to send you these thoughts quickly. With the exception of NEA PDAS Ron Schlicher, I have not had the opportunity to talk to Bill Burns or others about these ideas.

-- Jeff Jeffrey Feltman Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State 202-647-7209

subject: AAR
text:
She painted a very positive portrait of the trip, and said that nothing knocked you off stride, you stayed focused.

I'm just reading the clips now and the wrap up pieces are uniformly terrific. Might have been unorthodox, but you certainly raised the awareness in the US about Africa. The debate over the legitimacy of covering your town hall remarks all come with a heavy dose of the depravity occurring there. So there's a silver lining as people talk about something they otherwise wouldn't - irrespective of what triggered the conversation.

Colleagues —

The President has decided to nominate Jack Lew, currently the Deputy Secretary of State, to be the next OMB Director.

Like many of you, I have known Jack for many years and value his counsel and friendship.

With his experience, mastery of the budget process, and passion for public service, Jack Lew is an individual especially qualified to serve the President and the American people during these challenging economic and fiscal times.

Moreover, Jack is someone who knows OMB inside and out, having served as a PAD, EAD, Deputy Director, and Director. There are few people in Washington with his experience here and commitment to this organization.

I congratulate Jack on his nomination, and will do what I can to support him, the economic team, and the President as they work to put our country on a sustainable fiscal path. And while I will be leaving OMB at the end of the month, I do so confident that the agency is in good hands.

All the best,

Peter

Should I be flattered? Even a little bit? And, as for my alibi, well, let's just say it depends on the snow and the secret service. So, subject to cross for sure. Do you think there could be copycats? Do you think the guy chose that mask or just picked up the nearest one? Please keep me informed as the case unfolds--

On another matter, can you believe Dan Burton will be the chair of one of the House subcommittees we'll have to deal w? Irony and satire are the only sane responses.

Happy New Year--and here's hoping for many more stories that make us laugh!

Dear Secretary Clinton,

I am writing this note as I head for O'Hare en route to Israel-Palestine. For ten days I'll be with a small group of women to meet with both Israeli and Palestinian human rights and peace activists, with a focus on the work of women. Many things about Israel-Palestine make me very discouraged now, but I am always encouraged when I mingle with the grassroots lovers of peace and people—be they Christians, Muslims, or Jews. At those time I feel as if I have been gifted with a glimpse into God's Kingdom. So I am looking forward to this week.

The main point of this note is to offer my sympathy regarding your mother's death.

Please, Hillary, don't hesitate to ask if there is ever anything I can do for you.

For peace... Lynne

Lynne Hybels Willow Creek Community Church

subject: Attachments:
text:
Jake, I've made the point that the freely associated state of Palau votes with the US in the UN more than any General Assembly Member. Attached is a memo distilled from the annual State Dept. report on UN voting during 2009 substantiating this. Palau voted with the US 100% in the 12 key votes, more than any other nation. The issues concerned Cuba, Israel and other Middle Eastern matters, human rights, and nuclear proliferation. In 2008, the two nations that voted with the U.S. more than any other UN Member were Palau and Israel.

Happy New Year! Jeff

Jeffrey L. Farrow

subject: CIV Update: 3/24
text:
Today's highlights:

- CEP spokesperson held a press conference today at the CTV: no information unknown to us was presented, but it was a positive step towards having more transparency for the public

- one possible concern given the current backlog is that results would not be ready by march 31, unless one of 2 things happen: 1. the threshold is raised to reduce the number of PVs needing legal review 2. the legal unit's review capacity is increased. Given the lawyers are already working at high capacity, the only way to do this is by having more lawyers. We understand meetings were held at the CEP today to find ways of addressing this issue.

-we have observed differences in the quality and efficiency of the lawyers' review. Some are faster and more thorough than others. Overall, all are getting tired and it is being noticed in their work.

Best, SK

subject: Irish Times: North's leaders clash on devolution
text:
See the story below. Consensus recommendation is that you call PR and MM tomorrow or Wednesday. Because we expect them both to go to the press after they speak with you, we believe it would be best for you to keep the calls at a very high level. Essentially:

O Two months have passed since your trip to Belfast and you're checking in; • You're concerned about the news reports; O You understand that there are substantive differences and frayed nerves, but you want to encourage all parties

to take positive actions and avoid unhelpful ones; • You remain prepared to assist in any way — you are personally invested in seeing them work through to the

completion of this process; • Declan is hard at work, but his efforts are hampered by the lack of progress and the public conflict

You would be mostly in listening mode and wouldn't engage substantively on the issues that are dividing them — parades (Sinn Fein doesn't want to concede anything on parades without a date for devolution) and a date (DUP doesn't want to set a date until they get progress on parades).

If you're amenable, we-can move forward and schedule the calls.

Thanks, Jake

subject: Meeting With Bangladesh Foreign Minister on Sept 16
text:
Dear Melanne:

Greetings from Bangladesh!!!

Bangladesh Foreign Minister Ms Dipu Moni will call on Secretary Clinton on September 16 to discuss the details of the visit of Bangladesh Prime Minister Ms Hasina Wazed to the USA during the UN General Assembly meeting. Please see if the issues of Grameen Bank can be raised in a friendly way.

I sought an appointment with the Prime Minister to brief her on our problems, at the advice of the US ambassador in Dhaka. But it is now over six weeks, her office never responded.

Almost every important person in Bangladesh congratulated me for receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Prime Minister and her party said not a word about it.

So you can see the depth of the problem.

I thought I should keep you briefed and let you figure out what to be done.

Thanks for your help. Give my regards to H.

Cheryl I understand from Susan that you and she both received word that a decision has finally been made. We have gotten cleared around the building this evening a package with terrific help from 10 and DRL of a press statement, talking points and a cable notifying posts of the decision. NSC has cleared as well. We will not launch until tomorrow at 2:00. As part of the launch plan NSC has asked that we use quotes from Secretary Clinton and Ambassador Rice in the press statement. We would like to work with whoever is appropriate (Jake and Robert?) traveling with the Secretary to get a one sentence quote for the statement. Jennifer Simon on our staff will email you the draft statement shortly. Please let us know with whom we should follow up as we want to ensure we preserve the close hold nature of this process. Thanks - Erica (P.S. Ops has left a message for you as well from me - this is the topic - feel free to call anytime if you'd prefer discussing).

subject: The Hamburgs
text:
I had a longtime postponed lunch with Betty and David. He was remembering his briefing with you at Blair House before you were to officially become FL. He said after all the talk about what could be done for kids, he remembers telling you as he was leaving that you could you make a real contribution on the international stage and he hoped that you would consider doing so.

He would like to be helpful. He's done a lot of work on preventive diplomacy which he feels is too often overlooked and extremely essential.

subject: #s
text:
No, it's only an internal assessment from someone in the Iran Watch Office. Kay added me to their updates so I'm seeing their internal chit chat.

I have to admit I don't understand statistics enough to gauge it's accuracy, but they are trying to prove the accusation of egregious fraud. The only other #s are actual vote tallies coming from the Iranian Interior Ministry, showing Mousavi winning by far - but the #s are unconfirmed.

Since it's after 4am in Tehran, most of the reporting now is focusing on tumult

Nothing is coming from State publicly aside from what you said this afternoon.

subject: Burmese Minister of Health
text:
Cheryl:

Quick thought:

I just wanted your read on whether 'S' would want me to mobilize PEPFAR resources to begin a process to develop a more robust response to HIV/TB in Burma. It is a country that has not mapped out its dual epidemics and has depended solely on NGO's (#3) to be their total response as a result the unmet need is undefined and large. (I did some work for Clinton Foundation in northern Burma in 2003-2006 that brought 100 kids and 650 adults onto treatment). I am sensitive to not overwhelm or confound the maturation of the newly forming leadership. Derek Mitchell and I have met and discussed the potential role PEPFAR could/would play should we decide to engage. I am in the middle of budget decisions for next year so it would be good to know S's desire.

E

subject: Haiti Conference Call.
text:
Dear Margo,

I am writing you on behalf of Cristina Barrios, the Spanish Special Ambassador for the Reconstruction of Haiti. She participated yesterday in the Conference Call on behalf of Spain.

We were told to send you Ms. Barrios contact details so that we can be included in the distribution lists for the Conference call and the other preparations, and then be able to receive the different documents, plans, templates, etc. that are being distributed to all the participants. In particular, the WB MDTF-related documentation as well as templates for the different outreach meetings and whatever items everybody else is receiving. These are her contact details:

Ms. Cristina Barrios, Special Ambassador for the Reconstruction of Haiti Spain

We look forward to receiving the Agenda for Feb. 25th at 1600 (European time) and any related documents to be distributed.

Felix Fernandez-Shaw CODEV-REPER UE- Espatia

This may be a crazy idea, but as far as we can tell we need ideas. Suppose we launched a "Pledge for Palestine" campaign that copies Warren Buffet's "The Giving Pledge" campaign, described below — he's trying to get 40 billionaires to give away most of their money. I had asked some S/P folks to think about how we might take that campaign global to help change the attitudes of elites in places like Pakistan and Latin America, but perhaps Warren Buffet could be convinced to lend his name — or perhaps Michael Bloomberg or Danny Abraham (together with a very wealthy Muslim) to a similar Pledge for Palestine campaign. Such a campaign among billionaires/multi-millionaires around the world would reflect a strong vote of confidence in the building of a Palestinian state and could offset the ending of the moratorium for Palestinians (there would also be a certain shaming effect re Israelis, who would be building settlements in the face of a pledge for peace). With even 30 calls to the right people in the Clinton fundraising network it should be possible to generate a substantial enough amount quickly enough to capture the public imagination on the heels of the President's speech and, critically, to serve as an expression of global solidarity with the Palestinians and but also a meaningful promise of material improvements for Palestinians on the West Bank. That could significantly bolster Abbas in a way that could help him stay in the talks. This is what diplomacy beyond the state should mean.

A brief description of the Buffett campaign is below; a longer description with the people Buffett has approached is attached.

AM

subject: Kindles and State
text:
Hillary,

Sorry to bug you about this, but I learned today in a book industry bldg about State's partnership with Amazon for Kindles for embassies. I am sure there are great benefits to this program, but someday (maybe soon?) I'd love to chat with you about why this news is so distressing to independent booksellers across the country. Brad and I appreciate very deeply that you are a stalwart and steadfast champion of stores like Politics & Prose and all that they represent to their communities and to promoting an informed and engaged citizenry. But right now, Indies are in a battle for survival due in large part to the monopolistic and predatory business practices of Amazon and the uneven playing field on which we are forced to compete. I can't convey the scope and depth of this issue -- or the emotion attached to it -- in one email. But I really hope we can discuss it sometime.

On a related note, let me know when you're ready for some more book suggestions. Did you ever read God's Hotel, the book that Becky edited by the doctor working at Laguna Honda in SF? It's a must read for you. If you don't still have the galley, I'll send a hard copy over to you.

X0X0

Lissa

subject: Special Envoy Richardson
text:
Ambassador —

Pursuant to our conversation, it seems we have concurrence that we respond to the HFAC staff query (below) via telephone call which I would be pleased to make. (H also agrees it would be best to respond with a call.) Following are talking points for your review and approval:

• Secretary General Insulza's designation and announcement of Gov. Bill Richardson as a special envoy for the OAS was made without any consultation with or consent of the U.S. Mission to the OAS or the Department. In fact, we first heard of the announcement through press reports.

• Upon hearing the news, Ambassador Lomellin immediately raised concern with the Secretary General and expressed our displeasure, as he should have consulted with the USG before making this appointment. We specifically expressed concern that the Governor's views might be misconstrued as representing official U.S. policy, and in particular on the very sensitive issue of U.S.-Cuba policy. Insulza committed that it would not occur.

• Gov. Richardson is a private citizen and his views in no way represent U.S. foreign policy.

• We remain concerned with the implications of this designation in potentially misrepresenting the views of the , U.S. and the Organization of American States, and intend to raise the matter again with Insulza in light of Gov. Richardson's remarks at Brookings on U.S.-Cuba policy.

• It is not a paid position.

Please advise how you wish to proceed. Thanks.

Fernando

Fernando D. Rojas Alternate Representative U.S. Permanent Mission to the Organization of American States U.S. Department of State 2201 C Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20520 (202) 647-9482

subject: As you depart...
text:
Huma:

Happy New Year! As you board the plane and prepare to depart, please know that we are deeply grateful for the tremendous effort that you have made to allow the Secretary to participate in Brazil's historic inauguration.

The press here has focused intently on the Secretary's decision to participate, and has given prominent play to the statements that have come out of the White House and the Department describing the importance of our bilateral relationship. The Foreign Ministry and Dilma's transition team have given a very positive spin to the Secretary's role in the inauguration, and made clear that she is very welcome. Among the general public, the news has provoked a deep sigh of relief and is seen as evidence of our willingness to work with the new President and overcome the recent problems that have complicated our relationship.

When the Secretary arrives, she will also find a collection of heads of state looking to have a word with her. The format in PlanaIto will allow this to take place during the ceremony and immediately afterwards. In particular, Colombian President Santos has asked to speak with the Secretary. Also, last night the Peruvian ambassador told me that President Garcia will go to PlanaIto to speak with her. I am sure others will line up to greet her.

The Brazilians have worked hard to meet our logistical and security requirements, and the movements today should be smooth. Of course, if you can convince the pilots to fly fast and get here early it will be better for everyone.

Again, thanks for your great help. Your effort, and the Secretary's incredible stamina and willingness to go the extra mile (or extra 4,000 miles), will pay big dividends.

Regards, Tom

Was just contacted by Amb Goiii. President Bachelet eager to welcome the Secretary in Santiago on Tuesday morning for a working meeting. This can take place at airport--- at facilities that the Chilean air-force has that were not damaged (Grupo 10). President will describe damage and efforts Chileans making to address challenges. She would be accompanied by some of her ministers. Would be followed by press conference (that will have wide international coverage). S could then meet w Pifiera for another working meeting---scheduled after a short break--that would also focus on US Chile relations moving forward.

Deliverables: Pres Bachelet wondering if US could offer a field hospital-- would be used in areas where hospitals have been evacuated-- and to attend the many injured. No need for now of search and rescue teams.

subject: OPIC's Franchise Facility for Tunisia
text:
Dear Secretary Clinton, At your Deputies meeting earlier this week you asked about the status of the Enterprise Funds in Tunisia. I thought you would appreciate an update on OPIC's Franchise Facility for Tunisia, which OPIC initiated in response to your announcement that OPIC would provide $2 billion dollars for private investments in the Middle East and North Africa.

Since then, we have been working closely with the State Department, USAID, the Middle East Investment Initiative (MEII) and Shore Bank International (SBI), to establish a $50 million franchisee lending program in Tunisia. Last week, OPIC and USAID signed an MOU which will provide $1 million in grant assistance today and $4 million in subsequent years to cover operating expenses for MEII/SBI, OPIC's implementing partners in Tunis. Through MEII and SBI, OPIC will provide $50 mill in loan guarantees and technical assistance to local financial institutions, which will lend working capital to Tunisian franchisees interested in partnering with American, European and Tunisian franchisors. We will soon be disbursing to MEII/SBI for them to begin the diagnostics on the local banks for the facility.

As I have said about a number of recent projects, this facility would not have been possible without the keen support of the State Department and USAID, whose staff were a key part of getting this project done. This is yet another example to add to your list of U.S. development agencies combining forces quickly and effectively to advance the U.S. foreign policy and development agenda.

This facility will help small, local entrepreneurs bring new American franchises to Tunisia, and I am proud that OPIC, State and USAID have pulled this together after you called on us to support the MENA region.

Best,

Elizabeth

Elizabeth L. Littlefield President & CEO Overseas Private Investment Corporation

subject: Israeli demarche on Jerusalem statements
text:
Israeli Ambassador Michael Oren called me today to complain about our comments today on the Jerusalem housing evictions. Saying that he was calling under instructions, he made comments on three basic themes:

1) The evictions of the Palestinians in Sheikh Jarrah were purely a legal matter. These were illegal squatters. The case went all through the Israeli court system and was decided by the Supreme Court. This was not a provocation. If there was a provocation, it was when the illegal squatters stopped paying their rent.

2) Israel objects to the suggestion that this was a violation of the roadmap. Israel requests clarification of what part of the roadmap obligations the U.S. believes were violated.

3) Israel rejects the suggestion that the timing was connected to the Fatah Party Congress. There is no connection.

I undertook to convey the demarche and made our response about how this really is unhelpful, especially at this time.

Jeffrey Feltman Acting Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State

subject: Schedule
text:
I made a few changes to the line block yesterday so happy to send to you after I follow up on these items -- you will have meetings this week on Iran, Iraq and Non Pro with the Iran team tomorrow. - Hill is on Friday with the Iraq team -- you can see him privately either before or after. - Will move Holbrooke to 8am on Thursday. - Can I offer Collins, McCain, Graham and Lieberman Friday morning for a meeting? - Will follow up on Daalder, Kessler, Rahm and women's lunch/dinner.

Lona Valmoro Special Assistant to Secretary of State Hillary Clinton (202) 647-9071

subject: Jebali
text:
Jebali can speak at 2:30pm this afternoon.

We just received one change to the call sheet regarding the date of the FBI visit. It should say 1/17, not 1/15.

From NEA: In light of S call to Tunisian PM later today, wanted to ensure you were aware that the FBI trying to postpone Tripoli to 1/17 to accommodate the Libyan PM, who just scheduled a big visit to Qatar on 1/15 (the date of the originally planned visit).

This means FBI is trying to push Tunis back to 1/17 too-post is waiting to hear back from GOT.

I believe the call sheet still notes the orig 1/15 date for the visit.

subject: Problem...may need help from State
text:
As the attached indicates, Senator Lautenberg is holding up the Generalized Preferences bill that, if it expires, which it will on December 31 if it is not renewed early next week, 131 countries will see the tariffs on their imports to the US rise sharply and billions of dollars of their trade will be disrupted. The attached email from my counterpart at USTR describes the issue with Lautenberg. Ron Kirk would like the Secretary to'call Lautenberg ASAP to urge him to drop his hold and assure him that we are doing all we can to secure the release of Sean Goldman. If the hold continues, we face an enormous foreign policy and economic disaster with virtually all of the world's developing nations.

USTR is preparing additional talking points to the Secretary. Please let me know if she is willing to do this and if she needs additional information. Many thanks, Bob

subject: Mexico
text:
Cheryl: I don't want to presume anything, but I also don't want to leave a misimpression if other COM jobs are among the ideas. There were very specific reasons that I was enthusiastic about Mexico. The most important of those was how well I know Mexico after 8 years, and being so close by direct flight that even if my family stayed here, I could have seen them very often. There are obviously very few places similarly workable.

I just don't want people to go to trouble and then seem ungrateful if I can't take it. Thank you so much.

Steve—

I understand that plans are afoot to have EUR (Gordon) and SRMC (Pandith) lead the session on CVE at the Chiefs of Mission conference. We find this deeply problematic. S/CT has both the Department and interagency acknowledged lead on CVE. We have by far the most CVE activity going on at State, including a wide range of analytic and programmatic work. When it came to briefing the President on the Secretary's plan for Strategic Counterterrorism, a central component of which involves CVE, she asked me to do the presentation. We represent the Department regularly at the Tuesday WHSR meetings with the President, where we update him on, among other things, CVE; I am slated to be the deputy chair of the CSCC, which is perhaps the Department's foremost major CVE initiative this year.

S/CT has also spearheaded the effort to create a Department-wide CVE community of interest and convened the Administration's first interagency summit on the subject. In the context of our RSI meetings with posts in key regions, we have been working to motivate our ambassadors to innovate in this area. We have run three major international conferences in little more than a year on the subject. We are creating the Global Counterterrorism Forum, one of whose key working groups will be on CVE. Moreover, as I've discussed with both Cheryl and Jake, the transformation of S/CT from its current state to a full-fledged bureau, as envisioned in the QDDR, will center on the role we are developing in CVE and capacity building.

Dear Dr. Ballard:

We understand that the Government of Turkey has requested your assistance in the search for the Turkish Air Force RF-4 that was brought down off the coast of Syria on June 22.

As we have previously discussed, the United States supports the Turkish Government's determination to find its lost pilots and the wreckage of the Turkish aircraft. We wish to facilitate Turkish operations toward that purpose by any appropriate means. As Secretary Clinton said on June 24 we stand in solidarity with the Turkish people after the terrible loss of their pilots, and we lend our strong support to the Turkish government in this matter.

We recognize and respect that the EN Nautilus is a privately-owned and operated vessel registered outside the United States, and that its management will take its own decisions with respect to any contractual services it may undertake with the Government of Turkey. Nonetheless, we greatly appreciate your offer to the Government of Turkey to support its search operations.

Spoke to both Condi Rice and Jim Baker this afternoon re START op-ed. Condi said she plans her own op-ed, arguing in favor of treaty ratification, due out in next few days. She asked that I tell the Secretary again that she'll be supportive.

Baker said he agreed that things were breaking the right way on the Hill, and shared the view that ratification before the holidays is an increasing possibility. He was glad to have done the op-ed (even while complaining mildly about how much effort it took to "herd the cats" to get it out), and hopeful of its effect.

Bill

subject: ellen's meeting with SEc. Clinton Importance: High
text:
Dear Melanne: As you know, President Sirleaf and Sec. Clinton are meeting on Friday morning of this week.

A key point which Ellen will propose is the creation of a US-Liberian Bi-national Commission to institutionalize the gains in Liberia and ensure that the partnership endures well beyond the present administrations in the US and in Liberia. Such a proposal would allow the priorities (from AFRICOM to food security, MCC) to be categorized, charted, reported on and measured for success.

The Commission would oblige regular meetings and require constant high-level US engagement. Other areas of common concern and shared responsibility such as governance, energy, regional security could be incorporated into such a framework.

The US-Nigerian Bi-national Commission inaugurated in 2010 by Sec. Clinton is a model for consideration.

Given the anticipated departure of Sec. Clinton from the State department, regardless of the outcome of the US election in November, we would trust she would be supportive of such a superstructure to preserve and protect Liberia's future.

The second point, I want to signal is that Ellen would like a few minutes alone with Hillary at the meeting. Many thanks, Debbie

Hi, Alice. This appears to be a case of mistaken identity. The Saudi Press Agency reported yesterday that Prince Khalid bin Abdullah bin Saud al-Saud (the grandson of former King Saud and NOT/NOT a son of King Abdullah) had died over the weekend (http://www.spa.gov.sa/english/details.php?id=901305). According to the report, Prince Sattam led funeral prayers on Friday.

We have little information re. Prince Khalid aside from his having had some business interests and not appearing to have been involved in government or politics; his two brothers were air force pilots. We understand he was not close to the King, and we are not planning to send a condolence letter.

Regards, Glen Keiser, acting DCM

Updates

1. WFP: I sent you traffic on where we are; b/I, we will run a process,

2. India:

4. IHRC Comment Clean-Up: Rouzier (PM-designee) cleaned up his comment (albeit imperfectly), which was reported as changing/softening/correcting his comments. This unfortunately created tension w/Martelly who was apparently deeply unhappy about his remarks. Am headed to Haiti wed/thur and will meet w/ both. Intl partners quite unhappy b/c from their view, GoH can't coord donors so they don't understand what is positioning of new admin so next IHRC mtg will likely be interesting.

5. My memo to you is late but still coming, along w/some other draft material for you to give some early directional guidance.

6. Still working on

8. Rest this weekend!

Cdm

Cheryl: I have an excellent relationship with Senator Coons, brief him at least once a month on key issues, and do not understand why (if the attached email is accurate) he would say/suggest I or someone in the Bureau did not inform him about the Secretary's trip. Checking my records, I met last met with Senator Coons on May 17th in his office. At that time I briefed him on his forthcoming trip to Ghana, Benin and Abuja over the Memorial Day recess.

I remember telling him that the Secretary would be going to the AGOA Forum in Lusaka and to Tanzania and possibly several East other African countries. ( I was not specific about the other stops because they were still up In the air at the time.) Coons said the AGOA trip sounded interesting, but he was committed to traveling with Senator Johnny Isakson, the Chairman of the Senate's Africa Subcommittee, who has also been very supportive our policies. I also mentioned the prospects of the First Lady's trip in broad strokes.) The AF legislative officer also calls on Senator Coon's staff at least two or three times a month. Since Senator Coon's return from Africa, his staff has called to express his sincere appreciation for the outstanding support he received from our embassies and the Bureau. I intend to give Coons a back brief on the Secretary's trip and will make sure he feels our love. Johnnie

On the reunion, I wouldn't be able to do it anything til the spring because my house is small and I need the backyard. I obviously won't do it if you think it's a bad idea or would reflect badly.

But I did response for ABC News to the Republican debate last Sat night, and it just reminded me of the fact that you kicked ass in the debates and more broadly, we had a campaign that changed the country. Just thinking about NH - I mean that was historic. And at least for me, though it's taken a long time, the pain is over and I can feel pride in what we did. And I feel like if we don't take some pride in it, then it paints the whole thing as negative, when it wasn't.

I wouldn't impinge on your schedule to come. And I can see how that would create problems for you. And look, I'd be happy to take the heat. I deal w Plouffe and all these characters regularly, I know what they'll think. I'm happy to say what this is and what it isn't. But people are thinking about 4 yrs ago now because of the Rep primary - so I hate to wait til after the election. But I of course will if you prefer.

Anyway, it was great to see you. I can only imagine how exhausted you must be (now that I travel so much more for fundraising, I'm perennially exhausted!) and yet you find time to come to things like tonight - I always admire your generosity.

Merry Christmas Hillary.

Neera

subject: TFTP
text:
I hadn't heard that! As a Minnesotan, I'm offended.

Treasury is on the ground in Strasbourg (apparently your co-signed letter to Buzek really got Geithner's head in the game, so Treasury is now actively engaged). Our European ambassadors and DCMs are calling parliamentarians across Europe. Bill Kennard and Phil and his team are working the EP crowd.

Apparently late in the evening Brussels time the sponsor of the bill offered a deal to postpone until June, but EUR says we are by no means out of the woods yet.

Hopefully by 9 am our time tomorrow we'll have a better sense of the vote count. EUR will make further recommendations on your engagement tomorrow.

Hello - thanks for your message!

For Mon 10/18 the thought is to do Julia Roberts not too late in the day. and the lunch at 1 pm - the idea is to make space for Julia by moving your 9:45 am Monday departmental meeting to 9:45 am on Tuesday 10/19.

I checked with POTUS' schedulers about Fri 10/15 - unfortunately he is traveling that day. However, we do have a meeting locked in for Wed 10/20 at 10:30 am.

Understand you want your own pre-brief on Wed 10/20 before the Kissinger Event

No PC has been called yet for Wed 10/20 - though if they do call one during the normal 5 pm slot, that will indeed present a conflict with the Kissinger event. I've will ask for guidance about what we can expect w/Donilon now in charge...both in terms of PCs and whether he intends to continue the small group meetings with you and Gates.

Will check about Adm Mullen's dinner and if it is on Thurs 10/21, whether you can make it back in time.

Re the possibility of Raul Yzaguirre on Tues 10/26 - Sharon Hardy with Ceremonials relayed to Raul that we wanted to offer any date other than 10/21 that worked well for him. He came back with Mon 10/25...even though the Franklin Room is booked that evening. President WJC's schedule does have him coming back from Jamaica to DC on 10/26 - but that may be just because they were trying to match up RONs with you. Let me 1) double check w/WJC's office about where he'll be on 10/26 and 2) determine whether Tues 10/26 is an option for Raul Yzaguirre and/or the Council of La Raza folks

Will report back...happy to make any adjustments as you see fit...thank you again, Eric

...I miss you a lot. And I have no idea how you keep on keeping on doing whatever it takes to lift people-everywhere upchampioning your Core Purpose of Fighting and digging deep for the opportunity for each person to be able to live up to their God Given Potential. Here and Around the world.

The struggle for an Iran that is more concerned about its people than false power. The relentless quest to stabilize the un-stable. The never give up journey to inspire and empower women and young girls to have a seat at the table of full opportunity. The pursuit for opening doors of happiness for those who struggle with the unimaginable. The steady. The Steadfast. The unwavering commitment to the dream-not the hope-but the dream of a better USA and world for all. The tough and uncompromising "pretend leaders" whom you have negotiate with. The opinion rich and caring poor arrogance of the mean spirited. The stuff that is on the news but is not really the real news.

The love and respect you give freely to all whom love life and liberty and opportunity for all. The raw respect that you have earned in the trenches of real fears, real love and real longing for a village that is Dedicated to raising a village and its children.

So I say to a beloved and dear love one-that be you-I love you. I respect you. I miss you. I cherish every moment of our remarkable journey together.

God Speed. Dear Sis. We shall cross paths soon. And until then. Onward in all things. Love RS Ride at Dawn.

Following five days of high-level talks in Addis Ababa, the Government of Sudan and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement agreed to temporary political and security arrangements for the disputed Abyei Area. Under the terms of the agreement, which was brokered by the African Union with high-level interventions by Secretary of State Clinton, Special Envoy for Sudan Princeton Lyman, and others, the armed forces of both sides will withdraw beyond the boundaries of Abyei and an interim security force composed of one brigade of Ethiopian forces will deploy to Abyei under UN auspices to provide security, facilitate humanitarian assistance, and protect civilians. The Agreement also establishes an Abyei Area Administration composed jointly of Ngoc Dinka and Missiriya. The Administrator will be an SPLM nominee, and the Deputy Administrator will be a GoS nominee. The parties are expected to sign the agreement tomorrow morning, with Ethiopian forces expected to deploy to Abyei on or about June 25.

subject: Coordination Plan re Foreign Govts
text:
Cheryl;

Let me know if you are okay with process set forth below.

Also, as for Mexican kitchens, the offer was made to NorthCom and they have not/not rejected it. NorthCom is considering the offer and evaluating whether they can transport the kitchens because MX did not offer means of transport. They need a c-17 to make this work. NorthCom is going to get back to me with more info re accommodating offer tomorrow.

Related to the Northcom inquiry, once we get foreign govt process set, I can inform all relevant agencies with the ask that they send all inquiries/offers from foreign govts to us at State (for example, NorthCom offer).

I also include Jake here because S queried him abt the kitchens tomorrow.

Julissa

Happy Birthday!

I have to head to NY very early in the morning and wanted to wish you a Happy Birthday and a successful and safe trip to Pakistan. It is clearly one of the most important missions you've ever embarked on --- and there have been many.

We had a good gathering at the Mahmood's for the new foundation. Holbrooke was in good form. I think the discussion went a long way to persuading some of the skeptics that it was important to get the foundation off the ground and to sustain it over the years to come. I'm going to meet with some of the women as a follow up. Some have projects that they are already supporting; others feel we (AID) doesn't listen to advice on the ground, etc, etc. It can't hurt and may even help!

Whitney told me she talked to you about the Women's Fund. Yes, we are planning to have DRC be one of the key areas to target support.

As they say in Ukraine, "mnohaya lita" -- wishing you many years to come!

subject: State of USAID
text:
While this email is somewhat amazing in that someone actually sent this to me, I really believe our overall narrative lacks credibility and do believe the qddr will need be a key document in terms of trying to win over the building.

I don't place too much stock in this one email but I do believe I need your help and commitment to my leadership and the credibility of my overall narrative to be successful on behalf of the secretary.

Usaid and development should be a major part of her legacy and I feel I can deliver that but I need your help on the initiatives in particular because so much of my personal credibility rests on those.

Thanks for your help and support. Jeanne and I had a very long but helpful talk today.

For everyone one of these totally crazy emails/people there are 100 moderate people that we need to win over - and they are watching with skepticism right now.

In the meantime I am going to use this email as a teaching moment but I am not sure how - stay tuned...

Raj

subject: Calls
text:
Got it. Here is the list that I have. Do you want to do any of these?

1. Ban Ki-Moon reached out to you on Wednesday evening while you were on the plane.

2. We reached out to Fabius, Westerwelle, Blair and Hague on Wednesday and you spoke with all except for Hague. Not sure if you still wanted to speak with him.

3. HBJ called for you on 11/18 (after the call where you couldn't hear him). You tried him in the car on the way to dinner w the PM of Thailand but did not get through.

4. We've been asked by the desk to hold off on the Jebali call. Since the request has been made, the situation has evolved and the GOT is cooperating. The desk has said that they will keep your office updated on the situation.

Thanks to Jim Timbie's expert hand - and pending our ability to memorialize in writing a portion of the briefing we just concluded with Kyl staffer Tim Morrison - we have been informed that Senator Kyl is prepared to lift his hold on Bill's nomination.

Tim also tells me that Kyl is the last hold left on Bill (and I suspect he would know).

I have already been in touch with Reid's floor staff. The Senate will be in late tonight and apparently over the weekend. They know we're eager to move.

Bill, please be on the look out for the text Jim is going to circulate shortly. I suspect we'll need a fast clearance from several folks.

Thanks.

Miguel E. Rodriguez

subject: Fw: H: Intel: Egypt military v. Germany & Merkel
text:
A few things:

1. We've just finished editing the strategic posture diplomatic and public guidance, to address especially European sensitivities. This will launch Wednesday. May need you to take up with Tom and Panetta tomorrow.

2. Ross talked to Molho and got much the same message - they want to keep this alive (Ross said Molho is more concerned about the consequences of breakdown than he's ever seen him) but don't want any political pain. Meanwhile, Erekat has been making a variety of unhelpful comments.

3. News from Burma not great - looks like they will reduce sentences but not free prisoners.

4. Everyone is expecting the Iranians to make a pitch for renewed 5+1 talks, and much work with Euros to coordinate message, but no movement yet.

5. There are news accounts of a meeting among ACt, HQN, and the Afghan and Pakistani Taliban, in which the pitch was made for everyone to focus on American/coalition forces and not (in the case of the Pakistani Taliban) on Pakistan. We're trying to figure it out.

That's about it for now.

As predicted. Ct. narrowly upholds. Still reading. L will send an info memo before the end of the day

But as we are seeing it right now, the money quote from the section on the mandate: "Our precedent demonstrates that Congress had the power to impose the exaction in Section 5000A under the taxing power, and that Section 5000A need not be read to do more than impose a tax. This is sufficient to sustain it."

0 Roberts, as predicted places himself as the swing vote and controls the outcome. J. Kennedy not the "decider" This is the narrowest ground to uphold, allows Congress to say the Administration has imposed a hidden tax (now open). This allows CJ Roberts to reserve the wisdom of doing this to "the People", and will allow him to be described in post-term commentary as "deft" in his management of both this case and Arizona immigration.

More to come Harold

Jeff believes it would be helpful. This is his assessment:

I've been in touch more or less continually with the Tunisian Ambassador here, who suddenly seems as though his own handcuffs have been at least loosened. He in turn is in touch with Morjane. I know they'd welcome a call. Their requests to us have to be handled carefully. They are trying to restore calm, which on the one hand is a good thing -- violent riots and looting aren't inherently good things, especially now that Ben All has left -- but on the other hand could be, if we're too aggressive, part of a campaign to establish "Ben Ali Lite." The "system" has an interest in self preservation (and I suspect Ben All left because the army and party bosses told him they were jettisoning him). We have an interest in opening up political space.

While the transfer of power to the Parliamentary Speaker puts the interim presidency in more of a gray bureaucrat cog in the system than the PM is, there is a real plus: it acknowledges Ben Ali ain't comin' back. (Constitutionally, the PM assumes the interim presidency for a temporary absence or incapacity, while the Speaker gets it for a permanent departure or incapacity.) We're working with Embassy Tunis on ideas. This is a real opportunity

subject: Bolivia
text: Apologies for not giving sufficient background on this. Morales and other Bolivian officials argue that Embassy staff urged the march organizers to initiate the protest march in order to destabilize the Morales government (something our chargé told the Acting Foreign Minister was patently absurd; all diplomatic missions have contact with all political actors for information, nothing more). Morales has played out his theory of US officials conspiring against him on a number of occasions, notably during the Sep 2008 unrest in the eastern lowlands. At that time Morales expelled Amb Goldberg for purportedly organizing that opposition effort. He almost immediately thereafter expelled DEA. Speciously suggesting a US hand in political unrest is a common Morales tactic to draw attention away from the dispute itself. Hope that helps. Roberta

subject: Zambia
text:
Just finished dinner with the African women entrepreneurs we brought to DC last AGOA. Tell HRC, they've decided to follow Zambia's lead and establish AWEP chapters in ALL their countries! The Zambian is so impressive and has had AWEP all over the news that the President of Zambia inquired about AWEP and just named her a commissioner on an economics related commission. Her name is Sylvia Banda.

As you may have heard from Mike, the FL couldn't cope with the prospect of no podium so we're accommodating her. HRC can use it or use hand mike. The women are beside themselves with expectation!

Safe travels!

subject: Update
text:
Some cats and dogs:

1. Talked to Denis about EU summit issue and Saakashvili. He said he would work both of them.

2. Hikers meeting was interesting and will fill you in Monday. Bottom line — we are actively working a number of the options, including the British option.

3. Saw Kurt this evening to discuss a potential Asia speech in Hawaii and he was focused on Jim again. I know you spoke with him and assume he gave you the same analysis.

4. Sent you updates on Libya — it played as we expected...a demand for a complete settlement freeze including •Jerusalem. Our press line will be to gloss over that and focus on the top line: We have Arab support for efforts to create conditions to continue the negotiations .... i.e., no collapse. You will receive tomorrow morning two Plan B documents, one from the Mitchell team and one from Dennis Ross.

Will continue to report this weekend.

subject: Russia non-paper
text:
Have been working it over with the team and there is some paralysis because of the uncertainty of what might happen tomorrow. But I will get you something soon, before dinner.

Jeff and Robert and Fred met with Bogdanov. As Lavrov has probably told you, they are eager to get a monitoring mission authorized by the UNSC, including using military observers from the Golan or the MFO or other places in the region.

For my money, I think a monitoring mission is not a bad idea. But we'll need to take real care with the shape and scope of a UNSC product — Susan's team is working with the Brits and French to be prepared for what the Russians might bring.

Guys — we just concluded ad ref agreement with the GoJ on a new five year Host Nation Support Agreement that will provide about $1.8 billion dollars a year in direct financial support for US forces stationed in Japan (total = around $9 billion over five years). There are substantial areas of restructuring and new resources devoted to energy efficiency and facilities improvement. It's a good deal for both sides

Everything will be ready for announcement by Potus-PM in Japan later this week. My office will be distributing details of the agreement and information for back grounding purposes. I will be in touch with Jeff and Danny on various points. We just came out of the final deliberations with GoJ and wanted to be sure that you all were informed.

Best, Kurt.

Dr. Kurt M. Campbell Assistant Secretary of State East Asian & Pacific Affairs

Good afternoon,

We've been on the same emails but I will e-introduce myself- my name is Erin Murphy and I am Ambassador Derek Mitchell's Special Assistant. Kate (cc'd) and I have been asked by Amb Mitchell to work on a tentative schedule for the Minister of Health's May visit to the U.S. I would like to reach out to you, as I understand JHU extended the invite, to see what type of program MU had in mind and if we could help input with ideas of our own. We were thinking of hospital visits, opportunity to engage with CDC and NIH, meet with medical students, public health NGOs, and USG officials here in Washington, Baltimore, and if possible, Boston.

Amb Mitchell will be traveling to the region in early March and would like to begin to socialize the Minister's program to the GOB and also to the USG. Thanks so much and I look forward to hearing from you.

Best,

subject: Thanks and results
text:
Cheryl and Jake,

I wanted to pass along my profound thanks for your support of this week's Civil Society Summit. The response has been extraordinary. The Summit as a whole generated 14.5 million Twitter impressions and was the top political Tweet of the day on Wednesday. The Town Hall was by far the largest broadcasting event in IIP's memory — three times bigger than the runner up. We've also received excellent reports from the many ambassadors and embassies that held viewing parties, superb reviews from civil society reps in scores of countries, and even strong praise from Members of Congress when I testified on the Hill yesterday. None of this would have been possible without your continuing support. Along with vast numbers of our friends in the non-governmental world, I am grateful.

Thanks and enjoy the weekend, Tomicah

I don't know how much we've done for burn centers. I know they're looking for resources always. Allyson would be the one or Sepidah.

However, that reminds me, we should mention that this is an issue that has enjoyed the collaboration of the private sector and individuals in the US who have come together through the US- Afghan Women's Council to work in tandem with USG to support Afghan women to meet their critical needs; for example by conducting training programs for businesswomen and NGO leaders, economic development projects and burn specialists, as a few examples. It's a good way to show public-private collaboration not just US public money.

After five hours of talk at Downing Street tonight, Thursday, October 8, Shaun Woodward tells me that it seems Gordon Brown has brokered a financial package with Peter Robinson and Martin McGuinness that may in turn break the deadlock on devolution of policing and justice. They have covered the major issues in stage two in their discussions. On Monday, Brown will formally set out the details in a letter to Robinson and McGuinness. Gordon will share these with you when you meet with him on Sunday at Chequers. Shaun says that both Robinson and McGuinness, subject to some minor details, should be in a position to recommend to Unionists and Nationalists that this is a strong deal. The letter will confirm the details.,

hope that's right.

Had dinner last night (Tuesday, February 16) with Joschka Fischer. We had an interesting conversation on Iran and Saudi Arabia, among other things. (As you know Fischer is now director of the Nabucco pipeline project.) On Iran, harsh, targeted sanctions are absolutely necessary, but are most effective diplomatically when always coupled with an offer to negotiate. The iron fist in the velvet glove approach achieves several objectives: According to Fischer's intelligence, Ahmanijehad wished some negotiated settlement but was blocked. The regime has splits at the top. Perhaps true, perhaps not. But constantly pushing negotiations alongside sanctions puts additional pressure on internal divisions, whatever they are. Extending an open hand while brandishing a stick closes diplomatic and political room to maneuver for Iran: Its refusal to accept the open hand justifies application of the stick. Even when sanctions are enforced it always remains useful to say another way is open. The damage done to Iran is therefore the result of its own choice. This approach also aids the opposition. A purely condign sanctions strategy can contribute to the regime's will to punish and tighten repression. Talking of regime change, of course, undermines the cause of regime change. It is a gift to the regime. The opposition is a new factor in the Iran equation that must be taken into account on the political and moral level. Pushed to the wall, the regime may feel compelled to repress, which might involve thousands or tens of thousands of political killings. On Saudi Arabia, Fischer points out that if Iran develops nuclear weaponry the Saudis already have their own bomb. The Saudis invested in Pakistan's nuclear weaponry partly for this eventuality; that's their bomb in reserve.

subject: Senator Mitchell/Henry Kissinger
text:
Huma, Jake, Joe, S Specials -Two things that might be of interest to S:

1) I had a long secure call with Senator Mitchell this morning. He will be preparing a written report with recommendations to convey to her at the beginning of the week. But he's had a difficult series of meetings. I can brief her if she likes.

2) Henry Kissinger has asked to speak to me this morning. (Not me personally -- the NEA Assistant Secretary; he doesn't know me from Adam.) Netanyahu is calling him at 10 a.m., so he asked to speak to me at 9 a.m. Kissinger does not know the subject of the Netanyahu call. I talked with Senator Mitchell about this, to see what might be useful for Kissinger to say to Netanyahu.

Jeffrey Feltman

Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State

Dear Cheryl and Jake,

I wanted to let you know that after a great deal of soul-searching, I have decided to leave the State Department in about a month.

This was an exceptionally difficult decision; one of the most difficult I have made in my life. It has been a honor and a real joy to have been part of the team here at State; the past year has been one of the most enriching experiences of my career. I am leaving only for personal reasons; after pushing myself as hard as I possibly could the last several years, I need to do this for myself, to spend some time away from work with my family and friends and reenergize.

Thank you once again for the remarkable opportunity to serve our country and work for the Secretary. This has been a rare privilege, and I cannot stress enough how appreciative I am. I hold the entire team here in the highest possible regard.

subject: ICC
text:
Jake — We may be headed to a vote more quickly than I thought. They are back in chambers now. Brazilians right now appear to be giving up and letting us keep in the language we insisted on that states that are not party to the ICC having sole jurisdiction over their citizens. The only real question is China and India, and the Libyan PR's letter today explicitly asking for the ICC referral may mean that the direct referral remains in place. One potential compromise that has been floated is an automatic referral on March 15 unless the UNSC votes otherwise.

I wanted to triple check that HRC is OK with this as we may be voting within the next 45 minutes. I tried to call you and left a msg as well. — Erica

subject: (AP) Brazil Supreme Court action delays return of 9-year-old boy to his U.S. father.
text:
Colleagues, for your information:

The AP reports Thursday's ruling by Justice Marco Aurelio Mello is the result of a petition by the boy's Brazilian family that he remain in Brazil until the court decides whether the boy's own testimony should be heard in the case. The ruling suspends a Wednesday judgment by a lower court ordering that David Goldman be given custody of his son, Sean. Because the Court goes into recess tomorrow, a ruling on whether the boy's testimony should be heard is not likely before February. Media report the boy is expected to remain in Brazil at least until then.

Regards, H.

Hugo Rodriguez Senior Watch Officer State Department Operations Center 202-647-1512

HDR: the email below from Ann Deuel just breaks my heart. Our association with Ann and Jamal Place started in 1995 when she called me asking to invite you and WJC during the '96 convention to attend an ice cream social for Jamal Place. Maggie and I actually visited the then very new Jamal Place and decided it was too small for your visit; however, our involvement: Kathy Burgess, Ernie and Katie Ricketts and so many other friends only increased with time. Department of Human Services and general revenue funding cuts have been brutal and, I guess, inevitable given the present budget problems (a mild term) in Illinois. Hope you are well,

B

Betsy Ebeling Illinois Department of Human Rights 100 W. Randolph Street Suite 10-100 Chicago, Illinois 60601

subject: Feierstein
text:
Jake, the "March of Life from Taiz to Sanaa (Dec. 18 to 24) was the genesis of this. It was an Isiah-supported march, and many viewed Isiah as seeking to undermine the transition. Marchers called for the prosecution of Saleh and his allies, for example. Prime Minister Basindwa views continued demonstrations by the opposition as a real thorn in his side. The opposition is supposed to be a part of government now.

Making the whole thing worse, security forces allied to Saleh actually did wind up killing 13 demonstrators after the march arrived in the capital.

Isiah then called for today to be the "Friday Against the American Ambassador." But Isiah did not prevail and another theme was chosen.

As you may have seen, I spoke to him today. Tomorrow, if she agrees, I think S should encourage him to come here (and share my fun!). He is not perceived as anti-Shia. He is running to be president of Egypt, meaning he's neither going to want to have bad relations with the GCC nor going to want to be seen as selling out another country's revolution. And whatever else he may be, he's smart. I'd love to be working with him here right now. S can remind him that he and I worked well together on Lebanon, and encourage him to come here while I'm still here. I also think the more non-GCC visitors we can get here, the better behaved the Bahrainis (and Saudis) will have to be. Jeffrey Feltman

subject: Norway
text:
Madame Secretary

Our office has forwarded to your specials some cookstove talking points to include in your briefing materials for your upcoming trip to Norway, but I wanted to emphasize the importance of this opportunity. Norway is the biggest opportunity to put the cookstove alliance into overdrive.

In your conversation with FM Store nearly two years ago, he noted that their initial $500k commitment was to be a "down payment" once the Alliance had a strategy in place. We now have that. The Alliance has been seeking a major commitment from Norway - on the scale of a five years, $50M commitment. Your mention of the progress the Alliance has made in your meetings w PM Stoltenberg and FM Store could prove crucial in making these commitments happen.

This is the Alliance's highest priority request of you this year. Norway would be second only to the US in commitments.

Radha Muthiah, the Exec Director of the Alliance and I would be happy to go to Norway and give them the details of our long term strategy.

Thank you very much for your support on this effort.

Kris

Jake,

FYI since you're at the G-8 and this may come up.

Most models predict that the earthquake will shave about 3 percentage points from Japan's GDP with the biggest impact being in the April - June timeframe. However, the reconstruction efforts associated with recovery will likely off-set this loss in the latter half of the year. Clearly, if the nuclear issue becomes worse these models will need to be updated. The Nikkei fell by about 6.2 percent today, the largest drop since Lehman's insolvency in 2008. The BOJ injected a record 10 trillion Yen (-$200 billion USD) into the markets yesterday to maintain solvency. The Yen dropped below 81 to the USD and is currently at about 82. There are questions about what impact this move will have on the global financial markets.

Nirav

Nirav S. Patel Senior Adviser Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs U.S. Department of State (o) 202.647.4612

Lauren/Cheryl, And--Please let Hillary know that I have invited Australian Foreign Minister Kevin Rudd to speak at Occidental in the coming year--on China or whatever topic he pleases. His chief of staff Philip Green has responded with some interest, and the Australian CG in LA is very excited to make it happen. Consulate here has invited me to speak at conference in January in LA on the US and Australia in Asia, and I have accepted (a good topic too if embassy Canberra wanted to invite me down as PD speaker). It would be helpful, if Hillary can work it in to her informal time with Rudd to mention me and Oxy in a favorable way and encourage him to accept the invitation to speak on our campus. I'd certainly appreciate it. Thanks as ever, Derek I just saw the news reports on the program that Hillary will be doing with young Australians in Melbourne o Sunday. Looks great. And perhaps she will get to meet my friend Glyn Davis, head of University of Melbourne on margins of event.

Madam Secretary,

The outpouring of condolences from the international community and the Afghans for Richard's passing has been extraordinary. We have had a steady flow of visitors from the NATO and diplomatic community and, most importantly, Afghans of every walk of life for several days who have come to sign the condolence book.

Today, during my weekly meeting with President Karzai, I took along the condolence book to be signed at the Palace. President Karzai signed and wrote a nice tribute to Richard and graciously allowed us to bring an Embassy photographer to memorialize the occasion. A photograph is attached. We will separately arrange for a copy to be signed by President Karzai for Kati.

Separately, I would ask that you thank Mike Mullen for permitting the USO show with which he is traveling to stage an unprecedented performance at the U.S. Embassy today. Allowing Embassy Kabul to be the site of a USO show in Afghanistan was very gracious of Mike as normally USO shows are only held at military bases. We had an extraordinary turnout of our civilian and military team from all over Kabul gathered today to see Robin Williams and other entertainers. Mike remains a real champion of our civil-military cooperation and teamwork.

Ganzoury made a strong pitch for support in his telcon with the Secretary, stating he needed $3-4 bn in order to stabilize the situation this month and provide the security that would make economic progress possible. The Secretary noted we had spoken directly to the IMF, with it imperative that the GOE invite the IMF team and consult with Egyptian stakeholders in advance. Ganzoury said he would be seeing the IMF in a few days (Note: has the IMF not communicated its delay?), but that a program would take a month to build and Egypt needed assistance immediately. He specifically asked whether the US had identified and frozen Mubarak/regime assets that could be tapped, noting that Gulf pledges of aid were not materializing.

The Secretary pointed to Gulf concerns over stability in Egypt and said real concerns were raised by the on-going violence. The images were deeply disturbing, particularly of the women being beaten. Ganzoury insisted he had issued strict instructions to the security forces "not to use even water," but also blamed the actions of thugs in creating the disorder; S re-emphasized the need for security sector reform. Ganzoury agreed with S on the need to accelerate compensation for victims.

Dear Anne,

He called me about his son and I told him you were working on it. And that we hoped to keep it quiet until you could resolve. Ops has his number if you want to contact him directly if there is any news to share.

When I spoke w FM Amr this morning, he said he understood how important it was for our whole economic and security agenda to resolve the NGO issue. Roiling the waters further over LaHood's son is not, however, the kind of positive step we were hoping to see!

Thanks for all you're doing, Hillary

subject: Newsweek
text:
Really good stuff. Especially fantastic opening page

Getting very very good feedback I can't even remember now what if anything in it bugged me yesterday. Nothing in it has anyone making a double take to flesh out so far. Its overall frame of the partnership paints you in exactly the way I think people respect you most, and I think Hirsh might actually have come up with a theme that will stick. Have only seen the cover photo online, I want to see the hardcopy since we all know it's the pictures that really matter. Text on the cover is great

subject: CHAMBER EVENT
text:
I'm at the Chamber and the event is straight forward. You have the updated version of the remarks (time stamped April 8th at 930pm).

You are greeted by Tom Donohue and/or FM Patriota (depending on when the FM arrives).

Go into a brief hold for photos with: Donohue, FM Patriota, Mr. Andrade, who is the President of the National Confederation of Industry for Brazil and is Donohue's counterpart in Brazil, Ambassador Shannon and staff.

In the audience we expect: Ministers and Governors from Brazil, Roberta Jacobson, Reta Jo Lewis, Governor of Illinois Pat Quinn and Dep Sec of Energy Daniel Poneman. Martin O'Malley is still tentative.

You move to the stage and take a seat - Tom is to your right and the FM is to your left. Speaking order is: Tom, you, Mr. Andrade and the FM. Andrade and the FM will speak in Portugese and all of the remarks are open press. Your piece is set.

See you soon.

In OSCE Sec Gen race, we have remained mostly on margins, noting only that we could support several of the candidates. Lithuanians now pressing for a stronger signal, now that former Austrian FM Ursula Plassnik has taken a clear lead in straw poll. Unless anyone feels strongly in other direction, I plan to let him know we can support Plassnik as the front-runner.

Plassnik is a strong personality and as a former FM might have some difficulty in accepting the limited powers of the Sec Gen position in a consensus-based organization dominated by participating states. But she's clearly smart and experienced, and has the full backing of most of the West Europeans (including, particularly, by Merkel who has lobbied us on her behalf.) She may ruffle some feathers in Vienna, but I don't think we should stand in the way of this train.

That said, there is a chance others (Turks, Russians, etc.) could block her — in which case we'd be fine supporting Italian diplomat Lamberto Zannier, who would probably be next on the list.

Let me know if any objections. Jake/Huma you might want to run by S as well.

subject: haiti comments
text:
Hi Cheryl, Heard you yesterday on NPR. Right on the money in terms of emphasizing coop with GoH and coord with UN et. al. One thing I am not sure that I mentioned. I looked back and relatively early--4 weeks after Mitch at end Oct 98--we made the estimate that the US contribut would have to be about $1 b. (when early damage estimate was $6 b.) and that was the general amount mentioned in the first formin meeting by Madeleine here in early Dec and then the supplemental went to Congress with more of a breakdown from USAID in early Feb. As soon as you can get an early supplemental to the Hill while the focus is on Haiti, and our forces are on the ground there, the better chances that it will receive early action. Best, mark Mark L. Schneider Sr. Vice President International Crisis Group 1629 K St. NW Suite 450 Washin on DC 20006

www.crisisgroup.org Crisis Group - the international conflict prevention organization

Dear Team,

Thank you for your comments about what you would like said at the meeting with Secretary Clinton and Senator Graham. I will try to summarize them for you: first you want to express your appreciation for both her having such a meeting and also for defending religious freedom throughout the world. You also want to express the depth of commitment the faith community has to serving the neediest people in the world and give several examples of what you have done. Maybe most importantly you want to share that in order to work hand-in-hand with the government there needs to be mutual respect and an appreciation for differing religious beliefs, and that these beliefs should also be respected. They should not become barriers to working together and we must make every effort to avoid such conflict. Lastly, you expressed an interest in explaining how you want to impress on legislators the need for robust foreign policy budgets and that you plan to work actively to protect both programs and funding for them. I hope that was a good summary.

We should all meet in the lobby of the State Department at 10:00 sharp Thursday morning. At the end of the lunch tomorrow we should also try to meet for a few minutes to go over how we might want to structure the meeting. Thank you for your help in making this a meaningful moment in the challenges we have ahead regarding foreign assistance.

Best, Shepherd

Speech

Thanks for all your hard work on this difficult speech to get it as right as possible. Here are a few comments and questions:
