We decided the best language would be for the Secretary to say that if UNSYG cannot co-host, that she would welcome the participation of his representative. The important point here is that we do not want the FAO head — Jacques Diouf — to end-up co-hosting the UNGA event, and everyone agreed there was a danger Ban ki-Moon would suggest he do so. In the background at the bottom I included a point stressing that we do not want Diouf to co-host.

Thanks, Marisa

She'd be really good at that job. The strongest qualities she has are planning and the ability to realize/implement plans with a focus on results. Tons of energy and drive - like energizer bunny. The knowledge she lacks is organizational change but someone else could bring that. Also, she has a reputation for a strong personality and some glass breaking. I view this as a strength but there may be a few people whose toes she has stepped on in past. But not enough to make her ineffective.

I think she'd be even better at CSO but that may not be on the table.

subject: "Webchat"
text: I'm calling it a webchat for lack of a better name, but the idea was/is to solicit questions via video and text, show them to you, have you answer. While we managed to do the regional interviews, we never got around to this, in part because of some technical issues that we've since worked through. So we're hoping that you're still up for doing this, ideally next Wednesday, for 30 mins tops. Reason I'm asking now is because the media outlet we'd partner with to solicit, choose and pose the questions would like to start gathering questions today at a large march in Egypt, a ripe time and place to solicit questions for you.

*** To the Members of the Inter-American Foundation Board of Directors and Advisory Council: It is my pleasure to send my sincere congratulations and best wishes to Kay Kelley Arnold, both personally and on behalf of the United States Department of State, on the occasion of her successful completion of more than twelve years of service on the Board of Directors of the IAF. Kay has distinguished herself as an American and true public servant. I know that the Foundation, the American people, and grassroots communities across Latin America and the Caribbean have benefitted greatly from her steady leadership and vision, and that they will continue to do so as she transitions to her new role as Vice Chair of the IAF Advisory Council. Kay, thank you for your many years of dedicated service to the IAF and the nation.

Thanks so much for this Cheryl! Let me know if there is anything further I can do to facilitate. Best, Paul

Paul M. Zimmerman General Counsel

Inter-American Foundation 1331 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW Suite 1200 North Washington DC 20004

www.iaflgov

Chatted with Dr. K for about a half hour tonight at the Atlantic Council. He's fascinated by Burma, but admitted he wished he knew more and regretted that had never encountered any Burmese - other than U Thant back in the day and ASSK and her delegation tonight. He said he is a big fan of S, and especially her bold Burma policy. I told him about our "Kissinger-esque" planning for the 2011 S trip under Kurt's leadership - which delighted him and got him telling a few stories about his own Beijing adventure. Maybe these are old yarns, but I had no idea that he spent the nearly two days with Chou En-lai without bringing up the Nixon visit - he waited until the latter finally asked "What about the visit?" to which Dr. K coyly replied "What visit?"

He's looking forward to seeing Thein Sein next week (asked if I would be there; I explained ASSK travels - but said I thought Derek might be there). He's interested in going to Burma in October (from Singapore) and might contact S with his interest. I know October is packed with visitors, but I encouraged his general interest - noting that his China experience would in particular resonate with the reformist GOB. He asked if it could be done in a day, but agreed with me that he'd really need to do NPT and not just Rangoon. I'm not sure if he will follow up on this - but his mind was so sharp on all matters that I'm compelled to share this all with you tonight! Regards -

Patrick

Here are some odds and ends that need followup:

--should I call Prodi, the UN envoy for Sahel/Mali? Ask Jake

--are we still holding time for a UN/US/Russia trilat on Syria? Ask Jake

--are we still planning an Af/Pak speech? Ask Jake

--Fred Smith of FedEx asked me to address their meeting in DC Jan 23-24 and I'd like to do

--I'd like to visit: --the CVE center --R

--anyway I can go to launch of Melanne's Artisans Alliance on Tuesday?

This is a follow up from my earlier email. We will pull together in cable tomorrow.

We have a readout of the Tantawi meeting with the political parties from a participant. . The group will reconvene on Thursday mid-day. Tantawi called in about 15-18 political party figures, to focus on the constituent assembly. SCAF told those gathered it was important to move beyond the crisis, start a dialogue and show Egyptians they can find a solution. The SCAF was politely showing the FJP that it had gone too far. Liberals complained they had been shut out of the process. In the end, it seemed as if the FJP was looking at what they might do to allay fears about the constitution. The elections for the constitutional assembly were over, so there was no going back on that. But options on the table — which we have heard from other liberals — would be endorsing a "bill of rights" to be incorporated into the constitution. Participants seemed pleased that the SCAF was playing a positive role. More meetings to follow.

Another idea is taking shape of the idea of a trip for a broad group of parliamentary leaders to the US in a "getting to know you" visit. We will pursue that.

subject: FW: END OF THE GOLDMAN CASE Importance: High
text:
I thought I would share this heartfelt message from Patricia Lamego de Teixeira Soares, the head of Brazil's Central Authority, the office responsible for Hague Convention abduction cases. You will see that in spite of our efforts to protect the son, the Brazilian family chose to make a spectacle outside the Consulate this morning by parading Sean through a crowd. Ms. Lamego recently visited the U.S. where she met with members of Congress and others to explain all that the Brazilian Central Authority was doing to reunite Sean and his father under the Hague Convention. The delays we saw in this case were largely the result of a wealthy, well connected family able to influence court decisions.

We are all relieved and thrilled to see this long overdue but very happy ending. I should also highlight the amazing work done by US Mission Brazil. The consular staff, Charge, Acting DCM (Marie Damour, the Consul General in Brasilia), LegATT, RSO, and a host of others all played a role in this successful return. My OCS DAS, Michele Bond, and her dedicated team also played a big role in communicating with David, his lawyers, Congress, and the press. We had Members of Congress, former Assistant Secretaries and US Ambassadors all pitching in. While there were disagreements at times over tactics, we all agreed that we were working towards the same goal: the safe return of Sean.

We particularly appreciate the strong support from the Secretary. Many people will try to take credit for today's happy reunion but it was the Secretary's continued concern and interest in this case that made the difference. We could not have provided a better gift to David Goldman during this season of giving. Janice

Walter:

Hope all is well in Islamabad. Corley is incredibly excited about the possibility of going out there to help you guys. Hope it all works out. If it does, you will have to tell the Ambassador that he owes me big time since I will have given him 3 of my top people!!!

Just wanted to check with you to see if the Ambassador has begun to implement the new approach towards branding that we discussed last year. If so I'd like to know how it is going so I can assess if it provides a good model for other parts of the world and other programs.

Best to you and Mark. We miss you!

jm

We got back from Ukraine in the high winds which were kind of a metaphor for the situation in Kyiv. The US presence was greatly appreciated. I saw the Pinchuk's who send their best....also Mrs. Kuchmal The meeting with Yanykovych went very well. Gen Jones did a good job and Y said all the right things about IMF, integration with the Westetc. He is coming to DC in April for the nuclear summit but said he'd like to come sooner as well. Jones told him that you would like to visit at some point and he was pleased at that prospect, asked for help and seemed eager to cooperate in every way. Of course, the future will tell whether these are words, what the Russians will do, etc. Its a complicated situation but needs our leadership. I'm sure Phil G will be giving you the full readout .1 met with some of the key women activists and felt we were back in the 90's because of the recidivism in so many areas that's taking place there. Thank you for putting me on the delegation.

I Just met this morning with Sen Lugar and he said you were terrific in your hearing and he was very pleased at what you had said on Law of the Seas. He also was pleased to hear that we were working on conflict minerals re: DRC and thought his bill on transperency provided a good approach. I told hm that on your trip there, you elevated this issue and have been working on it since.

I know you're meeting with the S Koreans today. They have the G20 presidency next year and many of the parliamentaians and other officials want to put economic growth and investing in women-run SME's high on the agenda.

subject: Embassy Families: Nairobi Embassy Bombing
text:
Dear Cheryl and Alice:

I would be most grateful if you would pass the following message to Secretary Clinton from me:

Dear Madam Secretary:

Thank you very much both for the very kind, generous and thoughtful message which you released to the press yesterday and for the thoughts of Alice which you conveyed in it. She admired you and your leadershio very much and recalled with much joy the times she had met and worked with you.

Thank you so much for having done so.

I also understand you had asked to speak with me and I would very much like to do so and can call whenever it might be convenient.

With my deepest thanks,

Respectfully, Tom Pickering

subject: US Commission to UNESCO
text: Heather, I appreciate your and the Secretary's consideration in this matter, but I think that I will pass on it. I'm sure that Hillary has people on the east coast who might be better equipped to attend meetings and whose appointment might serve a needed purpose for her. Thanks for thinking of me. And please thank her for her recent letter regarding my course on Sports Diplomacy. I was pleased to hear of her new initiatives led by Ann in that area. Will HRC get a chance to attend the London Olympics? I hope that your summer is going well. Regards, Derek

Nancy —

Every once in a while you come across something that makes you realize anew what a great organization we work for.

As we speak, eight officers are combing websites all over the world to make sure we have a complete list of cables that have been leaked. The eight officers speak the following languages, and are combing websites accordingly: Burmese, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian, Chinese, Arabic, Hebrew, Swedish, Hungarian, Swahili, and Chichewa, the latter a tribal language from Malawi learned from Peace Corps days.

No wonder State has the most comprehensive list of leaked cables — and that colleagues from DOD, DIA, and CIA are seeking access to it.

Cheers,

Chat

PS — Feel free to share if you write about the Wiki experience for State Magazine!

subject: HC Calls
text:
Thanks, I will relay this to the WH.

I was sure to inform them last week that you spoke to Berry, and I understand Rahm was in touch with Berry as well. They're still nervous about him and were hopeful for a second call. But if President Clinton has already spoken to him, perhaps that's unnecessary.

As for Congresswoman Sanchez, I can reach out to her Chief of Staff and at the very least let her know that you've been trying to reach the Congresswoman.

I will be sure to let the WH know about Kanjorski.

Thanks again.

subject: hi & my book draft
text:
Dear Sheryl

Yay! So glad you are done. Congratulations!

Have printed and placed on her chair for when she gets back from Latin America so she will be able to take it home.

Will flag that it's bit crazy at the minute b/c of what you read about, but I am sure she will read and then decide whether she wants to provide a quote.

What is your deadline — I asked 'o/c while she has been Secretary, we have declined her doing endorsements of nongovernment ventures so what to know if this is pre or post her service.

Xo cdm

As most of you know, this will be my last week as Assistant Secretary for South and Central Asia. After three years in this job and an able successor about to have his hearing, I'm glad to move on. Before I slip out, I would like to stop by and exchange a few thoughts with the Principals. These can be short chats, a few words and a goodbye handshake.

I'm in the office all this week, and will be back with more time the week of May 26-29 to clean up and check out. Dona Richard, my OMS, can fix the times.

Thanks for your help in setting some meetings up for me, if there is time on your bosses' schedules.

Richard

Hi from Berlin. Qatari PM Hamad bin Jassim just called. He urged that UNSC discussions on Syria be postponed until Monday. He said that the UK is pushing for Saturday.

If the UNSC meeting is Saturday, he said, only Arab League Secretary General Nabil ElAraby will represent the Arabs. If the meeting can wait until Monday, Hbi will go, too. It's all in the scheduling, he said, arguing that waiting from Saturday to Monday shouldn't be a problem.

I noted that all I could do is pass on the request. I noted that I have no insights into procedures and scheduling for the UNSC. He said, answering my prodding, that he couldn't be in NYC until Sunday night.

Comment: I don't know the UNSC schedule.

Jeffrey Feltman

There are a number of different possibilities for how the decision on the Guinea/Madagascar credentials may go tomorrow. (It is Zambia and Tanzania bringing the challenge on behalf of the AU.) I was under the impression that we would not have to vote on the potential credentials challenges. We may have to.

We may have to vote on a motion to *deny* them credentials and exclude them. For the moment, the guidance is to vote to credential all countries — including these two — as is customary, while conducting outreach with Tanzania, Zambia, and the AU to explain that we have our own imperatives but we support the fact that they are taking a principled stand.

We may have to vote on a motion to *defer* decision, which would allow them to be seated and vote but would not formally grant credentials. For the moment, the guidance is to potentially support such a motion — this was the practice with respect to South Africa between 1983 and 1994. Everyone is in the same place on this.

Ultimately, however, the whole thing may die of its own weight. This is probably the most likely outcome.

Jake, I understand that S is meeting with Japanese FM Maehara tomorrow, and wanted to make you aware of news reports today indicating that Japan plans to announce shortly its intention to run for a UN Security Council seat for 2012-2013. Having just left the Council after a 2009-2010 term, this would be the earliest opportunity for Japan to seek another seat, and likely represents a strategy of seeking frequent election to a nonpermanent UNSC seat to bolster Japan's credibility in its pursuit of permanent Security Council membership. To date, Fiji, Kyrgyzstan, and Pakistan have announced their candidacy for a single Asia Group seat up in 2012. Japan has served ten times on the Council, tied for the most with Brazil. Esther

subject: Last Day
text:
Dear Colleagues,

On my last day as Deputy SRAP and DAS, I want to thank one and all for your collegiality and friendship over the past 18 months. We've achieved a lot, in my view, and I'm truly grateful to have had the opportunity to work with all of you on such critical and difficult issues, There will be other opportunities next week to say good-bye — or rather so long for now, since I hope to work again with as many of you as possible. Today I'd simply like to turn over the reins fully, after a week-long overlap, to my successor, Frank Ruggiero.

If the Senate confirm's me, I look forward to seeing you in Malaysia.

Best regards, Paul

PS — pis don't hit reply to all on this email.

subject: 2012.02.19 CODEL McCain Presser on SPD, Syria, Taliban Talks.docx
text: Rough meeting today, as you can see from the press work below, which Graham intended to be a tough message. I will do a report when I can. Much of the discussion was about the SPD in now familiar terms, with Graham getting emotional at times and all (McC, Graham, Sessions, Hoeven and Blumenthal) pressing K, McCain intervening at several points to calm Graham down. Graham told K flatly no SPD without process solutions on detentions and night raids; if that's not what he can accept, Americans will not support and he can forget it. K was obstinate and offensive, if calm, blaming the conflict on the US and twice describing US as occupiers— right after saying he is committed to the partnership. At one point he let slip that "the country that the US wants as an Ally must be sovereign." He also said that he is opposed to an Afghan detentions regime, and acknowledged that he had blocked what we regard as solutions on the legal framework for detentions, implying he would do so again. By the end Graham was fuming — and made a personal plea to K to do the right thing for the Afghan people. Noting K's repeated assertions that he wants the partnership, McCain observed that those who want an agreement usually find a way to get it and thought the message to K from his best friends in Congress would be useful, he'd need time to process. Wardak (not present) wants to get together on detentions tomorrow or Tuesday.

subject: Fw: Kindles and State
text:
Love Lissa. Adore Politics & Prose. And agree the program warrants further assessment.

But the same argument of unfair pricing is made against all online content sellers, Apple as much as anyone. So that would argue against using any kind of eReader at all. I get the idea that these companies squeeze independent booksellers - but it's not like State currently buys 10,000 books from the local store to put in our 3rd floor library and is replacing that purchase with books from the new Amazon mega store up the block (hypothetical, doesn't exist). This isn't a Wal Mart situation. State most likely already buys books bulk, so this program simply shifts our purchasing from one mammoth company to another. Not to mention that the USG has a different responsibility than the average consumer to obtain the best value possible. Bookstores are definitely in trouble. But because of the technology itself, not Amazon's or Apple's business practices - which certainly compound the problem, but doesn't create it. Al Gore did when he invented the Interwebs.

subject: SUBJECT: Impending Washington Post Article on the USAID/OIG Review of USAID/Afghanistan's Bank Supervision (Kabul Bank)
text:
I wanted to share with you a situation that recently has arisen in the event that it comes up during the FY 2012 Budget Hearings.

The USAID Office of the Inspector General (OIG) recently has completed a review of our Afghanistan Bank Supervision assistance activities. The OIG is set to release its report soon, probably next week.

However, I have been informed that the. Washington Post plans to publish an article on the OIG review of the USAID contractor advising the Afghan Central Bank on bank supervision - Deloitte Touche LLP. The article may appear in the March 13th Sunday edition. Deloitte trains Afghan bank examiners as part of its larger contract implementing our Economic Growth and Governance Initiative, which provides broad policy advice to the Afghan government.

I support the independence of our OIG and the audit community. They represent a vital check on all USG activities both home and abroad. As Administrator, I have made it a central goal to improve oversight of all USAID activities world-wide. I have directed the implementation of the Accountable Assistance for Afghanistan Initiative in order to ensure more stringent control and oversight of USG funds.

I am gravely concerned about the findings of the USAID/OIG and have directed our General Counsel to work closely with the USAID Mission to determine the appropriate course of action. I will keep you updated on this and as we move our assistance program in Afghanistan toward transition goals.

Shannon Darcy Sr. Development Advisor Office of the Special Representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan U.S. Department of State (202) 647-9403 (direct) (202) 647-9004 (main)

Dear Anne-Marie:

As you prepare to return to Princeton, I wanted to express my gratitude for your engagement with the U.S. Navy during your tenure as Director of Policy Planning at the U.S. State Department.

I valued deeply our exchanges, and I recall with special pleasure the time you and your senior colleagues took to come to Tingey House last spring to discuss State-Navy cooperation with my team. I know you depart State with a real sense of accomplishment, especially after bringing to closure the outstanding inaugural version of the Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review.

I, of course, stand ready to support your successor and State's Policy Planning Staff, but I hope you personally will not forget us once you are back home. If the U.S. Navy or I can do anything to support you and your work, please let me know. I am well aware that your public service began long before your stint in SIP, and I am confident it will continue unbroken into the future. The Navy is eager to be a partner.

Bravo Zulu!

Very best wishes, Gary

Admiral Gary Roughead Chief of Naval Operations

Latest:

During the evening of March 20 individuals with access to the French and British military and security leadership stated in confidence that French President Nicolas Sarkozy plans to have France lead the attacks on Libya's Muammar Qaddafi over an extended period of time. According to these individuals, Sarkozy is genuinely concerned about the possibility that Qaddafi's troops will commit genocide against the people of Benghazi. However, he also sees this situation as an opportunity for France to reassert itself as a military power. French military commanders were extremely disappointed when, what they believe to be, political differences between the United States and France prevented them from participating in the March 2003 invasion of Iraq. Sarkozy and his military advisors believe that operations in Libya will rebuild the reputation of the French military, which was also damaged by a problematic performance in the first Gulf War.

(Source Comment: For his part. British Prime Minister David Cameron is concerned over how the allies will deal with the rebel forces, if, and when, they take advantage of the air attacks on Qaddafi's forces to renew their move on Tripoli. British intelligence believes that when the rebels recapture Ras Lanuf and other towns they will find evidence of atrocities committed by Libyan troops against the local population. They are, in turn, concerned that the rebels will seek vengeance on Qaddfi's supporters.)

subject: Congratulations!
text:
Francisco, Just wanted to congratulate you and the entire team on a striking success. The Secretary's visit was jaw-dropping from the Mexican perspective. I have never seen such a positive reaction to a visit by a high ranking US government official. My personal favorite: Estamos hillarizados por estos dias. There is obviously also a "show me the money" aspect of the reaction, but even Mexico's newspaper of the traditionally anti-American left editorialized about "Good Clinton, Bad Napolitano". And inside President Calderon's circle they are thrilled with Wednesday's meeting. Many congratulations. OK, I will stop bothering you with my emails and allow you to get back to doing your job. warm regards, Pamela

Pamela K. Starr, PhD Senior Lecturer Public Diplomacy and International Relations Senior Fellow, Center on Public Diplomacy University of Southern California 3518 Trousdale Parkway Los Angeles, CA 90089-0043

Also, if there's a way to let her know that this new draft is coming (so that she doesn't start to mark up the old one if she hasn't already) that would be great.

subject: HAK Papers
text:
Dear Jeff,

Thank you for the status update - we appreciate it.

In response to your question regarding assuring "accelerated declassification of all of the HAK documents in the Library of Congress, not just those that have been referred to State by the Archives", the short answer is that we cannot.

I can inquire as to whether we could consider developing a plan that is consistent with our proposal and our reviewing authorities that might enable us to work the additional collection of non-State records while we are do our State records work; such a proposal would obviously involve incremental funding based on the scope of such a plan. It also would require the engagement of other agencies. Obviously I am not certain if such a proposal could work, because as we shared in the meeting between the Secretary and HAK at their meeting, we are not in a position to address other agencies' records.

Either way, we welcome being kept apprised.

Best.

cdm

subject: Passback and Approps committees
text: As far as Afghanistan goes, we still do not know if a budget amendment will be going up next week or not. We should know by Monday morning. Our staff has been asked to prepare a template without numbers so a decision could be implemented quickly. I am confident that there will be time to have a discussion both at the highest levels at OMB and the WH before this is locked. As far as the 2011 budget goes, we should hear back at least from staff early next week and I will reach out to Peter and Rob to start a discussion at the top line level. I think we will want you to enagage some time this coming week, but I would like to see what the real gap is first.

subject: Farewell
text:
Teammates -- As I leave Haiti today and turn over command of JTF-H to MG Sim Trombitas, I wanted to say thanks and express my deepest appreciation for all that each of you have done for the people of Haiti.

I have had the honor and privilege of working side by side with all our U.S. Military services; Ambassador Ken Merten and the US Embassy team; USAID's Office of Response Coordination led initially by Ambassador Lew Lucke and now by Chris Milligan; the UN Peace Keeping Forces from 18 nations led by Brazilian Major General Floriano Peixoto and now MG Paul Cruz; hundreds of non-governmental organizations (NG0s) like the Jenkins-Penn Haiti Relief Organization (VP HRO) led by Sean Penn; the Government of Haiti leaders from President Preval, Prime Minister Bellerive, to all his Ministers; and numerous community leaders in displaced persons camps and local Mayors. I believe no one can come to Haiti and leave unchanged. I know I have certainly been personally and professionally affected by what I have seen and experienced since 12 January 2010.

I can't help but look back to that January day when life seemed to stop. I saw death, suffering, pain, sadness and fear. I saw things that I will never forget. Today, I see courage, resiliency, and determination. I see it in the camps and in the markets. I see it in the faces of the vendors selling mangos. I see it in the artists who show off their paintings to passersby. And I see it in Haiti's leaders, with whom I met regularly. I see hope all around Haiti. .

subject: UNSC elections reporting
text:
All,

The President of the General Assembly (PGA) just announced the results of the first round of voting. Countries need to receive votes from at least 2/3 of the UN Member States present and voting in the General Assembly to win a seat. All 193 UN Member States were present and voting, so 129 is the required to win seat.

African Group (2 seats) • Mauritania 98 (proceeding to 2"d round) • Morocco 151 [ELECTED] • Togo 119 (proceeding to 2"d round)

Asian Group (1 seat) • Kyrgyzstan 55 • Pakistan 129 [ELECTED] (NOTE: Minimum # of votes needed) • Fiji 1— previously announced candidacy, but then rescinded

Eastern European Group (one seat) • Azerbaijan 74 (proceeding to 2' round) • Hungary 52 • Slovenia 67 (proceeding to 2nd round)

Group of Latin American and Caribbean States (1 seat) • Guatemala 191 [ELECTED] (2 abstentions)

The 2"d round (and 3rd rounds) of voting are restricted to the top two (in the case of 1 avail seat) vote recipients in the first round. The Eastern European Group will go to a rd round of voting, with Slovenia and Azerbaijan on the ballot. The African Group will go to the 2"d round as well, with Mauritania and Togo on the ballot.

The 2nd round of voting is starting now.

Dan

subject: From Sandy Berger- UNSC Resolution with different language
text:
Jake,

Sandy's email is down temporarily. He asked that I forward the following to you:

The domestic firestorm would be the same, regardless of the language. Congress will not parse the words; they will take the view that this is throwing Israel overboard. D's as well as R's. That will have consequences for the generally bipartisan support of our handling of Egypt, and put the Administration on the defensive. It will be seen as backtracking on our position—restated as recently as last week by Jim—that the UNSC is not the place to litigate these issues.

Undoubtedly, vetoing a resolution that echoes US policy hurts our credibility in the region and undercuts the forward-leaning posture we have cultivated over the past three weeks. That could feed the anti-American currents and manifest itself on the streets of Ramallah or elsewhere.

Obviously, better if we can get the Pals to withdraw, including holding out the prospect of putting forward TORs for negotiations. But if that is not successful, I come down—narrowly--on the side of veto. I know what happens here if we abstain; I am not sure what happens in the region if we veto.

If that is where you come out, it may be better not to change the language. And we certainly should try to get something from Bibi—on the g round or in his negotiating positions.

-Sandy

From our team in Cairo at the Opposition meeting, final session:

After about five hours the group agreed on a composition of the "follow up and communications committee." They will propose to their political bodies that it be a 21-person committee with three seats for the SNC; 2 seats for the KNC; and one seat for the other 16 groups.

This odd formulation was a result of the SNC's need to be perceived as the heavy weight and the Kurdish demand that it have more seats than the Turkmen. Despite getting their wish, the Kurds attempted (right before the vote) to add another seat in their umbrella which angered every participant in the room. Finally, after an Amb Ford scolding, they conceded.

Three people were selected to collect the names from each of the 18 groups. They are scheduled to submit the names of each group's participants to the Arab League in seven days.

subject: Latest from HRC friend
text:
Jake- Interesting report. Gene is closer to the action and I defer to him on the latest Jail-ian thinking and machinations vis-a-vis the cabinet and INC. I hadn't heard about ENI-related corruption but wouldn't be surprised.

On the federalism issue,. Jail is right to be concerned about eastern agitation for autonomy. A cabinet chance won't solve that problem, though. Nor will recruiting Belhaj and Islamist fighters to take on the Bardans. To the contrary, it would only lead to unwanted bloodshed - the large Obeid tribe still nurses a serious grudge against Belhaj and his ilk for the Islamists' presumed role in killing their beloved Gen. Yunis last July and would probably put up a fierce fight.

The cabinet and INC need to have a serious discussion with the Bargans - if they aren't already doing so - about how power and resources are to be distributed in the new Libya. The Libyans held similarly heated debates on this very topic in the early1950s as they held their first parliamentary elections and drafted their constitution (there were actually violent skirmishes in connection with those elections, and Washington delayed the arrival of the first US ambassador until after things had calmed down). Hopefully the current leadership can negotiate these issues peaceably in the corning months. Of course, we and the UN and our other partners should encourage them to do so.

- Chris

SBU

Dear Cheryl, My long time and good friend, Glenn Prickett, who is now the number two person at The Nature Conservancy respectfully asked me to put in an encouraging word with Secretary Clinton regarding the invitation that she has received from The Nature Conservancy. I always try to be judicious in my outreaches to the Secretary (and to you), but feel this one is a most appropriate one. I'm sure you know of The Nature Conservancy's longstanding, meaningful and important work in making our world a better place from an environmental standpoint and more broadly. I have been proud to be associated with The Nature Conservancy's efforts for over three decades now and was quite active in my participation and support during my tenure as CEO of Arkla Gas. It was a natural partnership given the environmental qualities of natural gas and the Conservancy initiatives. Donna also was quite active in the Arkansas chapter of The Nature Conservancy. One of the unique strengths of the Nature Conservancy is their strong state network organizations. I am sure that The Nature Conservancy dinner marking their 60th anniversary this Fall will be a well organized and special occasion. Of course, I understand better than most the demands of the Secretary's schedule but sincerely feel this one is worth her full consideration. Thank you for your consideration and for handling these types of matters in your usual professional and courteous manner. Personally, Mack

subject: I see
text:
You and president Obama now support the Colombia Free Trade agreement!

Hope you are well. I remain amazed at the schedule you are running.

We did at least get ADM to contribute to shanghai -- always happy to help on projects like that, earlier the better.

The midterms are likely to be brutal, that is for sure. Around the world the financial crises and it's repercussions are creating problems on the edge of insolvable in the long run. Putting aside the irony of the Colombia Free Trade agreement, the administration has an inadequate plan for long- term innovation and growth -- the only real ways to solve the debt. That was the real lesson of 96 to 98 when wjcs plans came to fruition to create a surplus.

Thanks again. Take care.

I'm sure the Ferraro memorial will bring back a gush of memories. You have had many vigorous defenders but no one was as fierce as she. Every time I saw her during the campaign, I got an earful. If she thought someone was unfair to you, they heard from her! And, of course, she did among the heaviest lifting to defend the universality of human rights at the Beijing conference. I remember her rounding up all the Catholics on the delegation one Sunday in Beijing to get to the Mass the Vatican delegate was officiating (during tough negotiations with the Vatican) to prove that our team had a lot of shared values! Ever the politician. I will miss her.

I'm heading back from Texas where the Bushes have been hosting a conference on role of women in Afghanistan. They were all there from Hadley and Khalizad to Hughes and the former president. Karzai is going to be on live via video today but I had to head back. I spoke last night on our continuing commitment to women in our afghan policy and mentioned what you said about Mrs Bush at the House hearing. An Afghan participant from MFA mentioned the effectiveness of US advocacy for women saying that "Madame Clinton" played a big role on women's participation in the peace jirga and on the shelter issue. It was all well received. There was also much private conversation about the need to improve the relationship with Karzai (more on this).

subject: Stu, below is text of the letter that David Schaecter will be faxing to Secretary Clinton any minute if it hasn't gone already. I believe the conversations were very important and productive, and more importantly, so do the survivors with whom you spoke. We look forward to working together this week and thereafter. Sam
text:
With reference to our letter dated June 19, 2009, on behalf of the Holocaust Survivors Foundation USA, Inc. (HSF), I would like to state that based on conversations that took place in the intervening time period between Ambassador Eizenstat and the leadership of the HSF, and the commitments he made to our leaders, we are no longer asking that he be replaced as the head of the U.S. delegation to the Prague Conference taking place on June 26-30. On behalf of all of the survivors for whom we have been fighting over the last decade, including tens of thousands in desperate need, we wish Ambassador Eizenstat the best of success as the head of the United States delegation at the Conference, as well as in the follow-up activities that we understand will occur on matters affecting Holocaust survivors' rights and interests.

Sincerely, David Schaecter

Good Morning Everyone. Or as they say here in Israel, 'Boker Toy'

Today's a special day, not simply because the trip is almost over, but because some of us are at home among our people. In honor of that, Pam has graciously allowed me to collaborate on today's daily missive. But don't worry, by popular demand she will resume the practice starting tomorrow - even though we'll be in Washington.

Today's isn't a quote per se, and it isn't anyone famoys. These traditional questions have been asked by Jewish children for millenia. They don't necessarily have answers tough, they are merely meant to encourage children to be inquisitive.

But I am attributing the below to one very special Jewish child who I know will go on to practice and further our rich traditions:

1) Ma nishtana ha-laila ha-zeh mi-kol ha-lelot? [Why is this stop different from all other stops?]

2) She-be-chol ha-lelot anu ochlin chametz u-matza, ha-laila ha-zeh kulo matza? [Why is it that on all other nights during the year we eat well-balanced, nutritional meals with vegetables, but on this trip we eat 5000 calorie meals mixing meats and cheeses and sauces that shouldn't be combined?]

3) She-be-chol ha-lelot en anu matbilin afilu pa'am echat, ha-laila ha-zeh shetay fe'amim? [Why is it on all other nights we do not eat ice cream dipped and fried even once, but on this trip we eat ice cream that has been dipped in artery clogging batter twice?]

4) She-be-chol ha-lelot anu ochlin bayn yoshvin u-vayn mseubin, ha-laila ha-zeh kelanu mesubin? [Why is it that on all other nights we eat either sitting or reclining, but on this trip we are admonished to eat in strapped to our seats in because we are within 200 minutes of landing?]

subject: Egypt: Communications Issues
text:
In the larger scheme of things, the communications issues implicated by events in Egypt are not nearly as significant as others. While they are important, they should not receive undue emphasis. That said, there are two admittedly obvious points that warrant mention:

1. The Government of Egypt has engaged in the most extensive shut down of the Internet in history. The only reasonably close analogies are efforts that were undertaken in Iran and Burma, but these were not nearly as extensive as what has occurred in Egypt. Just as important, the Government of Egypt has shut down other electronic communications almost completely. The only general exception is the wireline telephone system. The relative narrowness of this exception can be seen in the fact that there are roughly six times more now disconnected mobile subscriptions than wireline. Thus, while there has been considerable focus on the shutting down of the social media (Facebook, Twitter, etc.), what has taken place is much more significant.

2. The costs to any modern society of shutting off electronic communications are incalculably large. They include not only the economic costs, but also large non-monetary costs to individuals who, for example, are unable to learn the whereabouts and circumstances of relatives and friends. There does not seem to me to be any possibility that disconnecting almost all electronic communications can be sustained for long. The costs to the social fabric and to the economy are much too large. It is an action that, unless reversed almost immediately, will become a very powerful independent, universally felt grievance against the government.

Philip L. Verveer Ambassador U.S. Coordinator, International Communications and Information Policy U.S. Department of State 2201 C Street, NW Washington, DC 20520 202 647 5212 (p) 202 647 5957 (f)

subject: FW: Letter to Secretary Clinton from HRH the Prince of Wales
text:
Prince Charles is convening a meeting to discuss "how an economic analysis of food security risks, taking full account of the instability caused by the undermining of natural capital [water, energy, etc], would help governments design more resilient development pathways." He is modeling this on a process that he convened related to quantifying the costs of REDD (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation) that contributed to the OsloParis process and REDD financing. He hopes that a similar economic analysis of food insecurity will be carried forward by an informal working group launched at this Feb 28th meeting, which would then hopefully be considered by Rio+20 and the G20.

Would be good to know what other ministers and reps are attending. This does sound like an interesting process (esp if it can have the impact REDD analysis did) and we could try to send higher level to a follow-up event in the Rio+20/G20 lead up. Todd might be a good candidate.

Do you want me to call Claudia to get more details on the RSVP list?

1. Romney's insistence that the economy is in steep decline as a result of Obama's policies is more than central to his political argument—it is at the heart of his identity in this campaign. Romney's background as a private equity turnaround specialist merges in his sensibility with his deeply held Mormon belief of himself as the chosen son of his faith to be a redeemer of the country. He must be the turnaround man.

2. Romney's thinking is utterly schematic. He debates as though making a Power-Point presentation without the slides. This, too, derives from his very particular business background.

3. Romney's argument, method and even identity are all bound up in his key point—that he is the turnaround man—and can be crushed by refuting it. Obama should assert that the economy is now in turnaround, cite the 7.8 unemployment and other relevant statistics, observe that Romney has admitted he was "completely wrong" on the 47 percent, underscore that Romney is "completely wrong" on the true state of the economy, that he has the data "completely wrong," is operating from false premises, and that his approach would hurt people and hurt the economy. Obama is the turnaround artist; Romney would be the underminer of the turnaround. He's got the turnaround, just as he admitted on the 47 percent, "completely wrong."

Lebanese PR Salam called to inform us that Lebanon will put the draft resolution on settlements into blue within 24 hours based on a decision made in Sharm-el-Sheik. (This means that the draft can be voted on 24 hours after it is put in blue if a UNSC member calls for a vote.). He said a decision when or whether to put it to a vote would be made later subsequent to "how things develop".

Salam described a two-staged approach: first putting the draft in blue (to show their seriousness), and second a decision on a possible vote based on an assessment of further developments. He said that the vote would not necessarily take place this week but could not commit to timing at this point. He promised to keep in touch and plan to discuss the matter further with Susan tomorrow.

It appears that the Palestinians are awaiting our next step.

I just spoke to AC. He confirms that Maduro and Z are in Managua. Holguin should be just arriving in Colombia. They are waiting to hear from Holguin tonight or tomorrow morning after she gets word from Maduro that agreement has been reached on text of document. He confirmed that Maduro had agreed to 90-95 percent of document this morning. Holguin had urged Maduro not to propose anymore changes. Maduro asked for 48 hours to "socialize" document w ALBA-MERCOSUR. The document is titled "Cartagena de Las Indias Honduras.". The document is a proposal from PL, witnessed by Santos and Chavez, to Z. He said all four will sign document. He said he will let us know when-if he hears something. Hugo

subject: Recognition of US assistance efforts
text:
Raj:

Hope you are well and that you are having a good trip. I'm very much looking forward to catching up when you get back hearing how it all went, particularly in Pakistan.

As you and I have discussed briefly on several occasions, most of us feel there is a need to dramatically increase global awareness of USG assistance efforts. I have raised this issue with the Secretary and others at State and I would like to propose that Anne Marie, you and I co-host a small gathering of individuals from State, USAID and representatives from the private sector and NGO community to help us evaluate where we are and to develop some new approaches. If you agree, we can figure out a time which works for everyone and put together a list of people to invite. I'm happy to take the lead in organizing it. Let me know what you think.

Safe travels.

Judith

Hi Hillary -

Met Indra today for the first time. Spent the entire time not talking about me and my new law firm (!) but about you and why we both admired and supported you so. And still do.

She is a most remarkable person. And quite devoted to you.

Her daughter Preetha, as you may know, started in Iowa and stayed on in campaign as volunteer all the way through South Dakota and Montana.

And in all that time she never personally met you -- and "still grieves" (her mon's words) your loss. (Joining a big club!!!)

Can I call Cheryl and arrange a quick stop-by and handshake and photo any time--no rush--at your convenience?

Hope you are well - you look better than ever--as does President Clinton! And we are not getting any younger!!!

Warmest regards,

Lanny

I had dinner with Tony Fauci , his wife Christine , Harold Varmus , Francis Collins and Gary Nabel (Director, Vaccine Institute at NIAID). Great dinner but the conversation stayed on the Oslo speech for >20 minutes. As I had shared with you how Tony and Peter Piot felt about the speech, but Harold and Francis went on and on about how she defined the moment in global health and appropriately challenged the global community but at the same time kept the leadership position for the US. They thought it built on the November speech but brought the challenge ahead front and center. Really nice comments...just wanted you and 'S' to know.

Eric

subject: Death of NYT Reporter in Syria
text: Ops just called to report (via PA) that NYT reporter Anthony Shadid died today in Syria (exact location in Syria unknown at this time). Cause of death is believed at this time to be an asthma attack. Unknown if there was fighting in the area where he died or external contributing factors to the death. He was traveling with an AMCIT photographer, Tyler Bridges, who is with the body now in Turkey, heading to Adana. NEA is advising the Poles, and CA is reaching out to our embassy in Ankara and Consulate in Istanbul.

subject: rollout
text: initial stories are solid but we'll have to see how the commentary goes -- suspect we'll hear from the expected corners (see the Jennifer Rubin piece already in WaPo) about this ensuring America's decline by weakening defense + undercutting the military at a critical time give the Iranian threat, NK uncertainty, Afghanistan fragility, Pakistan morass, + Iraq unfinished business. Yet, the President has been clear from the outset that this was the direction he wanted to go to reduce the drain on our economy from the extended wars and military deployments. And, so far, the Administration has demonstrated that you can protect the nation and advance our national security by using our technology and getting others to do/cooperate more, i.e, our piece -- effective diplomacy. Bottom line, this roll-out sharpens the rhetorical debate. And we'll see more on leadership and everyone's favorite: leading from behind...

subject: Update on PSA
text:
Wanted to update you all on the PSA and where things stand. The Ad Council placed the PSA on Wednesday.

Overall, based on the MNR report, our estimated online audience for the PSA launch story was 5.4 million, including stories on Yahoo Finance, Forbes, and CNN. For just over 24 hours since the MNR distribution, this is fantastic pickup per the Ad Council.

The Ad Council will continue to push this out domestically and giving us updates on where it is. They are targeting large sporting events like U.S Open, etc. If you would like the full report with specific stories, I can send separately however because the file is so large I do not want to max out everyone's inboxes.

On the International side and specifically S interest in placing with Al Jazeera, the Ad Council did a slightly modified version of the 30 sec PSA, removing the texting information on the final screen and is overnighting the tape to the State Department today. Once we have that (timing for Tuesday), we will work with Dana and PA to have the PSA placed accordingly where makes sense.

Larry has already said that local stations in Pakistan liked the ad and were using it/reporting on it. As he is obviously very busy, hard to know more beyond this point. IIP has been great and the revised ad is going up on America.gov. Will work them to see what other embassy sites, etc we can promote this with.

We will continue to work to place the ad and will have donation reports on Tuesday that hopefully will reflect monetary upticks as well. Let me know if you have any questions. Best, Katie

subject: HRC in Paris
text:
Huma: please pass the following message to Secretary Clinton if possible:

Secretary Clinton:

Just wanted to write and congratulate you on your leadership inside the administration in the matter of Libya. I can only imagine the dynamic of French and British leaders racing ahead while some in the U.S. Administration were reluctant. It appears that you not only helped bring the administration to a laudable place but also handled the international diplomacy with great skill in a situation where the United States has chosen to change its traditional posture in international affairs.

With warm personal regards, affection and praise, your friend, Jamie.

James P. Rubin Executive Editor • The Bloomberg View 0:+1-212-205-0362

Cheryl, Hope all is we'll am now on my third visit to Port Of Spain. The upgrades Bea's interior decorator along with technology improvements has really turned this into a real residence. It has also put the Welters back in excess of 200k.But, she's pleased and that's what's important.The Embassy staff appears to be responding positively to her apporach.She hosted a reception for the entire Embassy and insisted that it included the janitors and cleaning staff. I think it surprised the Senior staff. I wanted to mention that Bea would still like the Secretary to do her public swearing in whenever her schedule permits.

Take Care, TonyW.

subject: FW: Asap. Gov Rendell and orphans
text:
Ambassador, We just received an email from the Adoption Service Provider about these cases. I am currently reviewing the files to determine if they qualify within the guidelines established recently by USCIS and DOS. Out of the 60 cases, 40 are being adopted by USC. Out of the 40, 5 of the cases were children escorted today and per CNN have just landed in Miami. The remaining 35 we are reviewing now. Some correspondence I've seen says that they plan on bringing the children straight to the airport, and we have responded that they first need to come to the embassy. Once case in particular will be an issue, as it requires the Presidential Waiver. Did you receive the talking points about Presidential Waivers?

The majority of the cases will qualify for Humanitarian Parole.

In the last 30 minutes a number of emails have been coming in about private planes, Ted Turner offering to fly children out, etc. We have a case coming in tomorrow morning in which the 2 adoptive families are being flown in by CBS helicopter from the DR. We are preparing as many cases in advance as possible tonight. Kind Regards, Linda

subject: S-Saudabayev call
text:
From John Beyerle ... Perhaps the Russians won't send troops:

I just called Karasin. He agreed that the situation had gotten worse in Osh and Jalalabad today but said the Russian position is still that sending in foreign troops, whether Russian or CSTO, will be counterproductive and lead to more violence and bloodshed.

The IL-76s that flew in to Kant today were the EMERCOM/M4C planes he told me about yesterday; they have humanitarian cargo, primarily doctors and medical equipment. I cited the news reports that a battalion of paratroopers had gone in -- he said there may be some troops on board to guard the plane or beef up security at Kant, but he was firm that at this point Russia has no plans to introduce its own forces in the south. The main objective was to stop the violence through peaceful means; Russia had provided the Kyrgyz forces with additional "technical means" for accomplishing that. He said they hoped this would help Kyrgyz forces get control of the situation, which was their main goal.

I asked about CSTO planning, and possible UN or OSCE PKFs. He said there is no formal CSTO meeting planned, although people are consulting via phone. He repeated their hesitation to see any CSTO deployments. They have not yet considered UN or OSCE PKFs, but if the situation continues to deteriorate, he wouldn't exclude the possibility.

Rushailo is currently in Moscow, but may be sent to Bishkek tomorrow or Tuesday. He agreed to call me if there is any major change in the situation on the ground, or regarding force deployments. Tomorrow is a Russian holiday but he'll have his cell phone on.

subject: NYT
text: FYI, I have been informed by Eric Schmitt of the New York Times that the story regarding possible end use agreement violations will run in tomorrow's paper. Based on a number of interactions over the past 48 hours, it will focus on the array of Pakistan's efforts, including possible reconfiguration of US-provided systems without prior authorization, to develop land-attack offensive missile options. The story will mention US-provided and indigenous Pakistani systems. In response, we have highlighted the fact that we take this seriously; we took aggressive action when we became aware of developments; we proactively engaged Pakistan at the highest levels; we kept Congress fully informed; and that Pakistan has responded to our concerns and that there will be mutually-agreed inspections to address our concerns.

The administration's response seems quite weak to me.

This is not like the Pentagon Papers or even the videos of the bombings, this is a wholesale capturing of the diplomatic material of the country. No State department can operate if it can't keep its own classified cables and internal orders confidential — I think this is unprecedented in history. And if this is wikileaks can get, what can the Chinese or other able to secure?

The issues surrounding the content are significant and could have legs.

But this security breach is not a targeted breach to make a whistle blower point, it is a wholesale leak that should be treated as putting lives in danger. For what it is worth, I think you need to order a full scale review and upgrading of the cyber security of the state department immediately. To offer a bounty for the capture of those responsible. And as I see you doing, take an aggressive position on Wikileaks. Just being seen as apologizing for the content is weak compared to reacting and acting to shore up the key principles behind security and aggressively dealing with the problem directly.

For what it's worth, that's my view.

subject: You ok with this?
text:
Sorry, with text this time...

The Passing of Ambassador Jerome Shestack

I am deeply saddened by the passing of my friend Jerry Shestack. He was a committed public servant and a dogged defender of human rights. Countless women and men are better off because of Jerry.

Jerry served the cause of human rights for more than half a century. He made a lasting impression as Ambassador to the U.N. Human Rights Commission where he launched the U.N. Working Group to investigate disappearances under oppressive regimes. Under President George H.W. Bush, he served with distinction on the delegation to the Moscow Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and on the Presidential-Congressional Commission to Improve the Effectiveness of the United Nations.

As President of the American Bar Association and in the years following he set the standard for how civil society leaders can promote human rights.

He was unwavering in his commitment to the highest of American values and international, human rights standards. Jerry was an effective advocate for the causes—and people—he cared about because he had a rare mix of wonderful qualities: optimism, resilience, humor, a thick skin, and a way of making everyone feel at ease.

Today my thoughts and prayers are with Jerry's beloved wife, Marciarose, and their two children, Jennifer and Jonathan.

subject: Molho and the Q
text:
Molho informed me this morning that he could not attend the Quartet meeting on March 2 in Brussels, but could meet at a later date. He cited a conflict requiring his presence in Israel to advise the PM, a desire to consult me in advance, and lingering anger over Serry's public reference Friday to the meeting.

After consulting the Senator, I informed Molho that, in seeking delay, we would like to provide the Quartet with an Israeli commitment to meet the following week. He said that was reasonable but wanted to check with the PM. In a later conversation, he said he still thought it would be ok, but said the PM wanted to consult the FM, and he (Molho) would get back to me in the morning.

After hearing from Molho tomorrow, I plan to convene an envoys call to propose we delay both the Israeli and Palestinian meetings one week, and hold them in Jerusalem/Ramallah. I expect the others will push to proceed as planned with the Palestinians, and then meet later with Molho. So long as we can point to a confirmed Israeli meeting, I'm not sure it matters much either way, but overall more delay, the better.

I don't want to speculate on the Israeli motivation on this system.

If we postpone both meetings one week, I would go out in advance to see Molho. If the Q insists on seeing Erekat this Wednesday, I would go to that, continue my planned consultations Thursday and Friday with the French and British, and end up in Jerusalem on Sunday.

Behold the Hillary Doctrine. And heap abundant gratitude—and rose petals if you have them on hand—on the firm, unfussy, deeply reassuring woman who has just offered it up to the world.

In the 20 months since this administration began administering (a verb I use only in the loosest sense), the speech on Wednesday morning by Hillary Clinton, delivered at the Council on Foreign Relations, was the first time we have been given an unreserved lift of the heart by any of its members. It was, by far, the best speech of this administration. Whereas her president has frequently wrung his elegant hands, doing the rounds of the world to reassure foreign leaders that America is a cuddly bunny at heart, the secretary of State declared that we are all living "a new American moment—a moment when our global leadership is essential." There was no bowing from her to potentates in robes; there was, instead, a promise that "we will do everything we can to exercise the traditions of American leadership at home and abroad."

Try this for size: "The United States can, must and will lead in the new century." In order to do that, Clinton promised "a new global architecture," "built to last and withstand stress." And in a muscular departure from the way in which this administration—for fear of seeming Bush-like—has been shrinking from the unembarrassed propagation of American values, she uttered these plainspoken, unadorned words: "Democracy needs defending."

Tunku Varadarajan is a national affairs correspondent and writer at large for The Daily Beast. He is also the Virginia Hobbs Carpenter Fellow in Journalism at Stanford's Hoover Institution and a professor at NYU's Stern Business School. He is a former assistant managing editor at The Wall Street Journal

Cheryl:

I am en route to Brazil with the Treasury Secretary. As I return to a week full of events (including our Economic Partnership Dialogue, a visit by Nancy Powell, and the White House pre-advance team), I wanted to take a moment to thank the Secretary and you for the Global Chiefs of Mission Conference.

I had a great time. The conference was substantive, relevant, and timely. I appreciated the big chunk of time the Secretary dedicated to the conference, especially during a time of perilous crisis. I also appreciated the opportunity to listen to Admiral Mullen and the Vice President. And I enjoyed the unique moment of camaraderie with all of my counterparts (even if some of them were whiney).

And...I thought the presentation by Mr. Spence to be a stroke of genius. It scrambled everyone's expectations of the conference and forced us to look at what we were doing in a very different way. The presentation is on its way to becoming an urban legend within the bureaucracy. One Treasury official told me today, "I heard about the Spence presentation. Very interesting. Not the kind of thing we would do at Treasury."

Thanks for sending such a clear message that our work is valued.

Regards, Tom

subject: Thank You
text: Cheryl, Thank you again for a wonderful lunch today. Along with the food (which was great!) I really appreciated the chance to sit down with everyone informally and just chat and eat. While we work with each person here on an individual basis, it is rare to have the opportunity for all of us to be in the same place at the same time with no formal agenda. You have assembled a great team -- which has both an abundance of smarts and personality — and I'm grateful that we had a chance to see each other one more time before we all dispersed for the holidays. Looking forward to 2010, Zia.

subject: follow-up to yesterday's email, re Nairobi terrorist attack
text:
I also wanted to follow-up on an issue that is very important to me — compensation for the families of State Department personnel who were killed in the Nairobi terrorist attack in 1998. I have tried to solve this with 3 Presidents and 3 Secretaries of State, yet I have been met by same old answers and zero willingness to help these families. Hillary, if I can't resolve this with you, I will never be able to resolve it. Like you, I believe in the fierce urgency of now.

I have gotten to know some of these families. Julian Bartley was the highest ranking African American as Consul General serving in Nairobi His son, Julian Jr. was interning at the Embassy that summer. Jay's body was cut in half in the explosion. He would have been 35 years old this October. Other victims left young children. One of the injured was blinded and contracted HIV while being treated in a Kenyan Hospital. I know you want to help these families as much as I do.

I got strong language in the Foreign Aid Appropriations bill that requires State to report on US victims of terrorism, and to draft a plan for providing compensation. I want to use this report and info to draft comprehensive legislation to provide compensation to American victims of terrorist attacks.

I need you to give me a high level, fresh person to work with at the State Department to resolve this issue. Someone who will come in the room with the willingness to offer solutions. We just need some fresh ideas and the will to put these ideas into action. I know we can do it.

Forward together! Barb

Complex Attack Sites:

1. At present, both Afghan National Army and Afghan National Police are heavily engaged with eight insurgents at Parliament on Darulaman Road.

2. Afghan National Security Forces are also engaged with four insurgents at a three-story building behind the Kabul Star. Security forces have cleared two of three floors. As government forces attempt to clear the third and final floor of the building, small arms fire is likely to increase significantly. One of the four has been killed and one is wounded.

3. Fighting IVO Camp Warehouse remains ongoing with Afghan forces engaged with three insurgents.

Thus far, eleven insurgents have been detained, two of whom had allegedly been wearing suicide vests and were planning to target Second Vice President Khalili.

Again, small arms fire remains ongoing at each of the attack sites.

subject: Australian! and update
text:
Dear Secretary Clinton,

I was heartened to read your forceful remarks about the US commitment to the Asia-Pacific region this morning. On Monday, our office held a workshop for the NIC that highlighted the downsides associated with an American withdrawal from the region. I will be providing you with our report from that event. Also, in early June, we are holding two workshops with US policy makers (one for Democrats and one for Republicans) to illuminate how contingencies in Pakistan might affect US-China relations. I will give you a read out on those events as well.

Anne-Marie was in touch last evening to tell me that she had looked into the possibility of working with LTSG and found that unfortunately her office would not be able to do so. Happily, Michele Flournoy's office is reaching out and has asked me to participate in a wargame next week for the QDR, which I hope will help build the foundation for a contract between her office and LTSG.

I am extremely grateful to you for helping me find opportunities to serve our government. As ever, I will keep you posted. Thank you again, and yrs, Jackie

Jacqueline Newmyer President, Long Term Strategy Group 12 Eliot St., Cambridge, MA 02138

www.ltstrategy.com

subject: Turkey
text: Madam Secretary, Many conversations this morning on the shoot down of Turkish reconnaissance plane, including call Phil and I did with U/S Sinirlioglu and several by Frank. Phil is doing a call sheet for you for your call with FM Davatoglu this afternoon. Most concerning is no doubt Turkey plans action, including first step by invoking Article IV for NATO consultations on Monday though deliberative about what and when beyond that, and not/not seeking NATO action at this point. More to come in EUR call sheet. Any or all of us available should you wish pre-brief. Wendy

"The Lady"

The film may make it to you in time for your departure for Burma. When we contacted the producer/director Jacques Besson, he tried to get it to Busan by FEDEX or equivalents. It proved impossible so they have put a courier on a plane in Paris to bring the DVD to Busan. He will arrive this morning and we are keeping our fingers crossed that he'll make it in time this morning to get to your plane.

I saw the film in rough cut in Paris and then Jacques and Michelle Yeoh, who plays ASSK, agreed to come to State for a small private showing they did for Kurt, Derrick, Philippe and a few others of us.

They have great admiration for you and wish you well on your trip to Burma. ASSK knows about the film but does not want to see it. It would be too hard to watch as much of it is about her

and the pain and sacrifice her commitment to Burma caused.

Michelle Yeoh saw ASSK a few months ago and told her all about producing the film.

Not too many hiccups here at the Forum. The Koreans are quite proud that they teamed with us on the Gender Plenary. Much excitement about your being here.

Cheryl: This is a heads-up: Senator Inhofe just called my deputy Don Yamamoto this evening to inform us that:

1) He had sent a letter to Secretary Clinton recently and was still awaiting a response. (Comment: We have not seen the letter in the Africa Bureau.)

2) The Senator will be sending an editorial or article to the Los Angeles Times as well as other news outlets tonight.

3) The Senator's message points are: (a) there is ample evidence of irregularities to demonstrate that opposition candidate Ouattara stole the presidential election; (b) there should be new elections; (c) the increased violence in Cote d'Ivoire is due to OUattara's more violent efforts to consolidate his position through force. (Comment: all the evidence demonstrates that Ouattara won and Gbagbo lost.)

The Senator concluded by saying that he was giving the Africa Bureau a heads up as a courtesy.

Comment: Senator. Inhofe has close ties to President Gbagbo, has criticized our Cote dIvoire policy and has resisted our previous efforts to get him to call Gbagbo to step aside.

Johnnie

Just got off with Sasae. He thanked us for quick action on agrement. He's planning to arrive in late nov early dec timeframe. Purpose of call was for him to inform us that GOJ will take steps shortly to buy the Senkakus from their private owner. They have agreed on a price and the private owner is trying to gain the understanding of mayor ishihara on this course of action. Ishihara is unlikely to consent. On my last visit to Tokyo on Aug 7, I urged Sasae and GOJ to consult and advise Beijing on their plans. The GOJ has just concluded a round of deliberations and apparently their PRC counterparts were irate. Sasae however believes that China actually understands the necessity of these actions and will accept them. (I'm not so sure.)

The GOJ has asked for further consults with me in Vlad and I will be sure to schedule.

Best,

Kurt

Steve just called me to report on his phoner with Jim. Steve made a yeomanly but unsuccessful effort to get Jim to attend the meeting, then discussed with Jim how his views on Iran could be reflected. Jim said he'd call me and give me his views over the phone and I'm welcome to pass them along to the group. That's fine by me, although let's see what he has to say and, among ourselves, decide whether it's worth my being the messenger (among other things, it will take up time from people who are actually in attendance, it calls attention to Jim's absence, potentially in both respects creating an undesirable precedent. Then, it turns out, Steve offered up to Jim the idea of phoning in for the Iran discussion. I told Steve I found that exceedingly unlikely, given that the whole discussion is classified, and I can't imagine that Jim's got a STU-III (or whatever you folks use these days)—and, once again, even if it were permissible, it could be more disruptive than contributory. Long/short, I promised to pass along the idea, but left Steve with my view that it was highly unlikely.

subject: RE: RE: RE: from GOH - Montreal meeting talking points
text:
Thanks Cheryl

I am now at my desk. I agree with concerns below. The cementing of the monopoly by Preval for the public container port is a prime example how elite capture runs directly counter to job creation and social welfare.

Assets (land, heavy equipment, cement, petroleum) that are in high demand during a construction boom are in the hands of a few. The risk is that price spikes will severely drive out the potential gains from aid dollars. Dual signatures and injecting foreign experts into a HRA task force to review projects for eligibility will counteract obvious forms of corruption.

The much harder task is to determine realistic benchmarks for project costs, given transfer pricing and de facto cartels. Injecting competition and open bidding is needed to counteract this. The problem is that any Haitian firm will loose business to US or Chinese contractors with much more favorable pricing structures (but limited spillovers to local economy). A middle ground may be to invite joint ventures between Haitian and international companies to build up the local workforce and overall skill base.

Best, JL

subject: Update on North Park Meeting with President Preval and Request for Call on Tuesday - 2 Nov - 7am
text:
You r doing a great job — if you weren't pushing...I could not imagine where things would still be with the IDB.

It will still be slower and more painful than all of us would like (but that is the nature of these processes as we know), but things had no focus that I could see until you got involved and I think we might have lost the belief that it could work without your determination.

Really — you are doing a great job and I admire and respect your efforts and don't know how you find the energy given I'm sure all of the other demands you must deal with. You are making a difference here and that is what it is all about.

Please don't bother replying again Cheryl — I know how busy you must be.

Just keep going!

Andrew J. Samet

5orini, 5a met & Associates, LLC

700 13th Street, NW Suite 930 Washington, DC 20005 Office: 202-393-4481 Fax: 202-393-4494 Email:

Attached is the final version that we sent in with all their proposed edits and our responses marked in track changes and explained in comments. I have also included 2 additional small edits that I think will help immunize us from complaints by the human rights/democracy crowd. If you can let me know by early tomorrow whether you approve or what you want to change I can them make the necessary changes on the document they sent back to us and send it in my the deadline late tomorrow. Jim Hoge likes the piece and told me that he took a personal hand in the editing. AM

Conflict Minerals in the Democratic Republic of Congo

Last year in the Democratic Republic of Congo, I spoke out against the trade in "conflict minerals" that has funded a cycle of conflict there that has left more than 5 million people dead since 1998, displaced countless more, and spawned an epidemic of sexual and gender-based violence.

President Obama has now signed into law a measure that will require corporations to publicly disclose what they are doing to ensure that their products don't contain these minerals. The DRC has formally expressed its support for this law and has thanked both the executive and legislative branches of our government. This is one of several steps we are taking to stop this illicit and deadly trade.

After my visit to the Congo, I directed the State Department to develop a holistic strategy on this issue as part of our broader effort to engage effectively with the DRC. We continue to work with the government to crack down on corruption, both bilaterally and through the Great Lakes Contact Group. At the United Nations Security Council, we successfully pushed to expand the listing criteria in the DRC Sanctions Committee to include those supporting illegal

Update from Laura

Dear Secretary Clinton,

I am both saddened and excited to inform you that I have accepted a clerkship with a new federal district court judge in the Southern District of California. I am thrilled to jump into the legal aspect of my career, but also sad to leave what has become a family over the last six years.

I dubbed the name, "Hillaryland 2.0" for the group of young women like me who have learned from you and the original Hillaryland - Capricia, Cheryl, Melanne, Huma and even new ones, like Maria Otero. The collective guidance and mentorship from you and these phenomenal women has helped me grow both personally and professionally in an unparalleled way. I assure you that it's a unique experience, distinguished from any other environment that exists in Washington for young women. Under your leadership, I feel that I have also become part of the State Department family, with all the ups and downs that a family inevitably experiences.

I look forward to meeting with you before I leave for San Diego at the end of the month. I know you are incredibly busy, so I appreciate the opportunity to thank you in person for the opportunities you have given me. I never thought a small border-town girl like me would have the chance to travel the world representing the United States, and share with countries all the values that we hold so dear.

I am deeply grateful for the honor to serve with you.

All the best, Laura

subject: tying up a couple of loose ends from this week
text:
You mentioned at Thursday's 8:45 meeting that you had talked to Qureshi and that he thought he was not going to get any trade access to the EU. My EU contact writes that the Member States in the EU have been slowing up progress on trade concessions to Pakistan, although the draft language negotiated w/ Pakistan still leaves room for the Commission (which is pro-trade) to keep working on enhanced trade benefits for Pakistan. Still, the original timetable of 2011 will not be kept. Even more ominous, any agreement will have to go to the European Parliament, which is down on Pakistan for human rights reasons.

I have also read Esther's note to you on UN Security Council Reform. You are right that overall our best position for the moment is

Have a good trip! AM

subject: URGENCE
text:
Dear Hillary,

I just arrived back but my heart and mind are back in Haiti I am thankful that you helped me get there and supported the resurrection of the hospital in just one week. General Keen was key in reestablishing the hospital (and I got to appreciate MRE's). When we got there there were 1500 patients and 400 corpses in a deserted hospital — our team of 7 was the only group there.... And slowly over the week we have built a functioning hospital again.

Meeting and working with Paul has been good for the soul---- although when I felt I wanted to meet him –this was not the way...But I think I am in this for the long haul...

Below is an email for President Clinton (it was good to see him and Chelsea and Mark there) I promised to forward this email by a medical student he spoke to in the operating room .... Desperate to find a way to continue his education. Attached is picture of him and I in front of the surgery area. And there were 3 more I met a few nights later who had volunteered since the first days but had not eaten in a week (I managed to gather bag of biscuits from the world food program from behind 3 padlocks after 1 hours of searching–They slept on the hospital grounds because their homes were destroyed.

I am not sure what we can do... But I promised to pass this on!

Thank you for who you are in the world.. God bless you!

Your friend in gratitude,

Mark

As I mentioned last week, I was on a panel at the Brussels forum with Lady Ashton (who insisted everyone call her Cathy), Estonian president Toomas lives, and Senator Voinovich.
