The Qatar FM will be handling coordination of this. We also received confirmation that no vote will take place before the meeting already schedule with Amb. Rice with a sub-set of the Arab Group PRs on Tuesday next week, as previously promised to Amb. Rice.

The results of Susan's Tuesday meeting will, obviously, be important. She wants to ensure we make the best use of the next few days so that she has all tools in hand to work this.

subject: CTV Update: 3/31
text:
Highlights:

- very late start today, with reduced staff.

- 1527 pres PVs quarantined in total 471 deputy PVs 546 senator PVs

- the rate of quarantine seems to be lower with the legislative PVs. This could be due to less fraud or more probably due to more lax reviews during these last days.

subject: Update
text:
Huma--grateful if you'd pass attached to the Secretary. Many thanks. Eric

Madam Secretary:

As I suspect you've heard from Ops, four US military aircraft are now taking home Egyptians (some 300 or so -- we don't yet have precise figures) from Tunisia. We had to jump through a number of hoops, but your interest was all the boost we needed. We are working with Embassy Cairo on PA and PD elements.

Today's project: moving on transport for the stranded third country nationals (Asians, Africans, etc.). At yesterday's DC, USAID said they'd fund it, but their planned funding arrangement (a budgetary "swap") with DOD may not work, and AID doesn't want to tap its disaster account for this particular purpose. But one way or another, we'll have a concrete commitment -- today -- and we'll find the $3 million or so that we'll need from our State/MRA account if need be.

Many thanks for your support, and best,

Eric

subject: Guatemala mudslides
text:
I spoke w President Colom today. He said they had lost 44 people and have considerable damage including bridges that have washed away. Fortunately the rains stopped today-- although he is very concerned about the upcoming rainy season.

-- the Embassy provided 3 NAS helos (with a team of 19 emergency workers) for emergency response to the flooding and landslides .

President Colom expressed his gratitude for Embassy support. I took advantage of the call to also tell him that we have reprogrammed $4.38m to Guatemala for reconstruction for which he was also very grateful.

As you may know President Colom has repeatedly asked whether he might be able to get a meeting w the President--

We think that a meeting is impt not only because of Guatemala's key role in the Merida plus initiative and the fragility of Guatemalan institutions-- but also because of the up-coming revelations of the Cutler study-- (the Tuskegee like experiments in Guatemala). It strikes us that we will be in a better position to react to that damaging news (with its negative connotations beyond the bilateral relationship) within the context of a clear and positive engagement w Guatemala.

President Colom said that he will be at UNGA on the 19 or 20th and I intend to see him then-- perhaps if a POTUS meeting does not materialize you might consider whether such a meeting could fit into your schedule.

Best Regards,

Arturo

subject: Call with Sen. Lautenberg
text:
Madam Secretary:

I have spoken with Carlos Ceglia, the Brazilian charge' here, as well as Lisa Kubiske, our charge' in Brasilia.

Carlos met with Sen. Lautenberg yesterday and took him through the case. He explained that there could be a Supreme Court ruling on the stay this weekend or Monday. In the meantime, however, there is no mechanism for the son to be reunited with Mr. Goldman while the Supreme Court deliberates. I think there are two possible sources for confusion on this point:

--Carlos did tell the Senator that the Brazilian family had floated the idea of allowing the son to spend Christmas with his father in Brazil. (I told Carlos that Hanukkah would have been quicker and more appropriate.)

--If the Supreme Court rules in favor of the Goldmans, the possibility arises that father and son could return to the United States even while the Brazilian family pursues further appeals in Brazilian courts.

Carlos reiterated that the Brazilian government is on our side on this, and regreted the GPS-related hold. I said we appreciated the efforts of the executive branch, and understood the separation of powers, but the interests of the child are undermined by constant delays. Carlos promised updates.

Best regards,

ck

subject: Latest from Wendy
text: Sergey just reported on his bilat. Cathy now seeing Jalili. We expect no other bilaterals. Cathy will debrief and then we will have final plenary. Cathy will then do press announcement. I will then background our press. Appears that Cathy will be asked to agree to preparatory meeting of deputies/experts before next meeting likely May 10 in Baghdad (Baghdad does not yet know officially). We are all for such a meeting, as well as a 8+1 and E3+3 preparatory meetings. So will be very busy next few weeks. Will debrief detail of conversations in secure channels. Good that we are talking about nuclear, urgency, step by step, etc. but very, very long way to destination. Next meeting will be much more difficult. Nonetheless, this outcome today is certainly preferable to what might have been.

MS— My heart is breaking this week for the whole extended state department family. What a terrible loss and unbelievable heartbreak. Many of my old friends at the State Department who have moved onto other posts wrote to me to tell me how moved they were by your remarks. I watched it from here on the west coast with great sadness. I am sure that your remarks also meant a great deal to the families of the victims.

"My" Bill is going to see "your" Bill tomorrow afternoon. I was hoping this might happen in our offices in the suburbs so I could say hello, but they're going to meet up instead over at the convention center in downtown seattle. Since Bill never uses staff when he is "off-campus" in Seattle, I will miss seeing the WJC team, but I hope he has a successful trip. It's the best time of year to be out here — picture-perfect weather and breathtaking views of the mountains.

I think of you (and the whole team) often and love keeping up with your travels on the news and the State Department facebook posts!

Jake,

Hope the new job is going well. Just wanted to let you know that EPA's Administrator Lisa Jackson might be calling S. I was in Nairobi with Lisa and she mentioned calling S about some of the environment issues related to Rio 2012. We are working closely with EPA on preparing for that meeting. The key topics are the green economy and the institutional framework for sustainable development.

Also, I believe Lisa is interested in traveling with the president to Brazil and may call to ask S about that. I think it would be a good idea for Lisa to go to Brazil —

Best, Kerri-Ann

subject: Fw: Time sensitive
text: Your final schedule has not been resolved, and no firm commitment has been made on your doing a separate women's event to announce the US commitment to women in the Pacific. The Aussies and NZ are supporting the travel of key women leaders to the Cook Islands to highlight the gender initiative. They have expressed concern that you might not join all of them for a gender announcement. Gillard is now staying over on Friday. It is true, she will have made a huge Aussie gender commitment earlier at the Forum, but the Aussies and Kiwis want to unveil the Cook Islands initiative for women of the Pacific with you to demonstrate the ongoing commitment (and new resources)by all of you that you first announced in PNG. We have been working with all the governments, including with Amanda, but final decisions on your schedule are still a work in progress. Gender is one of the key themes of this Pacific Forum, and given your leadership on this issue, the other govts were eager to underscore their collective commitment with you to this when you are there on Friday.

subject: Chen Guangcheng says China not honoring agreement, wants to meet U.S. diplomats
text:
ABC ran it as the second story: Hillary's Choice, will Chen get to leave with the Secretary. All eyes on Secretary Clinton a champion of human rights. What will she do? Secretary has said nothing since Chen changed his mind and wants to leave. Chen a symbol of Hrs abuses in China. Chen re-united with family at a hospital but today kept away from US officials . Bob Fu interviewed — Chen in danger. Chen did not know his wife was threatened. Chen called Hearing saying he wanted to leave China. Interview with Locke: we want to sit down with him sot discuss what he wants to do. ABC closed with: Should the U.S have turned him over to Chinese in first place and what can US do now?

Nothing on being "abandoned." Monitoring other network news. I'll be sending the next media summary, including all the networks' news and any other coverage at 8 pm tonight.

Interesting observations from DecIan:

Foster was a critical component in the talks apparently. However there is already speculation that PR may use this moment to try to come back early and resume position of FM given that the other investigations have been delayed pending the outcome of the police investigation. He went to London with his family yesterday to visit his wife, who is in a clinic there apparently.

Empey still not on board apparently so the "community confidence" round may be used to put pressure on him to do so.

Our intervention on Thursday night/Friday morning was seen as a very important moment/catalyst. That, coupled with the jobs losses that day and the fact that the radio and tv phone-in lines and newspapers were full of commentary supporting what we said, seems to have made people realize, that they couldn't lose the moment.

Kurt and Cheryl,

In my meeting yesterday with FM Smith, he said he'd still like to speak with S. Originally, they were scheduled to talk last Friday but it was cancelled. Given the change in leadership, and Smith's increased responsibility -taking on trade and aid portfolios as well as foreign affairs -- I think a brief call would be helpful.

Also, I spoke at length with former PM Rudd on Monday. Although he did not raise the issue, his aide called Edgard afterward and noted that Rudd had not heard from S, and would have hoped for a sympathetic call. I have no strong point of view on this one. He has received such a call from POTUS already.

But, I think he and S had a good relationship and he may want to talk to her about his future career goals.

Best,

J.

Hillary and Cheryl, I'm feeling very good about our recent efforts to connect our speeches thematically. We've done it with development, human rights, and Internet freedom; and most recently with AIPAC, Ctr for Middle East Peace, and next the AJC. Here's what I want to suggest: The three most basic elements of human existence are food, water, and health. We have now done major speeches on food and water. I'd like us to consider a major speech on global health — the third in a trilogy. Linking these three issues thematically, we can explain how and why foreign policy challenges and solutions must be seen through a prism of human survival and why the conditions of people's lives influence everything from economic development to political stability and more. This trilogy of speeches (with the right PR) could further underscore our elevation of development AND our comprehensive, smart power approach to foreign policy. After all, food, water, and health are the sine qua non of human progress. And this is a Hillary Clinton signature idea, at least to me. Thoughts? LM

subject: Update Regarding Fighting and Casualties in Mogadishu
text:
Colleagues:

Further to our earlier alert, the press is widely reporting Somali gunmen disguised in army uniforms stormed a hotel popular with government officials on Tuesday, and a legislator said at least 15 parliamentarians were killed. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.

The African Union confirmed at least 15 people were killed in the attack on the Huna Hotel, in a government-controlled neighborhood between the presidential palace and the Indian Ocean. It did not say whether the dead were all MPs.

Embassy Nairobi spoke with President Sheikh Sharif who confirmed that seven MPs are now dead and numerous others • are wounded. The number of attackers is not clear, but they were dressed in Transitional Federal Government military uniforms. At least two blew themselves up.

Christine P. Jackson Watch Officer Operations Center - U.S. Department of State 202-647-1512

The AL Ministerial, led by Qatari FM Hamad bin Jassim, began at 1700 local/1100 EDT. Media report HBJ convened several (mostly GCC) Foreign Ministers at a local hotel this afternoon to discuss a joint position prior to the formal meeting. The FMs discussed options other than fully suspending Syria from the AL, including suspending the Syrian delegations' participation in AL meetings (less punitive than a formal suspension).

Foreign Ministers who arrived in Cairo today include: • Qatari FM Hamad Bin Jassim • Libyan NTC Leader Mahmoud Djibril • Bahraini first deputy of foreign affairs Hamad Ahmed Abdel Aziz El Amer • Omani FM Yousef Bin Alawi • UAE State Minister for Foreign Affairs Mohammad Anwar Korkash • Iraqi FM Hoshyar Zebari • Palestinian FM Riyadh El Maliki • Jordanian FM Nasser Judeh • Lebanese FM Adnan Mansour

Lebanese FM Mansour announced prior to departing Beirut for Cairo that Lebanon would support Syria, and said he hoped the Ministers would achieve an Arab consensus that serves the higher interests in Syria and the region.

Stephanie L. Hallett Office of Political & Economic Affairs U.S. Embassy Cairo Tel: +2 (02) 2797-3999 Fax: +2 (02) 2797-3497

subject: Follow-up information regarding legislation mentioned in Senator Voinovich's call to the Secretary (S. 321 and S.840)
text:
Wilma,

Attached is background information on the legislation Senator Voinovich referenced in his call with Secretary Clinton today.

As Senator Voinovich mentioned to the Secretary, both bills are personal priorities for him.

I am the point of contact for the Passport Card Travel Enhancement Act of 2009 (S. 321), and we would like to work with you in an effort to address State's concerns with the legislation. Please let me know if you have questions or need additional information regarding this bill.

Todd Johnston is the point of contact for the International Clean Energy Development Act of 2009 (S.840). He can be reached at 202-224-3353.

Thanks, Tara

Tara Shaw Counsel Senator George V. Voinovich Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management 202-224-1331

subject: Resout, 10/22 0845 meeting
text:
Congress We'll aim to do QDDR rollout to Hill 11/16. Jack and Rich will meet with Congressional officials next week to begin discussions of final likely budget levels, identifying necessary tradeoffs. Rich is continuing work with DoD on Afghan infrastructure and pooled funding components of defense authorization bill. Carlos Pascual delivered a great speech on US-Mexican relations at Stanford yesterday; Rich will circulate to key Hill members/staff.

Afghanistan Jack and Eikenberry recommend separate calls to Karzai on PSC issue on Monday, after deMistura raises with him today, Afghan NSC meets tomorrow, and Eikenberry sees him on Sunday.

Press Likely strong attention to NYT story on US human rights vetting of Pakistani units and WP report of shutdowns of AID operations in Afghanistan over PSC issue. Next tranche of leaks by Wikileaks likely to hit the wires tonight; State's likely only vulnerability will be on reports of Congressional visits.

India Bill wraps up his visit to Inda today; hgopes to steer Menon to a better place on nuclear liability.

Jeff:

While speaking on phone today with FM regarding upcoming VIP travel to Egypt, he asked that I convey to the Secretary that he is "amazed". ..tell the Secretary that "Ahmed is amazed" that she is going to Qatar and the Kingdom and flying right over Egypt. I pointed out that S has been here twice and that they just met in the US last month.. .but he was having none of it. .."just tell her 'Ahmed is amazed' that she would not stop here."

May I ask that you find way to convey this to S appropriately?

He also asked for detailed info on measures to be taken at our points of entry for incoming travelers—key ministers very upset at what they have heard, that there will be "no exceptions." We'll work with consular to convey the correct info and try to calm this issue.

Cheers, margaret

subject: any truth to this account? Sid
text: The writer was not only a correspondent for The Guardian there but also apparently was on the Maldives delegation putting him in various rooms. The accounts from the conference have been very fragmentary, the administration has explained very little (for whatever reasons and to its detriment), and it is being widely blamed internationally. The broader lesson I draw from Chinese disrespect for the president (and US) on his trip (I've heard accounts from journalists), its behavior at Copenhagen, mercantalist economic policy (eg, currency), and its rough use of and contempt for international organizations, not to mention the strange form of Chinese neo-colonialism in Africa, is the need for policy review. Fear of Chinese retribution (economy. Iran, etc) can't be allowed to paralyze reassessment, though it should be factored into scenarios. The Europeans are being damaged worse by Chinese economic policy than us and China policy is a new area for the Western alliance to consult on. Leaving it to Treasury apparently parks policy in a laissez faire twilight zone. Treasury has been as effective on China as it has been on AIG. Just thoughts of an observer.

Dear Assistant Secretary Posner:

I am writing to express my deep appreciation to you, Dara, Lynne, and the entire DRL team for your tireless support in connection with the recent Community of Democracies meeting. The Secretary's speech was superb. I was sitting with representatives of "embattled NGOs" in the balcony of the Slowacki Theater, and many were literally awe-struck. They told me that it was the most important, most inspirational speech they had ever heard relating to civil society. I agree.

I realize that considerable behind-the-scenes work goes into a speech like this. While civil society has an important role in critiquing governmental actions, I also think that it's important to recognize the efforts of our remarkable colleagues in government. So please allow me to say "thank you" to you and your team. Please also know that you can count on ICNL to redouble its efforts - within the CD Working Group and otherwise - to advance the objectives set forth in Krakow. Indeed, I've already met with the Working Group and have reached out to other partners to ensure that civil society properly complements the tireless efforts you and your team have displayed in protecting civic space around the world.

With best regards,

Doug *** Douglas Rutzen President International Center for Not-for-Profit Law 1126 16th Street NW #400 Washington, DC 20036 www.icnI.org

Jeff -

Been in touch with ADMs Stavridis and Locklear. They are working the issue hard, thru both US and UK channels, to solidify liaison cells with the rebels, The diversity of the opposition makes setting up the contacts more difficult, but the Nato command is fully engaged in trying to set up the right structure to ensure closest possible coordination between Naples and the TNC.

Relatedly, FR and UK are pushing the idea of sending a Nato liaison to the TNC to work the PA angle as well as to provide a way to improve communications between INC and Nato HQ on the bigger picture. Sounds sensible, the we need to avoid sense that Nato is recognizing TNC or wants role in any political process. Would welcome your thoughts on this.

Ivo Sent Using U.S. Department of State / Blackberry Server

Dear Cheryl,

I don't know who the Goodspot Production company is, but they certainly hit the "sweet spot" on this one. So powerful, visually and the narration. I'm sending it all over the place. The Secretary talked to Jim about the video (they ran into each other at National Airport, go figure). We're going to send the link to all the House Hunger Caucus members and encourage them to put it on their web sites. In the meantime, knowing how much leisure time you have on your hands, and using Matt Damon as the "link" between the two, check out this video clip from this week's episode of Entourage where Matt Damon talks about US domestic hunger — hilarious, but tough —

(And, in my typical single-minded way, if you do a Spanish version of your global food security video, you might want to ask Juanes to do the narration — I'm pretty sure he'd say yes.)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VJQZXnVrtpM

Enjoy!

Cindy

- Corker is still being savaged by Heritage activated county commissioner level START opponents -weird, not exactly grass roots - and there's not nearly enough pushback (need national security message.)

- Kyl has a an op-ed tomorrow and doing news shows Sunday. They expect McCain, Durban to join him - The opponents are still pushing modernization and now this new thing alleging the admin cutting "secret deals" with Russia on defenses

- they really need help with pushback - including the kinds of points Gen Adams was highlighting about the breakthroughs with allied/Russia agreement on missile defense in Lisbon - and some urgent help in Tennessee - can we get Castellaw, others?

Burns Strider

subject: Gender- Melanne's Comments on QDDR
text:

subject: Update
text:
Just spoke to FM Fernandez. Two points:

1. They definitely want a quick S visit, as Arturo laid out, centered around the airport, with perhaps a quick site visit, followed by a pinera meeting.

2. On assistance, President is chairing a meeting to determine needs. Initial requests will include satellite radios (to supplement the 25 they receive tomorrow from the UN) and a field hospital with surgical capabilities. We will get the full list in the next couple of hours. We should regroup at that point ti see where we can be most helpful

I also got a call from Pinera FM designate Alfredo Moreno. Moreno's wife was in Talca at the time of the earthquake (close to the epicenter) and made it back to Santiago but is pretty shaken up. His son was badly injured in a disco collapse on the coast but wil be ok. These stories are typical here. Moreno asked about the S trip and said that Pinera would be available to meet w S on Tuesday at the airport if the trip happens.

Cheryl, Just heard that this year's World Food Prize winners are Kufuor (former President of Ghana) and former President Lula. This info is embargoed until the S announcement on June 21g. S can talk about our strategic partnership with Brazil and perhaps announce Phase II for Ghana. As we discussed, I have requested that AID hold the Phase II announcement for S in Tanzania (June trip). We can also ask them to hold Uganda — I know you said no separate FTF/1,000 Days event there — but it could be incorporated into another speech. Will start on the building blocks. Thx, Cindy

Possible legislative responses to strip search decision

As we discussed, this week, in a 5-4 decision, the Supreme Court upheld the use of visual strip searches (without physical contact) for every individual who enters the general population of a detention facility. Under this rule, the Fourth Amendment does not require reasonable suspicion that the detainee is hiding contraband, or that the detainee is alleged to have committed more than a minor offense, before prison or jail officials conduct such a search. The Department of Justice had filed an amicus brief supporting this result.

As noted by the Chief Justice and Justice Alito, the Court left open the possibility of exceptions, such as where the detainee is to be segregated from the general population. Justice Kennedy's majority opinion, however, appears to rule out a test based on the seriousness of the offense. Justice Breyer, in his four-justice dissent, would have held that a strip search of an individual arrested for a minor offense that does not involve drugs or violence is "unreasonable" unless supported by reasonable suspicion. Critics of the Court's opinion have argued that it embraces a "police-state logic" that seeks to eliminate any and all security risks, without balancing that goal against other values such as privacy, liberty, and anti-discrimination.

subject: Suspending embassy ops
text:
Jake, we weren't told that there was decision to suspend operations now. We are working with post to reduce staffing down to critical levels to allow them to get the amcits on the ferry tomorrow and, over the next days, deal with the remaining community. Jeff, Pat Kennedy and Steve Mull felt that we couldn't just plug the plug at this point but wd be poised to do so shortly if that decision is made. If we need to suspend tomorrow, please let me know we will do our best to move quickly. Janet

Janet A. Sanderson Deputy Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near East Affairs Department of State 202-647-7166

Speech Draft

I'm faxing you a draft of the speech. It is way too long and something of a hybrid, having started out as a big policy speech in advance of the summit. Now it is a town hall one day before the POTUS outlines his agenda at the intervention. My suggestion is that you review this long draft, which covers a lot of ground (though not everything). In the meantime, I'll work on an abbreviated version that focuses on your main themes -- the urgency of our working together with other countries to narrow the income gap and reduce poverty by creating a safety net of education, food security, and public safety that unleashes the full potential of the people and nations of our Hemisphere.

Great news--

The video that S taped this am will likely kick off the World Food Prize conference. I will also coordinate with Katie to make sure we get this up on the website.

Below is more info on its likely placement from the team at the World Food Prize.

"We would like to show the Secretary's remarks at the outset of the symposium on the afternoon of Wednesday, October 14. The symposium begins at 1 p.m. with about 15-20 minutes of introductory comments by Ambassador Quinn. He would incorporate the video into this opening as her remarks tie together so many of the themes so perfectly. Dr. Ejeta will be on stage at the time; it would be a great moment to honor him, to remember Dr. Borlaug, and to have the Secretary's message foreground the discussions that will follow. (For your reference, the 3 opening keynotes will be delivered by ADM CEO Patricia Woertz, DuPont CEO Ellen Kul!man, and Dutch Minister of Agriculture Gerda Verburg.)"

subject: Please Pass to the Secretary
text:
Madame Secretary,

U.S. security and law enforcement personnel have engaged local and federal security officials to seek their help on understanding the immediate risks and measures that can be taken. I have urged U.S. families at the Consulate in Monterrey not to send their children to school in the coming days while we review the events that took place on August 20. We also are advising U.S. citizens in the area that we have urged Consulate personnel not to send their children to school while we complete this security review.

I am sure that the warden notice will lead to a rash of press reports on U.S. concerns about security in Monterrey. More broadly, if the government cannot get the kidnappings in Monterrey under control, that may affect our ability to function in Monterrey. I have advised Secretary Espinosa of this, and have sought her help as well to address consulate security.

Consulate personnel are currently on "authorized departure" and have the option to send their families to a U.S. location. Pat Kennedy is in close touch on these matters.

Carlos Pascual

This message has been sent via BlackBerry

subject: Noor and ramsey
text:
There is no/no indication that the GOE intends to intervene in the judicial process which has yet to fully hear Mr. Bower's legal challenge to his wife's Egyptian custody order. As I read the read-out of Sen Kerry call to President Mubarak (forwarded in separate email), Mubarak said he could not intervene in the judicial process.

The next hearing is set for October.

A meeting on Sept 20th has been set for Mr. Bowers, the Egyptian "Good Intentions Committee" which is an extra-judicial group of officials who try to facilitate resolution of custody cases involving foreign parents (but the committee has no authority to order the children's return to Mr. Bowers), and the ex-wife, and possibly the children.

We have been urging the GOE to assure that the boys are available to see their father on the 20th. We do not expect that the boys will be released to him and do not understand how the family came to believe this.

Margaret

subject: CODEL McConnell
text:
As I believe you know, Senator McConnell is leading a delegation of newly elected R Senators (listed below) to Islamabad and Kabul next week. I have had several conversations with the team in Islamabad about their concerns in terms of any planned or unplanned interactions with Pakistanni media while the Senators are there.

Given the highly volatile situation in Islamabad at the moment, and the very challenging media enviroinment in Pakistan, we are doing everything we can to try and prepare them for what they might encounter. However, we all remain concerned that they may not fully appreciate what they will face or how their remarks will be interpreted or, frankly, deliberately misinterpreted.

I'll keep you posted as things move forward. Let me know if you have any other thoughts or suggestions.

Hope your trip goes well.

Jm

As Haiti enters the period of electoral contestation, it is essential that all political actors remain calm and encourage their supporters to do the same. The United States, together with Haiti's international community partners, stands ready to support efforts to thoroughly review irregularities in support of electoral results that are consistent with the will of the Haitian people expressed in their votes.

Like others, the Government of the United States is concerned by the Provisional Electoral Council's announcement of results from the November 28 national elections that are inconsistent with the published results of the National Election Observation Council (CNO), which had more than 5,500 observers and observed the vote count in 1,600 voting centers nationwide, election-day observations by official U.S. observers accredited by the CEP, and vote counts observed around the country by numerous domestic and international observers.

Haiti's transition to democracy over the past 24 years has seen many successes, overcoming major challenges. The 2010 elections represent a critical test of whether the Haitian people will determine their destiny through their vote. The United States is committed to the consolidation of democracy in Haiti and calls on the Government of Haiti, the CEP and all political forces to ensure that the will of the people is fully reflected in the outcome of this election.

Hi Bob—

The Secretary had a conversation with Senator Levin today about Jackson/Vanik — Levin told her that the Administration has been opposed to his efforts to lift the Jackson Vanik restrictions pertaining to Russia. He said that Administration officials have been telling him that the Russians don't want them lifted. This didn't make a whole lot of sense to me, but she asked me to follow-up with you to find out our current posture on Jackson Vanik and Russia. She'd like to get back to Senator Levin soon. I leave it up to you how you want to get the info to her, but I did want to pass along her request.

Thanks, and hope all else is well.

Rich

subject: Stevens Update On Benghazi -- 4/26 7arn
text:
All:

Ops has provided below the latest Stevens update on Benghazi:

The USG employees were returning from the airport when the incident occurred. A total of four people died and six injured. USG employee Mjuries are light if any. subject: DoD Guidance
text:
Cheryl, AM,

I've attached Admiral Mullen's 2011 guidance that just came out today. He makes a direct reference to supporting implementation of the QDDR (in conflict prevention and response) on p. 6 at the bottom in the Conclusion. Just this line alone will result in a trickle down effect that will lead DoD and the military to look for our leadership and a more formal mechanism to support us in this area. Our implementation planning on conflict prevention and response would benefit from a very active effort and a more formal initiative to harness DoD. The final report makes room for this by making CSO a center for civil-military collaboration on conflict - but it does not say much more than that. So the details will need to be worked out in implementation planning.

I've had two people from DoD send me this document today asking what our plans are and looking for some direction on next steps :)

Best, Karen

Ambassador LeBaron and Diane Parsont spent a successful hour and a half with Paul Matulic,'a long-standing staffer for the Senate Intelligence Committee, and the committee's deputy staff director, Lorenzo Goco.

They discussed the genesis of the CSCC, how it fits into the interagency process, and some ongoing projects. There were no surprises, and no detailed questions about budget, staffing pattern or other quotidian matters. Instead, the conversation focused on strategy and tactics.

Paul, whom I've known for a few years, is a straight-shooter and a strong PD supporter. More than once during the meeting he indicated how glad he is that the CSCC is a reality, and that he remembers well the testimony that Judith gave to his committee that included plans for CVE. He wrote afterward, "Ambassador LeBaron conveyed a very solid sense of mission in a realistic world. Lorenzo and I were impressed."

Lynne

subject: CODEL McCain wheels down
text:
Just landed in Crete, safe and sound, and I want to thank all of you for making this amazing day possible. The Senator is thrilled. It was extremely informative and valuable for him, and -- I'm confident to say -- for Chris and his terrific team on the ground. Despite all of the complexity, uncertainty, and moving parts that came along with this CODEL -- and despite the fact that most of what you did to make it happen had never been done before! -- the day went flawlessly. Just flawlessly. I know how much time and extra effort that all of you dedicated to make our trip successful, and we cannot thank you enough. If we can ever be of help to you, please let us know.

Best,

Chris Brose

Two options

The US views the Transitional National Council as the sole/only legitimate interlocutor of the Libyan people during this interim period, as Libyans come together to plan their own future and a permanent, inclusive constitutional system that protects the rights of all Libyans. This is in contrast to the Qadhafi regime, which has lost all legitimacy to rule.

The US views the Transitional National Council as the legitimate interlocutor of the Libyan people during this interim period, as Libyans come together to plan their own future and a permanent, inclusive constitutional system that protects the rights of all Libyans. This is in contrast to the Qadhafi regime, which has lost all legitimacy to rule. The INC is the institution through which we are engaging the Libyan people at this time.

subject: your legacy
text:
I just want to say that as I brief the QDDR (20 times and counting), one of the points that makes the strongest impression, and that I frankly think is an enormous part of your intellectual and practical legacy, is putting together all the bureaus that focus on protecting individuals — protecting them from insurgent or criminal violence (CCO and INL), protecting their rights through law (DRL, GTIP, S/WCI), or meeting their basic needs in humanitarian emergencies (PRM). It is a major statement about the direction that the world is going and we must follow. This was really your idea, and it is a powerful one. I know your decision today and applaud it. AM

Anne-Marie Slaughter Director of Policy Planning U.S. Department of State (202) 647-2972

Rosemary: I just spoke to AU Chairperson Jean Ping, who is Mauritania. He is prepared to fly to Paris tomorrow at the invitation of the French but does not have his own Diane.

Ellen Powell,

I have been in touch with our ambassador in Mauritania, Jo

have stressed to Ping the importance of having African representation at the Paris meeting and the need for the AU to embrace and wrap itself fully in yesterday's UNSC resolution.

The five African heads of state were slated (under their original schedule) to meet in Mauritanian on Saturday evening and then travel to Libya on Sunday. Without going into any detail, I told Ping that no mechanism had been put in place for air clearances and that it was absolutely imperative to touch base with the UN and all appropriate authorities before any of the African presidents attempted to travel to Libya on Sunday. I also told Ping his participation in the Paris meeting would provide him with additional information and might convince him and his colleagues that a trip to Libya was not necessary. When we receive further word from Mauritania about the AU travel plans, I will let you know. Johnnie

Dear Steve,

We most recently saw each other downtown at the Meridien Hotel.

State just announced the long anticipated appointment of Johnnie Cash as Assistant Secretary of State for Africa - a very good man by all accounts. I have expressed interest in being one of his three deputies concentrating on financial markets where I have a great depth of experience and knowledge. It won't be easy persuading people to keep their markets open and private, having made such a mess of our own financial sector, but it is central to our long-term security and development interests. More broadly, if the State Department is seeking an expanded role in dealing with global economic issues, then my combination of business and government experience in Africa might be appropriate somewhere in the Undersecretary for Economic, Energy, and Agricultural Affairs. In USAID there is a position where my experience and skills could be helpful: Assistant Administrator — Bureau of Economic Growth, Agriculture, and Trade.

I was contacted last week by the administration for a position at EXIM Bank, but I am not the right person for export financing for Boeing et al. I promoted the idea of shifting or emphasizing EXIM's focus to infrastructure/project finance where the huge gap in emerging—frontier markets has only widened. I offered to help Fred Hochberg (seemed a nice man — apparently worked in Clinton administration at SBIC) recruit someone and he kindly went back to Obama folks suggesting OPIC is a better spot for me, but an opportunity to work at State for the Secretary would be my first choice.

Cheryl:

Here is the latest update on Michel Kazatchkine's (MK) situation:

1. Simon Bland (SB) and Dr Mphus (GF Board Chair and Co-Chair) continued placing calls to Board members

2. MK called Simon last night to request a one-on-one meeting today at 4pm in Geneva. SB will call or email me with a readout.

3. Simon, John Monahan and I had dinner last night with Mireille Guigaz, the new French AIDS Am bassador (and new

GF Board member), who drove in from Lyon to meet with them. (The French fired Patrice as AIDS Ambassador and GF

Board member)

a. Guigaz had been in dialogue with MK and French FM all day. We had 2+ hour dialogue over dinner.

b. She insisted that all donors meet their pledges

So, final chapter about to close. Thank you and the SeCretary for all the support and insights. As I said in Rwanda memo, heading to SF today for some meetings with Gilead Pharma on 2nd line drug for kids and Christmas Holiday. Will look forward to talk to you during the week. Eric

Josh

Thank you so much for all you have done — not only in terms of serving the Secretary well, but also the leadership of and advocacy on behalf of the speechvvriting team. You have been an impeccable partner and I am grateful for your open, candid and transparent approach. It has helped me strive to do a better job and I will be eternally grateful for that.

I wish you the best of luck a back west. And if I can ever be of assistance, know that I would be honored to have the chance to do so.

Best.

cdm

Dear Jakarta Friends, We're very eager to get a quick read from you on how Usama bin Laden's death is playing in the Indonesian media and in cyberspace. Any illustrative snippets you can get to us early and quickly on your Tuesday morning would be very valuable to us here. We assume you'll send in a fuller report through the usual media reaction channels (which we'll read with interest), but we could really use some quick, short stuff soon. Best, Thomas

Thomas Hodges Director, Office of Public Diplomacy (EAP/PD) Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs U.S. Department of State (202) 736-4598; HST, Rm. 5318

Cheryl/Jake,

When we were discussing whether to accept the Pentagon's offer of a replacement for Gen. Selva a few months ago, we also discussed making a reciprocal offer of a senior F50 to travel with the incoming Chairman of the Joint Chiefs. If we are still interested in pursuing, S's meeting with Gen. Dempsey later this week provides a unique opportunity for her to mention the idea and to plant the seed for assigning an F50 to travel with him.

Let me know whether this is worth following up on. If so, I can prepare a point to add to S's BCL.

Andrew

Jake,

FYI — I have just returned from a meeting at DOI. This was a scheduled meeting with Tom Strickland (A/S for Fish/Wildlife and National Park Service) to discuss our efforts on many topics — e.g. CITES, Biodiversity, etc. Tom brought Sec. Salazar in to meet us and discuss a few topics. There are two issues you should know about:

1) Arctic — Sec Salazar plans to join S in Canada next week at the Arctic-5 meeting. (He is still very interested in engaging in the Arctic and does not seem to be a big fan of the Arctic Council — suggesting it is too low level. ) Regarding the meeting in Canada, we are looking for a role for Sec Salazar and think the best issue for him might be the outer continental shelf. We are going to check into this based on the current meeting agenda.

2) Sec Salazar is interested in pursuing a "peace park" linking Big Ben National Park in Texas to land in Mexico. From our discussion it seems that the land in Mexico is not yet owned by the government. Sec Salazar indicated that he has had discussions with the NSC about this, specifically in terms of President Calderon's visit in May and the state dinner. He suggested that this would be a subject of discussion during the visit. He is already planning meetings with DHS on this topic. (We are tracking down more details on the potential park.)

I am passing this on to you as Sec Salazar mentioned that he would be discussing the park and the upcoming Arctic meeting with S soon.

Best Regards, Kern-Ann

subject: Public Diplomacy Commission
text:
Cheryl,

Wanted to give you a heads up on this in case calls S. The WH announced their intent to nominate Sim Farar and Ryan Crocker to the Public Diplomacy Advisory Commission in November However, the WH has NOT yet nominated them, citing concerns that the Committee has not been reauthorized.

My understanding from speaking with R and H (though waiting on final confirmation from Pat Kennedy) is that although the authorization for the Committee expired on October 1, 2010, because the Committee was re-funded by Congress under the CR, it was "by de-facto" re-authorized until March 4th. If no funding is authorized in a 2nd CR or omnibus budget or the Committee itself is not re-authorized by Congress by March 4th, then the Committee's activities must cease on that date.

H called Sen. Kerry and Sen. Lugar's offices, both who said they are fine with the nominations going forward even though the authorization has not been sorted out, understanding the importance of public diplomacy initiatives to this administration. I relayed this to PPO, but they still are holding.

While the general consensus appears to be that it will likely be re-funded, Sen. Boxer's office (who was supportive of in this role) is saying chances are only 50/50 and others have mentioned that Sen. Coburn may block it.

I will keep you posted on this, but wanted to get it on your radar in case he calls S about it as well. Many thanks. Heather

subject: 10 AmCits arrested with 33 orphans
text:
I am seeking more information about this but want to let you know before the 5pm call that 10 Amcits were reportedly arrested by Haitian police near the DR border with 33 Haitian children whom they reportedly planned to take to an orphanage they are establishing in the DR. They are currently under arrest at a PAP police station or, according to one report, at "the Justice Building near the airport." The whereabouts of the children is unknown.

The group is called the New Life Children Refuge America Organization (NLCR). Bill Bistransky found the attached "Plan of Action"(P0A) on their web site when he googled that name. As he notes, either today's arrest is their second run into Haiti to get children, or their original schedule is off.

Michele

PJ-- Senator Menendez and company are released their report on Lockerbie/Megrahi release timed for tomorrow, the 22nd anniversary of the bombing. One of their recommendations that is that the State Department "launch its own inquiry into al-Megrahi's release" to "exhaustively identify and interview sources" to determine how and why Megrahi was released. Looking for comment... Im also led to believe that the British govt. inquiry promised by Cameron has in fact uncovered additional documents showing there may have additional communcations by the Brits to the Scots about the importance of releasing Megrahi. Im assuming that State Department has been informed about some of this and you might be able to shed some light... Mike Isikoff

Dear Secretary Clinton,

Happy Memorial Day! So many veterans must be thrilled to celebrate the holiday knowing that OBL is no longer hatching plots.

I thought the speech was impressive. The beginning — where he thanked you for your tireless efforts -- was a high point, and he deserves credit for identifying the United States as being on the right side of history in a region where so many autocrats are on the wrong side of it. The section with the line about the obsolescence of "strategies of repression and strategies of diversion" was powerful.

Beyond what could be addressed on that occasion, I can't help being wary of the fact that the region remains a place where states are interpenetrated and outside powers have consistently intervened. Turkey is in a very interesting position vis-a-vis Syria, even as Iran and Saudi Arabia compete for influence there; I would not be surprised ifChina were working behind the scenes both to shore up Qaddafi and to cultivate good ties with a range of possible successors; etc. Given these dynamics, in a future address, it might be appropriate to go into further detail in laying out our principles for resolving regional rivalries and disputes -- like you did in the South China Sea context. I also can't help thinking about how the Middle East might look if Iraq realizes its potential as a major energy producer.

Thank you again! All best, Jackie

ps It was my tenth college reunion over the weekend, and Jen and Johann and Aksel were staying with us, so Jen told the story of how Johann confronted you with the world's primary challenge, the bane of Norway.

subject: Egypt $
text: Briefly, from end of 90s we started to reduce levels, in part because of improvements in incomes/social indicators and in part due to budget pressures, At the beginning (post camp david), when levels included a lot of commoddiitties it was running about a billion a year. As cash became more predominant, it went down to about 800 a year and that is when what was called the "glidepath kicked in with planned decreases to the 250 level over several years up til around 2008 with some blips along the way. There also some special events like iraq one that got them extra.

Depending of course on how the meeting goes today, we think it would be very good if the Secretary could attend the VP meeting tomorrow to make sure that the hard questions about where we are on Iraq government formation are addressed.

The Secretary uniquely brings the ability to express her instincts on where this process is going (or not going) and she brings the understanding of the whole region that we must take into account as we push for an Iraqi government. Her understanding of where we are on the Peace Process, our credibility with the full range of Arab leaders, and our relationship with Iran, are subjects she can put on the table and make sure are comprehensively considered before any decisions on a way forward are reached.

Michael

Mike and Esther:

I wanted to share my thinking with you for going forward. I am copying Pat and Wendy for their imformation.

As you know, the Secretary created this DAS position in this Administration to facilitate a series of objectives, including furthering the effective implementation of our human rights agenda in multilateral for a (which includes now the HRC). And while this position did not exist in prior Administrations, we believed it was (and is) critical to playing a larger multilateral leadership role on these issues.

In the interim, I have asked Heather to work with Esther to codify the revised position description for this 10 DAS position so that Esther can move forward with hiring recommendations. My goal in the end is to achieve effective process and policy implementation in this important area — and to count on your respective openness to constructive criticism and your leadership in helping to shepherd your teams to this place. Many thanks and I will be following up. Best. cdm

subject: Fw: Burma's Suu Kyi going online after detention (AP)
text: Thanks Madame Secretary we had already been working with folks around her about how to assist with twitter, mobile technology and other aspects of running a modern organization. I had already spoken to Katy about this (who we worked with on Shangai and has since left for California). I think getting Alec involved is a terrific idea. There is no internet service or enabling technology for mobile devices in most of Burma and what does exist is both deeply penetrated and disrupted by government elements or badly behind in terms of technology. We really need to help ASSK and her party modernize and a significant effort on our part is probably essential to make this happen. Thanks and best Kurt

subject: Holbrooke hotline
text:
5:00 update -- the nurse just came

She had nothing significant to report, but said whenever the family is back, they'll do an update briefing. So hopefully no news is stable news.

I'm still at the hospital, with Frank R, Chris L, and John Silson. Sarah and Chris J are out for a quick break. Jim Steinberg is on the 2nd floor, along with Frank Wisner. Ben Bradlee and Sally Quinn came by to say hello, but just stayed in the lobby. Marvin Kalb somehow got through to the ICU desk by phone, by saying he was a member of the family.

Adding Sarah H and Frank W to this.

Ops is compiling a list of calls received, which we'll address. Zardari would like to speak with Kati, if she wants, and according to Frank, Z has called Haqqani at least 3 times asking for updates, and there is some organized prayer event for him in Pak.

Madame Secretary,

Huma and Lona mentioned to me that you would like to see Phil today. I've asked him to stop by at 9:15. Wendy also would like a few minutes with you to continue your conversation from yesterday. I've asked her to come by at 9:30am. The large Monday meeting normally at 9:15 has been postponed due to the inclement weather. I will have an updated mini on your desk and go over this with you when you arrive in the office.

Claire

Claire L. Coleman Office Manager to the Secretary of State U.S. Department of State Tel: 202-647-7098 E-Mail: ColemanCLPstate.qoy

subject: S call with Meles -
text:
I want to flag for you that one of the commitments S made was that she would ask a team of senior advisors to sit with Meles' team to help work through how Ethiopia might implement the recommendations she shared for policy changes that would yield long-term benefits for hunger in the region.

The goal is to have you all travel to the region after preparation to provide this assistance. I am assuming you all can coordinate to ensure an effective and collaborative trip.

Please let me know this travel won't work for you all in the near term.

Many thanks.

cdm

Pulled me aside after a meeting on another topic to express his interest in being involved in long term Haiti planning — everyone loves Haiti now. He pushed that "there is a body of literature that disasters give rise to new opportunities". I said we had a plan and agree that we need to ask how responding to the disaster requires modification, but that the presumption is that we have a plan. I also (based on my conversations with Shoshi who actually has read the literature) said that there is literature that disaster recovery should be tied to a long term plan than made and makes sense apart from the disaster response — and that we did not need to reinvent the wheel. Sounds like you can expect more help.

Bill Drozdiak met in Berlin last night with Christof Heusgen, Merkel's national security adviser, and learned the following information:

Immediately after the ceremony taking the oath of office, that very day, Hollande will dramatically fly to Berlin to meet with Merkel. Jean-Pierre Ayrautt, the Socialist Party leader in the National Assembly, from the same area of Normandy, where Hollande was raised, will be named the new prime minister, possibly tomorrow, May 11, or when Fillon resigns, if not that day. Ayrault is a former professor of German and will be a key interlocutor with the Germans. Merkel will not renegotiate the fiscal compact, but with Hollande will agree to new programs financed through the European Investment Bank in Luxemburg for infrastructure building throughout Europe, in effect an annex to the original compact aimed at economic growth. Note that the Bundesbank yesterday raised the level of acceptable inflation, another gesture to growth. Merkel and Hollande may also fly together to Washington for the G-8 summit to demonstrate new European unity.

subject: WaPo: Pakistani case shows limits of women's rights http://www.washingtonoost.com/world/pakistani-case-shows-limits-of-womensrights/2011/04/25/AF2H571E story.html
text:
Dear Melanne,

Per your request, I reached out to Mukhtar Mai to see how she is doing and am concerned by what she shared with me.

Mukhtar said she is going to keep fighting the ongoing battle, but commented that, "Even if someone like me [who has the support of the international community] cannot get justice, think of the thousands of women who suffer in silence or try and seek justice." The situation is very disheartening and underscores the point brought up in the Washington Post article that, "Her long journey through the legal system was a closely watched test case, and observers said the court's rebuff may deepen the silence surrounding the abuse of other rural women."

Thanks! Saba

Dear Hillary,

A few meetings ago, we talked about how we — US companies and the USG - can help other countries develop the shale oil and gas with hydraulic fracking in an environmentally responsible way. The responsible development of these resources can change the energy and geo-political landscape in profound ways.

The DOE points of contact who can support State:

Chuck McConnell Asst. Secretary for Fossil Energy Charles.Mcconnell Offire• 207-SRA-ARAn

Cell

John Duda Director, Strategic Center for Natural Gas and Oil National Energy Technology Laboratory (NEIL)

I am sorry to have taken so long...in part because I had to navigate through the "Texts from Hillary" web site with an ultra-slow connection.

Steve PS: The second attachment from the New Yorker is relevant to our scheduling lunch.

Steven Chu Department of Energy

text:

subject: Statement for *after* flight goes wheels up
text:
Below is the statement for spox to release for after the flight goes wheels up. I will let you know when that happens. We anticipate around 8:30pm. CA has reached out to HHS who will be receiving the plane and they will help keep media away from the AmCits and facilitate entry. Once they arrive in Miami it is up to them to get to their destination.

Thanks, Caitlin

Today, the Haitian judge released eight of the ten American citizens and they have departed Haiti for the United States. Two members of the group are being detained in Haiti to answer further questions, as the investigation is ongoing. The United State Government respects the sovereign right of the Government of Haiti to conduct its own judicial processes. The United States Embassy in Port au Prince has been providing the detained Americans with consular visits and assistance to ensure that they are safe and receiving necessary care. Haitian authorities have been cooperative in ensuring the individuals' safety and welfare since their arrest and we have every expectation this will continue.

This is the one we love best. Your expression and hand on your heart make it so genuine, and President Clinton has a great expression. Just a wonderful connection.

There's nothing to do about the sandwich and the clutter, they're in every shot. Makes it real.

It's barely 6am at home but hopefully Huma will be able to take a look too. I'm on the clock because I want the morning shows to use it. That's an hour from now.

The network identification has been scrubbed, for a few reasons. 1) I don't want to that network to take this as an endorsement 2) the other networks won't use it 3) it's the heinous MSNBC and I just can't bring myself to give them that satisfaction. Obviously I'd be completely transparent & forthright about it. Not worried about that part.

subject: Congratulations!
text:
Dear Nora, Please pass along the following message to Cheryl.

Thanks,

Dear Cheryl, Congratulations on the launch of the $20b G8 initiative. This will stand as a historic success of President Obama and Secretary Clinton. Please do convey my personal congratulations and gratitude to Secretary Clinton if you have a moment to do so. I know what a key role you personally played in bringing this to fruition. I would like to suggest one overarching strategy for success. Please do push hard on the donors (USAID included!) to pool the donor resources into one, at most two, multilateral funding streams. Certainly the World Bank should be the main spigot, and IFAD possibly a second. By pooling the resources, we'll cut down BY YEARS on the delays, donor negotiations, further talk, report writing, expert trips, etc., etc., which are now the biggest single threat to success of the initiative. I look forward to a few minutes by phone or in person to offer some tips coming from long years of experience in this sphere. This can be a real historic path-breaker, if its not swallowed in the agencies! Warm regards and kudos! Jeff Sachs

I have a meeting scheduled with Jeff Feltman this afternoon to review the concept of a "transition team" for Tunisia. I have put together a list of functions and identified potential candidates for some of the slots which I will discuss with Jeff when we meet. In the meantime, we have designated officers within ECA and IIP who will be focused on Tunisia and who have already begun to work with the CAO there on some of the education and information initiatives. I met yesterday with Mike Posner and members of his team and Mike is planning a trip out there in the next few weeks to meet with civil society groups, with a special focus on the impending elections. Finally, the PA team is developing a media training plan to complement the work being done by USAID and MEPI.

I have kept Gordon Gray up to speed on what we have done to date and he has responded enthusiastically so far.

Will keep you posted.

jrn

Judith A. McHale Under Secretary for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs U.S. Department of State Washington, D.C.

Peggy, we should discuss further but the key points to bear in mind are as follows: The key safeguard that we are relying on to protect women's rights is the requirement that reintegrated insurgents respect the Afghan Constitution. The Constitution states that "the citizens of Afghanistan--whether man or woman--have equal rights and duties before the law" and includes special provisions (article 44 requires the state to create and foster balanced education for women; article 53 stipulates that the state must render aid to women without caretakers; and articles 83 and 84 provide quotas for women's participation in the upper and lower house respective) to encourage women's access to education and government.

It explicitly notes that the state to abide by the UN charter, international treaties, international conventions that Afghanistan has signed (Afghanistan has also ratified CEDAW which prohibits discrimination in public and private realms) and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

However, article 3-- which stipulates that no law "shall contravene the tenets and provisions of the holy religion of Islam" --leaves the rights accorded to women ambiguous and up for interpretation The power of interpretation is left up to the Supreme Court, whose members often have a conservative religious training.

As witnessed in the debate over the Shiite Family Law, there is now a significant women's movement in Afghanistan which is prepared to challenge any effort to curtail women's rights. However, they continue to rely heavily on the international community to promote and protect women's rights and to create a space for their advocacy.

Tom and Craig--

I spoke w Secretary Solis and thanked her for going to Honduras. She is eager for your briefing and advice when you meet w her today. And it is very important that Craig is going w her to guide her thru this process.

Oscar Arias told me he is very worried about whether the agreement will be implemented and is meeting w the leading Presidential candidate this week to urge that he produce his party's 55 votes for restitution.

I also spoke w Insulza who is focussed on the elections which I told him we would fully support. Is there more we should be doing?

Again, thanks for all your great work and good luck in the effort to get this across the finish line. Best, HRC

I am told this information is especially sensitive. Two points that can be drawn: 1. The commitment of Egyptian Special Forces to the overthrow of Qaddafi is rooted in more than longstanding Egyptian hostility to Qaddafi, but also the Egyptians' belief that their economic future may be greatly aided by the outcome in Libya and the relationship with post-Qaddafi Libya. 2. The personal name-calling by certain U.S. officials of Qaddafi is stiffening his resistance and he is using it internally to support his case with his followers that he is fighting Western/Israeli imperialism, foreign interests, etc., according to one of his advisers. This rhetoric differs from the formal condemnations of Qaddafi's abusive rule and policies by other senior officials and Western governments.

subject: Tara Sonenshine
text:
I understand you are talking to her about the McHale job.

Without exaggeration, Tara is one of the most talented people I have ever worked with -- in government or out.

She is razor sharp, politically astute, with a great sense and understanding of communicating foreign policy effectively. She works incredibly hard. She will be completely loyal. She has the respect of the foreign policy community.

There is noone I would rather be in a foxhole with (and indeed have been more than once).

This is a perfect time in her life/career to take on this challenge.

I'd grab her.

Best, Sandy
